headline: Will GTE, Long Seen as the Tortoise, Win the Race?
abstract: Analysts discuss GTE Corp as an investment in light of fact that Wall Street remains largely unimpressed by the company; note GTE, nation's third-largest local telephone company, is possible takeover target in light of industry's rapid consolidation; stock price graph (M)

headline: Assistance for the 401(k) Challenged
abstract: Barriers to employers providing workers with customized advice about 401(k) pension plan investments are shrinking; some employers are hiring outside firms to dispense answers; recent Labor Department decision to let TCW Group offer tailored advice is raising interest among other plan managers; graphs; photo (M)

headline: Products intended to evoke the exotic world of Picasso, Hemingway -- and Max Morgan.
abstract: Line of merchandise focusing on Max Morgan, free-spirited aviator, and his fabulous though fictional life style, is being sold by retail stores across the country (Advertising column) (L)

headline: Harold S. Geneen, 87, Dies; Nurtured ITT
abstract: Harold S Geneen, who virtually invented international conglomerate while transforming ITT during 1960's and 70's, dies at age 87; photo (M)

headline: 'A Careful Dance' for U.S. Envoy in Switzerland
abstract: United States Ambassador to Switzerland, Madeleine M Kunin, says her Jewishness is frequent topic for Swiss, especially since United States began pressing Swiss to acknowledge and publish information about World War II-era bank accounts belonging to Jewish refugees, including Kunin's mother; Kunin is concerned that if US is not careful, all the emphasis on money will burst into new wave of anti-Semitism in Switzerland, country in which only 18,000 Jews live; photo (M)

headline: G.M. Sales Hurt by Shortage of Rail Cars
abstract: General Motors Corp says its US sales will decline this month and perhaps rest of year because of shortage of rail cars; supplies of rail cars in US dropped after Union Pacific Corp acquired Southern Pacific Railroad because of track construction in California and Texas (S)

headline: European Trade Inquiry To Focus on Aid to Dow
abstract: European Commission will probe subsidies German Government paid Dow Chemical when Dow bought three eastern German chemical factories (S)

headline: Market Place; Wealthy Executives Have Compensation Troubles, Too
abstract: Market Place: Survey of 150 affluent executives by United States Trust Corp, investment management company, finds that two-thirds of them worry that too much of their net worth--about 35 percent, on average--is tied up in their companies' stock; one reason for imbalance is corporate America's rapid proliferation of stock options combined with bull market of recent years (L)

headline: AIG Plans $2.2 Billion Insurance Acquisition
abstract: American International Group Inc to buy American Bankers Insurance Group Inc for $2.2 billion in stock (M)

headline: In Birthplace of U.S. Democracy, Jiang Finds the Trappings and Traps of Liberty
abstract: Pres Jiang Zemin of China visits revolutionary sites in Philadelphia, but cancels his plans to see Liberty Bell because of demonstration by about 200 people (M)

headline: Merrill Settles With County for $1.9 Million
abstract: Merrill Lynch agrees to pay $1.9 million to settle securities fraud class-action suit brought on behalf of Orange County (Calif) bondholders in wake of county bankruptcy in 1994; suit charged Merrill and other firms with misleading investors about financial health and risks of county investment pool (S) y

headline: People
abstract: Craig Karpel is named president of Karpel Group Inc, new music marketing and public relations agency in New York (S)

headline: In Answer to Whisper Campaign, Castro Talks for 7 Hours
abstract: Fidel Castro delivers 6-hour, 43-minute opening speech to Cuban Communist Party congress; he blames US for most of Cuba's problems; photo (M)

headline: A Dispute That's Worthy Of the Title 'Battle Royale'
abstract: Sony Pictures Entertainment announces that its Columbia Pictures studio has signed long-term agreement to produce series of new films about James Bond with producer and director Kevin McClory; MGM/UA studio contends that it owns rights to James Bond franchise; MGM/UA has produced most of Bond films and says it controls rights to character; studio immediately sends out harsh warning that huge legal battle is likely to ensue; MGM chairman Frank G Mancuso says McClory's claims of ownership of rights to James Bond have been disputed for over 10 years (L)

headline: Thousands of Thais Protest Bangkok's Inaction in Crisis
abstract: Thousands of people rally in Bangkok for second to protest Thai Government's vacillation in face of severe economic crisis; farmers and factory workers join bankers and brokers in demanding resignation of Prime Min Chavalit Yongchaiyudh; photo (M)

headline: AT&T to Reduce Its Agency Roster
abstract: AT&T Corp says it will reduce its advertising roster from three shops to two by eliminating McCann-Erickson Worldwide; AT&T Wireless Service account with billings estimated at $90 million, which had been handled by McCann's San Francisco office, is being shifted to Foote, Cone & Belding, a True North Communications agency that handles consumer business accounts for AT&T; consolidation leaves as two remaining AT&T national agencies Foote, Cone and New York office of Young & Rubicam Advertising; Ameritech Corp names Carat ICG to handle media buying on its account, with billings estimated at $100 million; assignment had been handled by Leo Burnett Co (S)

headline: MCI Board Agrees to Closer Look At Worldcom's Unsolicited Bid
abstract: MCI Communications Corp board orders MCI's bankers and lawyers to examine Worldcom Inc's unsolicited takeover bid (M)

headline: MICROPROSE AND GT INTERACTIVE END MERGER TALKS
abstract: GT Interactive Software Corp and Microprose Inc drop plan for GT to acquire Microprose; plan to continue to work together on marketing and distribution projects (S)

headline: Iran Says U.S. Overreacts
abstract: Iranian Defense Minister, Ali Shamkhani, says US decision to send aircraft carrier Nimitz to Persian Gulf ahead of schedule is nothing more than attempt by US 'to justify its presence' (S)

headline: When Stars Converge
abstract: Carole Gould (Funds Watch) discusses Masters Select International Fund, which in two weeks since its introduction has collected $39 million from investors; also notes some changes in portfolio managers at Fidelity Investments (M)

headline: Japanese Phone Giant Buys a U.S. Stake
abstract: Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp makes its first significant push into American telecommunications market, agreeing to pay $100 million for minority stake in Teligent Inc, small wireless communications company; NTT is betting that some American companies seeking integrated voice, data and video communications will choose relatively untested wireless technology over fiber optic cable, the prevailing delivery system; Teligent aims to take customers from regional Bell companies by offering advanced communications services directly to buildings without wires; Worldcom, fourth-largest long-distance carrier, is reportedly planning to acquire Brooks Fiber Properties, small, independent local phone company (M)

headline: Vertical Real Estate
abstract: Competition between television broadcasters and wireless communications services gives rise to new sub-industry of radio tower companies; they are vying to tie together far-flung clusters of local transmission antennas into national webs that will bring next-generation technology to customers; little-known tower companies are transforming themselves into integrated operators that can offer wireless carriers array of services from finding new sites to building towers to leasing antenna space on under-used radio towers; photo; chart (M)

headline: I.M.F. Seeks Thai Decision on Lenders
abstract: International Monetary Fund want Thai Government to move faster on deciding future of 58 finance companies that have been shut since June because of insolvency; Bank of Thailand governor Chaiyawat Wibulswasdi says IMF is satisfied with measures imposed since $17.2 billion emergency credit line was extended in August; adds main concern is 'quick resolution' about insolvent lenders (S)

headline: Quixotic Quest to Invent A Different Car Engine Fails
abstract: Brothers Ben and Harold Rosen are abandoning quixotic quest to remake automobile industry; brothers say they are closing down Rosen Motors, venture they founded in 1993 to create a car that would run on conventional gasoline but would have virtually none of pollutants and twice fuel economy of today's automobiles; Rosens have decided to call it quits because they have been unable to attract major auto maker that would provide cash needed to transform prototype into commercial vehicle (M)

headline: 3d-Quarter Profit Off at Hughes Electronics
abstract: Hughes Electronics Corp says third-quarter profit fell 4.7 percent; net income was $209.7 million, down from $221.5 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue rose to $4.1 billion from $3.8 billion (S)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHORR, ROBERT
abstract: SCHORR-Robert. Of Delray Beach, FL., died peacefully on October 22, 1997. Beloved husband of Joan. Devoted father of Steven Schorr, Andrea Kadin and Melissa Lubliner. Dear brother of Morton Schorr. Adored grandfather of Jourdann, Brittany and Justin. He will be sorely missed. Graveside services Sunday 1 PM, Mt. Ararat Cemetery, E. Farmingdale, L.I.

headline: German Court Rejects Claims of 21 Auschwitz Slave Laborers
abstract: German court rejects claims of 21 of 22 elderly Jewish women seeking payment for their work as slaves at Auschwitz, holding they already got reparations payments and that some are still getting pensions; awards compensation to woman unable to claim reparations earlier; case is seen as precedent for thousands of other Holocaust survivors (M)

headline: COOPER AGREES TO BUY BRITISH COMPANY FOR $280 MILLION
abstract: Cooper Industries agrees to buy Menvier-Swain Group PLC, a British lighting and security company, for $280 million in cash (S)

headline: TBWA to Close St. Louis Office
abstract: TBWA Chiat/Day says it will close its St. Louis office, opened in 1983, by end of year (S)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING ; From airlines to shoes to computer software, accounts worth millions are undergoing changes.
abstract: Company marketers are busy making changes in their advertising agency assignments; Pan Am Corp, Travelers Corp and Nike Inc are among those companies moving their advertising accounts (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.38   5.08   4.77        3-MO. headline: F. Schumacher's Waverly is starting a campaign to update its image in home furnishings.
abstract: Waverly, moderately priced home furnishings division of F Schumacher & Co, is starting campaign in effort to update its image and compete more effectively against designers like Ralph Lauren and Liz Claiborne; Lotas Minard Patton McIver to handle $4 million ad campaign (L)

headline: Coming Soon: Face-to-Face Help from the I.R.S.
abstract: Internal Revenue Service, responding to stinging set of recent Senate hearings that disclosed abusive collection practices, says it will open its doors one Saturday a month so taxpayers with unresolved cases can meet face to face with agency officials in hopes of resolving disputes; photo (L)

headline: Federal-Mogul to Buy T & N of Britain
abstract: Federal-Mogul Corp agrees to buy T & N PLC of Britain for about $2.4 billion, in move that would place compamy among world's largest makers of engine parts for cars and trucks (S)

headline: Winnie Mandela Faces Accusers With Display of Silent Witnesses
abstract: Winnie Madikizela-Mandela, week after being questioned during closed hearings of South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, produces five witnesses she says will prove she was not guilty of murder and any acts of violence (M)

headline: Zurich Group-B.A.T. Deal Is Made Firm
abstract: Zurich Group announces firm agreement to take control of BAT Industries' insurance businesses in complex merger that would create one of world's biggest financial-services companies and major new player in US; two companies will pool their insurance and money-management businesses and tobacco business of BAT will be spun off into separate entity; Zurich will own 55 percent of new financial company, with BAT owning the rest; new company will be called Zurich Financial Services Group; company will be based in Zurich and run by chairman Rolf Huppi; as money-management concern that is growing with Zurich's current acquisition of American mutual fund company Scudder, Stevens & Clark, it will oversee more than $342 billion in assets; as an insurance conglomerate that includes Kemper Corp, a Zurich unit, and Farmers Insurance Group, a BAT unit, it will have annual premium income of $40 billion; BAT's tobacco interests will remain separate as yet another publicly traded company, called British American Tobacco; BAT owns Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corp (L)

headline: Microsoft Browser Heavily Downloaded
abstract: Microsoft Corp says more than one million users downloaded its Internet Explorer 4.0 browers in first 48 hours, threatening to erode Netscape Communications Corp's leading market share (S)

headline: Stocks Fall as Lower Earnings Are Expected
abstract: Stocks on Wall Street fail to respond to positive news from Asia, indicating that earnings worries might become bigger factor in investor decisions in near term; Dow Jones industrial average ends down 18.90, to 7,957.41, and Standard and Poor's 500-company index ends down 2.50 points, to 965.54 (M)

headline: Treasury Sets Sale Of Short-Term Bills
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.    By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.16 percent and on a six-month bill, 5.25 percent.

headline: Kenya's Woes Seem Unlikely To Tip Election
abstract: Pres Daniel arap Moi is favored to win re-election in Kenya only because he faces 13 challengers deeply divided along ethnic lines; majority of voters are expected to cast their ballots against Moi; opposition candidates scramble about the country to address small crowds at roadsides and parking lots, while Moi travels from town to town in his presidential jet to make speeches attended by all the trappings of power; photos (M)

headline: A Revival of Small Stocks: Big Rewards but More Risk
abstract: WITH small companies in their sixth month of leading the market, investors need to realize that shopping for them is far different from shopping for the large outfits that had long set the pace on Wall Street.    And there may be many rookie shoppers out there, for the recent performance of small companies has been relatively very strong. The stocks of both large and small companies have been pummeled by the recent difficulties in Asia, of course, but even with the setbacks, the Russell 2000 index, which tracks small-capitalization stocks, has gained 8.7 percent since midyear. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is up only 4.2 percent in that time.

headline: Ivester Is Named to Top Posts at Coca-Cola
abstract: Coca-Cola Co's board elects M Douglas Ivester chairman and chief executive, replacing Robert C Goizueta, who died on Oct 18; board does not select a president to replace Ivester; photo (M)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: AMDAHL CORP., Sunnyvale, Calif., a subsidiary of Fujitsu Ltd, named Francis Barton executive vice president and chief financial officer.    MORGAN STANLEY & CO., New York, named Stephan Newhouse vice chairman of its securities business.

headline: ONE BUYER REMAINS FOR BZW UNITS OF BARCLAYS
abstract: Barclays PLC is in exclusive talks with Credit Suisse First Boston to sell part of its BZW investment bank (S)

headline: Acquisition in 1999 Suggested by Times
abstract: The New York Times Co says it is 'counting on an acquisition to provide considerable future growth' sometime in 1999; company also predicts increases in revenues and operating profits, and its stock rises to 52-week high of $62.5625; president-chief executive Russell T Lewis says next step in external development plan is to bring investment banker on board to examine potential properties; Times also discloses that it plans new section of technology news called Circuits in February and that will publish seven to nine special one-time sections in 1998 (S)

headline: Pride and Censure Mix With a Dash of Apathy
abstract: Article focuses on wide range of reactions to Chinese Pres Jiang Zemin's visit to US among Washington's large and diverse Chinese-American community (M)

abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.56   5.37   5.41        3-MO. headline: Accounts
abstract: * Electronic Newsstand Inc., Washington and New York, to Thinking Media, New York, as the first agency to handle advertising for the on-line magazine retailer. Billings were estimated at $1 million.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  SCHUTZER, SEYMOUR, M.D.
abstract: SCHUTZER-Seymour, M.D. A most compassionate man, dedicated and caring physician, a true friend. Thank you for taking such good care of us all. Our thoughts are with those for whom you cared. The Schur Family

headline: Tyco to Buy Unit From American Home
abstract: Tyco International Ltd to buy Sherwood Davis & Geck, American Home Products Corp's medical products unit, for $1.77 billion in cash and integrate it into its Kendall Co unit (M)

headline: DOMINION TEXTILE URGES REJECTION OF BID FROM POLYMER
abstract: Board of Dominion Textile Inc urges shareholders to reject takeover bid by Polymer Group Inc while it holds talks with potential rival bidders (S)

headline: Peace Prize Goes to Land-Mine Opponents
abstract: International Campaign to Ban Land Mines and its American founder Jody Williams are recipients of 1997 Nobel Peace Prize; Nobel committee praises anti-land mine campaign as exciting new form of post-cold-war political action in which broad, grass-roots coalition of citizens' groups and smaller nations working on their own have led to world change; says it is openly trying to influence treaty process and that award can be interpreted as message to big powers that they should eventually fall in line; Williams uses award to pressure recalcitrant countries, including US, arguing that Pres Clinton will be branded coward if US fails to sign it; Russian Pres Boris Yeltsin unexpectedly declares that Russia will sign pact, hours after award is announced; US and China remain chief holdouts; photo (M)

headline: In Belgium, Leuven-Louvain Split Speaks Loud
abstract: LEUVEN, Belgiumâ€”  There was the Latin American who turned up for post-graduate studies at the ancient Roman Catholic university here and attended courses for a month before discovering he was actually supposed to be at the French-speaking university of Louvain-la-Neuve, 25 kilometers away across Belgium's invisible language frontier.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ANNETT CO., Arlington, Va., the publisher of USA Today and other newspapers, said it had entered into an agreement to buy the Maine Broadcasting System's television stations in Portland and Bangor. Terms were not disclosed.     PENTEGRA DENTAL GROUP INC., Phoenix, a dental practice management company, said it planned to sell 2.5 million common shares in an initial public offering.

headline: AVCO FINANCIAL TO BUY 80% STAKE IN ARGENTINE CONCERN
abstract: Avco Financial Services Co, unit of Textron Inc agrees to pay $56.7 million for 80 percent of Financiera Argentina SA from Banco Frances SA (S)

headline: BORDEN AGREES TO SELL UNITS FOR $310 MILLION
abstract: Borden Inc agrees to sell its wall covering and vinyl units, Borden Decorative Products Holdings, to Blackstone Group for about $310 million (S)

headline: Young & Rubicam Hires Forecasters
abstract: Young & Rubicam Inc hires two executives in fields of consumer trend forecasting and business development; they are Marian Salzman and Judi Francis (S)

headline: The Hunt Is On for the Toy That Will Make Parents Panic
abstract: Toy manufacturers and retailers often play guessing game in determining which toys will be popular items at Christmastime; marketing process begins 16 months before start of each holiday season, and recipe usually includes link to popular television show, strong television marketing, adoration from unpaid celebrity fan, strong dose of adult appeal and nagging fear among parents that toy might soon be sold out; photos (L)

headline: Israeli Cabinet Fails to Decide on Pullouts
abstract: Israeli Cabinet meets for more than six hours and fails to agree on size of long-overdue pullback in West Bank (S)

headline: Shift in Focus Is Expected At Coca-Cola
abstract: M Douglas Ivester, who will likely be named chief executive of Coca-Cola Co following death of Roberto C Goizueta, is expected to focus more attention on developing enormous global network that Goizueta built up during his 16-year reign; analysts agree that Ivester will shift company's emphasis from expansion to exploiting its existing dominance around world; Goizueta will be tough act to follow--during his tenure company's profits rose sixfold, revenue trebled and market capitalization exploded from $4.3 billion in 1981 to $145 billion in 1997; Ivester must prove to investors that he can nurture creative talent and create same consistent double-digit earnings performance in time when strong dollar is reducing Coke's overseas profits; photo (M)

headline: Monsanto Earnings Fall 3.7% in Quarter
abstract: Monsanto Co says earnings from continuing operations fell 3.7 percent in third quarter; profit fell to $103 million from $107 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue rose 21.4 percent, to $1.7 billion from $1.4 billion (S)

headline: Korea Situation Deteriorates, Raising Specter of a Default
abstract: South Korea plunges deeper into crisis when Korean Development Bank postpones effort to raise $2 billion to help pay billions of dollars in debts due in next few weeks; postponement raises specter that South Korea might become first Asian nation to default on its debts since economic crisis began to engulf region last summer; bank's decision comes barely a week after nation signed record $57 billion bailout agreement designed to restore global investor confidence (M)

headline: 8 Countries Join in an Effort To Catch Computer Criminals
abstract: US joins with Britain, Canada, Russia, Germany, Japan, France and Italy in pledge to apprehend and prosecute high-tech criminals even when extradition laws do not apply; communique promises coordinated efforts against industrial espionage, money-laundering, child pornography and other wrongdoing in cyberspace (S)

headline: Noisy Game In Colombia: Big Danger Is the Player
abstract: Article describes game of tejo, played for fun behind beer shacks across Colombia, that invovles beer-swiggging contestants who throw heavy weight down outdoor court size of bowling alley to strike and explode triangles of gunpowder; game is played to 9 or 21 points, or until players pass out--at which time loser must buy next round; was originally played by Zipa and Zaque indigenous tribes, who called it turmeque and played it with stones or pieces of wood, with object of testing how far player could throw marker; gunpowder and beer may have filtered into game during period of violence between two traditional political parties in 1950's, in which 200,000 Columbians died (M)

headline: Stocks Tumble in Japan and South Korea
abstract: Stocks prices decline on Tokyo Stock Exchange and in Seoul on December 8 as weakening South Korean currency threatens to erode Japanese competitiveness; Nikkei average lost 266.34 points, to close at 16,158.14; Korean composite index loses 20.82 points, to close at 414.91 (S)

headline: The Great Green Hope; Are Fuel Cells the Key to Cleaner Energy?
abstract: Article on fuel cells that use hydrogen to make electric power without combustion and with less waste than conventional power sources; says either hydrogen gas or hydrogen-rich liquids like methanol or gasoline can be used as fuel; fuel cells developed by Ballard Power Systems Inc and International Fuel Cells, division of United Technologies Corp, described; diagrams; photos (L)

headline: In Naples, Crime Totters but Survives Onslaught
abstract: The story of Vincenzo De Muro, 35, is depressingly familiar. He fell behind with his bills, asked a friend of a friend for a loan, and found himself in the clutches of a ring of loan sharks who jacked up his debt from $2,000 to $20,000, destroying his life and his young private investigation agency in the process.    But Mr. De Muro, a former member of Italy's military police, was not a typical victim. As the threats grew more and more vicious, he began to tape his phone calls, secretly followed his pursuers, and once even made his way past armed guards into the villa of the local gang boss to confront his tormentor. When he failed to win a reprieve, he went to the police with an armful of tapes, photographs and documents.

headline: TI Group to Sell Landing-Gear Interests
abstract: TI Group PLC sells its landing-gear interests to Snecma, French aerospace company, for $345.8 million (S)

headline: Executive Changes
abstract: AETNA INC., Hartford, the health insurer, promoted Richard L. Huber, its president and chief executive, to succeed Ronald E. Compton as chairman.

headline: Carol C. Tatkon, 59, Former Oil Official
abstract: Carol Clark Tatkon, former senior vice president for Exxon USA, dies at age 59 (S)

headline: Market Place; The board of Dow Jones is said to vote for selling the data unit.
abstract: Market Place column on Dow Jones & Co board's vote to put its Dow Jones Markets division up for sale, one day after company announced planned layoffs in the unit; possible suitors noted (L)

headline: Pomeroy Loses A Big Contract
abstract: Pomeroy Computer Resources Inc says that Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp, customer accounting for 10 percent of Pomeroy sales of computer products in first nine months, will not renew its contract for 1998 (S)

headline: She's Wound Up in Her Career, but He's Ready to Wind Down
abstract: Having distinguished themselves as first generation to leave house to work in large numbers, women in their late 50's and early 60's are now in the retirement range; while surveys show that many keep working if they are single, divorced or widowed, married women in growing numbers are staying on the job--breaking with practice of sharing their husbands' retirement; one major reason for trend is promise of independent pension to avoid poverty that often comes to widows who rely on their husbands' benefits; profiles of some women in this age group who continue to work; graphs, including benefits of working longer (L)

headline: Games People Play
abstract: Cyan Inc finishes Riven, sequel to Myst, genre-busting computer game that sold more than 3.1 million copies, almost twice that of its nearest competitor; Riven is a year behind schedule and cost Cyan $10 million, but expectations are very high for its success; Riven, like Myst, has simple point-and-click interface that does not require quick reflexes or demand understanding of technical manual; hope is that Riven can continue Myst's success in appealing to people who might not otherwise like computer games--especially women; photo; chart (M)

headline: Foes of Rebels In Mexico Attack Bishop And His Kin
abstract: Clash between Roman Catholic Church and pro-Government groups in Chiapas State, Mexico, intensifies sharply with attack by gunmen on motor convoy in which Bishop Samuel Ruiz Garcia was riding and with attack by hammer-wielding man on bishop's sister; Miguel Mendez Topek, who confesses to hammer attack, charges Ruiz fomented 1994 Zapatista uprising; Ruiz aide holds incidents were spurred by systematic smear campaign in local media; Federal officials score attack on Ruiz and deny Government backs local pro-Government paramilitary groups (M)

headline: Of Megatrends and Giveaways: Some Thoughts and Regrets of Chairman Hundt
abstract: Interview with Reed E Hundt, who is leaving as Federal Communications Commission chairman, on his four-year tenure; photo (M)

headline: Ratings in Jeopardy At 4 Indonesian Banks
abstract: Standard & Poor's Corp says it might cut its credit ratings for three of Indonesia's four largest publicly traded banks as collapse of Indonesian currency, the rupiah, could lead to surge in loan defaults; Bank Danamon, Bank Negara Indonesia, Bank International Indonesia and Bank Umum Nasional have been put on credit watch (S)

headline: What Smoke? New Device Keeps Cigarettes in a 'Box'
abstract: Philip Morris Companies is planning to test microelectronic cigarette holder that eliminates smoke and ashes from end of cigarette; battery-powered 'smoking system' is first of its kind and cost $200 million to develop after years of research; device is beeper-sized, four-ounce box containing specially designed cigarette and electronically controlled lighter that runs on rechargeable batteries; tobacco burns only when puffed; critics say device demonstrates lengths to which tobacco industry will go to make dangerous addiction more socially acceptable; photo (M)

headline: Skis Rossignol Denies Takeover Speculation
abstract: Shares of Skis Rossignol SA close little changed after company says it is not target of takeover (S)

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization             Oct. 24   Oct. 17   Oct. 25          1997   1997   1996       Gasoline production, daily   7.8   8.1   7.6       Distillate production, daily   3.5   3.7   3.8       Gasoline stocks   197.6   197.7   186.0       Distillate stocks   136.1   136.1   117.9       Crude imports, daily   7.5   7.9   8.6       Product imports, daily   1.7   2.0   2.3       Crude stocks   306.3   301.0   303.1       Crude production, daily   6.4   6.4   6.5       Refinery utilization (%)   93.7   95.1   94.0          Source: American Petroleum Institute

headline: Worldcom Fancies Itself Muffler of the Local Bells
abstract: Worldcom Inc bid for MCI Communications would create most significant new competitor in local phone service market, largely unchallenged domain of five regional Bell companies; combined company would be likely to increase pressure on state regulators to open local markets; map (M)

headline: Richemont to Buy The Rest of Vendome
abstract: Cie Financiere Richemont of Switzerland plans to buy 30 percent of Vendome Luxury Group of Britain that it does not own for 1.036 billion pounds ($1.73 billion) (S)

headline: Colombian Insurgents Undermine Election by Scaring Voters
abstract: Leftist guerrillas in Colombia succeed in keeping voters away from polls in regional elections; streets are deserted in city of Puerto Rico after bomb blows up local prosecutor's office; photo; guerrillas called boycott and threatened bombings to demonstrate, and deepen, their control over countryside, and humiliate Pres Ernesto Samper's Government (S)

headline: Red Meat May Not Be Enough for Irradiation Companies
abstract: Analysts who follow companies involved in irradiation of food are skeptical at best their prospects about Food and Drug Administration's decision to allow irradiation of red meats; cite doubts about consumer reactions and cost of building new facilities; most analysts believe some irrradiation will take place, but there remain big issues about how much and how fast (M)

headline: COKE TO BUY BOTTLING ASSETS OF KOREAN CONCERN
abstract: Coca-Cola Co says it will acquire soft drink bottling assets of Doosan Beverage Co for $450 million, giving it control over bottling, distribution and sales of Coca-Cola products in South Korea; Coke acquired its other Korean bottlers earlier this year (S)

headline: Breast-Feeding on the Run
abstract: To the Editor:    Hooray for ''Have Pump, Will Travel: Combining Breast-Feeding and a Career'' (Earning It, Dec. 14).

headline: Welcome, A Bit Blase, For Fellow Traveler
abstract: For many Chinese in New York, President Jiang Zemin's trip yesterday to their new hometown was in a strange way not that different from their own journeys to America.    They had come from China and Taiwan to the center of the financial world searching for business opportunities and better lives.

headline: Runway Colors Jump Onto the Store Shelves : Makeup:Now It's for Show, Not Just for Shows
abstract: PARISâ€”  A lightening bolt of blue across the eyes at Jil Sander's spring show in Milan last week was one more sign that the pale face that has dominated runways lately is on its way out.

headline: Onetime Hero Prosecutor Rises To Political Stardom in Italy
abstract: Antonio Di Pietro, former prosecutor from Milan, wins seat in Italian Senate with 67 percent of vote in three-way by-election; photo (M)

headline: Clinton Aides Confident On Eve of NATO Debate
abstract: PARISâ€”  Clinton administration officials said Monday they were confident of winning what promises to be a difficult debate in the Senate over NATO enlargement.

headline: People
abstract: * Diana Long was named president of Commonhealth Direct, Parsippany, N.J., succeeding Mathew Seymour, who was named to the new post of executive vice president and managing director for Commonhealth Worldwide, focusing on global business. Ms. Long had been senior vice president and managing director at Ferguson 2000, Little Falls, N.J., which like Commonhealth is owned by WPP Group.

headline: Dresdner Bank Reports Earnings Are Up 42%
abstract: Dresdner Bank AG says its third-quarter operating profit rose 42 percent to 674 million marks ($390 million) from year earlier; nine-month operating profit rose 25.5 percent to 2.374 billion marks ($1.37 billion) (S)

headline: Farrakhan, on Visit to West Bank, Meets Arafat
abstract: Louis Farrakhan, leader of Nation of Islam, visits Palestinian-controlled areas of West Bank and Gaza Strip, where he urges Pres Clinton to use financial leverage to force Israel to resume peace talks with Palestinians (S)

headline: Sulzberger Passes Leadership of Times Co. to Son
abstract: Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, who steered New York Times through 34 years of expansion and enormous changes in way it delivers news to it readers, retires as chairman and chief executive of New York Times Co; Sulzberger had relinquished control over newspaper's daily operations in 1992, when he stepped aside after 29 years as publisher in favor of his son, Arthur Sulzberger Jr; generational changing of guard is completed with announcement that elder Sulzberger, 71, has also turned over corporate leadership to his son; younger Sulzberger, 46, takes over as chairman, and Russell T Lewis, company's president, becomes chief executive; Michael Golden is named senior vice president and vice chairman; elder Sulzberger is named chairman emeritus, and he remains company director; photo (M)

headline: Distributor Of Electricity Sold in Brazil
abstract: Consortium of Brazilian industrial and financial companies agrees to buy Companhia Paulista de Forca e Luz (CPFL), big Brazilian energy company whose privatization prospects had been clouded by crisis in country's financial markets; consortium will pay $3.02 billion, 70 percent more than Government's minimum price; Brazil's ambitious program to privatize electricity industry is expected to raise $45 billion by end of decade (M)

headline: Prosecutor Says French Balk at Seizing War Criminals in Bosnia
abstract: Louise Arbour, chief prosecutor of war crimes tribunal for former Yugoslavia, accuses French peacekeepers in Bosnia of making no moves to arrest indicted war criminals and asks officials to issue stronger orders quickly; says French have shown total inertia; France rejects allegations as scandalous (M)

headline: Aide Calls IMF Rules For Bailout Too Strict : Thai Leader Reshuffles His Cabinet
abstract: BANGKOKâ€”  After a week of intense political negotiations, Prime Minister Chaovalit Yongchaiyut appointed a new cabinet Friday and made clear his intention to call elections in Thailand as early as possible.

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Nov 16 article on effects of annual fees on value of workers' 401(k) plans

headline: SCHNEIDER TURNS DOWN A TAKEOVER BID FROM MAPLE LEAF
abstract: Schneider Corp says it rejected takeover bid by Maple Leaf Foods Inc of $19 (Canadian) a share; calls bid inadequate (S)

headline: Bosnian Serb Leader Is Reported to Balk at Imposing Peace Pact
abstract: The Bosnian Serb President, who has been championed by the West as an alternative to defiant nationalism, has not delivered on her promises to carry out the Dayton peace agreement, Western diplomats and United Nations officials contend.    The President, Biljana Plavsic,  has grown in confidence since the summer, when she won NATO and Western support after splitting with her predecessor, Radovan Karadzic, and other hard-liners, accusing them of widespread corruption that she says has decimated the Serbian-run part of Bosnia.

headline: D. R. HORTON SET TO BUY CONTINENTAL HOMES
abstract: D R Horton Inc to buy Continental Homes Holding Corp for $305 million and will also assume $278 million of Continental's debt (S)

headline: Broadway is using nontraditional methods to attract Hispanic people to the theater.
abstract: Advertising column discusses how theatrical producers are attempting to market to 2.1 million Hispanic people living in NYC metropolitan area; photo (M)

headline: McDonald's to Add 100 British Outlets
abstract: McDonald's Corp will spend $142 million (US) in next year in Britain to open 100 new restaurants and create 5,000 jobs (S)

headline: N.A.S.D. Cites Stratton Staff
abstract: National Association of Securities Dealers says Daniel M Porush, president of Stratton Oakmont Inc, and 32 employees defrauded at least 70 customers through aggressive telemarketing and other sales practice violations (S)

headline: In Latvia, the First Token of Swiss Remorse: $400
abstract: Reva Shefer, 75, who survived Nazi Holocaust in Riga, Latvia, is first survivor to get check from Switzerland, receiving $400; is among only 80 survivors still in Latvia, although Riga was once center of world Judaism; local Jewish leaders are dismayed by relatively small payment but laud Swiss Government (M)

headline: Jorge Castaneda, 76, Diplomat And Foreign Minister for Mexico
abstract: Jorge Castenda de la Rosa, who was Mexico's Foreign Minister from 1979 to 1982, died on Dec 11 at age 76 (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * The Good Guys, Brisbane, Calif., to Citron Haligman Bedecarre, San Francisco, to handle radio advertising for the consumer electronics retailer, which had been handled in-house. Billings were estimated at $10 million to $12 million. The print portion of the account remains in-house. Goodby, Silverstein & Partners, San Francisco, a unit of Omnicom Group, handles television campaigns; Hal Riney & Partners, San Francisco, handles media buying.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: GTE Joins Chase for MCI With $28 Billion Cash Bid  GTE added its name to the list -- it now stands at three -- of companies pursuing MCI in the richest takeover battle in American history, making an unsolicited offer of $28 billion in cash.    MCI, which already has an agreement to be acquired by British Telecom for $19 billion in cash and stock, and which is studying an all-stock offer of $30 billion from a smaller telecommunications company, Worldcom, said only that its board planned to meet again soon to weigh its options. [Page A1.]

headline: Doles to Join Clintons on Bosnia Trip
abstract: Bob Dole and his wife, Elizabeth, are heading to Bosnia with Pres Clinton, Hillary Rodham Clinton and a dozen members of Congress for pre-Christmas visit with 8,500 American troops stationed there; Clinton invites Dole after Dole backs Clinton's decision to keep Americans in Bosnia beyond June 1998 deadline (S)

headline: Florida Study Claims That Prudential Cheated Customers
abstract: Internal report on Florida's two-year probe of Prudential Insurance Company of America holds company trained its agents for over 13 years to mislead, misrepresent and defraud policyholders; shows state, which in end reached class-action settlement with company, was prepared to file civil racketeering charges; at issue was practice of persuading customers to use cash value of life insurance policies to buy new policies with greater coverage, with false promise that their premiums would not rise; company denies deception charges; Insurance Comr Bill Nelson comments (M)

headline: Company Briefs
abstract: LOCKHEED MARTIN AERONAUTICAL SYSTEMS,  Marietta, Ga., a unit of Lockheed Martin Corp., said it received a $650 million order from the Department of Defense for 14 C-130J airplanes.    TEL-SAVE HOLDINGS INC., New Hope, Pa., said it would buy back up to $71 million, or about 5 percent, of its stock using proceeds from a settlement with Intermedia Communications Inc. and Shared Technologies Fairchild Inc.

headline: Orders for Machine Tools Rose in October
abstract: American orders for machine tools rose in October for second consecutive month, pushing total purchases so far this year to $6.87 billion, 17.6 percent above 1996's level (S)

headline: PNC Bank to Buy 4.9% of a Brokerage Firm
abstract: PNC Bank Corp is buying 4.9 percent of institutional brokerage firm, Friedman, Billings, Ramsey & Co, for about $45 million; Friedman is also arranging to sell further 17.3 percent of its stocks in an initial public offering that is expected to raise $150 million; deal comes as banking and brokerage industries are consolidating rapidly across country following recent relaxation of Federal Reserve regulations restricting brokerage businesses to 10 percent of bank's revenue (M)

headline: Horror and Pain, but Oddly, Some Relief
abstract: Many emotions sweep over Wall Street on Oct 27, but for lot of market gurus, strongest feeling is of relief; that may sound odd on day when stocks fall farther and faster than they have in decade, with Dow Jones industrial average plunging record 554.26 points; many traders and investors say it is about time; some optimists almost welcome market's setback; stock market had completed its longest stretch without sort of decline that Wall Street calls correction, meaning drop of 10 percent from a peak; in this case, that peak occurred on Aug 6; rally that preceded it lasted seven years, or twice as long as next best period in financial history, way back in early 1960's; historically, such setbacks occur about every 18 months; so even while stocks soared on strong economy, low inflation and great earnings, there has been undercurrent of anxiety on Wall Street (M)

headline: 30 Firms to Pay $900 Million In Investor Suit
abstract: Thirty brokerage firms, including some of the biggest and most trusted names on Wall Street, agree to pay about $900 million to settle civil suit contending they colluded for years to fix prices on the Nasdaq stock market; chart (M)

headline: BTR TO ACQUIRE EXIDE ELECTRONICS FOR $352 MILLION
abstract: BTR PLC agrees to buy Exide Electronics Group Inc for $352 million in cash (S)

headline: Despite Crackdown, Islamic Group Keeps Killing
abstract: Islamic Group, believed responsible for killing scores of tourists at temple in Luxor, remains Egypt's most active Islamic fundamentalist organization, despite years of harsh Government repression and imprisonment of 15,000 sympathizers and top leaders (M)

headline: Stocks Lower, With the Dow Falling 38.31
abstract: Stock prices move modestly lower in light trading; Dow Jones industrial average falls 38.31 points to close at 8,057.98, and Standard & Poor's 500 stock index loses 4.56 points, to 965.72 (M)

headline: People
abstract: * Ray Gillette, president for integrated services at DDB Needham Chicago, a unit of Omnicom Group, was named to the new post of president of Beyond DDB, a unit of all American DDB Needham offices that will oversee integrated services like direct marketing, promotions and interactive communications. He continues as a managing partner at DDB Needham Chicago.    * Gregory J. Osberg was named to the new post of president for sales and marketing at CNET Inc., New York. He had been vice president and associate publisher at Newsweek magazine, New York, owned by the Washington Post Co.

headline: TRAVELERS TO SPLIT STOCK AND BUY BACK $1 BILLION WORTH
abstract: Travelers Group Inc says it will split its common stock 3 for 2 and buy back up to $1 billion worth of shares; company also announces dividend of 10 cents a share on post-split basis (S)

headline: International Briefs; Nikon Profit Off 55%; Technology Costs Cited
abstract: The Nikon Corporation said yesterday that net profit for the first half of this year plunged 55 percent from a year earlier, to 2.64 billion yen ($21.9 million), because of higher-than-expected costs associated with the transition to next-generation excimer laser steppers for computer chip production. Excimer laser steppers are used in the production of 64-megabit dynamic random access memory chips while the more conventional i-line steppers are used mainly in the production of 16-megabit D-RAM's.

headline: U.S. Petroleum Data
abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization             Oct. 10   Oct. 3   Oct. 11          1997   1997   1996       Gasoline production, daily   8.2   8.3   7.6       Distillate production, daily   3.4   3.6   3.6       Gasoline stocks   198.0   198.5   195.8       Distillate stocks   136.4   135.8   114.3       Crude imports, daily   8.3   9.5   7.3       Product imports, daily   1.8   1.7   1.6       Crude stocks   304.6   308.2   299.2       Crude production, daily   6.4   6.4   6.5       Refinery utilization (%)   97.1   97.6   92.7          Source: American Petroleum Institute

headline: He's Soft, He's Tough, He's Steiff / Survivor of the Cold, Cruel World Market : Who's King of Teddy Bears?The Inventor Has It All Sewed Up
abstract: GIENGEN, Germanyâ€”  Paying a couple of hundred dollars for a teddy bear that neither walks nor talks hardly seems like a Christmas bargain. And yet, in what must be one of the most unlikely success stories in toy history, a small stuffed animal company in southern Germany has found an enduring bull market for bears, consistently commanding plush prices both in toy stores and on the auction block â€” hundred of thousands of dollars at Christie's and Sotheby's, for example.

headline: Russians Press U.N. to Relax Iraq Sanctions
abstract: Diplomats say United Nations Special Commission rebuffed Russia when it asked that Iraq be declared free of nuclear weapons and nearly free of prohibited missiles; such declarations would bring Iraq closer to meeting conditions for lifting crushing economic sanctions imposed at end of Persian Gulf war in 1991; only China supported Russia's request; American officials say too many unanswered questions remain regarding both nuclear and missile arsenals to permit any serious move toward closing files; International Atomic Energy Agency, which is responsible for nuclear monitoring in cooperation with Special Commission, has come close to declaring Iraq free of prohibited weapons and activities and suggesting that nuclear inspections be phased out and routine monitoring begin; no nation has suggested that Iraq is close to compliance requirements on biological or chemical weapons; photos (M)

headline: Travel Update : The Wealthy and Worried Build 'God Forbid Rooms'
abstract: Crime rates have been falling across much of America, but you wouldn't know it from the way some people spend their money. Sales of body armor are up in this country where there is nearly one privately owned gun (223 million) for every inhabitant, children included. Even bulletproof bras are selling. And small, but growing numbers of people are building secret, heavily protected redoubts into their houses. Some people, reports The New York Times, call them the "God forbid room," as in "God forbid that a kidnapper should come storming in here with a gun."

headline: Clinton Calls for Keeping Troops In Bosnia With No New Exit Date
abstract: Pres Clinton abandons June deadline for withdrawing American forces from Bosnia in favor of open-ended commitment of troops to international peacekeeping mission, which he says is helping to rebuild Bosnia; denies misleading Congress, saying he was simply wrong to set deadline, but asks that critics also look at larger truth that mission has enforced fragile cease-fire, advanced US security and values and made it less likely that US forces will be pulled into European conflict in future; expects US forces to leave Bosnia in 'near term' but refuses to set new exit date; will look for 'concrete benchmarks' like creation of adequate civilian police force; does not foresee permanent presence, or specify size of force after June, but hopes it will be fewer than 8,500 Americans there now; Clinton is to make holiday visit to troops, along with Congressional delegation that includes opponents of his policy; photo of preparations; Clinton also supports Dutch-led arrest of two Bosnian Croats indicted for atrocities, and praises efforts to return refugees (M)

headline: Burger King Campaign Is Promoting New Fries
abstract: Burger King introduces $70 million advertising campaign that trumpets its new fries as 'the taste that beat McDonald's'; as part of campaign, all Burger Kings that are participating in campaign in US will give away bags of french fries on Jan 2; Burger King also buys rights to use Mr Potato Head, children's toy, from Hasbro for undisclosed sum; Burger King plans marketing tie-in with toy beginning in January; McDonald's spokesman Chuck Ebeling says his company's fries remain top sellers in the country (M)

headline: Pivot Rules, a little-known maker of golf clothing, spends heavily to raise its profile.
abstract: Pivot Rules Inc, small, publicly traded men's golfwear company, has begun extensive advertising campaign to raise profile of its relatively unknown brand; advertising campaign was developed by CMG Communications (M)

headline: How a Daughter's Account Has Divided a Family
abstract: Laura Pedersen-Pietersen article answers reader's question about Uniform Gift to Minors Act account and how to respond when parent takes back money deposited in account (M)

headline: A Mandela In the Dock: Accusers' Day
abstract: Witnesses tell South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission about murders and other abuses involving Winnie Madikizela-Mandela in late 1980's; it is unlikely that Madikizela-Mandela will ever be indicted, but hearings could affect her political comeback battle (M)

headline: Treasury Prices End Higher in Light Trading
abstract: US Treasury prices end higher in thin trading; price of 30-year bond rises 5/32, to 102 21/32; yield falls to 5.96 percent, from 5.97 percent on Dec 15; graph (M)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  WILLIAMS, STANLEY
abstract: WILLIAMS-Stanley. Peter Martins, Ballet Master in Chief, Eugene P. Grisanti, Chairman of The Board, Howard Solomon, President of The Board Directors and everyone at New York City Ballet deeply mourn the passing of Stanley Williams, legendary teacher, colleague, mentor and dear friend. We shall remember fondly his gentle and patient spirit and his lifelong dedication to his craft and to his beloved students. Our heartfelt sympathy goes to his family. We have lost a cherished and irreplaceable member of the NYCB family, but his enduring legacy to generations of dancers will never be forgotten.    WILLIAMS-Stanley. The entire School of American Ballet family notes with greatest sorrow the death of faculty member Stanley Williams. The entire faculty, all the stdents and staff join Chairman Albert C. Bellas, Faculty Chairman Peter Martins, and President Larry Alan Smith in mourning the loss of this extraordinary teacher. In his quiet, unpretentious way, he was one of the most influential ballet academicians of his era, and left his indelible mark on generations of American dancers.    WILLIAMS-Stanley. The Trustees of the George Balanchine Trust mourn the loss of Stanley Williams, teacher, friend and mentor of so many colleagues. Stanley's commitment to the art of dance served as an inspiration to all.

headline: PEPSICO BUYING SNACK UNITS WORTH $440 MILLION
abstract: Pepsico Inc will buy salty snack businesses in Europe and Australia from United Biscuits Holdings PLC of Britain for $440 million (S)

headline: Assisi Holds Its Breath, and Rebuilds Treasures
abstract: Tremors continue to jolt central Italy, even as art experts and engineers hasten to salvage basilica of St Francis of Assisi and its magnificent frescoes; dozens of restorers are trying to mend broken faces of saints painted by 13th-century masters like Cimabue and Giotto; engineer Giorgio Croci explains damage and emergency efforts to shore up building, without further loss of life; photo; map; diagram; plans call for internal scaffolding to permit repairs; most optimistic prediction for basilica's reopening is year 2000 (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Van Melle Inc., Erlanger, Ky., to Avrett, Free & Ginsberg, New York, to handle the account of Airheads candies, previously at GSD& M, Austin, Tex., part of GGT Group, which resigned. Billings were estimated at $2 million.    * Navistar International Corp., Chicago, to Ogilvy & Mather Chicago, part of WPP Group, to handle corporate and branding advertising for the truck and bus maker, previously handled by Young & Rubicam Chicago. Billings were estimated at more than $2 million.

headline: Americans Uncertain on Egypt Travel
abstract: United States travelers appear uncertain about visiting Egypt in wake of tourist massacre in Luxor despite World Tourism Organization's stand that tourists should not be discouraged from visiting; are unlikely to visit Egypt in big numbers for many months and then only if there are no more attacks on tourists (M)

headline: EASTERN ENTERPRISES IN STOCK DEAL FOR GAS DISTRIBUTOR
abstract: Eastern Enterprises to buy Essex County Gas Co in stock swap valued at $80.5 million (S)

headline: Electronic 'Branding' Receives Accolades at the Frankfurt Book Fair
abstract: Hundreds of publishing executives attending Frankfurt Book Fair get glimpse of electronic marking, or branding, system that could be used to track goods in digital commerce; several publishing companies have already tested brands--known as digital object identifiers--but at book fair all publishers were invited to participate; with branding system in place, publishers expect to develop new tools to encrypt and secure documents and to regulate access to them (M)

headline: Sotheby's to Tighten Procedures Regarding History and Sale of Art
abstract: Sotheby's, while denying that it has knowingly auctioned smuggled art works, says it will tighten its procedures in response to accusations of widespread improprieties involving sale of illegally exported paintings and looted antiquities; changes are announced after 10-month, $11 million internal investigation stemming from publication of book, Sotheby's: The Inside Story, by Peter Watson, and an accompanying television series (M)

headline: Mideast in Flux: Fiasco in Jordan Strains Old Links
abstract: Alan Cowell analysis contends that Israel's bungled assassination attempt on Sept 25, when Mossad agents sought and failed to kill Hamas leader in Amman, Jordan, was direct threat to King Hussein's need to balance his inclinations toward peace with Israel against his needs to keep faith with his Palestinian constituents and avoid offense to his neighbors (M)

headline: Tory Leader Asks Delegates to Back a Conservatism That Cares
abstract: William Hague, Britain's new Tory leader, urges Conservative Party to take responsibility for election defeat in May, and calls on delegates at annual party conference in Blackpool to follow his leadership to new, caring form of conservatism; says party has been too exclusive and preoccupied with economic issues at expense of social ones (M)

headline: All Sides In Kenya Cry Fraud In Election
abstract: Kenya's general election degenerates into confusion as both Pres Daniel arap Moi and opposition candidates accuse beleaguered Kenyan Electoral Commission of rigging election against them; politicians on all sides are laying groundwork for rejecting results as polls finally close on unexpected second day of voting; photo (M)

headline: Factory Orders Jump 1.3% On Big Electronics Demand
abstract: Commerce Department reports that orders placed with factories increased 1.3 percent in August, helped by the strongest rise in demand for electronic components in almost four decades; chart (S)

headline: Mathematica is a software program that puts joy back in the numbers game.
abstract: Edward Rothstein Technology column on Mathematica, powerful mathematical program devised by Stephen Wolfram that encourages the user to pursue the most elaborate forms of experimentation; drawing (M)

headline: Quality Child Care Comes at a Price
abstract: Letter from Paul Wesley Knopp comments on Nov 9 essays on child care and child care workers (S)

headline: Patents; A gene therapy technique that is seen as easier and less expensive than the main alternative.
abstract: Drs William N Kelley, Thomas D Palella and Myron Levine win patent for gene therapy technique they developed at University of Michigan in 1980's; university owns patent, which encompasses virtually all gene therapy research using in-vivo technique pioneered at school (M)

headline: Iraqi Opens His Palaces (but Not to Those U.N. Inspectors)
abstract: Pres Saddam Hussein of Iraq invites foreign experts, but not UN arms inspectors, to live in his Presidential palaces for up to month to expose as lies American accusations that weapons are hidden there; offer is dismissed by UN as not very serious; US has focused attention on dozens of palaces--huge installations with enough space for weapons production and storage that are of limits and are controlled by Hussein's security and intelligence service; commander of US forces in Persian Gulf says Hussein's personal security forces would be among first targets if US were to attack; photo (M)

headline: CULLIGAN WATER OFFERS $172 MILLION FOR PROTEAN P.L.C.
abstract: Culligan Water Technologies Inc says it offered to acquire Protean PLC for $172 million (S)

headline: Behind the Killings, an Unbending Briton
abstract: Brig Reginald Dyer, British officer who ordered troops to fire on unarmed Indian demonstrators in Amritsar in 1919, recalled; he refused to admit he erred at British inquiry into massacre and forfeited his military career; photo (M)

headline: Greenspan's Jawing Gets The Job Done For the Fed
abstract: Analysis of Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan's testimony before House Budget Committee on state of economy; says analysts believe Greenspan's primary goal was to let some air out of stock market, which by some measures has been hitting new highs in days before his testimony and seemed poised to continue to rise; holds although stock prices do not directly affect the economy, most economists believe that bull market makes people feel wealthier and encourages them to spend more; says with unemployment already low at 4.9 percent, economists say that any further pickup in demand caused by booming market could tilt economy into inflationary danger zone (L)

headline: Newsprint Stakes Are Sold
abstract: Dow Jones & Company and the Washington Post Company said that they have sold their matching 35 percent stakes in two newsprint and timber companies to their partner, Brant-Allen Industries, for a total of $226 million. Dow Jones and Washington Post said that the sales of their interests in the Bear Island Paper Company and the Bear Island Timberlands Company would result in fourth-quarter gains of $28 million. The Bear Island companies produce 225,000 metric tons of newsprint annually and own 130,000 acres of timberland in Virginia.

headline: IPC TO BE ACQUIRED BY CABLE SYSTEMS HOLDING
abstract: IPC Information Systems Inc to be acquired by Cable Systems Holding LLC and its Cable Systems International unit; acquisition is valued at $253 million, including debt (S)

headline: ITT Seeking More Bidding, With Board As Auctioneer
abstract: ITT Corp directors say they want bidding between Hilton Hotels Corp and Starwood Lodging Trust to continue, and that they are best qualified to handle auction process; this draws angry response from Hilton, which ends talks with ITT, claiming it is not receiving same access to informationas its rival, Starwood Lodging; ITT shareholders will be asked to vote for one of two competing slates of directors on Nov 12; Hilton is expected to continue its bid even if its slate loses (M)

headline: Teva and Biovall in Deal
abstract: Teva Pharmaceutical Industries says it has entered into marketing and product development agreement with Biovall Corp; says it received exclusive United States marketing rights for eight Biovall generic products (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: U.S. Stocks Bounce Back As Foreign Markets Relax   Stocks recovered more than half of the previous day's losses, bolstered by calmer markets overseas and by expectations that slowdowns in Asia and Latin America would keep United States interest rates low.

headline: Havana Journal; No Joy in Cuba, as Its Baseball Team Strikes Out
abstract: Cuba's vaunted baseball team, often regarded as best squad not playing in major leagues, suffers humiliating defeats in Spain and Japan that set off purge of Government officials who have run sport for decades; fans, reporters and others attribute problem mainly to Government's failure to adequately reward loyal team members who have chosen to stay home while others defect and to replacement of many of better players by those renowned more for revolutionary spirit than baseball prowess; photo (M)

headline: AMETEK AGREES TO ACQUIRE ROTRON BUSINESS FROM EG&G
abstract: Ametek Inc agrees to buy EG&G Inc's Rotron Inc unit for about $103 million in cash (S)

headline: THE ASIAN CRISIS: THE JAPANESE INVESTORS ; In Tokyo, Taking a Collapse in Stride
abstract: Investors with failed Yamaichi Securities Co take collapse in stride, reassured by Japanese Government pledges that they will not suffer losses; those waiting to withdraw funds appear embarrassed, reflecting Japanese view of stock market as sort of disreputable casino; photos (M)

headline: BROWNING-FERRIS TO PAY $585 MILLION FOR 7% OF ITS STOCK
abstract: Browning-Ferris Industries says it will pay $585 million to repurchase about seven percent of its common shares outstanding as part of planned $1 billion stock buyback (S)

headline: Another Year Of Mad Bulls And Big Gaffes
abstract: Roundup of winners of 'awards' for misdeeds and gaffes in 1997 in world of stocks and finance; cartoons; photo (M)

headline: Mitsubishi Chief Apologizes for Scandal
abstract: Mitsubishi Motors Corp pres Katsuhiko Kawasoe apologizes to shareholders for auto maker's involvement in scandal that helped push down its domestic sales by 30 percent in Nov (S)

headline: Further Swiss Bank Lists Fail to Calm Uproar
abstract: Swiss Bankers Association publishes further lists of nearly 3,700 foreign-owned and over 10,000 Swiss-owned dormant accounts from World War II era totaling about $12 million; move does little to end debate over role of Swiss banks in trading gold looted by Nazis and in failing to aid Holocaust survivors claim assets deposited by relatives; Amb Madeleine M Kunin says United States seeks to help Swiss achieve closure, phone interview; banks say new accounts came to light when they began searching for smaller passbook and savings accounts (M)

headline: U.S. Will Ask U.N. to Force Iraq to Admit Arms Monitors
abstract: Clinton Administration will ask United Nations Security Council to take swift and firm action to force Pres Saddam Hussein to allow Americans into Iraq as members of UN weapons inspection team; UN officials say Sec Gen Kofi Annan will send three-member delegation to Baghdad to press message that Iraq must comply with Security Council resolution and may not bar Americans or people of other nationalities from weapons inspection teams; photo (M)

headline: Economic Data Point to Future Growth
abstract: Conference Board says its index of leading indicators rose two-tenths of 1 percent in September, fifth consecutive increase, and matching analysts' estimates as well as matching average for four previous months; graph; chart (L)

headline: Edmond Moriarty, Merrill Executive, 69
abstract: Edmond N Moriarty Jr, senior executive of Merrill Lynch & Co, died Oct 26 at age 69 (S)6

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: LASER POWER CORP., San Diego, a laser manufacturer, agreed to buy EMI Acquisition Corp., Murietta, Calif., a maker of infrared night vision optics, for stock valued at $11.8 million.

headline: For Unpaid Interns, A Lack of Legal Protection
abstract: Martha Krisel letter warns that the fact internships in business do not provide salaries or benefits bars college interns from court protection against sexual harassment (S)

headline: For Many Market Players, Panic Is for the Other Guy
abstract: Traders and investors may be concerned that one of mightiest bull markets of all time could be stumbling, but while mutual fund companies do say there are some redemptions, almost no one actually admits feeling panic; some Wall Street analysts have voiced fears that big plunge would cause panic among many of 25 million first-time investors who have come into market since 1990, but resilience of individual investors has buoyed stocks repeatedly when there have been dips (M)

headline: FORD SAYS IT PLANS $1 BILLION FACTORY IN BRAZIL
abstract: Ford Motor Co says it plans to spend up to $1 billion to build factory in southern Brazil (S)

headline: Asia Strategy, From One Who Has Been There
abstract: Interview with Prof Warren B Bailey on his strategy for investing own money in Asian emerging markets; table; photo (L)

headline: Will GTE, Long Seen as the Tortoise, Win the Race?
abstract: Analysts discuss GTE Corp as an investment in light of fact that Wall Street remains largely unimpressed by the company; note GTE, nation's third-largest local telephone company, is possible takeover target in light of industry's rapid consolidation; stock price graph (M)

headline: Assistance for the 401(k) Challenged
abstract: Barriers to employers providing workers with customized advice about 401(k) pension plan investments are shrinking; some employers are hiring outside firms to dispense answers; recent Labor Department decision to let TCW Group offer tailored advice is raising interest among other plan managers; graphs; photo (M)

headline: Products intended to evoke the exotic world of Picasso, Hemingway -- and Max Morgan.
abstract: Line of merchandise focusing on Max Morgan, free-spirited aviator, and his fabulous though fictional life style, is being sold by retail stores across the country (Advertising column) (L)

headline: Harold S. Geneen, 87, Dies; Nurtured ITT
abstract: Harold S Geneen, who virtually invented international conglomerate while transforming ITT during 1960's and 70's, dies at age 87; photo (M)

headline: 'A Careful Dance' for U.S. Envoy in Switzerland
abstract: United States Ambassador to Switzerland, Madeleine M Kunin, says her Jewishness is frequent topic for Swiss, especially since United States began pressing Swiss to acknowledge and publish information about World War II-era bank accounts belonging to Jewish refugees, including Kunin's mother; Kunin is concerned that if US is not careful, all the emphasis on money will burst into new wave of anti-Semitism in Switzerland, country in which only 18,000 Jews live; photo (M)

headline: G.M. Sales Hurt by Shortage of Rail Cars
abstract: General Motors Corp says its US sales will decline this month and perhaps rest of year because of shortage of rail cars; supplies of rail cars in US dropped after Union Pacific Corp acquired Southern Pacific Railroad because of track construction in California and Texas (S)

headline: European Trade Inquiry To Focus on Aid to Dow
abstract: European Commission will probe subsidies German Government paid Dow Chemical when Dow bought three eastern German chemical factories (S)

headline: Market Place; Wealthy Executives Have Compensation Troubles, Too
abstract: Market Place: Survey of 150 affluent executives by United States Trust Corp, investment management company, finds that two-thirds of them worry that too much of their net worth--about 35 percent, on average--is tied up in their companies' stock; one reason for imbalance is corporate America's rapid proliferation of stock options combined with bull market of recent years (L)

headline: AIG Plans $2.2 Billion Insurance Acquisition
abstract: American International Group Inc to buy American Bankers Insurance Group Inc for $2.2 billion in stock (M)

headline: In Birthplace of U.S. Democracy, Jiang Finds the Trappings and Traps of Liberty
abstract: Pres Jiang Zemin of China visits revolutionary sites in Philadelphia, but cancels his plans to see Liberty Bell because of demonstration by about 200 people (M)

headline: Quaker State Narrows Its Review
abstract: The Quaker State Corporation has narrowed the review on its motor oil account to two finalists from five semifinalists. The account, with billings estimated at $20 million, had been at Foote, Cone & Belding in Chicago, a unit of True North Communications, which resigned in September.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Still a Long Way to Go To Open Phone Markets  Last week's Justice Department report recommending rejection of BellSouth's bid to offer long-distance telephone service in Louisiana offered the latest confirmation of something most people already knew: Competition among telephone service providers in local markets remains a goal, rather than a reality.    Two years after the passage of the Federal Telecommunications Act of 1996, little progress has been made toward fulfilling one of the act's principal aims -- giving consumers as broad a range of choice in local service as they already have among long-distance providers. [Page D10.]

headline: Pakistan's Army May Settle Political Feud
abstract: Pakistan Prime Min Nawaz Sharif attacks President and Supreme Court, accusing them of setting off political crisis that has paralyzed Government and damaged economy; court is hearing contempt case against Sharif, as well as cases in which he has been charged with corruption; Western diplomats see likelihood that that military will step in to settle political feud (S)

headline: Fed Chief's Remarks Spur Rally in Bonds
abstract: Treasury securities rally after Alan Greenspan, Federal Reserve chairman, tells Congressional committee that growth appears to remain robust and inflation low despite tight labor market; 30-year Treasury bond gains 1 5/32 points to price of 102 12/32, pushing its yield down to 6.20 percent from 6.28 percent day earlier (M)

headline: PIONEER NATURAL TO SELL GAS AND OIL PROPERTIES
abstract: Pioneer Natural Gas Co to sell natural gas and oil properties in Oklahoma, West Texas and New Mexico for total of $105 million to unit of Titan Exploration Inc and to Sheridan Energy Inc; to use funds for debt reduction (S)

headline: Microsoft Is the Latest Target of Nader's Consumer Crusade
abstract: Ralph Nader and several of his public interest groups plan national drive against growing power of Microsoft Corp, computer software publisher; Nader met recently with top Justice Department antitrust division officials, urging action against Microsoft; plans Washington conference to discuss company's strategy and influence on software market (M)

headline: AMERICA ONLINE IN DEAL WITH TRAVEL SERVICE PROVIDER
abstract: America Online Inc agrees to make Preview Travel Inc its main travel-service provider; Preview will pay America Online $32 million over five years and will provide services that include ticket sales, car rentals and hotel reservations (S)

headline: Albright, in Uganda, Steps Up Attack on Sudan's War of Terror
abstract: Sec Madeleine Albright visits northern Uganda to focus attention on victims of brutal campaign by Lord's Resistance Army, bizarre Christian rebel group that is supported by Islamic Government in Sudan; she also steps up criticism of Sudanese Government, vowing that US will continue campaign to isolate regime; Albright also meets in Kampala with six leaders of Sudanese rebel alliance (S)

headline: True North Cleared for Vote on Bozell Bid
abstract: Judge Joan Gottschall denies bid by Publicis SA to block vote by shareholders of True North Communications on its planned acquisition of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt (S)

headline: Xerox Earnings Jump 28% As Digital Copiers Sell Well
abstract: Xerox Corp says earnings rose 28 percent in third quarter; net income rose to $320 million from $250 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue rose 5.2 percent, to $4.38 billion from $4.16 billion (M)

headline: AVON SAYS EARNINGS WILL FALL SHORT OF EXPECTATIONS
abstract: Avon Products Inc says its fourth-quarter earnings will not meet analysts' estimates (S)

headline: REYNOLDS METALS IN TALKS WITH BALL ON CAN BUSINESS
abstract: Reynolds Metals Co says it is in talks to sell its aluminum can business to Ball Corp as part of plan to pay down debt and increase its share price (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.50   5.49   5.22        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   4.99   5.10   4.99        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.01   5.10   5.06        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.53   3.54   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   5.87   5.97   6.38        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   6.20   6.28   6.68        TELEPHONE BONDS   7.33   7.35   7.75        MUNICIPAL BONDS***   5.42   5.45   5.88          *Estimated daily average, Dow Jones Markets  **Realized dollar amount rises with inflation  ***Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer  Sources: Salomon Brothers and Dow Jones Markets for Treasury's bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: A Good Fit Is Starting to Pinch; Nine West Tries to Fend Off Investigations and Debt
abstract: Signs of trouble at Nine West Group, leading shoe manufacturer, discussed; include Securities and Exchange Commission probe of possible accounting irregularities, which led to sharp drop in stock price; company warns fourth-quarter earnings will be 40 percent lower than expected; graph; photo (M)

headline: Istanbul Journal; Turks, Ever Zealous, Storm a Magazine's Stunt
abstract: Time magazine has been flooded with letters, faxes and e-mails from Turks who want Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, founder of modern Turkey, to be included in Time's special issue celebrating century's outstanding figures in five broad categories; most public appeals have not mentioned that Time editors plan to make choices themselves, and that idea of asking for nominations is promotional lure; Turks are so determined that Ataturk be included that they are casting votes for him in every category, including century's greatest entertainer; photo (M)

headline: Scandal Pushes Powerful Family From Pinnacle In Mexico
abstract: Raul Salinas Lozano is patriarch who raised his family to pinnacle of power in Mexico, then watched it slide to depths of scandal; in political career spanning half century, Salinas Lozano, now 80, was Cabinet secretary and senator; allegations of wrongdoing that landed his eldest son Raul Salinas de Gortari in jail and forced his second son Carlos, former President, into exile also touched leader of Salinas clan; convicted Mexican drug trafficker Magdalena Ruiz Pelayo, who was described in sworn court testimony in US as having been Salinas Lozano's secretary, testified to US investigators that he was part of drug smuggling ring; Salinas Lozano calls Ruiz Pelayo liar who was never his secretary; photo (M)

headline: Bell Atlantic Internet Pact
abstract: Bell Atlantic Corp picks equipment by Farallon Communications as router for its Internet access service (S)

headline: Oxford Health Receives Fine Of $3 Million
abstract: New York State Insurance Dept, after completing another phase of its extensive review of Oxford Health Plans, releases harsh critique of Oxford's management and fines company $3 million for violating state insurance regulations; dept also orders company to refund roughly $500,000 to some customers; report describes 'poor planning and/or inexperienced management' as apparent cause of many of Oxford's difficulties and catalogues numerous regulatory infractions by company, including raising customers' premiums without sufficient notice, issuing contracts without approval of regulators and using unlicensed insurance agents to sell its products; Stephen F Wiggins, Oxford's founder and chairman, says Oxford has been cooperating with Insurance Dept for past two years, and 'is happy to get this report behind us, allowing us to move forward in the new year' (L)

headline: Vietnamese Fear Boom May Falter
abstract: Asian investors who fueled building boom in Ho Chi Minh City now have huge economic troubles to deal with at home, threatening Vietnam's growth; Vietnam, whose economy grew about 9 percent in 1997, hopes to stay clear of economic turmoil; is eager for foreign investments and hopes to lure back some of millions who fled after Communist victory (M)

headline: NINE WEST SAYS EARNINGS WILL FALL SHORT OF FORECASTS
abstract: Nine West Group Inc says fourth-quarter earnings will be well below analysts' forecasts; company says third-quarter earnings fell 2 percent, to $34.6 million, for quarter ended Nov 1, from $35.3 million in year-earlier period (S)

headline: U.N. Extends Monitoring of Police in Haiti
abstract: United Nations Security Council votes to extend mission of a multinational police monitoring force in Haiti for a year and to increase its size to 300 members from 250 (S)

headline: 23 Basque Leaders Go on Trial in Spain
abstract: 23 top leaders of Spain's Leftist Basque party go on trial for killing of nearly 800 people since 1968 in fight for independent homeland (S)

headline: Dow Jones Sets Wide Cutbacks At Data Unit; Loss to Result
abstract: Dow Jones & Co announces layoffs and other cutbacks at its troubled financial-information division that will result in first annual loss of company since it went public 34 years ago; Dow Jones says it will dismiss between 300 and 400 people at 4,000-member staff at Dow Jones Markets, formerly called Telerate, cut investment spending for unit next year and take 'very sizable' charge against fourth-quarter earnings to reflect the cost; analysts and other experts say loss could possibly reach $600 million or more (L)

headline: Newfangled Idea For Old-Fashioned Toy; These Next-Generation Jigsaw Puzzles Take Off in a Direction All Their Own
