abstract: Profile of Wrebbit Inc, Canadian jigsaw puzzle firm started by Paul E Gallant, who grew company into multimillion success by focusing on exports; firm, along with its new United States partner, Hasbro Inc, will turn out more than 10 million three-dimensional puzzles this year; financial graph; photo of Galllant (M)

headline: Trial of Vichy Official Lifts Veil on Killing of Algerians
abstract: French Government will open secret archives relating to killings of dozens of Algerians in Paris in 1961 after Maurice Papon, senior functionary under both wartime Vichy government and postwar Republic, denies that police he once commanded were responsible; Papon is on trial for allegedly organizing deportation of Jews from Paris between 1942 and 1944 to concentration camps (M)

headline: For Citibank, A Problem Plum; Mexican Deal Survives, Despite Fraud Case and Political Turmoil
abstract: Citicorp's agreement in August to buy high-profile Mexican bank from Jorge Lankenau Rocha looked like good deal; it still may be, but in months since acquisition of Banca Confia was announced, it has become major headache for Citibank and its Mexican director Julio de Quesada; Lankenau has been arrested and charged with fraud, and deal has become lightning rod for Mexican criticism of foreign corporate ownership; Citibank paid $45 million for Confia and has injected up to $175 million in capital into the bank; Confia is a plum for Citibank; it has 200 branches throughout the country and reputation for service that is rare in Mexico; acquisition fits Citibank's desire to get into street-corner banking in Mexico and to become banker to world's rising middle class; chart on status of 18 Mexican banks since collapse of peso in late; photos (L)

headline: Accounts
abstract: -- 800-4-Referral, Ramsey, N.J., to Lois/EJL, New York, part of Lois/ U.S.A., to introduce a telephone referral service linking consumers to service professionals like doctors and electricians. Billings were estimated at $3 million for an initial campaign in metropolitan New York.  -- Dirt Devil, Cleveland, a subsidiary of Royal Appliance Manufacturing Co., to Meldrum & Fewsmith Communications, Cleveland, owned by Wolf Group, to handle media planning for Dirt Devil vacuum cleaners. Those duties on the account, with billings estimated at $15 million, had been handled by the Griswold-Eshleman Co., Cleveland, which closed. Meldrum already handles the creative portion of the account.

headline: Market Place; Egg on Face, But Analyst May Profit
abstract: Market Place: Erroneous prediction on Sept 18 by UBS Securities analyst Thomas H Hanley that pegged Bankers Trust New York as takeover target for Travelers Group that resulted in $1.16 billion jump in market value of Bankers Trust stock before trading was halted that morning is focus of investigation by Securities and Exchange Commission into possible manipulation of Bankers Trust stock; Hanley's false call left egg on his face, but it also may have put money in his pocket when Travelers announced week later its plans to buy Salomon Inc; Hanley invests with money manager Harry V Keefe whose firm Keefe Managers had good fortune to buy Bankers Trust stock shortly before Hanley predicted a takeover; Keefe says Hanley played no role in his timely decision to buy or sell Bankers Trust shares; Hanley and Keefe's financial relationship offers example of some of potential conflicts on Wall Sreet that may compromise objectivity of analysts' research or market calls; it is well known that independence of analysts is sometimes undercut by brokerage firm's need to sell stock or win underwriting business (L)

headline: Lacking Plans for a Pullout, Israeli Heads to U.S. Talks
abstract: Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu, after another brutal and inconclusive Cabinet battle, leaves for Paris meeting with State Sec Madeleine K Abright without formal proposal on further Israeli withdrawal from West Bank; Min Ariel Sharon wrests from him pledge not to offer any new maps or plans, spurring Foreign Min David Levy to boycott trip; photo (M)/

headline: Senate Approves New F.C.C. Chairman
abstract: Senate gives approval to Pres Clinton's choice of William E Kennard to fill top post at Federal Communications Commission by vote of 99-to-1 (S)

headline: In Heaping Helpings, the New Flavors of I.R.A.'s
abstract: As the new year approaches, investors will be faced with such problems as new tax law requiremnts and continuing economic volatility in Asia; to meet these concerns, personal finance magazines will seek to guide readers through rough spots; efforts of Mutual Funds magazine, Money magazine and Worth in providing guidance to investors discussed; photos (M)

headline: Computers Let Japan's Drivers Play in Traffic
abstract: Car navigation systems, popular in Japan, are becoming hub of car information and entertainment, delivering television, data, video games and other amenities; Japanese experience could be prelude to what will happen in United States, where systems are starting to be offered to consumers; photos (M)

headline: In Mexican Village, Signs of Death Hang Heavy
abstract: Villagers in area of Chenalho, Mexico, react with grief and fear to massacre of 45 indians, reportedly by local men who critics say are trained and armed by the ruling powers in Chiapas for campaign against Zapatista rebels; map; photos (M)

headline: On 'Happy Day' for Wei, U.S. Is Careful Not to Gloat
abstract: White House officials say Pres Clinton pressed for dissident Wei Jingsheng's freedom from prison during recent state visit of Chinese Pres Jiang Zemin; says he made no deals for Wei's release, and had received no promises of action from Jiang (S)

headline: CIRCON SHAREHOLDERS VOTE TO BACK U.S. SURGICAL'S BID
abstract: US Surgical Corp says shareholders of Circon Corp have voted to support its hostile bid to acquire Circon for $254 million (S)

headline: CANADIAN OCCIDENTAL IN DEAL WITH PINNACLE RESOURCES
abstract: Canadian Occidental Petroleum Ltd, which is 30 percent owned by Occidental Petroleum, says it will sell part of its Wascana Energy unit to Pinnacle Resources Ltd for $308 million (Canadian), or $221.5 million (US) (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: JACOR COMMUNICATIONS INC., Covington, Ky., which owns and operates radio stations, agreed to buy KSJO-FM in San Jose, Calif., from American Radio Systems, for $30 million in cash.     QUESTOR MANAGEMENT CO., Southfield, Mich., said it had bought Avnet Inc.'s Channel Master unit for an undisclosed price.

headline: Stocks Higher in Tokyo
abstract: Japan's Nikkei stock index is up 173.43 points, or 1.01 percent, at 17,383.52 at midday Oct 22 (S)

headline: NBC Sports Decides Olympic Assignment
abstract: NBC Sports division of NBC, owned by General Electric Co, names Fallon McElligott Berlin in New York to advertise and promote coverage of Olympics in 2000, 2002, 2004, 2006 and 2008; billings undisclosed (S)

headline: Nazi Gold Was Recast And Issued In the U.S.
abstract: Federal Reserve says New York Federal Reserve Bank recast hundreds of gold bars to remove Nazi imprint in 1950, at time when Treasury knew much of gold, then worth $23 million, had been looted by Nazis; bars, which may also have contained gold from death camp victims, had been sold on world markets before May 1945 by Swiss National Bank, helping to finance German war effort; Federal Reserve Bank acted at request of bank that later became Citibank; there is no evidence that Federal Reserve or Treasury knew then that any of gold, used as collateral for purchase by Spain, came from Holocaust victims (M) bars often contai

headline: DIARY
abstract: ASIAN IMBROGLIO  The Tigers Clean House   Pacific leaders met in Vancouver, British Columbia, and joined in President Clinton's chorus, decreeing that only stringent policies and close monitoring could calm the financial storms washing through South Korea, Indonesia and Thailand. For the sick, the leaders prescribed a combination of belt-tightening, propping up of currencies, rooting out corruption and toughening oversight of banks. South Korea, humiliated after insisting it would dig itself out of the crisis, asked the International Monetary Fund for $20 billion in help, then quickly acknowledged that it would not be nearly enough.

headline: Payoff Scandal Widens For Mitsubishi Units
abstract: Payoff scandal involving Mitsubishi conglomerate in Japan widens as another company admits to transferring money to man arrested on suspicion of extortion; Mitsubishi Electric says it transferred money to same man who was arrested on Oct 22 for reportedly taking payoffs from Mitsubishi Motors; Mitsubishi Motors executives Atsushi Ueba, Yuichi Ueki and Shoichi Shima were also arrested; there are reports that many companies in Mitsubishi group are suspected by police of links to arrested man, Teiji Nakamoto; Mitsubishi Estate says it is investigating whether its officials paid money to Nakamoto; Mitsubishi Corp says it has not made any such payments (S)

headline: Nextlevel Gets Orders Totaling $4.5 Billion
abstract: Nextlevel Systems Inc says it won $4.5 billion in orders from 9 cable-television operators for new generation of boxes that will bring higher-quality TV pictures and interactive services into home; Tele-Communications Inc, Time Warner Inc, Comcast Corp and Cox Communications Inc and other cable companies will get right to buy 16 percent of Nextlevel for ordering 15 million set-top boxes; Nextlevel will also swap 10 percent of its equity for part of Tele-Communications' satellite distribution network (M)

headline: Swiss Banks Pay First War Account Claims
abstract: swiss banks pay first war account claims**Swiss banks pay first 10 or 12 claims to dormant accounts dating back to Holocaust and are ready to pay another 30 to 40; set up inquiry led by Paul A Volcker to comb their archives for any other assets belonging to Holocaust victims or survivors; delegates to 41-nation conference on Nazi gold in London criticize Vatican for not being as forthcoming as others documenting its treatment of Jews and trading with Nazi Germany during war; urge Vatican to respond to charges by Gypsy representatives that Nazi-backed regime in Croatia sent Vatican $2 million in gold coins and rings stolen by Gypsies killed at Jasenovic concentration camp (M)

headline: KPMG Files Suit Against a Rival
abstract: KPMG Peat Marwick, accounting and consulting firm, sues rival consulting firm Stern Stewart & Co, contending that it is unfairly trying to stifle competition in lucrative niche; KPMG lawyers contend Stern Stewart has tried to scuttle conference on 'economic value' consulting that KPMG is sponsoring next month; suit contends Stern Stewart has sent letters to potential speakers and attendees, urging them not to participate (S)

headline: PC Docs Acquisition
abstract: PC Docs Group International says that it plans to buy Fulcrum Technologies Inc for about $30 million (Canadian), or $20.9 million (United States) in stock (S)

headline: SHARED TECHNOLOGIES TO ACCEPT INTERMEDIA BID
abstract: Shared Technologies Fairchild Inc accepts an unsolicited takeover bid from Intermedia Communications Inc for $15 a share, or $366 million, plus assumption of $274 million in debt; deal terminates an earlier deal by Tel-Save Holdings Inc to acquire Shared Technologies (S)

headline: At a Family Castle, a Bridge Over a Financial Moat
abstract: SOMETIMES, the good news is also bad. How else to describe inheriting a 70-room, 12th-century castle in the heart of the Tyrolean Alps?    For one American couple, it was good news, because the castle is a national historic monument, includes an 800-year-old watchtower and is a storehouse of not only Austrian history but also of fond family memories.

headline: SUNGARD DATA TO ACQUIRE INFINITY FINANCIAL
abstract: Sungard Data Systems Inc to acquire Infinity Financial Technology for about $313 million in stock (S)

headline: Protest Disrupts Contempt Case Against Pakistan Premier
abstract: Supporters of Prime Min Nawaz Sharif storm Pakistan's Supreme Court ind Islamabad, forcing it to suspend contempt proceedings against Sharif; Sharif stands accused of criticizing the high court after it reinstated a corruption inquiry against him and blocked a constitutinoal amendment aimed at strengthenint his power; criticizing court is a crime in Pakistan, and Sharif, if convicted, could be forced from office; photo (M)

headline: Bodrum Journal; Ataturk the Icon Is About to Take a Bit of a Hit
abstract: British journalist Andrew Mango is writing book about Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, founder of Turkish Republic; Turkish law bans all criticism of Ataturk; intellectuals are eagerly awaiting book by Mango, who is one of world's most respected specialists on Turkey; map; photo (M)

headline: HOSPITALITY TO PURCHASE 9 HOTELS FROM MARRIOTT
abstract: Hospitality Properties Trust buys nine hotels, seven of which are still under construction, from Marriott International Inc for $129 million (S)

headline: Columbia Plan Would Recast Health Care
abstract: Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp says it is planning to trim about third of its roughly 340-hospital network; Columbia says it is reorganizing its hospitals into five distinct units; company plans to retain two units--known as East and West groups--which have total of 232 hospitals, for which 1996 revenues were approximately $14.2 billion; remaining units--the America, Atlantic and Pacific groups--combined have 108 hospitals and about $4 billion in revenues (L)

headline: Weak Demand Forces Down Copper Prices
abstract: Copper prices tumble as weak demand from Asia and rising mine output pushes stockpiles close to 20-month highs (S)

headline: Panel to Consider New Rules For Digital TV Broadcasters
abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore convenes advisory panel charged with determining what public-interest obligations broadcasters must fulfill to borrow second channel for digital broadcasts; instructs panel to find ways to improve children's programming and require broadcasters to offer free air time to political candidates; National Assn of Broadcasters has vowed to fight any new public-service requirements panel might suggest (M)

headline: Across the Desert, Across the Ages
Telefonica of Spain To Acquire All of Unit
abstract: Telefonica de Espana will pay Spanish Government 127 billion pesetas ($876 million) for the 23.78 percent of Telefonica Internacional SA that it does not already own; move will give Telefonica complete ownership of Tisa, which controls telephone companies in Latin America (S)

headline: Market Place; Some analysts think Kodak won't cut deep enough today.
abstract: Market Place column on analysts' speculations about long-awaited plan to whip Eastman Kodak into shape; chief executive, George M C Fisher, will disclose plan today (M)

headline: Equity Sale Set For This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    AHL Services Inc., Atlanta, 2.7 million shares. BT Alex. Brown.

headline: Turkey Is Urged Not to Turn Its Back on the European Union
abstract: European diplomats urge Turkey to reconsider its action, day after Prime Min Mesut Yilmaz froze official ties with European Union because of organization's rebuff of its bid for membership (M)

headline: Glass Maker Is Cutting 6,000 Jobs
abstract: Pilkington PLC says it will cut 6,000 jobs by March 1999 and take charge of about 200 million pounds ($335 million) for reorganization intended to make company more competitive (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Bolle Inc., Rye, N.Y., a unit of B.E.C. Group, to Hanft Byrne Raboy Abrams & Partners, New York, as the first agency to handle worldwide branding for the eyewear company. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

headline: In Brazil, Clinton Urges the Rich to Share Gains of Free Trade
abstract: Pres Clinton, in Brazil, urges rich of Latin America to share gains from free trade with poor; responds to concerns that hemispheric free-trade zone he seeks could cause American wages to fall and working and environmental conditions in Latin America to deteriorate (M)

headline: Congo's Opposition Pays Price of Defying Kabila
abstract: Six months after Laurent Kabila toppled Government of Pres Mobutu Sese Seko in former Zaire and banned political activity by any party but his own, there is little sign that Government intends to loosen hold on country's politics; under Kabila's Government, members of opposition party have been jailed, others have have been forbidden to travel abroad and have had houses and offices ransacked; critical Congolese journalists have been repeatedly arrested (M)

headline: Egypt's Farmers Resist End of Freeze on Rents
abstract: Egyptian Government has ended freeze on farm rents and begun to allow landlords to set rents as they please and terminate leases, a power they have not had since Gamal Abdel Nasser's agrarian reform in the 1950's; estimated 900,000 tenant farmers, who along with their families account for nearly 10 percent of country's population, will be affected, and their reaction been predictably violent; riots and armed clashes have led to scores of arrests and more than two dozen deaths; map; photo (M)

headline: Crisis Shakes Poise of Businesses
abstract: Seoul, South Korea, offers remarkable spectacle of modern, industrial economy that seemingly has come creaking nearly to a halt; financial crisis underscores how essence of modern commerce is confidence, and how computers and digital phone lines mean little without it; stock market has moved up somewhat, but uncertainties are so great that commerce is still crippled; trade finance system has broken down, credit that businesses depend on for working capital is unavailable, nervousness is so great that suppliers are unwilling to let go of their goods unless they get cash; overall apprehensiveness is so overwhelming that businesses are extremely cautious about deals when they do not know what exchange rate or costs they are committing themselves to; photo (M)

headline: Cantor Fitzgerald Shutting a Trading Unit
abstract: Cantor Fitzgerald LP says it will shut down its fixed-income trading unit, known as Global Trading Securities Group, and consolidate different brokerage operations under umbrella of its United States Taxable Fixed Income unit (S)

headline: International Briefs; National Westminster Rejects Bid for Unit
abstract: National Westminster Bank P.L.C. rejected a bid yesterday from Deutsche Morgan Grenfell for the global equities division of its NatWest Markets investment banking operation, saying the proposal was ''not in the best interest of its shareholders.''

headline: FRESH AMERICA TO BUY ASSETS OF FRANCISCO DISTRIBUTION
abstract: Fresh America Corp signs letter of intent to acquire substantially all assets of Francisco Distribution Co; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Auto Business Sold to Rival In Korea Crisis
abstract: Ssangyong Group, one South Korea's biggest family-run businesses, has sold off its auto company to rival Daewoo Group in what executives describe as first friendly takeover in history of Korea's largest conglomerate; unusual sale caps swirl of activity as Korean companies continue the makeover spurred by nation's economic crisis and rescue by International Monetary Fund last week; Daewoo announces greatest management reshuffle ever; Hyundai Group says it will cut capital investment next year by 40 percent and mount big export drive; photo (L)

headline: 1,057 Calls? A Telephone Bill Is on Hold
abstract: Nynex Corp, now Bell Atlantic, charged Jonathan Berman for 1,057 locals calls in New York City, but he says Nynex could not document many of them; Berman has refused to pay for calls that are not itemized; informal hearing has been held in front of Public Service Commission; decision is expected in mid-November; chart; photo (M)

headline: Grocery Giant To Be Created In $2 Billion, 3-Chain Merger
abstract: Fred Meyer Inc will acquire Quality Food Centers Inc and Ralphs Grocery Co in separate deals that will create fourth-largest chain in the nation; acquisitions, for $2 billion in stock, will create a chain with more than 800 stores in 14 states, with annual sales of $15 billion and cash flow of about $1.15 billion (L)

headline: Dresdner Bank Head to Quit in 2 Weeks
abstract: Jurgen Sarrazin, chief executive of Dresdner Bank AG, announces that he will quit in two weeks, months earlier than he originally planned, apparently because of widening scandal over tax avoidance that has already engulfed several top bank executives; Sarrazin has not been charged with wrongdoing; unexpectedly early resignation is clearest sign yet of turmoil in top ranks of Germany's third-largest bank; it also raises questions about Dresdner's push to become world-class competitor in investment banking (L)

headline: Israel Frees Ailing Hamas Founder to Jordan at Hussein's Request
abstract: Sheik Ahmed Yassin, spiritual leader of Islamic movement Hamas, is released from Israeli prison and flown to Amman, Jordan; Israeli Army says he was freed in response to request from King Hussein and in view of paraplegic sheik's deteriorating health (M)

headline: Browning Sets $1.45 Billion Sale Overseas
abstract: Browning-Ferris Industries agrees to sell its overseas operations to subsidiary of Suez Lyonnaise des Eaux in cash-and-stock deal valued at $1.45 billion; transaction will make Lyonnaise des Eaux world's third-largest waste-collection company; sale caps efforts by Browning-Ferris, second-largest trash hauler in US, to dispose of money-losing or marginally profitable overseas operations (M)

headline: Keybank to Sell Health Coverage To Businesses
abstract: Keybank plans to announce that it will begin selling health insurance to small businesses, many of whose employees now have no coverage; Keybank will offer choice of service from three healthcare companies to businesses with as few as two employees; Keybank will be creating competition for Blue Cross organizations, in much of country the only available health insurers for indviduals and small groups (L)

headline: Daubs of Oil and Exultation As Caspian Pipeline Opens
abstract: Foreign oilmen and regional leaders mark opening of world's richest new oil reserves to the West in Baku, Azerbaijan; it is first direct flow of crude from Caspian Sea to the West since breakup of Soviet Union; opening of pipeline signals initial triumph in three-year US-backed effort to break Russian blockade of energy exports from former Soviet Caspian republics; map (L)

headline: Atlanta Broadcaster Seen in Bid for Lin Television
abstract: Alabama state pension fund, acting through Atlanta broadcaster it has backed, is bidding at least $1.6 billion in cash for Lin Television Corp, topping $1.45 billion offer Lin accepted in August from Dallas buyout firm Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst; Lin says it is in talks with higher bidder, which it does not identify; people close to talks say it is Raycom Media; Hicks, Muse and its ally in Lin bid, NBC, issue statement with subtle threat to deny any other bidder the prize in the whole deal: the NBC affiliation now held by Lin's Dallas station (L)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.63   5.57   6.26        3-MO. headline: Stuart Northrop, 72; Led Huffy Company
abstract: Stuart Northrop, former chairman and chief executive of Huffy Co, dies at age 72 (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: BAYER CORP., Pittsburgh, a unit of Bayer A.G., said it was reducing its focus on arthritis to pursue new drugs to treat diabetes, cancer, obesity and osteoporosis.     PREMIUM CIGARS INTERNATIONAL LTD., Scottsdale, Ariz., agreed with a Mobil Corp. unit to begin setting up cigar stands this month in 500 Mobil-owned and operated convenience stores.

headline: Treasury Prices Bolstered by 5-Year Note Sale
abstract: Treasury auctions $11 billion in five-year notes at yield of 5.769 percent amid strong demand; 30-year bond rises 4/32, to 100 31/32, to yield 6.05 percent; graph (M)

headline: 10 Years After the Crash, Fall Is Not in the Air; Talking the Talk, Walking the Walk On Main Street
abstract: Stock market is key conversational topic in Marshalltown, Iowa, 10 years after market crash; many residents are now investors; photo (M)

headline: Pol Pot Unapologetic
abstract: Pol Pot, who as leader of the Khmer Rouge was responsible for the deaths of at least a million Cambodians in the 1970's, said in his first interview in 18 years that his conscience is clear. ''I came to carry out the struggle, not to kill people,'' he told the Far Eastern Economic Review in a report published this week.     Article, page A12.

headline: Lafarge to Buy Stake In Cementos Molins
abstract: Lafarge SA says its Spanish subsidiary, Asland SA, will buy 39 percent stake in Cementos Molins SA from Ciments Francais SA for about 800 million francs, or $134.5 million (S)

headline: China's Payoff: New Respect, New Status
abstract: Steven Erlanger analysis of summit meeting between Pres Clinton and Chinese Pres Jiang Zemin; contends that first Chinese-American summit meeting since crushing of democracy protests in Tiananmen Square in 1989 was also first since Soviet Union collapsed and sense that China is supplanting Russia as America's prime concern dominated meetings, in ways both practical and symbolic (M)

headline: ABLE TELCOM CONSIDERS OFFER FROM APPLIED CELLULAR
abstract: Able Telcom Holding Corp receives unsolicited takeover offer from Applied Cellular Technology Inc worth nearly $100 million (S)

headline: Sulzer Seeks to Sell A Troubled Unit
abstract: Sulzer AG is trying to sell its troubled building services unit, Sulzer Infra France, to Belgian Groupe Fabricom, a subsidiary of Tractebel SA; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: In Colombia, Support Grows for a Candidate With a Hard Line
abstract: Support is surging in Colombia for Gen Harold Bedoya, presidential candidate, spurred by spreading disarray; he bucks traditional party structure at time when parties have lost favor with voters; advocates defeating leftist guerrillas and restoring law and order; denies reports of torture, murder and forced disappearances by military and paramilitary units protected by military during his leadership (M)

headline: KOREAN COMPANIES ARE LOOKING RIPE TO FOREIGN BUYERS
abstract: South Korea's plummeting stock market and currency have made its companies potential takeover targets for foreign corporations, just as International Monetary Fund's economic rescue is forcing nation to open up to foreign investments; most of country's family-owned conglomerates are either bankrupt or reeling under heavy debt, forcing fire sales of assets that took generations to acquire; chart (M)

headline: PIONEER NATURAL RESOURCES BUYS GAS PROPERTIES
abstract: Pioneer Natural Resources Co agrees to buy natural gas properties in east Texas from American Cometra Inc and Rockland Pipeline Co for $157 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: Ex-Executive Who Exposed Archer Scandal Pleads Guilty
abstract: Mark E Whitacre, former Archer Daniels Midland executive who became Government informant and exposed global price-fixing scandal, pleads guilty to 37 Federal criminal charges, including theft, money laundering, conspiracy and tax evasion; crimes center on theft of $9 million from company in variety of schemes (M)

headline: Malaysia Curbs 5 Brokerages
abstract: Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange restricts trading activities of five brokerage firms: Sime Securities, Capitalcorp Securities, MBF Northern Securities, Sin Khoon & Company and Labuan Securities (S)

headline: A Raider Nonpareil; France, at Least, Sees Few Capitalists Like Him
abstract: In the corporate world of France, with its cozy intertwined shareholdings and classically educated business elite, it took an outsider like Francois Pinault, a school dropout at age 16, to shake things up.     The local version of a corporate raider, Mr. Pinault has made his way as a capitalist without capital, a businessman who aggrandized himself with other people's money, borrowing and buying low and selling high to pay back his debts and still have plenty left over.

headline: Michael von Clemm, 62, Eurobonds Pioneer
abstract: Michael von Clemm, investment banker who used lifelong interest in anthropology to help pioneer global Eurobond market, died on Nov 6 at age 62; photo (L)Ã»

headline: Kamuzu Banda Dies; 'Big Man' Among Anticolonialists
abstract: Hastings Kamuzu Banda, founding father in postcolonial Africa who led Malawi to independence in 1964, declared himself President for Life in 1971, then was turned out in 1994, dies; there is no record of his birth date; he was in his 90's; he ruled with combination of eccentricity and cruelty for 30 years until Western nations forced elections by threatening to withhold aid; photo; map (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: In a Shake-Up, Kodak Replaces Consumer Chief  Kodak replaced the head of its ailing consumer division, David P. Biehn, left, part of an accelerating effort to cut costs and reconstruct its photography business.

headline: Warsaw Journal; Infidelity, Wife-Beating and Greed: Must-See TV
abstract: Polish television is offering groundbreaking new soap opera, Clan, that addresses personal financial and ethical issues never before dealt with in mass-market series in nation; director Pawel Karpinski says series, about three generations of family, is based on Polish reality; photo (M)

headline: 4 Americans Killed
abstract: Four Americans and their Pakistani driver were killed today when gunmen fired on their vehicle in Karachi, the authorities said. No one claimed responsibility for the slayings, but the city's police chief said that ''there is a strong possibility'' that they were linked to the conviction Monday of a Pakistani for fatally shooting two employees of the C.I.A. outside its headquarters.     Article, page A3.

headline: U.S. Presence in Gulf Is Denounced in Iran
abstract: Iran opens world Islamic conference with harsh denunciation of West, urging Muslim countries to resist what it calls 'persistent and cunning enemies' led by US and Israel; Ayatollah Ali Khamenei says US and its military presence in Persian Gulf is main threat to security in region; photo (M)

headline: U.N. Finds Corruption Is Difficult To Root Out
abstract: Report by Under Sec Gen Karl T Paschke, who heads United Nations' anti-corruption effort, reveals corruption is hard to root out because of sloppy management practices that makes diverting funds relatively easy; Paschke focuses probes on procurement, holding contracts for catering, food purchases and air-charter services seem particularly prone to abuse; reports recouping some $30 million for UN over last year (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: RAYTHEON CO., Lexington, Mass., said it had received six engineering and construction contracts with a total value of more than $100 million.     TRINET CORPORATE REALTY TRUST INC., San Francisco, has acquired two office properties in Dallas for about $39 million.

headline: King World's Chiefs Hope for New Syndication Success With Old TV Standbys
abstract: King World Productions Inc, led by Michael and Roger King, sells rights to television programs, and has just pulled off favorable deals for Roseanne Barr's coming talk show as well as new version of Hollywood Squares; though both new programs could flop, Wall Streetreacted favorably, pushing King World's stock up; King World, which has not had new hit in several years, is enjoying comeback (M)

headline: Unanimous Security Council Tightens the Vise on Iraq
abstract: United Nations Security Council votes unanimously to impose new sanctions on Iraq, including ban on foreign travel by officials who do not cooperate with UN disarmament commission; Iraqi Deputy Prime Min Tariq Aziz says resolution is 'unjust' and will be ignored; United States Amb Bill Richardson says Council has not ruled out military option; US and Britain believe use of force is authorized by existing resolutions, stand disputed by Russia, France and China; photo (M)

headline: When Parting Is Such Strange Sorrow
abstract: On the Job: readers describe how they were dismissed from their jobs; some were handled with tact, others with heavy hand; sometimes, in retrospect, there was cause for laughter; drawings (M)

headline: Hong Kong Builder Sees Shares Crumble
abstract: Shares of Hopewell Holdings Ltd, builder based in Hong Kong, fall to record low on concern over fate of company's projects amid Asia's financial problems; graph (S)

headline: Clinton and Jiang in Their Own Words: Sharing a Broad Agenda
abstract: Excerpts from joint news conference by Pres Clinton and Chinese Pres Jiang Zemin; photo (L)

headline: GPU to Buy Australian State's Electrical Network
abstract: GPU Inc buys high-voltage electricity transmission network of Australia's Victoria state for $2.72 billion (Australian) (US $2 billion); plans to sell all its nonnuclear power generation assets to focus on power transmission (M)

headline: At a Saudi Base, U.S. Digs In, Gingerly, for a Longer Stay
abstract: Work nears completion on sprawling housing complex in Prince Sultan Air Base in Saudi Arabia for 4,000 or so US Air Force personnel who help maintain the no-flight zone over southern Iraq; complex, 70 miles outside Riyadh, will provide many of the comforts of home, but appears more like a prison, thanks to the array of security features incorporated after June 1996 bombing of military housing complex in Dhahran; Pentagon struggles with host of problems caused by prolonged presence in Saudi Arabia; map (M)

headline: Treasuries Are Little Changed On Sign Inflation Is Still at Bay
abstract: Price of 30-year Treasury bond slips 2/32, to 101 3/32 on Nov 28 (M)

headline: Stock Rally Stalls on Corporate Earnings
abstract: Dow drops 25.79 points to close at 8,034.65, while Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 3.79 points, to 968.49 (M)

headline: Two Magazines Name Agencies
abstract: New York magazine selects DeVito/Verdi to handle its advertising account, which had recently been inactive; billings undisclosed; Good Housekeeping names New York office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles to handle its trade advertising, with billings estimated at $1 million to $2 million (S)

headline: Calendar Whirl ; Thousands of Ways to Keep Track of 365 Days
abstract: Calendar publishing, by both start-up companies and large book publishers, is surging industry with annual sales of over $5 billion; factors figuring in eventual success of given calendar include production costs, licensing fees or guaranteed royalties, discount given retailer and return rate of unsold calendars; photos (M)

headline: Honda Is No. 2 in Japan
abstract: Honda Motor Co is Japan's second-largest auto maker after Toyota Motor Corp; in November, Honda overtook Nissan Motor Co to sell more vehicles in Japan (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Banks to Let South Korea Delay Loan Repayments  Leading commercial and investment banks have agreed to extend payment deadlines for as much as $15 billion in troubled loans to South Korea. The agreement is an extraordinary show of support for the troubled Korean economy, coming a week after the International Monetary Fund and big industrial countries agreed to speed up the delivery of $10 billion in aid.

headline: Toshiba Profit Off 77% In Computer Competition
abstract: Toshiba Corp reports pretax profit of 8.74 billion yen, or $68.8 million, for six months that ended on Sept 30, down 77 percent from year earlier (S)

headline: Catholic Bishops Finish Survey of Challenges to the Americas
abstract: Special synod of Roman Catholic bishops from North and South America convened by Pope John Paul II has concluded monthlong survey of moral, social and economic challenges confronting Western Hemisphere, from foreign debt to broken families; participants prepare 76 proposals and write final collective message; these will form basis for papal document on tasks facing church in Americas--home of about half world's 1 billion Catholics--as it approaches its 2,000th year; many bishops say most significant result of special synod was fact that they came together from two continents that do not always see themselves as single region (M)

headline: GLOBAL WARMING: Around the Globe, Big Worries and Small Signs of Progress; Poland's Pollution Drops Even as Economy Rises
abstract: Even though Poland has succeeded in reducing air pollution since collapse of Communist rule, it remains criticized by Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development over its dirty air, and upcoming Kyoto, Japan, conference on global warming is expected to add extra pressure; reduction has been achieved, in large part, by investments in desulfurization installations at power plants and gradual phasing out of small emission sources, like coal-burning stoves and boilers; Polish environmental official, Wojtek Ponikiewski, says there is no possibility that country will agree to suggestion by European Union that world's nations commit to 15 percent reduction in greenhouse gases, to 1990 emission levels, by 2010; photo (M)

headline: Dyno of Norway Raises Offer for Krems Chemie
abstract: Dyno Industrier ASA raises its bid to buy Austrian chemical company Krems Chemie AG to $57.80 (US) a share from offer of $52.18 (US) that it made on Sept 29 (S)0

headline: ELECTRONIC RETAILING AND TELEPANEL SYSTEMS TO MERGE
abstract: Electronic Retailing Systems International Inc will merge with Telepanel Systems Inc in $68 million deal; Electronic Retailing shareholders will own two-thirds of combined company and Telepanel shareholders will hold one-third (S)

headline: World News Briefs; Botha Again Ignores Truth Panel's Subpoena
abstract: Former Pres P W Botha again defies South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission, ignoring third subpoena to appear before panel to answer questions about how many apartheid-era atrocities were sanctioned by Govt (S)

headline: Union Membership Drops Worldwide, U.N. Reports
abstract: International Labor Organization annual report says union membership dropped in most industrial countries between 1985 and 1995, pushed down by shift away from manufacturing and loss of many unionized jobs; says unions, however, have not lost influence, especially in Europe (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  Construction Spending Oct.

headline: U.S. Backs a Global Plan by U.N. to Fight Drugs
abstract: The Clinton Administration has decided to endorse an ambitious United Nations program to eliminate drug production worldwide, according to an American proposal on combating the drug trade.    The proposal, which has not been made public, calls on governments ''to commit themselves to ending all illicit cultivation of opium poppy and coca bush by the year 2008, using all available means, including alternative development, eradication and law enforcement.''

headline: U.S. Intervenes On Problems Of Union Pacific
abstract: Federal regulators declared a transportation emergency in the West yesterday, but stopped short of a major takeover of the troubled lines of the Union Pacific Railroad, choosing instead to open only a small area in Texas to a local competitor of the railroad.    The decision by the Federal Surface Transportation Board came after months of accidents, jammed rail lines and late deliveries in the area served by Union Pacific, which became the nation's largest railroad with last year's merger with the Southern Pacific Rail Corporation. It and the Burlington Northern Santa Fe are now the two major carriers in the West.

headline: When the Tax Bill Exceeds the Return
abstract: INVESTORS in the Berger 100 fund found a big lump of coal in their stockings this month when the fund distributed a whopping one-third of its net assets in capital gains.    For shareholders who owned the Berger fund in a taxable account, that payout could produce a tax bill bigger than the total return generated by the fund this year.

headline: Census Bureau Names Five Ad Agencies
abstract: Census Bureau names Young & Rubicam Inc and four other agencies to handle first paid advertising campaign to persuade Americans to participate in census, set for 2000; four include two Y&R units, Bravo Group and Mosaica, and J Curtis & Co and Gray & Gray Advertising (S)

headline: Mawgan Journal; Forgive Us Our Trespasses? Not Here in England!
abstract: Sir Ferrers Vyvyan is battling hikers who want to add path on his Mawgan, England, ancestral estate to Britain's definitive right-of-way maps; ramblers in Britain depend on huge network of public paths that crisscross private land and such disputes flare up regularly; map; photos (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: BANK OF NEW YORK CO., New York, agreed to purchase the corporate trust business of First American Corp., Nashville, as the bank develops its fee-based businesses. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: U.S. Urges Prompt Action On Nazi Gold
abstract: US, at close of internatonal conference in London on Nazi gold affair, seeks to increase pressure for having compensation paid to hundreds of thousands of aging Holocaust survivors during next two years; Stuart E Eizenstat, leading American negotiator, urges deadline of Dec 31, 1999, to complete inquiries and pay compensation (M)

headline: Asia's Down, but Is It Out? The Past Suggests Not
abstract: Asia's economic prospects remain bright despite current crisis, one of several that the region has suffered over the last 25 years; each crisis spread the kind of gloom seen today, and each was followed by a new period of unprecedented growth; experts think that crisis will be good for region if it forces banks and markets to modernize so as to allocate capital more efficiently; some say this is already occurring (M)

headline: Thick Maze Of Objections Slows Down U.N. Reforms
abstract: Sec Gen Kofi Annan's plans to reform UN operations are being buried in blizzard of questions and objections in General Assembly committees; national delegations are dissecting every proposal to streamline management and apportion money based on results; American observers warn of adverse effect in Washington (S)

headline: Market Place; Starwood's earnings once ITT is absorbed should more than offset an increase in shares.
abstract: Hilton Hotels Corp, in its fight with Starwood Lodging Trust for control of ITT Corp, said Starwood was issuing too much stock as part of its $10.2 billion offer and that investors were taking big gamble if they accepted its bid; Starwood says it has filed $2 billion shelf registration with Securities and Exchange Commission for sale of stock, preferred shares, warrants or debt; Starwood issues statement saying it has no intention of issuing even more shares to pay for ITT; analysts say they are not worried about any possible dilution, in large part because addition of ITT will add so much to Starwood's earnings (L)

headline: Paris Company Buys Ad Research Rival
abstract: ASI Market Research Inc agrees to be acquired by IPSOS Group SA; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: ELECTRO RENT COMPLETES PURCHASE OF G.E. UNIT
abstract: Electro Rent Corp buys GE Capital Technology Management Services' computer rental business for $241 million, lower price than announced in September (S)

headline: Dissident Meets Clinton, Urges Pressure On Beijing
abstract: Wei Jingsheng, prominent dissident released by China on November 16, meets with Pres Clinton at White House and urges him to continue pressing Beijing to improve its record on human rights and democracy; White House declines comment on meeting out of sensitivity to Beijing's concerns (M)

headline: VIEWPOINT; General Electric's Victory in Europe
abstract: Stephan-Gotz Richter article on success of GE Capital, financial arm of General Electric, in quietly acquiring network of companies in all areas of Europe's service industry; notes most of acquisition targets are midsize service providers unable to raise equity capital domestically to grow dynamically on own (M)

headline: LENDERS TO ALLOW KOREANS TO DELAY DEBT REPAYMENTS
abstract: Leading commercial and investment banks agree to one-month extension of payment deadlines for as much as $15 billion in troubled loans to South Korea; extraordinary show of support for troubled South Korean economy comes a week after International Monetary Fund and big industrial countries agreed to speed up delivery of $10 billion in aid; agreement, which essentially bends rules for large borrowers near default, is only realistic alternative for banks, which faced prospect of losing much more and perhaps causing far greater crisis if they demanded payment (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Barclays Said to Discuss A Merger With NatWest  Barclays and National Westminster, two of Britain's largest financial institutions, are discussing a merger that would be worth more than $20 billion and would vault the merged concern to the top of the British banking industry, bank advisers say.

headline: No Winner in 2 Yugoslavia Presidential Votes
abstract: Races for President in two republics that make up Yugoslavia appear to be headed for deadlock that would force new election in Serbia and runoff in Montenegro; ultranationalist Vojislav Seselj appears to be defeating Zoran Lilic, but low turnout will necessitate new voting; Momir Bulatovic, ally of Slobodan Milosevic, leads Milol Djukanovic in Montenegro, but neither gets majority (S)

headline: TEXAS INSTRUMENTS IN DEAL FOR AMATI COMMUNICATIONS
abstract: Texas Instruments Inc agrees to buy Amati Communications Corp for $395 million, topping bid from Westell Technologies Inc (S)

headline: First Pacific Selling Pacific Link Stake
abstract: First Pacific Co sells a mobile telephone business to Hong Kong Telecommunications Ltd for $625.3 million (US); First Pacific owns 65 percent of the business, Pacific Link Communications Ltd; Vodafone Group PLC owns rest of Pacific Link (S)

headline: GOLDMAN, SACHS IS ACQUIRING 9.5% STAKE IN IDB HOLDING
abstract: Discount Investment Corp will sell 9.5 percent stake in IDB Holding Corp to Goldman, Sachs & Co for $79.2 million (US) (S)

headline: German Builder Gets Prison Term
abstract: Jurgen Schneider, real estate developer once regarded as Germany's construction king, is sentenced to six years and nine months in prison for fraud that led to nation's largest corporate bankruptcy; case reviewed (S)

headline: Praise for the Global Warming Initiative
abstract: British Petroleum Co chief executive John Browne has won grudging approval from some environmentalists, many of whom place his company at forefront of multinationals willing to tackle problem of global warming; Browne praises what he describes as limited progress achieved at Kyoto climate conference; says he hopes future agreements will go further; photo (L)

headline: Business Travel; Those headed for the Middle East and South Asia are warned to be extra cautious these days.
abstract: Business travel news roundup; Ackerman Group, executive-security firm that serves many multinational companies, is warning clients about dangers of sending business travelers to Middle East and South Asia; warns anti-American sentiment is running high throughout Muslim world; Siemens Corp to test equipping its North American employees with smart cards provided by US Bancorp that will automatically compare rates to insure it is getting negotiated travel discounts (M)

headline: Japan Bank-Aid Plan Sends Dollar Lower
abstract: US dollar falls sharply after Japan's Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto backs plan to prop up nation's banks and securities firms; dollar rises to two-month high against German mark (S)

headline: FROM THE DESK OF; Million Dollar Delusion
abstract: Commentary by Fred Waddell disputes financial-planning advice that at least $1 million must be saved to insure secure retirement; says this figure is product of financial services industry that stands to churn up business by perpetuating this notion; says he has noted several distortions that are used to spread self-serving myth; drawing (M)

headline: Breeding Seeds of Discontent; Cotton Growers Say Strain Cuts Yields
abstract: Monsanto Co calls genetically engineered cotton it developed with Delta and Pine Land Co most successful product introduction in farming history--likely to make cotton nation's first crop in which genetically altered varieties predominate; genetic makeup of plants is intended to make them more resistant to infestitation or pesticides; but in Mississippi Delta, revolution has produced enough casualties that officials are warning farmers to hold off until further testing proves technology's reliablity; disillusionment, shared by dozens of farmers in Mississippi who are seeking millions of damages from two companies, exposes risks of speeding new technology to a market like agriculture where caution has ruled; in Texas, companies face lawsuit over performance of another genetically altered variety; Pioneer Hi-Bred International Inc has announced its refusal to add Monsanto's 'Roundup Ready' gene to its corn, saying Monsanto's proposed charges and restrictions outweigh benefits for farmers, a point Monsanto disputes; tables; photos (L)

headline: Gruntal Plans To Purchase Hampshire
abstract: Gruntal & Co is expected to announce that it plans to acquire, for undisclosed sum, Hampshire Securities Corp, New York; Guntal's chairman-chief executive Robert Rittereiser comments (M)

headline: Market Place; Marvel returns to the brink as another reorganization fails.
abstract: Plan to reorganize Marvel Entertainment Group collapses as some secured creditors balk; those creditors evidently were enticed by plan put forward at last minute by Toy Biz Inc, company partly owned by Marvel, to reorganize Marvel on terms better for secured creditors but worse for existing Marvel shareholders (Market Place column) (L)

headline: Hyundai Motor Delays Venture in Indonesia
abstract: Hyundai Motor Co says its joint-venture project to build cars in Indonesia with Bimantara Citra is on hold until Apr; cites Indonesia's plan to cut tariffs on car imports from 200 percent to 40 percent under terms of International Monetary Fund bailout (S)

headline: Albright to Consult Arab Countries on Iraq
abstract: Sec of State Madeleine K Albright will visit Arab countries to consult leaders on how to deal with Pres Saddam Hussein of Iraq in crisis over United Nations weapons inspectors; Arab governments have already said they do not want military means used against Iraq; Albright meets in Switzerland with Yasir Arafat for talks on peace efforts with Israel; officials say meeting produced only modest progress; Arafat looks pale and frail, lending support to rumors that he is ill; photo (M)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  GLUCK, SARAH
abstract: GLUCK-Sarah. Beloved wife of the late Louis. Devoted mother of Dr. Joel and Stephanie. Dear sister of Joseph Biegen. Adored grandmother of Eric and Robin. Graveside services Friday, 1 PM, Mt. Hebron Cemetery, Flushing. For information, call RiversideNassau North: 516-487-9600.

headline: Interpublic Unit Resigns Account
abstract: Ammirati Puris Lintas resigns from peripheral products account of Epson America (S)

headline: As Yale Moves Away From Apple Computer, Cries (Nay, Shouts) of Conflict of Interest
abstract: Yale University's director of information technology, Daniel A Updegrove, is being besieged with flood of hate E-mail since sending letter to incoming freshmen, steering them toward purchase of personal computers using Microsoft's Windows and microprocessors from Intel, and away from Apple Computer's Macintoshes; Updegrove says he was unaware that Yale had applied for grant from Intel at same time; Apple devotees are skeptical about such a seeming coincidence; Yale did receive $2.7 million 'Technology for Education 2000' grant from Intel; Updegrove points out that shift at Yale away from Mac's has been under way, without any prodding, for last several years; photo (M)

headline: World News Briefs; U.S.-Born Killer Is Freed by Israel
abstract: US frees Alan Goodman, American-born Israeli who was sentenced to life in prison 15 years ago for killing Palestinian mosque guard during shooting in Temple Mount in Jerusalem (S)

headline: Serbia Election Again Seems Inconclusive
abstract: Serbia's third attempt in three months to elect new President appears to be headed for new round of voting as results of current election are inconclusive; Milan Milutinovic, candidate from governing Socialist party, initial projections give Milan Milutinovic, candidate from governing Sociality party, with 42 percent of vote, 10 percent ahead of chief rival but short of majority needed to assume office; photo (S)

headline: B. F. GOODRICH TO ADD TRIARC'S C. H. PATRICK BUSINESS
abstract: Triarc Companies agrees to sell its C H Patrick & Co dyes and chemicals unit to B F Goodrich Co for $72 million (S)

headline: Stocks Rebound, With Dow Rising 74.41
abstract: Strong earnings reports from some major companies lift stocks out of slump; Dow Jones industrial average gains 74.41 points, closing at 7,921.44, and Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gains more than 1 percent, or 11.45 points, to 955.61 (M)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Credit on Oct 12 with picture of John Osher, founder of Cap Toys Inc, cited in article about disagreements with family-run companies, misspelled given name of photographer; she is Courtney Kealy, not Cortney (S)

headline: U.S. and China Reach Trade Pacts but Clash on Rights
abstract: Pres Clinton and Chinese Pres Jiang Zemin, in unexpectedly contentious talks, Washington, produce several key commercial accords but appear to broaden gulf on human rights; China agrees to buy $3 billion worth of American civilian airplanes; clears way for Americans to compete to sell nuclear reactors to China by agreeing to end its nuclear cooperation program with Iran, which United States suspects is cover for development of nuclear arms; accords come after Jiang tries but fails to win American trade concessions; Jiang defends China's preference for order over personal freedom, news conference with Clinton; stresses mutual economic benefits of ties; Clinton insists China cannot expect to prosper while suppressing freedom; photos (L)

headline: People
abstract: * Charlie Rutman was named to the new position of executive vice president and director for client and media services at Carat MBS, New York, a unit of Aegis Group P.L.C. He had been senior vice president and media director at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, New York, owned by MacManus Group, overseeing the media planning account of the Coca-Cola Co.    * Norm Waterman, associate publisher at Vogue magazine, New York, part of the Conde Nast Publications unit of Advance Publications, will retire, effective Dec. 31. His duties will be divided between two Vogue executives who will serve as associate publishers: Erica Bartman, who has been advertising director, and Ed Menicheschi, who has been associate publisher for Europe.

headline: Taco Bell and Others Award Accounts
abstract: Taco Bell Corp names Foote, Cone & Belding and TN Media to handle portions of its account, with billings estimated at $200 million; Aiwa America Inc selects Gigante Vaz Partners to handle its account; billings estimated at $10 million; American unit of Club Mediterranee SA names Lowe & Partners/SMS to handle its account, with billings of $8 million; Boston Globe consolidates its account at Holland Mark Martin Edmund, with billings of $5 million to $6 million (S)

headline: REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES IN DEALS FOR 5 AUTO DEALERSHIPS
abstract: Republic Industries to buy five auto dealer franchises for $30 million in stock, adding to its holdings in Florida and Georgia (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.50   5.52   5.28        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.02   5.02   4.78        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.11   5.14   4.97        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.55   3.54   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   5.72   5.79   6.30        30-YR. TREAS.
