headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLERSBERG, ZINA
abstract: ADLERSBERG-Zina, died peacefully on October 21, 1997. Singer and voice teacher, known professionally as Zinaida Alvers. Beloved wife of the late Dr. David Adlersberg. Loving mother of Margaret and Mark Berger. Devoted grandmother of Josh and David Berger (Tracey Altman). Dear great grandmother of Tashi. Service on Friday, 1:15 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to your favorite charity.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  BLISS, PHILIP
abstract: BLISS-Philip. Age 82. Formerly of Brooklyn, died on October 21, 1997, in Los Angeles. Beloved husband of Rose. Loving father of Elaine and David Levy, Susan and Richard Levine and the late David. Devoted grandfather of Lori, Dana, Wendy, Jonas and Robin. Great grandfather of six. Brother of Sylvia Cohen, Mac and Jules Bliss. Private services were held October 22 at Hillside Cemetery in Los Angeles.

headline: ABC Analyst To Join CNN
abstract: Jeff Greenfield, who has been ABC News's best-known political analyst for 14 years, is leaving ABC in January to join Cable News Network (S)

headline: Clinton Says He'll Win New Powers For Trade
abstract: Pres Clinton leaves Venezuela for Brazil on second leg of South American trip; praises Venezuela for efforts to open economy and to permit private investments in nationalized industries; arrives in Brazil, where he predicts he will ultimately win enhanced authority from Congress to negotiate trade deals in Latin America and worldwide; extends hand of friendship and partnership to Brazil, with which he says US shares vision of better tomorrow; photo (M)

headline: I.B.M. Offering Voluntary Buyouts to Some
abstract: International Business Machines Corp says it offers many employees voluntary buyout; will load cost of plan into normal operating expenses; seeks to shift employment to growth areas (S)

headline: Pilot Hiring Plan Reported
abstract: American Airlines Inc. will hire its first new pilots in five years to fly new airplanes that will begin arriving next year, The Dallas Morning News reported today. Airline officials did not disclose the number of pilots to be hired, but indicated it could be as many as 2,000. American, a unit of the AMR Corporation, already employs 9,000 pilots. Most big carriers have now resumed hiring after a period of restraint.

headline: On the Way Out the Door, Some Last Words on Finance
abstract: Taking stock is common at this time of year, but these five people, each from a different sphere of personal finance, have more reason than most to do so: They are leaving their jobs. Here, in interviews with Sharon R. King, are their parting shots on the achievements, failures and futures of their respective fields, as well as some practical advice for 1998.    MARGARET M. RICHARDSON left her post as Commissioner of the Internal Revenue Service in May. She is now a partner at Ernst & Young.      Whenever major tax-law changes are enacted, the effect on investments is of interest. But there is little evidence that the 1997 changes have had a significant impact. The reduction of the capital-gains tax rate may have persuaded some investors to sell low-basis assets and reinvest in more attractive investments, but such proceeds do not seem to have moved out of the financial markets.

headline: Ulster Ex-Militants Press New Cause: Nonviolence
abstract: Over 500 militants jailed for murders, bombings and other terrorist acts have come out of prison in Northern Ireland, trained to lead nonviolent efforts to end political strife; play key role in peace effort; former prisoners, Catholics and Protestants, find common jail experience has enabled them to open tentative channels of communication; map; photos (L)d

headline: On Visit to Congo, Albright Praises the New Leader
abstract: Sec of State Madeleine K Albright praises Pres Laurent Kabila on a visit to Congo and pledges to increase American aid; alludes repeatedly to need for democracy and rule of law in Congo, but her message seems intended to play down concerns over political repression, violence and official corruption; major battle is reported in Bukavu between Kabila's army and a coalition of Rwandan Hutu and indigenous armed opponents of the Government; photos (M)

headline: Bond Prices Fall Slightly In Quiet Day
abstract: US Treasury prices fall; price of 30-year bond drops 21/32, to 102 7/32; yield rises to 5.96 percent from 5.92 percent on Dec 29; graph (L)

headline: Welcome Aboard!
abstract: Readers are invited to submit anecdotes about contents of package of data and goods given them when they joined company; drawing

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Dow Surges 123.56 Points In Year-End Buying Spree  The Dow Jones industrial average goes into the last trading session of the year with a gain of 22.3 percent. If the gain holds today, it will be the first time that the Dow has gained 20 percent or more in three consecutive years.

headline: Yeltsin Enters A Sanitarium, The Victim Of a Virus
abstract: Russian officials say Pres Boris Yeltsin has respiratory infection and will remain at sanitarium outside Moscow for 10-12 days (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: Advertising accounts column; GTE Communications account goes to Robinson & Maites, to handle its consolidated consumer direct marketing account (S)

headline: Surprise Offer Swells Trading on Nasdaq
abstract: Nasdaq stock market says record number of shares traded on exchange in wake of Worldcom Inc's $30 billion offer to buy MCI Communications, with closing volume of 970.6 million shares exceeding previous high of 877.3 million set July 16, 1996 (S)

headline: Satellite TV Provider Waits for World to Catch Up
abstract: United States Satellite Broadcasting Co, founded in 1981, is still trying to turn profit from business of beaming pay-television programming to pizza-pan-size satellite antennas on roofs and windowsills of consumer America; USSB is programmer for leading direct-to-home satellite television service, DirecTV, and it distributes pay-television and advertiser-supported services of Time Warner Inc and Viacom Inc, including some of most popular channels on cable and satellite television; failure to become profitable is due in part to what critics consider unwieldy marketing arrangement with DirecTV; photo (M)

headline: Police Hunt For a Fiat Tied to Diana
abstract: French police begin questioning owners of 40,000 French-registered Fiat Unos in search for car that may have been lightly sideswiped by car carrying Diana, Princess of Wales, just before fatal Aug 31 tunnel crash (S)

headline: VIVUS STOCK TUMBLES AFTER 4TH-QUARTER FORECAST
abstract: Stock of Vivus Inc tumbles more than 31 percent after company says it will not meet its production goals for fourth quarter; stock falls $6.3125, to close at $13.8125 (S)

headline: The Internet in the courtroom results in more clamor than consensus.
abstract: Technology column examines way that the Internet seemed like an extension of the courtroom during recent trial of Louise Woodward, British nanny convicted of killing infant in her care; says Internet provided controversy and disagreement, resulting in more clamor than consensus; drawing (M)

headline: Women Gain At The Top, But Slightly
abstract: Percentage of female corporate officers at Fortune 500 companies rose slightly last year to 10.6 percent from 10 percent previous year, according to survey by Catalyst, nonprofit women's research group; survey found that some companies added women to their executive ranks, while others subtracted women, and that 24 percent of Fortune 500 companies have no female corporate officers, up from 21 percent in 1996 survey (M)

headline: Japan Stocks Soar on Possibility of Bank Bailout
abstract: Stocks surge in Tokyo in early trading Nov 20 on renewed optimism that Government will use public funds to bolster troubled banking system; at midday recess, Nikkei index is up 545.45 points, or 3.44 percent, at 16.387.91; in Seoul, stocks are lower as South Korean currency, the won, falls its daily trading limit, under new, widened band; at midday, stock market's main index is down 16.29 points, or 3.2 percent, at 486.30 (S)

headline: Mistrial Declared in Dispute Over Billionaire's Empire
abstract: Judge Nikki DeShazo dismisses deadlocked jurors and declares mistrial in bitter battle between Harold C Simmons, Dallas billionaire, and two daughters for control of his business empire; judge sets Mar 3 for retrial but orders two sides to try to negotiate settlement; lawyers involved say any settlement agreement appears doubtful; estranged daughters, Andrea Swanson and Scheryle S Patigian, contend their 66-year-old father abused his power in controlling two trusts that hold most of fortune he amassed as corporate raider; two women, and two other sisters, are named beneficiaries; estranged daughters say he used trust funds to make donations to conservative Republican political candidates they loathed, to buy jewelry for his third wife, and to buy luxury homes for his use; Simmons claims he stayed within broad powers allowed him; blames suit on greedy sons-in-law (M)

headline: Quantum Closes a Plant and Cuts 430 Jobs
abstract: Quantum Corp has halted production at its Louisville, Colo, plant, eliminating 430 jobs (S)

headline: Winnie Mandela Killed Youth, Apartheid Inquiry Is Told
abstract: Former member of Winnie Madikizela-Mandela's entourage testifies that in 1989 he saw her stab and kill a young activist she had accused of being police informer and who was later found dead; Katiza Cebekhulu, in most gripping testimony so far before commission investigating Pres Nelson Mandela's former wife and her notorious bodyguards, repeats charges he made in recently published book regarding death of 14-year-old activist, Stompie Seipei; his testimony reviewed; photo of Madikizela-Mandela with Archbishop Desmond M Tutu (M)

headline: 2 Japanese Racketeers Face Extortion Charges
abstract: Tokyo District Court indicts two corporate racketeers on separate charges of threatening to disrupt shareholders meetings at Toshiba Corp and Mitsubishi Motors Corp; Takeyoshi Kikuchi is accused of extorting 6 million yen, or $46,000, in payoffs from Toshiba in return for insuring that company's June 1995 general shareholders meeting would be disrupted; Wasaburo Shimizu is accused of extorting 1.5 million yen, or $11,500 in payoffs from Mitsubishi from July 1995 through September 1997 (S)

headline: FIGGIE REVISES ITS AGREEMENT TO SELL SNORKEL
abstract: Figgie International Inc revises its agreement to sell its Snorkel aerial platform unit to Omniquip International Inc in way that might lower original $150 million price by as much as a third, although Figgie says it now values transaction at $120 million (S)

headline: KOREANS PRESSING U.S. AND JAPANESE FOR SPEEDIER AID
abstract: South Korea, with investor confidence again starting to erode despite international rescue of its economy, calls on US and Japan to provide some money that they had pledged only as last resort; Clinton Administration rejects South Korea's request; Japanese Finance Ministry says its funds will only be available as backup; Korean request reflects growing signs that International Monetary Fund bailout has not restored confidence in South Korea's shaky financial system; graph; photo (M)

headline: A Kinder, Gentler Tamerlane Inspires Uzbekistan
abstract: Young rulers of Uzbekistan settle on Tamerlane as their national hero and contend that he was not the bloodthirsty tyrant outsiders says he was; maps (M)

headline: CORRECTION: Carbon Dioxide Emissions
abstract: Correction of Dec 4 chart with article on Europe's efforts to reduce emissions of heat-trapping gases

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Asia Lull Helps Markets, But Wall Street Is Still Wary   Calmer markets in Asia yesterday provided some solace to investors in the United States. Although the Dow Jones industrial average retreated for a 14.17-point loss, most stock indexes finished with small gains.

headline: British Petroleum Buys Polystyrol Unit
abstract: Huels AG, chemical unit of German utility Veba AG, says it has sold its polystyrol business to German unit of British Petroleum Co PLC (S)

headline: German Bid Reported For Hambros of Britain
abstract: Westdeutsche Landesbank Girozentrale has reportedly made offer for Hambros PLC (S)

headline: Economic Scene; A new look at why the U.S. outdoes Europe in job creation.
abstract: Peter Passell Economic Scene column discusses new theory about why United States outdoes Europe in job creation, in article by Alan Krueger and Jorn-Steffen Pischke; says most popular explanation is America's competitive low-end wages, but Krueger and Pischke say it has as much to do with vitality of small and medium-size business in US as it does with low wages; note that virtually all employment growth in recent decades in US has come from small and medium-size service businesses, and that American entrepreneurs face lower hurdles than those in Europe (M)

headline: Two Deals by Staffmark
abstract: Staffmark Inc agrees to acquire RHS Associates Inc and Emjay Companies; terms not disclosed (S)

headline: ALLIED SIGNAL'S PRESTONE ADDS OVERSEAS OPERATIONS
abstract: Allied Signal Inc's Prestone Products unit buys British car-care company Holt Lloyd Group Ltd for $155 million (S)

headline: AMERICAN BUILDINGS IS ADDING UNITED DOMINION UNIT
abstract: American Buildings Co agrees to buy United Dominion Industries' Windsor Door division for $60 million in cash (S)

headline: The Street.com Picks D'Arcy Masius
abstract: Street.com LLC names D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles to handle its general market advertising account, which has been at Ryan Drossman & Partners for last year (S)

headline: Index Shows Activity Cools For Factories
abstract: National Assn of Purchasing Management's factory index, closely watched gauge of manufacturing, cooled in November, reflecting slowdowns in new orders and production that suggested that factory activity peaked earlier in year; gauge declined to 54.5 last month from 56 in October; chart (S)

headline: Coal Nightmares, Electrical Dreams
abstract: Role of coal-powered electric generating plants in global warming dispute discussed; electric industry argues that plants actually reduce carbon dioxide emissions by displacing far greater amounts of other fuels; photos (M)

headline: J. C. Cabrera, 62, Search Firm Executive
abstract: James C Cabrera, executive search firm aide, dies at age 62 (S)

headline: Iraqi Assails U.S. at the U.N. And Says Albright Is a Liar
abstract: Iraq's Deputy Prime Min, Tariq Aziz, sharply criticizes US as he presses his country's case at UN; calls Sec of State Madeleine Albright liar; presents Sec Gen Kofi Annan with new list of demands, including taking part in any further Security Council debate on Iraq and substituting 'neutral' aircraft for American U-2's; says there are too many Americans on arms-inspection teams and that U-2 surveillance planes used by disarmament commission in Iraq are working for Washington, not UN; Security Council passage of new draft resolution tightening sanctions seem likely in light of Iraq's intransigence, which has aroused widespread outrage among diplomats; US Amb Bill Richardson comments; Baghdad fails to make good on threat to shoot down U-2 surveillance aircraft as flights resume; Government moves families with babies and small children into lavish palaces owned by Pres Saddam Hussein to act as human shields in event of US military strikes; photo (M)

headline: Fed Policy On Rates Seems Tough After All
abstract: Absence of inflation is making Federal Reserve's short-term interest-rate policy more restrictive than it may appear; real Federal funds rate, adjusted for inflation, is 3.28 percent, up from 2.22 percent in Feb; graph (M)p

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Clinton Expects Asia To Overcome Crisis   President Clinton used a gathering of Asian leaders in Vancouver, British Columbia, to offer reassurance that the current financial turmoil in Asia is temporary and said the United States would exert its influence to promote sound economic policies in the region and pry open global markets in a range of goods and services. Mr. Clinton said the economic future of Asia remained promising.

headline: A Full-Court Press Against Business
abstract: Letter from Merrie Spaeth comments on Nov 9 article on transporting lawsuits across state lines, which failed to discuss trend in which companies are targets of similar lawsuits in many different states (S)

headline: Bozell and Valvoline Split After 13 Years
abstract: Bozell Worldwide and Valvoline Co are parting ways after 13 years on Valvoline account, with billings estimated at $20 million to $25 million; Valvoline has placed the account in review (S)

headline: GTECH TO FORGO A NEW BID FOR TEXAS LOTTERY CONTRACT
abstract: Gtech Holdings Corp says it will not rebid its Texas Lottery contract, its single biggest, and might have to write off investments and costs associated with contract (S)

headline: Bristol-Myers Picks Kaplan Thaler Group
abstract: Bristol-Myers Squibb Co expands its relationship with Kaplan Thaler Group, naming it to introduce major product line for its Clairol division, Daily Defense shampoos and conditioners, with estimated $40 million budget for marketing (S)

headline: AXA Unit Sells Stake In New Ireland Holdings
abstract: AXA-UAP SA of France says its Sun Life and Provincial Holdings unit will sell its 83 percent of New Ireland Holdings to Bank of Ireland for about $311 million (S)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  O'BYRNE, MARGARET M.
abstract: O'BYRNE-Margaret M., of West Long Branch, NJ, Oct. 22, 1997. Wife of the late John P. O'Byrne. Mother of Reverend Charles J. O'Byrne, Dr. Margaret G. O'Byrne, Deidre O'Byrne, and Patricia O'Byrne. Sister of Elizabeth T. Koch and Mary Ann Fortunato. Grandmother of Melina & Mariah Mastrodimos. Visitation Friday 2-4 and 7-9PM, at the John E. Day Funeral Home, 85 Riverside Ave., Red Bank, New Jersey. Funeral mass Sat., 9:30AM, at St. Michael's R.C. Church, West End, N.J. Interment to follow in Mount Olivet Cemetery, Middletown, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to St. Vincent de Paul Society, c/o St. Michael's RC Church, 960 Ocean Ave., West End, NJ 07740.

headline: Business and Politics Merge To Mourn Coke's Chairman
abstract: Funeral is held for Roberto C Goizueta, Coca-Cola Co chairman and chief executive, who died at age 65; photo (S)

headline: Judge Blocks Bid For True North
abstract: Chancery Court Judge William Chandler temporarily blocks Publicis SA's $269.4 million hostile bid for True North Communications; rules that Publicis, which already owns 18.4 percent of True North, cannot proceed with its offer to acquire enough additional shares to gain control until he conducts hearing on Dec 22 (S)

headline: Siemens Says Profit Rose 4.8% for Full Year
abstract: Siemens AG says its full-year profit rose 4.8 percent, to 2.61 billion marks ($1.5 billion) from year ago; sales rose 11.8 percent, to 107 billion marks (S)

headline: Pakistani President Quits in Feud With Prime Minister
abstract: The President of Pakistan resigned this evening, saying that he had continually lost fights with the Prime Minister to preserve the rule of law, and that the Prime Minister was responsible for the political crisis because of his attacks on the judiciary.    The resignation of the President, Farooq Ahmed Leghari, ends the monthlong crisis with a clear political victory for the Prime Minister, Nawaz Sharif, who has emerged as one of the most powerful leaders in Pakistan's 50 years of independence.

headline: Gore to Join U.S. Team at Global Climate Conference in Japan
abstract: Pres Clinton, concerned that global climate-change conference in Kyoto, Japan, will adopt more stringent pollution targets than US is willing to accept, says he will send Vice Pres Gore to meeting to argue US position forcefully (M)

headline: People
abstract: * Steve Keenan was named to the new position of vice president for marketing and operations at America Online Inc., Dulles, Va. He had been a marketing and advertising consultant in Ridgefield, Conn.

headline: A Price Tag Of Billions In Nazi Gold
abstract: Study conducted for World Jewish Congress concludes that Nazi Germany looted at least $8.5 billion in gold between 1933 and 1945, and estimates that nearly one-third of money came from individuals and private businesses rather than from central banks; estimates that more than $2 billion of privately-owned gold ended up in Swiss banks; congress director Elan Steinberg questions ethics of Switzerland holding onto money, whatever the legality (S)

headline: Coffee Plunges as Big Brazil Harvest Is Seen
abstract: Coffee prices plunge on New York Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange after influential coffee trader, Charles Cronly, says Brazil, world's top coffee grower, will produce its biggest crop in 11 years in 1998; coffee for March delivery falls 6.4 cents, to $1.5865 a pound (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Humbled By Debt Crisis, Seoul Seeks I.M.F. Aid   South Korea formally requested an emergency $20 billion aid package from the International Monetary Fund to help avert economic paralysis caused by rising debts and a loss of investor confidence. But the total amount of I.M.F. aid could surpass $60 billion, many economists say, which would make it the largest bailout by the lending agency ever.

headline: Talking ads may be coming soon to a gas pump or automated teller machine near you.
abstract: Full-motion, talking ads are invading neighborhood gas pumps and cash machines; Rio Network Inc has installed screens and speakers in gas pumps at 600 convenience stores nationwide; Electronic Data Systems Corp has begun testing 15-second spots on 165 automated teller machines in San Diego area (L)

headline: Nasdaq Reports 2.1% Rise In Uncovered Short Sales
abstract: Open positions of short sales on Nasdaq market rose 2.1 percent, to record 1.79 billion shares as of mid-December; figures reflect trades reported through Dec 10 and settled as of Dec 15; tables (M)

headline: Defying NATO, Hard-Line Serbs Resume Broadcasting in Bosnia
abstract: Hard-line Bosnian Serbs return to airwaves, managing to circumvent NATO troops who had seized their transmitters; international officials have declared their broadcasts danger to peace (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: FEDERATED DEPARTMENT STORES INC., Cincinnati, said its Rich's/Lazarus/Goldsmith unit planned to close five stores in Pennsylvania and Ohio and cut 385 jobs.    MOTOROLA INC., Schaumberg, Ill., said its Cellular Infrastructure Group had won a contract to provide $260 million of equipment to Pele-Phone Communications Ltd., Israel's cellular network operator.

headline: Updates/Media and Technology; Software to Track Business Prospects By Web Visits
abstract: Matchlogic Inc plans to introduce software it says will allow accurate counts of how many people see World Wide Web page advertising, even when page is copied and displayed by Internet service providers; General Motors Corp and Audit Bureau of Circulations back software (S)

headline: South Korean Chaos Could Eventually Mean Opportunity
abstract: Outlook for investing in South Korean stocks discussed in light of nation's economic crisis; political and financial situation seen remaining uncertain for some time (M)

headline: Patents; A system that effortlessly switches telephone calls between cellular and land-line networks.
abstract: Bell Atlantic Network wins patent for personal communication system that switches calls between land lines and cellular networks; four inventors receive patent for system that buys calling time in advance from phone company and then divides time into blocks according to their monetary value; inventors are Eugene Woynoski, Carol Caldwell, Wayne Beder and George Jenson; James Wicks receives patent for Sony Corp for wall-mounted computer system, and David Register receives patent for two-screen display system for Dell USA; IBM wins patent for way to double usefulness of each key on computer keyboard, depending on how hard key is struck; Denise Wright patents heated mouse pad to combat repetitive stress injuries; Patent and Trademark Office increased some fees by 2.6 percent as of Oct 1, 1997 (S)

headline: France Amasses Bitter Evidence Five Decades After the Holocaust
abstract: Maurice Papon, now 87, will go on trial in Bordeaux, France, on charges of complicity in Nazi crimes against humanity by ordering deportation to death camps of 1,560 Jews; subject of French civil servants and functionaries who did Nazis' bidding has been long taboo in France; Papon will be highest-ranking French official during German occupation to go on trial on charges of complicity in crimes against humanity, and only second French citizen to be tried on those grounds since World War II; Papon claims he did not have direct authority over police, but lawyers, victims' relatives and prosecutors have amassed 50,000 pieces of evidence, including arrest reports to Papon's superiors; victims and victims' relatives will testify at trial; photos (L)

headline: CONCORD SHARES RISE 47.3% IN INITIAL PUBLIC OFFERING
abstract: Shares of Concord Communications Inc rise 47.3 percent above its initial public offering price of $14 a share; shares close at $20.625 (S)

headline: Smell Something? Yes, The Scent of a Dollar; Costly Factors Drive the Perfume War
abstract: Perfume industry, historically competitive, has become even more cutthroat in recent years; consumers clamor for fresh scents, then quickly discard them for newest fad; in $2.28 billion perfume market, prestige segment is most popular, but retail is growing faster; what distinguishes a perfume that lasts for generations, like Chanel No. 5, from one that fades with its era--such as Windsong in 70's--is complicated and often intangible alchemy of science, advertising and market research; descriptions of different segments of perfume industry: prestige, relaunch, classic, mass market and retail; chart; table shows top selling brands of perfume and manufacturer; photos (L)

headline: Hitachi Lowers Pretax Earnings Forecast
abstract: Hitachi Ltd lowers its full-year pretax earnings forecast 36 percent (S)

headline: G.E. Raises Dividend and Buys Back Stock
abstract: General Electric Co increases its stock buyback program by $4 billion, to $17 billion, and raises its dividend 15 percent; company also adopts program to let owners of GE shares buy stock directly and avoid brokerage fees (M)

headline: Hong Kong Stocks Fall Steeply, New Victim of Region's Ills
abstract: Hong Kong stocks fall nearly 30 percent in month as financial forces wreak havoc across Southeast Asia; benchmark Hang Seng stock index plunges after Hong Kong Monetary Authority raises overnight lending rate to 20 percent from 10.5 percent in effort to defend Hong Kong dollar against waves of selling by currency speculators; move by Hong Kong Monetary Authority prompts Hong Kong's three biggest banks to raise their prime lending rates to 9.50 percent from 8.75 percent; analysts attribute slide in Hong Kong to fears of attack on Hong Kong dollar, and rush of money managers out of Asian investments in general and Hong Kong's in particular; analysts say they do not expect crisis in Southeast Asia to abate in near future, given unwillingness of some political leaders to deal with region's underlying problems; photo; graph (M)

headline: CLINTON ADAMANT ON 3D WORLD ROLE IN CLIMATE ACCORD
abstract: Clinton Administration says that it will not submit proposed treaty to reduce emissions of climate-altering gases for Senate ratification until developing nations agree to participate in global environmental effort; developing countries at global climate-change conference just ended in Kyoto, Japan, say they will not act until they see rich countries succeed in cutting their own emissions; Pres Clinton defends agreement as 'environmentally strong and economically sound'; Administration officials admit that its flaws make it unacceptable to Senate; photo (M)

headline: Seoul's Mighty, Once Immune, Now Feel the Arm of the Law
abstract: Kim Hyun Chul, youngerc son of South Korean Pres Kim Young Sam, receives three-year prison sentence for bribery and tax evasion; conviction is seen as stunning demonstration of how Korean democracy has come to apply rule of law, even to nation's most powerful family (S)

headline: DIARY
abstract: MERGERS  Another Suitor for MCI  Joining America's richest corporate takeover battle ever, the once-stodgy GTE, the nation's third-largest local telephone company, made an unsolicited $28 billion offer for MCI Communications. That's $2 billion less and two weeks later than a bid in stock from upstart Worldcom. The original suitor, British Telecommunications, with three board seats and 20 percent of MCI's shares, may now emerge as kingmaker.... An Italian insurer, Generali, made a hostile $9 billion bid for AGF of France, and the Zurich Group agreed to take over B.A.T. Industries' insurance business, creating one of the world's biggest financial services companies....Is accounting's Big Six (only a few years ago it was Big Eight) about to become Big Four? Ernst & Young and KPMG Peat Marwick are expected to announce a merger, although neither would confirm it on Friday. Coopers & Lybrand and Price Waterhouse have already agreed to merge.    MARKETS  Earnings or Expectations?  It has become a mantra on Wall Street: the market is earnings-driven. Actually, it's greed-driven. Or, to put the matter more sophistically, is the existential question reality (earnings) or illusion (expectations thereof)? Compaq Computer reported a 41.6 percent profit increase on Thursday, topping the consensus forecast by 3 cents a share, but the market slashed 6 percent from its share price. The Street wanted more. Ford reached a 52-week high of $50.25 on Monday, beat forecasts with a 64 percent profit gain on Wednesday and saw its share price nibbled; G.M.also had solid earnings but slipped in price. Merck had a 19 percent increase but was a penny below estimates. Traders pushed its shares down 4.5 percent, and it helped grease the skids under the Dow, which finished the week at 7,847.03, off 198.17. Intel reported earnings of 88 cents a share, 3 cents below forecasts, and its shares, too, were pounded, despite news of an ultrafast microprocessor chip that it is developing with Hewlett-Packard. The Nasdaq composite lost 77.18 TK for the week, closing at 1,666.85. But the houses behind all this trading did well. Big profit gains were reported by Merrill Lynch, J. P. Morgan, Travelers, Bear Stearns and other Wall Street firms.    GOLDMAN, SACHS  Teachers for a Day  To be fair, some on Wall Street are taking time off from doing well to do good. Some 2,000 employees of Goldman, Sachs & Company, from secretaries through investment bankers, are serving as teachers for a day in New York City public schools. Besides giving lessons on basic business concepts, they hope to demonstrate to students that successful business people are not that different from them. Andy Derrow, above, skips rope in Inwood. ''In a lot of these neighborhoods the most successful business person is the local drug dealer,'' said Peter Mertens, executive vice president of Junior Achievement of New York, which coordinates the volunteers.    NOBEL LAUREATES  A $1 Million Formula  Since the Bank of Sweden began awarding the Nobel Memorial Prize in Economic Science in 1969, Americans have dominated the list of winners the way the Yankees once dominated the American League. This year Robert C. Merton, right, of the Harvard Business School and Myron S. Scholes, left, a Canadian-born professor emeritus at the Stanford Business School, will share the $1 million award for helping to devise a mathematical formula published in 1973 to answer a simple but seemingly insurmountable problem confronting Wall Street: how to measure the worth of an option? Their solution served as a foundation for today's vast global marketplace.    AUTOS  A Clean, Lean Machine  Toyota beat its rivals -- not only Nissan and Honda, but also Detroit's Big Three and Volkswagen -- in unveiling the world's first gasoline-electric hybrid car. Hiroshi Okuda, Toyota's president, climbs into the car, the Prius, which the company said got as much as 66 miles a gallon during test drives while emitting only half the carbon dioxide of a regular gasoline engine. It will sell for $17,700 in Japan -- a loss leader, since analysts estimate it costs $41,000 to produce each one. Consider the difference an advertising expenditure, they said, as Toyota cloaks itself in the mantle of environmental leader. It may be sold in the United States in about six months, Toyata said.    NEW ORLEANS  The House Goes Bust  New Orleans, whose unofficial motto is ''let the good times roll,'' has rolled snake eyes. Casino gambling, legalized by the Louisiana Legislature in the early 1990's, was to sweeten the city's allure to tourists and challenge Las Vegas and Atlantic City for a piece of the action. But over the last three years, all three downtown riverboat casinos, including the Flamingo, above, have foundered on economic, regulatory and legal difficulties. The city's only land-based casino has folded, too. Analysts cited high taxes on the take -- 18.5 percent, compared with an average of 7 percent elsewhere -- as a chief problem. Hillary Crain, chairman of the State Gaming Control Board, called for ''some creative financing.''    THE ECONOMY  The Taming of Inflation  Retail sales rose three-tenths of 1 percent in September and were revised upward for July and August. That pushed down bond prices on Wednesday, but analysts contended that the gain masked an economy that was actually decelerating. Indeed, the Consumer Price Index for September edged up a less-than-expected two-tenths of 1 percent. Because of inflation's slowdown, Americans who receive Social Security and other Federal benefits will receive an increase of only 2.1 percent in January, the second-smallest since automatic cost-of-living adjustments began in 1975.

headline: FROM THE DESK OF; You've Found Your Dream. Stop Yawning.
abstract: Article by Linda Carroll Martin on being bored with one's job; says current and ridiculous notion that we need only do what we love to find personal fulfillment and unlimited wealth is largely to blame for this malaise; holds with few exceptions, financial success come by doing what you dislike; drawing (L)

headline: First American Sets $2.4 Billion Bank Acquisition
abstract: First American Corp agrees to pay $2.44 billion in stock to acquire Deposit Guaranty Corp (M)

headline: Stocks Mixed As Volatility Seems to Ease
abstract: Wall Street calms down a bit day after one of biggest stock market rallies in history, ending with mixed results despite continued heavy trading volume; Dow Jones industrial average gains 8.35 points to close at 7,506.67, and Standard & Poor's 500-stock index falls 2.69 points, to 919.16; Russell 2000 index of smaller company issues has solid gains; volume on New York Stock Exchange is more than 777 million shares traded, second-busiest day in history; in Far East, markets resume their slide; in Tokyo, Nikkei index of 225 issues is down 452.44 points at 16,404.60, and Hong Kong's main stock index is down 6.7 percent at midday break; gains recorded around world on Oct 29 give some investors hope that economic crisis gripping much of Southeast Asia will not topple bull markets in other, more prosperous, regions; graphs (M)

headline: Stocks Tumble As Earnings Disappoint
abstract: Stock market suffers its worst drop in more than a month, hurt by handful of disappointing corporate earnings reports that drag down wide range of blue-chip and technology issues; Dow Jones industrial average falls 119.90 points, or 1.48 percent, to 7,938.88; Nasdaq composite index loses 23.71 points, or 1.38 percent, to 1,699.66; Standard & Poor's 500 slips 10.47 points, or 1.08 percent, to 955.25; Russell 2000 index falls 5.58 points, or 1.21 percent, to 457.16; table (L)

headline: China Loses, China Wins
abstract: News Analysis: China, by releasing leading dissident Wei Jingsheng and sending him into exile in US, made major concession to international pressure while ridding itself of its most potent political martyr (M)

headline: N.A.S.D. Wants Central Market for Orders
abstract: National Association of Securities Dealers proposes creating central market for customer orders in attempt to generate more competition on Nasdaq market; plans has been criticized by brokerage firm trade groups, which fear it will narrow dealers' profits and reduce trading volume (S)/

headline: Tibor Fabian, 74, Institute Founder
abstract: Tibor Fabian, founder of Mathematica Inc, leading economics and public policy research institute in Princeton, NJ, dies at 74 (S)

headline: Dollar Falls Against the Yen But Rises Versus the Mark
abstract: US dollar falls against yen on renewed expectations that Japan will bail out its ailing banks, but rises against mark on speculation that German interest rates will not head higher soon (M)

headline: Thailand Warns Currency Speculators
abstract: Bank of Thailand says it will take action against companies that it believes are speculating in dollars (S)

headline: Andrew Young Reportedly Picked by U.S. for Congo Mission
abstract: Clinton Administration plans to send special envoy to Congo to discuss stalled international investigation into allegations that Rwandan refugees were massacred in eastern part of country over last year; officials say leading candidate is Andrew Young, former US representative at United Nations (M)

headline: Gains Harder For Blue Chips In 3d Quarter
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average set yet another closing high in third quarter, just ended, but some of its component shares faltered; several large multinationals, including Eastman Kodak, Procter & Gamble and Coca-Cola, ended quarter lower than when it started; Dow ended quarter up 3.55 percent, slightly below its 4.02 percent increase in comparable quarter year ago, and full percentage point below its move in first quarter of this year; blue chips' performance is nowhere near as robust as their performance in second quarter, when Dow soared 16.5 percent; analysts find hopeful signs for near-term stock outlook in strong performance of other market sectors, especially stocks of small companies (M)

headline: Arafat Is Making an Offer That Netanyahu Can Refuse
abstract: Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat announces that he will present his own 'comprehensive plan' to save the peace with Israel when he meets with Pres Clinton next month, including a proposal to station international peacekeeping toops between Israel and the West Bank; photo (M)

headline: Albright in Africa: The Embraceable Regimes?
abstract: News analysis of Sec of State Madeleine K Albright's tour of Africa to promote democracy; seven-nation tour only served to cast doubt on Washington's new African choices since her very choice of countries seemed to undermine any American emphasis on democratic development in continent still struggling with heavy legacy of dictatorship; except for South Africa, power was won by gun in every country she visited; photo (K)

headline: Canadian Senate: Substantial Power but Not Much Attendance
abstract: Canadian Senate, under public pressure because of its generally woeful attendance record, votes to penalize Sen Andrew Thompson, 73, who spends most of his time in Mexico and has shown up for work only 14 times in last seven years; takes away his office and secretary and orders him to be present after Christmas break (M)

headline: Frederick Haas, 85, Ex-Counsel at Liggett
abstract: Frederick P Haas, Liggett Group former general counsel, dies at age 85 (S)1

headline: Executive Agrees to Settle for $300,000
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission announces that Peter R DeGeorge, chairman of DeGeorge Financial Corp, has agreed to pay almost $300,000 to settle Federal complaint that DeGeorge used company money for his own benefit (S)

headline: Big Pay Packages at Top of Bear Stearns
abstract: Bear Stearns Cos pays its top five executives total of $87.8 million for bank's 1997 fiscal year, ranking them among highest-paid Wall Street executives; company had record earnings for year (S)

headline: Editor of Los Angeles Times Quits Amid News Shake-Up
abstract: Los Angeles Times announces resignation of editor Shelby Coffey 3d and names new editorial team that will further dismantle wall that has traditionally separated news and business sides; replacing Coffey will be managing editor Michael Parks; job of managing editor will be split among Leo Wolinsky, Karen Wada, John Lindsay and John Arthur; Jeffrey S Klein, senior vice president for consumer marketing, is named to new position of general manager for news; photo (L)

abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.50   5.42   5.16        3-MO. headline: Anger Behind Them, Krupp And Thyssen Plan Merger
abstract: Germany's two biggest steel companies, Krupp-Hoesch Group and Thyssen AG, announce friendly merger, less than eight months after Krupp aroused nationwide furor by attempting hostile takeover that would have accomplished same end; merger will create industrial conglomerate with $37 billion in annual sales; Krupp group, formally known as Fried Krupp AG Hoesch-Krupp, confronted storm of criticism last March with unwanted bid to buy Thyssen for about $8.6 billion (L)

headline: Samsung Cuts Jobs and Pay As Koreans Brace for Pain
abstract: South Koreans receive taste of painful overhaul of their economy as Samsung Group, nation's second-largest conglomerate, announces that it will sharply reduce investment, shift about 30 percent of its 260,000 employees into new jobs and cut management salaries; announcement is strongest response so far by any South Korean conglomerate to pressure created by enormous debts; several other companies have announce cutbacks as they brace for austerity measures that are expected after South Korean Govt asked last week for at least $20 billion in loans from International Monetary Fund; deep cuts in Govt spending and tighter credit are expcted to be stipulations of IMF aid, slowing growth (M)

headline: Stanford Opotowsky, 73, Editor At New York Post and ABC News
abstract: Stanford L Opotowsky, former managing editor of The New York Post and director of news coverage for ABC News, dies at age 73 (S)

headline: KELLEY OIL TO PURCHASE SCANA UNIT FOR $110 MILLION
abstract: Kelley Oil and Gas Corp to buy Scana Petroleum Resources Inc from Scana Corp for $110 million (S)

headline: Memories Of Dachau Still Hold A Survivor
abstract: Martin Zaidenstadt, 86-yeear-old concentration camp survivor, returns to site of Dachau camp in Germany almost every day, visiting and revisiting scene of horrors; he insists that number of dead was ten times higher than official count of 30,000, and that gas chamber which official guides say was not used was indeed employed to terrifying effect; his obsession is not shared by most other survivors, who cannot talk of ordeal even now; Nazis opened Dachau within weeks of coming to power in 1933; map (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY  None  TUESDAY

headline: Microsoft Seems Near Deal to Invest in U S West Cable TV
abstract: Microsoft Corp is close to agreement to invest up to $1 billion in cable television operations of US West; investment would buy Microsoft as much as 6.3 percent of US West's cable business at current stock price; it would further Microsoft's strategy of turning nation's cable systems into primary providers of high-speed access to Internet--with Microsoft hoping to control television set-top box software that people use to get on line; in June, in similar deal, Microsoft agreed to pay $1 billion for 11.5 percent stake in another big cable company, Comcast Corp (L)

headline: North Italy Votes for 'Parliament' Without a Ghost of a Chance
abstract: Italy's secessionist Northern League stages its own parliamentary elections in Montecchio Maggiore, but few turn out to vote; map (M)

headline: Greenspan Urges More Attention Be Paid to Banks Abroad
abstract: Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, called for increased efforts tonight to shore up banks in developing countries, saying that the current crisis in Asia has shown that global markets will ruthlessly batter weak financial systems.    Mr. Greenspan said institutions like the International Monetary Fund should do more to identify and head off banking problems in developing nations. And he said that governments in those countries should stop shielding banks from the forces of market competition, and in particular should stop directing banks to lend to politically connected borrowers and industries singled out for special treatment.

headline: High Court Weighs 'Gray Market' Legality
abstract: US Supreme Court is weighing legality of 'gray market' items, unauthorized importation of American consumer goods, originally sold at discount overseas, for resale in US; Court will decide degree of protection that copyright law offers to manufacturers seeking to segment and control foreign and domestic markets of such products; decision could determine whether gray market continues to thrive (L)

headline: Treasury Prices End Day Higher; Stock Loss and Asia Crisis Cited
abstract: Treasury prices end slightly higher, lifted in part by late tumble in stock market; also helping bond prices are growing expectations that falling demand from Asia will slow United States economic growth (S)

headline: Banc One to Pay $3 Billion In Stock for First Commerce
abstract: Banc One Corp agrees to buy First Commerce Corp of New Orleans for $3 billion in stock; deal will make Banc One biggest bank in Louisiana in terms of assets and deposits (M)

headline: Britain Reviews Iraqi Request to Free Millions in Frozen Funds
abstract: Britain is considering request by Iraq to release some of $760 million in assets frozen in 1990 so that Baghdad can pay for legal defense against billions of dollars of claims stemming from Persian Gulf war (M)

headline: Hillary Clinton Sees Hope in Ulster, Too
abstract: Hillary Rodham Clinton stayed strictly on track today, traveling to this troubled city to sound the themes she has embraced in her carefully planned re-emergence: women, children and families.     In her first overseas trip after the very public celebration of her 50th birthday last weekend and the speculation it raised about her recast role as First Lady, she began the day by delivering a lecture in memory of Joyce McCartan, whom she met in 1995, when she and the President visited Belfast together. Mrs. McCartan, who lost a son and 17 other relatives to sectarian violence, ran a center that brought Catholic and Protestant women together to promote peace.

headline: Malaysia and Thailand Offer Bargain Hunter's Paradise : A Currency Crisis Fire Sale
abstract: KUALA LUMPURâ€”  Attention shoppers! The Southeast Asian sale of the decade is on! Buy now while supplies last!

headline: Bukhara Journal; In This Islam, Practices (Not Beliefs) Make Perfect
abstract: Article on Uzbekistan's Nakshbandi order, world's largest Muslim order that preaches gentle, all-embracing form of Islam that abhors sectarianism and orthodoxy; map; photo (M)

headline: Review by Levi Strauss To Include Foote, Cone
abstract: San Francisco office of Foote, Cone & Belding announces it will take part in unexpected review of its oldest account, domestic Levi's brand of Levi Strauss & Co, with billings estimated at $87 million; decision comes a day after Levi Strauss stunned agency by placing in review the account, which Foote, Cone and a predecessor have handled since 1930 (S)

headline: S.E.C. Schedules a Meeting As Small-Stock Fraud Soars
abstract: Wall Street's biggest firms are being pressured to prevent some small brokerage operations from defrauding investors who trade in stocks of tiny companies; Arthur Levitt Jr, chairman of Securities and Exchange Commission, has summoned at least six big firms that process trades of thousands of smaller outfits to meet with various regulators; Levitt says one of his highest priorities is minimizing abuses in market for so-called microcap securities; state and Federal regulators report fraud in small stocks is soaring, costing investors billions of dollars (M)

headline: A Pragmatic Agenda For Residential Service
abstract: Worldcom Inc has become powerhouse by sidestepping messy, less profitable business of catering to residential phone customers; Worldcom's president, Bernard J Ebbers, says merger with MCI Communications will benefit American consumers, but analysts see Worldcom's new-found concern for residential customers as pragmatic accommodation to get regulatory approval for its merger; analysts expect businesses to get benefits of merger far before residential customers do (M)

headline: British Trade Deficit Rises as Exports Slide
abstract: Britain's global trade deficit grew to 1.25 billion pounds ($2.08 billion) in September, up from 616 million pounds; pound's 22 percent increase against basket of currencies over last 16 months is making British products more expensive (S)

headline: European Union Court Upholds Affirmative Action for Women
abstract: European Court of Justice upholds principle of giving hiring and promotional preferences to women as valid way of correcting earlier discrimination; decision could affect affirmative action programs across Continent; European Union's high court rules in favor of law passed by German state of North Rhine-Westphalia that gave women preference in public-sector jobs (M)

headline: Staid Leo Burnett intends to buy a stake in the hot, independent shop, Bartle Bogle Hegarty.
abstract: Advertising column discusses most recent merger in series that is remaking Madison Avenue: Leo Burnett Co's announcement that it will buy significant minority stake in Bartle Bogle Hegarty, feisty British agency regarded as one of world's most creative independent shops; Burnett executives seem to be signaling their realization that change is necessary to regain monmentum after loss of several large accounts and to counter widening perception that they have lost their way after decades of success (M)

headline: Sey Chassler, 78, Redbook's Editor in Chief
abstract: Sey Chassler, who expanded the purview of women's magazines beyond printing recipes to promoting equal rights as the editor in chief of Redbook, died on Dec. 11 at the Tisch Hospital at New York University Medical Center. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.    The cause was complications from colon cancer and a stroke, said his wife, Natalie.

headline: Baron Edmond de Rothschild, 71, French Financier, Dies
abstract: Baron Edmond de Rothschild, French-born financier said to be wealthiest of surviving descendants of legendary banking family, dies at age of 71; photo (M)

headline: First Move Made to Mine Mineral Riches of Seabed
abstract: Australian-owned Nautilus Minerals Corp has filed mining claim to rich mineral deposits in Papua New Guinea's Bismarck Sea, first such claim to deep sea minerals; claim foreshadows possible rush to open oceans for metals and possible fight with conservationists; hot volcanic deposits are very different from icy manganese nodules that litter global seabed and first spurred dreams of mining deep; are much richer in precious metals and tend to lie closer to sea's surface; hundreds of expeditions have mapped such deposits, but no one has yet mined rocky outcroppings; company holds deep mining can be profitable and will eventually go global; map; photos (L)

headline: Securities Firm Disavows Report on Indonesia Debt
abstract: Indosuez WI Carr Securities disavows report by Pablo Zuanic, its acting head of research in Jakarta, that estimated Indonesia's foreign debt at $200 billion; report raised ire of Indonesia's Pres Suharto; $200 billion figure is almost double official $118 billion Government estimate (S)

headline: Airbus Industrie Wants to Use Euros
abstract: Airbus Industrie wants to offer airlines option of buying planes in euros, a move that would break tradition of pricing aircraft in dollars (S)

headline: World News Briefs; British Press Authority Imposes Code on Privacy
abstract: Govt commission that oversees behavior of press in Britain publishes new code of conduct seeking to curb invasions of privacy, intrusions into grief, harassment of photo subjects and exploitation of children (S)

headline: EXTENDICARE OF CANADA PLANS TO BUY ARBOR HEALTH CARE
abstract: Extendicare Inc agrees to acquire Arbor Health Care Co for $45 a share, or $325 million; it will also assume $107 million in Arbor debt (S)

headline: Scores Die When Big Russian Jet Hits Apartments
abstract: Huge Russian AN-124 transport crashes into apartment complex in Irkutsk, Siberia, seconds after taking off from nearby airport killing and injuring scores in one of country's worst air disasters; Pres Boris Yeltsin sends Prime Min Viktor Chernomyrdin to crash site to oversee investigation; news reports say two of plane's engines failed immediately after it left runway; maps; photo (M)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  GARZON, JULIO M.
abstract: GARZON-Julio M., 92, newspaper editor and USIA official, died on October 19. Born in Bogota, from 1925 to 1958 Mr. Garzon was Sports Editor & Managing Editor of the Spanish daily ''La Prensa'' of New York. From 1958 to 1971 he was Director of the Latin American Branch of the Press and Publications Service at the United States Information Agency. He was a founder of the InterAmerican Press Association. He retired to Florida in 1971 and was active in inter-American activities. Mr. Garzon was awarded the Maria Moors Cabot Gold Medal of the Columbia University School of Journalism, and was named a life member of the American Society of Newspaper Editors. Mr. Garzon is survived by his wife of sixtythree years, Manuela; two daughters, Maria Garzon of Los Angeles and Laura Wyman of Washington, D.C; three grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. For further information: All Care Cremation and Funeral Service.

headline: Cooke Estate to Sell Los Angeles Paper
abstract: Estate of Jack Kent Cooke has put The Daily News of Los Angeles up for sale (S)

headline: Pope's Unanswered Request: Put Christmas Back in Cuba
abstract: Vatican, with only one month to go before Pope John Paul II visits Cuba, is stepping up pressure on Cuban Government to restore Christmas as public holiday (M)

headline: Silicon Graphics Expects A Loss, and Its Stock Dives
abstract: Silicon Graphics shares lose a third of their value after company says it expects to report loss for its first fiscal quarter; company attributes loss to unexpectedly weak sales in quarter ending Sept 30 (M)

headline: A Bacardi Account Goes to Burrell
abstract: Bacardi-Martini USA Inc, which markets Bacardi line of rums, names Burrell Communications Group as first agency to handle consumer and trade advertising and promotions aimed at black consumers; billings undisclosed (S)

headline: Ford Planning To Spin Off Lending Unit
abstract: Ford Motor Co, in effort to persuade investors that its stock is undervalued, says it will distribute to shareholders its 80.7 percent stake in its highly profitable consumer and commercial lending unit, handing out shares in Associates First Capital Corp worth nearly $18 billion; spinoff would leave Ford even more dependent on highly cyclical automotive business (L)

headline: I.B.M. Earnings Rise 6%, Beating Analysts' Estimates by 4Â›
abstract: International Business Machines Corp reports its earnings increased more than 6 percent in third quarter, to $1.369 billion, from year earlier; company's total revenue grew by 3 percent, to $18.6 billion; revenue in company's hardware business, its largest source of revenue, was flat at $8.3 billion; Lawrence R Ricciardi, acting chief financial officer, says many areas are offering employees voluntary buyout packages, and some will have mandatory layoffs; company hopes to save money by merging its consumer PC business into its business PC unit and by merging two of its midsized computer businesses (M)

headline: S.& P. Lowers Ratings On South Korean Debt
abstract: Standard & Poor's Corp lowers its long-term and short-term ratings of foreign currency debt of South Korea; move reflects escalating cost to Government of supporting country's ailing corporate and financial sectors (S)

headline: Market Place; An Analysis By Goldman Can Be Used Against It
abstract: Market Place column says quickly shifting allegiances among telecommunications investment bankers can lead to situations in which analysts can find themselves favoring stock of company that is competing with interests of important client; cites case of Richard G Klugman, analyst at Goldman, Sachs & Co, who has been bullish on stock of Worldcom at time when his company is advising GTE Corp in its battle with Worldcom to acquire MCI Communications Corp; Goldman claims this is evidence of wall between research and other divisions so prized by investment banks (M)

headline: Ciba Specialty Chemicals Buys Mallinckrodt Unit
abstract: Ciba Speciality Chemicals buys Mallinckrodt Inc's pre-blend additives business (S)

headline: Shareholders of True North Communications approve a $440 million acquisition of Bozell.
abstract: Shareholders of True North Communications Inc approves its $440 million acquisition of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt Inc, ending two-month battle in feud between True North and its former partner, Publicis SA of France (L)

headline: Gulf War Alliance: 6 Years Later, Seams Fray
abstract: News analysis of fraying Persian Gulf war alliance, after six years of sanctions against Iraq; US policy bars negotiations with Saddam Hussein, so that simple act of sending UN delegation to discuss arms inspections required envoys to promise not to 'negotiate'; diplomats nevertheless hope for face-saving way for Hussein to change his mind about expelling Americans from arms inspection team; coalition partners are calling privately for more coherent strategy, suggesting that sanctions are unsustainable and that Hussein could be in power for years; photo (M)

headline: I.M.F. Aid Plea By Indonesia Appears Near
abstract: Indonesia, struggling to defend its beleaguered currency, appears on verge of asking International Monetary Fund for financial help; officials say final decision to seek such help will hinge on decision by Pres Suharto, longest-serving national leader in Asia, whose family is deeply involved in many of Indonesia's biggest ventures (L)

headline: Fireball Over Greenland Sends Scientists on Hunt for a Meteor
abstract: Danish scientists hunt for gigantic meteor impact which they believe was source of very bright flashes that lighted up southern tip of Greenland on December 9, in dead of Arctic night; news of huge fireball is reported by Niels Bohr Institute; dazzling flashes were observed by crews of three widely separated Scandinavian trawlers, and seismic signals were detected minutes later at stations in Norway, Finland and Germany; main impact area is believed to be on Greenland ice cap (S)

headline: One Dissenter At Fed Urged Rate Increase
abstract: Federal Reserve policy makers--faced with fragile markets, Asia's crisis and concerns about inflation--had one dissenter, Alfred Broaddus, president of Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond, in their decision to leave short-term interest rates unchanged at their meeting on Nov 12; Federal Open Market Committee voted 11 to 1 to leave Federal funds target interest rate for overnight loans between banks unchanged at 5.50 percent (S)

headline: BB&T TO PAY $359.2 MILLION IN STOCK FOR LIFE BANCORP
abstract: BB&T Corp agrees to buy Life Bancorp Inc for $359.2 million in stock (S)

headline: France Telecom Bids For Dutch Cable Unit
abstract: Royal PTT Nederland NV says it has received several bids for its cable TV operations since it put them up for sale to satisfy regulatory concerns as Dutch market opens to competition; France Telecom SA says it is among bidders for Dutch cable business (S)

headline: W. B. Doner Gets Cigarette Account
abstract: Imperial Tobacco Ltd, division of Imasco Ltd, names W B Doner & Co to introduce company's first product for American market, 'natural' tobacco cigarette named Mercer (S)

headline: Pressure Builds on Corestates' Chief Over Merger Stance
abstract: Terrence A Larsen, chairman and chief executive of Corestates Financial Corp, is under intense pressure to prove why his bank should remain independent in face of takeover bids from larger banks; Larsen says Corestates is well equipped to determine its own fate, and he will present investment community with his latest strategy for achieving revenue growth that has eluded Corestates during last few years; Larsen has been determined cost-cutter, laying off 6.4 percent of work force in 1995 and slashing expenses to improve bank's bottom line; while such moves have made bank one of the most profitable in the country, they have not resulted in marked improvements in some key Corestates businesses; photo (L)

headline: TRAVELERS AND TISHMAN SPEYER IN REAL ESTATE VENTURE
abstract: Travelers Insurance Co, unit of Travelers Group Inc, says it formed real estate venture with Tishman Speyer Properties with initial investment by companies of $800 million; says venture will focus on global real estate acquisitions and development and is starting with portfolio of 15 office properties and five development sites (S)

headline: Adam Opel to Cut 1,900 Jobs in Belgium
abstract: Adam Opel AG, German unit of General Motors Corp, says it is cutting 1,900 jobs at its plant in Antwerp, Belgium, almost a quarter of work force, to offset sluggish sales in Europe (S)

headline: The Budget and Mexico: A Vote for Stability
abstract: News analysis of success of Mexican Pres Ernesto Zedillo in winning approval of budget in Congress dominated by scrappy opposition parties; Zedillo passed acid test of his leadership, proving he can deal with contentious legislature as well as subservient one he and other Mexican Presidents have faced since early decades of century (M)

headline: VULCAN VENTURES TO BUY CONTROLLING STAKE IN METRICOM
abstract: Vulcan Ventures Inc will buy controlling stake in Metricom Inc; Vulcan, investment group for Microsoft Corp's co-founder Paul G Allen, says it will buy Metricom for $56 million; Vulcan agrees in separate deal to acquire 2.58 million Metricom shares from Lindner Group; two purchases raise Vulcan's interest in Metricom to 49 percent (S)

headline: FROM THE DESK OF; Coming Of Age With the Transistor
abstract: Article by Curtis J Crawford, head of Lucent Technologies' Microelectronics Group on how transistors have changed how we live and work; says transistor, invented 50 years ago, was not just a major development of the 20th century, it has been the defining invention of latter half of the century; says today, most people in industrialized world are probably never more than foot away from a transistor; notes that are more than 20 billion microchips in use on this planet and each one of them contains upward of million transistors (M)

headline: Judge Says Dow Corning Implant Plan Is Flawed
abstract: Federal Bankruptcy Court Judge Arthur Spector rules there are numerous flaws in Dow Corning Corp's proposals for disposing of breast implant damage claims; says it would be 'monumental waste of time' for claimants and other creditors to vote on bankrupycy reorganization plan containing the proposals; also says proposals leave Dow Corning with too much control over trust fund that company would set up to distribute up to $2.4 billion to breast implant claimants; Dow Corning says it will continue to negotiate on all of issues court has pointed out (M)

headline: Iraqi Official Says Baghdad Will Continue to Defy U.N.
abstract: Foreign Min Mohammed Said al-Sahaf says Iraq remains committed to its threat to expel American weapons inspectors (M)

headline: Despite Sluggish Sales, Toyota Earnings Rise
abstract: Toyota Motor Corp says earnings in fiscal first half rose as cost cuts, growing exports to US and Europe, and weaker yen made up for slack sales in Japan; company reports its pretax profit increased 26 percent in half ended Sept 30, to 324.56 billion yen ($2.6 billion), from year earlier; net income grew 43 percent, to 187.56 billion yen; Toyota is being hurt by Thailand's economic crisis; says it will halt production at its two Thai factories from mid-November to at least end of year because of poor demand; Mitsubishi Motors Corp says Thai currency plunge resulted in foreign-exchange loss of $276 million, on money it borrowed to pay for aggressive expansion drive in Thailand (M)

headline: Unlikely Envoy: U.N. Point Man on Iraq
abstract: Profile of Richard Butler, head of United Nations commission set up to disarm Iraq; blunt Australian, noted for his salty language, is key figure in UN standoff with Iraq; photo (M)

headline: WINSTAR SAYS IT IS BUYING GOODNET FROM TELESOFT
abstract: Winstar Communications Inc says it is buyer of Goodnet, an Internet access provider, from Telesoft Corp for $22.5 million (S)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  ADLERSBERG, ZINA
abstract: ADLERSBERG-Zina, died peacefully on October 21, 1997. Singer and voice teacher, known professionally as Zinaida Alvers. Beloved wife of the late Dr. David Adlersberg. Loving mother of Margaret and Mark Berger. Devoted grandmother of Josh and David Berger (Tracey Altman). Dear great grandmother of Tashi. Service on Friday, 1:15 P.M., at ''The Riverside'', 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to your favorite charity.

headline: CANADIAN SOFT DRINK MAKER EVALUATING SALE OF COMPANY
abstract: Cott Corp, a Canadian soft drink producer, hires invesment bank Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Co to help it evaluate possible sale of company (S)

headline: ENGELHARD PLANS 4TH-QUARTER CHARGES OF $96 MILLION
abstract: Engelhard Corp will take fourth-quarter charges totaling $96 million to restructure joint venture and two businesses; in October, Engelhard said it was looking at ways to eliminate drag on earnings of its Paris-based Engelhard-CLAL joint venture; company plans to resume five-million-share repurchase plan (S)

headline: More on Markets
abstract: A WEAK LINK -- When Hong Kong stumbles, must Wall Street fall? Page D1.

headline: London Journal; In Hallowed Reading Room, Last Page Is Turned
abstract: British Library's hallowed Round Reading Room closes after 140 years as singular retreat for tens of thousands of scholars, and ordinary folk, who have sat at leather-covered desks and worked under great Victorian dome; photos; 12 millions books are being moved across London, to efficient new library near St Pancras Station; huge red-brick structure lacks venerable charm, but librarians are delighted with computerized catalogue system that replaces dusty volumes and pneumatic tubes (London Journal) (M)

headline: DAVEL COMMUNICATIONS TO BUY RIVAL PAY-PHONE PROVIDER
abstract: Davel Communications Group to acquire Communications Central for $70 million, including assumed debt (S)

headline: How to Make Big Rubles? Invest in a Comrade's Debt
abstract: Russia's mountain of overdue debts has spawned $15 billion market in IOU's; known as veskels, many are redeemable for cash, goods and services; companies issue them to pay suppliers, which barter them for other goods or resell them to speculators for cash; banks and brokerage companies trade more than $100 million worth of them each month, and post prices for them on Internet; even few American investors are snapping them up, viewing them as Russia's variant on American high-yield junk bonds; trade in veskels is primitive version of corporate bond market--similar to practice in US of bundling mortgages, car loans or even troubled loans from distressed companies into securities that are sold to investors; diagram (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   6.00   5.56   5.60        3-MO.
