headline: Witness Links Winnie Mandela to Guards' Crimes
abstract: Former anti-apartheid colleague of Winnie Madikizela-Mandela's, Azhar Cachalia, tells South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission that Madikizela-Mandela was either aware of murderous assaults and other criminal activities her bodyguards engaged in during late 1980's or directed and actively took part in them; Cachalia, now Secretary for Safety and Security, says bodyguards, known as Mandela United Football Club, were Madikizela-Mandela's 'own personal vigilante gang,' and that numerous efforts were made by other anti-apartheid leaders to persuade her to disband them; says she even ignored appeals by her then-husband, Nelson Mandela, who was still in jail at time (M)

headline: STARWOOD LODGING IN $2.1 BILLION DEAL WITH VNU
abstract: Starwood Lodging Corp, which is acquiring ITT Corp, reaches agreement to sell ITT World Directories Inc to VNU NV for $2.1 billion; sale is contingent on Starwood's acquisition of ITT (S)

headline: Lomas Trustee Sues Auditors
abstract: Ernst & Young L.L.P. and two of its audit partners are being sued by a bankruptcy trustee for the Lomas Financial Corporation who contends they mismanaged the defunct mortgage company's audit and did not properly disclose the company's financial troubles.     Martin R. Pollner, the trustee representing the company's creditors and shareholders, is seeking at least $300 million in a state court in Dallas. The suit contends that the accounting firm and the two partners collaborated with management to conceal risky financial practices that contributed to the company's failure. The suit, filed in October, was reported today in The Wall Street Journal. Ernst & Young said in a statement that it ''performed its duties professionally.'' ''The losses Lomas cites in its complaint were caused by its own decisions, and all of its allegations against us are totally without merit.''

headline: French Insurer Rejects A Takeover Bid
abstract: Board of Assurances Generales de France SA rejects unsolicited $9.3 billion takeover bid by Italy's Assicurazioni Generali SpA (S)

headline: AT&T TO USE MCLEODUSA NETWORK FOR SERVICE IN 30 CITIES
abstract: AT&T Corp will offer local phone service to business customers in 30 Midwestern cities using McLeodUSA Inc's network to cut fees that AT&T pays to regional Bell companies; terms of agreement not disclosed (S)

headline: As Panama Canal Transfer Nears, More Jockeying to Fill a Power Vacuum
abstract: Panama maneuvers to fill power vacuum, created by sudden resignation of Panama Canal Commission chairman Joe R Reeder, with barely two years before US yields control of vital waterway; nine-member bi-national board has chosen US Army Sec Togo D West Jr to succeed Reeder, but, in nod to Panama's increasingly assertive posture regarding running of canal, board also created new position of vice chairman and named Panamanian, Jorge E Ritter, to job; appointment of West has sparked debate among shipping executives and other canal experts, who note he is relatively new to canal matters and his preoccupation with other issues may render him unable to properly supervise handover and assure that Canal Treaties are properly implemented (M)

headline: Companies Reported Spending More on Research
abstract: National Science Foundation reports American companies increased their spending on research to $118.65 billion last year, 9 percent more than in 1995; another big jump is expected for this year as companies seek to sustain sales by offering something new to consumers; Federal subsidies companies received for research fell slightly, to $20.9 billion, as they have almost every year in this decade (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: HOME DEPOT INC., Atlanta, plans to open 61 stores and create 10,000 jobs in California by February 2000. The company currently operates 95 stores and employs about 20,000 people in the state.

headline: In Kyoto, The Subject Is Climate; The Forecast Is for Storms
abstract: Representatives of 150 nations are set to meet, Kyoto, Japan, to begin decades-long effort to cope with prospect of global climate change; will seek accord on reducing emissions of carbon dioxide and other waste industrial gases that trap heat in atmosphere; effort to curb use of fossil fuels that create 'greenhouse' gases has set off complex clash of economic and political interests; pits rich countries against poor ones and against one another and producers and heavy users of fossil fuels against rest of world; graph; photos (M)

headline: Resignation Sends Aetna Shares Tumbling
abstract: Resignation of Aetna Inc's financial executive James H Dickerson Jr sends company's stock down nearly 12 percent; stock drops $9.375, to $69.50; analysts say resignation raises prospect that a second quarter of disappointing earnings looms (L)

headline: HEALTH CARE'S GIANT: Artful Accounting -- A special report.; Hospital Chain Cheated U.S. On Expenses, Documents Show
abstract: Court document show Federal investigators believe Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp hospitals intentionally distorted expense claims to increase Federal reimbursements; confidential hospital records show hospitals, some acting both before and after Columbia/HCA acquired them, overstated expenses knowing Government oversight was spotty and that if caught, they would could repay money without fines or interest; show they waited two to three years to be sure tricks went undetected before counting added money as profits; graphs; table; photo (L)

headline: Justice Dept. and Pentagon Clear Raytheon-Hughes Deal
abstract: Raytheon Co wins approval from Federal antitrust officials to buy military business of Hughes Electronics in $9.5 billion deal (M)

headline: Stocks Are Mixed on Earnings That Mostly Top Expectations
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 24.07 points, to close at 8,096.29; Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks gains 2.18, to close at 970.28; Nasdaq composite index loses 9.33 points, to close at 1,732.79; table (L)

headline: London Journal; Parliament Defines Itself in Gestures of Chivalry
abstract: Women members of British Parliament, whose numbers increased greatly in last May's Labor sweep, complain that many male members behave like boorish schoolboys; many men in Parliament seem to be clinging happily to old ways, despite growing propensity for American-style sensitivity in rest of Britain; photos (M)

headline: Judge in Texas Jars U.N. Effort On War Crimes
abstract: Elizahan Ntakirutimana, Rwandan Hutu pastor indicted by international tribunal for genocide during country's civil war, is freed by Federal magistrate-judge in Laredo, Tex, where he fled to live with son and was arrested in 1996; decision by Marcel C Notzon jolts US efforts to cooperate with both Rwanda and Balkans war crimes tribunals, and represents slap at Rwandans seeking justice for killings, which left estimated half million dead; says 1996 agreement between US and tribunals, passed as part of bill in Congress, is unconstitutional since extraditions have historically been negotiated between nations and are covered by formal treaties made with advice and consent of Senate; Ntakirutimana, trusted Seventh-day Adventist pastor in Mugonero, Rwanda, is charged with leading well-armed band of Rwandan soldiers and militiamen to hundreds of people who had hidden in church and hospital compound at his urging (M)

headline: Bonds Rise on Weak Report From Purchasing Managers
abstract: US Treasury securities rally on unexpectedly weak manufacturing report that suggests economy is slowing enough to suppress inflation; 30-year bond surges a full point, to price of 100 24/32; its yield, which moves in opposite direction, falls to 6.32 percent, from 6.40 percent on Sept 30; graph (L)

headline: MANAGEMENT GROUP OFFERS TO BUY SYBRON CHEMICALS
abstract: Sybron Chemicals Inc says group of its major shareholders and manangement will buy shares it does not own already, for as much as $103 million; investor group includes Citicorp Venture Capital Ltd (S)

headline: Treasury Securities Scheduled for Sale This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three-  and six-month bills.     By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.16 percent and the six-month bill was 5.09 percent.

headline: Zurich Group to Buy a Big Piece of a Hong Kong Investment Bank
abstract: Zurich Group agrees to pay $200 million to become biggest shareholder in Peregrine Investment Holdings Ltd, fast-growing Asian investment bank that has been hurt by plunge in regional stock and bond prices (L)

headline: Auto Makers Report Weak October Sales
abstract: General Motors Corp says sales fell 4 percent in October compared with year-earlier period, mostly because of weak sales of vans and small utility vehicles and pickup trucks; Ford Motor Co says sales dropped 2.1 percent; seasonally adjusted annual rate of sales in US reached 14.7 million, compared with 15 million in September and 15.5 million in August and July; Toyota Motor Co says sales rose 2.9 percent; Mazda Motor Co says sales rose 5.7 percent; Mercedes says sales jumped 81.8 percent; Hyundai Motor Co says sales rose 9.9 percent, and Porsche AG says sales climbed 69.6 percent; Volkswagen AG sales fell five-tenths of 1 percent; sales at Suzuki Motor Corp plunged 29.4 percent; sales at BMW AG fell 3.2 percent, and sales at Juguar, the Ford unit, dropped 6 percent; chart; graph (L)

headline: Many have seen the hand of God, not the enemy of religion, in technology.
abstract: Technology column discusses new book by David F Noble, The Religion of Technology: The Divinity of Man and the Spirit of Invention; Noble argues that technological enterprise has always been essentially a religious endeavor; he traces religious view of technology back to early Middle Ages, when innovation became associated with God's will and monasteries became centers of invention as well as worship; drawing (M)

headline: Updates/Media and Technology; 4 British Cable Channels Enlisted Against B Sky B
abstract: Time Warner's Warner Brothers studio agrees to supply films for four British cable television companies that plan to create pay-per-view movie channels; cable systems seek to compete with News Corp's British Sky Broadcasting, which responds with own plan for pay-per-view channels; four cable companies are Telewest Communications, NTL Inc, General Cable and Diamond Cable (S)

headline: Incubators of Creativity; Can Japan Inc. Put Corporate Individualism to Work?
abstract: Creative corporate whiz kid, a business personality often prized by corporate America, has come to Japan; many Japanese companies are clearly eager to cultivate entrepreneurial spirit; major companies think that in order for them to develop into next century, they need to let ideas buried within the company bloom on individual basis rather than defer to an organized effort that favors authority and devotion to group solidarity; photos (L)

headline: Market Place; The High Hopes Of Investors In Stock Funds
abstract: Survey by 750 mutual fund investors conducted by Montgomery Asset Management found that those shareholders questioned anticipated average annual returns of 34 percent on their investments over next decade; such results contrasts starkly with warning by Federal Reserve Board chairman Alan Greenspan against expecting recent stock market gains to continue indefinitely; graph (L)

headline: Big, if Not Quick, Rewards From College Internships
abstract: Letter by Dr Marcia Cantarella on Oct 19 article on unpaid college internships (S)

headline: A Black Panther's Mellow Exile: Farming in Africa
abstract: For more than a quarter century, the man who thinks of himself as the last Black Panther has lived in exile in a village at the foot of a mountain in Tanzania, a fugitive from American justice.     His days are filled with farming, mountain climbing and running an exchange program for troubled youths from his homeland. But at night, Pete O'Neal still dreams of his boyhood on 12th Street in Kansas City, Mo., of the bakeries along Paseo Boulevard, the jazz clubs, the famous barbecue joints.

headline: 3Com Shares Drop on Bad Earnings News
abstract: Shares of the 3Com Corporation tumbled more than 13 percent in after-hours trading today after the company said it would report quarterly revenue and earnings far below Wall Street estimates.    Shares of 3Com, a leading maker of modems and computer networking equipment based in Santa Clara, Calif., fell to $30.625 from its close of $35.3125, or 13.3 percent. Other computer issues also fell.

headline: A Xenophobic Weed Is Growing in Denmark's Tidy Little Garden
abstract: COPENHAGENâ€”  In the mind of its people, Denmark has been a preserve of good nature and gentle fortune, scrubbed and apple-cheeked, without arrogance or subservience, a small place so fair, decent, and mild that it stands out in its cosy virtue as God's own little red house with white picket fence.

headline: When the world doesn't work, try moving to the Web.
abstract: Sampling of cyberrealms that are partly meant as dissents from real world, objections to it and attempts to remake or redo it; they include first cyberdiocese, created by dissenting, leftist Bishop transferred by Vatican to Sahara, and site by separatist Italian party seeking to split Northern Italy off from south as new country; drawing (M)

headline: The Brave New World of General Motors
abstract: Profile of General Motors Corp; GM, under chairman and chief executive John F Smith Jr, has replaced losses with near-record profits by paring work force, closing or selling unneeded plants and shaking up highly bureaucratic structure; GM's share of United States market has stopped shrinking and begun to grow; GM plans to sell more than half of its cars and trucks abroad by 2006, up from 43 percent in 1996, aiming at markets with potential for double-digit growth; map; tables; graphs; photos (L)

headline: Commerzbank Considers Buying Barclays Units
abstract: Commerzbank AG is considering buying BZW corporate finance and stock brokerage businesses of Barclays (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY   None

headline: A Funny Man Earns It The 2,000-Year-Old Way
abstract: Interview with entertainer Mel Brooks on his career and conservative personal investment strategy; Brooks discusses finances in his persona as 2,000-Year-Old Man with Carl Reiner; photos (L)

headline: Law Publishing Merger Planned
abstract: American Lawyer Group, owned by US Equity Partners LP, equity fund managed and partly financed by Wasserstein Perella Group, says it will acquire National Law Publishing Co, creating country's leading publisher of legal news; sellers are Boston Ventures and James Finkelstein, National Law's president and chief operating officer; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: A Plunge in Hong Kong Shakes Markets
abstract: Plunge in Hong Kong stock market on Oct 23, touched off by attack on local currency, shakes financial markets around world; stocks loose 10.4 percent of their value in Hong Kong, causing frantic selloff in Japan and on Europe's stock exchanges; Dow Jones industrial average finishes down 2.3 percent, or 186.88 points, at 7,847.77; some smaller stock markets, including those in Brazil and Mexico, come under even more pressure, falling 5 percent or more, as confidence is shaken in many emerging markets; selloff spread as investors learned that what appeared in July as isolated currency problem in Thailand had become full-blown crisis in Southeast Asia; there are signs on Oct 24 that Asian markets are stabilizing; photo (M)

headline: NatWest Sells Equity Unit to Bankers Trust
abstract: National Westminster Bank P.L.C. said today that it had sold its European equities business to the Bankers Trust New York Corporation and its United States and Asian equity derivatives units to Deutsche Morgan Grenfell for a total of $301.7 million .    ''We have been unsuccessful in developing this business,'' said Derek Wanless, chief executive of NatWest, ''and have therefore taken the very tough decision to effect an orderly exit.''

headline: Paper Warehouse Deal
abstract: Paper Warehouse Inc plans to buy Gibson Greetings Inc's Paper Factory unit for about $38.6 million in cash to create largest operator of retail party stores in United States (S)

headline: With Pilots Finally on Board, US Airways Plans New Direction
abstract: US Airways plans to elbow its way into top ranks of airline industry now that it has reached tentative labor agreement with its pilots; carrier and its pilots reached deal minutes before company says it had to tell Airbus Industrie whether it would confirm order for as many as 400 planes (L)

headline: A Nobel Winner Wears Several Fund Hats
abstract: Interview with Myron Scholes, Nobel Prize winner in Economics, on mutual fund investing; he discusses role in inventing index funds; photo (M)

headline: Marketing Agencies Announce Merger
abstract: Advertising agencies specializing in integrated marketing--Integer Group in Denver and Kragie/Newell in Des Moines--are merging to form shop with combined billings estimated at $305 million; terms undisclosed; agencies will keep their separate names and headquarters (S)

headline: WorldCom Wins Over MCI With New $36 Billion Bid
abstract: NEW YORKâ€”  With a sweetened offer of $36 billion, WorldCom Inc. brushed aside two rival bidders and emerged Monday as the suitor of choice for MCI Communications Corp.

headline: Updates/Media and Technology; British Cable Companies Reach Deal With Warner On Rights to Movies
abstract: Four British cable companies sign contracts to show Warner Brothers films on pay-per-view basis and are close to signing two more Hollywood studios; contracts mean customers of four cable companies can watch films from studio without using British Sky Broadcasting Group, which now has exclusive distribution rights (S)

headline: Stocks Tumble, With Dow Falling 91.85
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average drops 91.85 points, to 7,847.03, on New York Stock Exchange trading volune of 625 million shares; table (M)

headline: Au Pair's Release Disturbs Jurists as an Excess of Mercy
abstract: WASHINGTONâ€”  Legal experts said Tuesday that they supported a Massachusetts judge's decision to lower a British au pair's murder conviction to manslaughter, but many of them criticized the sentence sharply as being surprisingly lenient and out of line with normal practice.

headline: Waiting for Those Dreams to Get Cheap Enough to Buy
abstract: Article on buying stocks on pullback or downturn in the market; mutual fund managers Shelby Davis, Richard Weiss and Steven Reid suggest some companies that they consider overpriced but otherwise great; chart (L)

headline: Efforts are under way to change the image of older consumers as tradition-bound tightwads.
abstract: Efforts to counter perception of older consumers in their 60's and 70's as tradition-bound tightwads increasingly portray so-called mature market as beginning with people in their 50's; market is expanding by some 10,000 a day as baby boomers reach 50 (M)

headline: Neoprobe Stock Off On Query by F.D.A.
abstract: Stock of Neoprobe Corp drops 17 percent after company says Food and Drug Administration is seeking more information about its cancer-detection technology; Neoprobe's RIGS (radio-immuno-guided surgery) product, named Rigscan CR 49, is used in surgical detection of metastic colo-rectal cancer (S)

headline: Voice of America Was Warned on China Interview
abstract: National Security Council says national security adviser Samuel R Berger asked Voice of America director Evelyn Lieberman to consider that interview with Chinese dissident Wei Jingsheng could offend Chinese Government and hamper efforts to win release of other dissidents; denies Berger tried to dissuade Government-financed agency that makes own editorial decisions from airing interview, which it chose to broadcast (S)

headline: Japan Securities Firms Report Lower Results
abstract: Japan's Big Four securities firms--Daiwa Securities, Yamaichi Securities, Nikko Securities and Nomura Securities--report lower results for first half of 1997-98 fiscal year amid payoff scandals and falling commission rates; Nomura reports pretax profit of 49.30 billion yen, down 29.4 percent from year ago, while Daiwa posts profit of 18.96 billion yen, down 33.6 percent; Nikko's profit stands at 2.18 billion yen, down 90.2 percent, and Yamaichi reports loss of 2.74 billion yen compared with profit of 6.44 billion yen (S)

headline: Complex Bargaining On Global Warming
abstract: There was optimism at the global-warming talks in Kyoto that industrial countries might reach an agreement next week setting targets and timetables for the central issue of cutting their emissions of heat-trapping waste gases. Pieces of an agreement ''are beginning to take shape,'' an American negotiator said.     But there appears to have been little headway on the related issue of how the developing countries would control waste gases in the immediate future. That issue threatens the success of the whole meeting.

headline: Key Japanese Panel Devises $77 Billion Bank Rescue Plan
abstract: Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party agrees to use at least 10 trillion yen ($77 billion) in public money to strengthen country's shaky banking system, following collapse of four financial institutions last month; there is new evidence that banks' frailty and Asia's deepening financial crisis are further undermining confidence in Japan's economy; party panel proposal is for Government to supply 10 trillion yen in bonds to Deposit Insurance Corp; agency could then call on Government to purchase bonds back for cash as needed to help solve financial crisis engulfing banks, securities firms and insurers, many of whom are swamped in bad loans; some analysts say it will take more than 10 trillion yen to strengthen Japanese financial system, and panel has left open possibility of raising more money; in share trading in Tokyo on Dec 16, benchmark Nikkei index of 225 issues is down 104.89 points, or two-thirds of 1 percent, at 15,804.50 (M)

headline: EASTMAN CHEMICAL MAY SPIN OFF OR SELL PET PLASTIC UNIT
abstract: Eastman Chemical Co says it is looking at ways to improve returns on its PET plastic packaging business, including selling it or spinning it off (S)

headline: North Korea Called Ready For Talks
abstract: State Department official reports North Korea appears ready to start serious negotiations to formal end to Korean War, which ended inconclusively 44 years ago; four-way talks between diplomats from North Kortea, South Korea, US and China reportedly will begin in Geneva in December after preliminary meeting in New York (M)

headline: Christmas Fades As Retail's Rescuer; Stores Look to Rest of Year As December Sales Flatten
abstract: Nation's retailers are keeping expectations low for Christmas season, mindful of fact that Christmas is slowly shedding its role as annual rescuer of American retailers; retail sales in last two months of year fell to 23.9 percent of annual sales in 1996, from 25.4 percent in 1988; one sector of retail industry that enjoys better trends--luxury goods--may be hurt if stock market plunge continues; retail analyst says Americans are working more hours and harder, and spending money differently; traditional retailers and mall developers are working harder to make rest of year count more, hyping marginal holidays like Halloween and Mother's Day and offering inducements like buying clubs to build customer loyalty; drawing; graphs (L)

headline: Consultant's Report Clears Bre-X Chairman
abstract: Forensic Investigative Associates Inc, private investigative firm hired by Bre-X Minerals Ltd, concludes that Bre-X chief executive David Walsh was unaware of tampering by company geologists that helped to convince investors that company had found world's largest gold deposit (S)

headline: Frugal Koreans Rush to Rescue Their Rapidly Sinking Economy
abstract: South Koreans are responding to economic crisis with large outpouring of tiny gestures in show of patriotism and return to grit and determination that built economy; are turning foreign currency and gold into Korean wons to bolster currency and cutting consumption of all kinds, particularly of luxury imports thought to contribute to foreign debt problems; some economists fear spending cuts will hurt economy; photos (L)

headline: In Big Corporate Accounting, Will 4 Be Sufficient?
abstract: Proposed mergers of nation's largest accountants raise questions about whether four major firms are enough to look over books of nearly every large corporation in United States; Ernst & Young and KPMG Peat Marwick announce their plans to merge, as have Price Waterhouse and Coopers & Lybrand; Arthur Levitt Jr, chairman of Securities and Exchange Commission, emphasizes need to evaluate consequences of further concentration in industry; mergers will not become final if Justice Dept's antitrust division finds they would create overconcentration of power; at Ernst and KPMG, combined organization will be headed by Ernst's chairman, Philip A Laskawy, and KPMG's chairman, Stephen G Butler, will be chief executive until Laskawy's retirementin 2000, at which time Butler will become chairman until 2002; stated impetus behind merger is need to become even larger as businesses they serve undergo their own consolidations; no layoffs or cost savings are anticipated; chart (M)

headline: Avian Flu Transmitted To Doctor, Officials Say
abstract: Health workers report first evidence of probable human-to-human transmission of avian influenza in Hong Kong, but say it is not necessarily a harbinger of a lethal epidemic; transmission was detected from recent blood tests of doctor who cared for first known human case of the new viral strain, a 3-year-old boy who became ill last May; physician did not develop any symptoms (M)

headline: From Carrier Nimitz, F-14 Tomcats Ride Shotgun for the U-2
abstract: Navy and Air Force warplanes escort unarmed U-2 spy plane in flight over Iraq in challenge of Pres Saddam Hussein's threat to shoot down plane; planes return without incident (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Technology Stock Rebound Helps Stop Four-Day Slide  Stocks in the United States ended higher for the first time since Dec. 16 despite fears about the consequences of Asia's worsening financial crisis. Renewed interest in technology stocks and buying related to a number of new corporate takeover deals helped arrest the market's decline.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: U.S. Seeks Changes In Microsoft Browser Policy  The Federal Government asked a judge to order Microsoft to stop forcing makers of personal computers to include its Internet browser when they install Windows 95.    The challenge to Microsoft promises to have broad implications for the heated contest between it and Netscape over which company's browser will dominate the Internet. Netscape's stock soared. [Page A1.]

headline: Correction: Fidelity Funds on Tuesday
abstract: Correction of Oct 29 mutual fund table, which included erroneous data for some funds managed by Fidelity Investments (S)

headline: Rival Asserts Philip Morris Smuggles in South Africa
abstract: Rembrandt Group Ltd files suit, London, contending that Philip Morris Companies, world's largest cigarette manufacturer, has been allowing its cigarettes, primarily Marlboros, to be smuggled into South Africa through bordering countries; according to pleadings in case that have not been made public, Rembrandt argues that movement of smuggled Marlboros violates an exclusive license that Rembrandt acquired in 1981 to make and sell Philip Morris products in South Africa; legal issue is a narrow argument over whether that licensing agreement is enforceable; worldwide, cigarette smuggling is depriving governments of billions of dollars in tax revenue (M)

headline: William S. Ogden, 69, Executive Of Chase and a Banking Rescuer
abstract: William S Ogden, retired banker who helped save Continental Illinois National Bank & Trust Co from insolvency, dies at age 69 (M)

headline: Comedy Central makes the most of an irreverent, and profitable, new cartoon hit.
abstract: Hottest, most-talked-about new program of television season is South Park, animated show made on shoestring budget and appearing on Comedy Central, six-year-old all-comedy cable channel; photo of Matt Stone and Trey Parker, show's creators (M)

headline: Some See Opportunity in Global Push to Remove Land Mines
abstract: De-mining technology show is held in Ottawa in conjuction with signing of treaty to ban land mines; a few delegates express misgivings about mixing of business with land mine misery (M)

headline: LEARNING AGREES TO ACQUIRE CREATIVE WONDERS
abstract: Learning Co agrees to acquire Creative Wonders LLC for $40 million in cash and stock options (S)

headline: Britain Opens Trial Process in Libya Case to U.N.
abstract: British Government, in effort to defuse Arab and African criticism that two Libyans wanted for trial in 1988 bombing of Pan American jetliner over Lockerbie, Scotland, will not get fair trial there, opens Scottish legal system to inspection by three international organizations; extends invitations to UN to appoint team of high-level experts, as well as to Arab League and Organization of African Unity (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY   Existing-Home Sales Nov.

headline: Israeli Reaction to Iran's Buildup Is Heightening Nuclear Fears in Mideast
abstract: The Middle East could end up living under the threat of nuclear confrontation, U.S. officials say, unless Washington succeeds in stopping the flow into Iran of material for weapons of mass destruction. For the Clinton administration, the problem of Tehran's buildup is complicated by Israel's response to it.

headline: Stocks Decline On Concern About Profits
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average falls 10.69 points, or one-tenth of 1 percent, to 7,838.30; Nasdaq composite index falls 21.96 points, or 1.4 percent, to 1,536.58; Standard & Poor's 500 index falls 1.55, or two-tenths of 1 percent (M)

headline: Disney and Katzenberg Reach Pact on Lawsuit
abstract: Walt Disney Co and its former studio chief, Jeffrey Katzenberg, announce unexpected settlement that avoids legal battle in court but leaves open amount Katzenberg will receive to further negotiations; Katzenberg's suit sought at least $250 million from Disney from profits of several hit films while he ran Disney studio; Disney contends Katzenberg forfeited his share of profits by leaving company before his contract expired; trial had potential to open Disney's financial records, providing far greater details than in documents required by Securities and Exchange Commission; both sides agree to keep terms of settlement confidential; final setlement will be determined by mediating judge; photo (M)

headline: Airlines Test Tighter Rules On Baggage
abstract: Airlines, after years of complaints, are moving to clear out their increasingly crowded baggage areas in airplane cabins, by limiting amount of bags and baggage passengers can bring on board with them; they are likely to face new round of complaints, from infrequent leisure travelers, since most business travelers apparently will be exempt from baggage restrictions; Northwest Airlines is already limiting many passengers to one carry-on bag on its routes, and United Airlines unit of UAL Corp will try out similar restrictions; jammed overhead bins in airplane cabins have long been an irritant to full-fare business passenger--airlines' most valued customer, who typically pay three to four times the fare of leisure passenger on same flight, and who together account for as much as 60 percent of an airline's revenue (M)

headline: Shift of Cable Subscribers
abstract: Time Warner Inc will transfer 640,000 of its cable subscribers in New York, Florida and North Carolina to Time Warner Entertainment, its joint venture with Advance/Newhouse Communications; in exchange, venture will assume more than $1 billion of Time Warner's debt (S)

headline: AT&T Plans to Expand Cost-Cutting
abstract: A top executive of the AT&T Corporation said yesterday that the company would expand its $2.6 billion cost-cutting plan in an effort to have the industry's lowest expenses.    ''We have to be something we have never been before -- the low-cost supplier in our industry,'' John D. Zeglis, AT&T's vice chairman and president, said at the Salomon Smith Barney telecommunications conference in New York.

headline: Baghdad Journal; An Arrival! Just the Idea Has This Airport in Orbit
abstract: Word that plane might actually land at Saddam International Airport in Baghdad touches off party preparations, with children chanting their ritual anti-American slogans and sheep assembled on runway for celebratory slaughter; plane, reportedly carrying Russian nationalist Vladimir Zhirinovsky, never arrives, and airport remains unused as it has since UN imposed embargo after Persian Gulf war; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Proposal on Pension Funds Is Faulted
abstract: Retirement advocates warn that Labor Dept plan could seriously erode ability of workers to make sure that their pension funds are being properly handled; large pension funds must annually disclose what stocks, bonds and other assets they hold; under Labor Dept plan these holdings would no longer be disclosed in annual reports, known as Form 5500's; Karen Ferguson, executive director of Pension Rights Center, contends that annual disclosures are critical to making sure that workers collect promised benefits (M)

headline: Saudi Bombing Still a Mystery, U.S. Officials Tell Victims' Relatives
abstract: Atty Gen Janet Reno and other top US law enforcement officials meet privately with families of 19 American airmen killed by a bomb in Dhahran, Saudi Arabia, and tell them that investigators still do not know who was responsible; investigators are said to suspect Saudi dissidents who oppose stationing of American troops in Kingdom and rule of Saudi royal family (S)

headline: Indonesia Securities Firm Is Expected to Cut Jobs
abstract: PT Lippo Securities, one of Indonesia's biggest brokerage firms, will dismiss most of its foreign analysts, salesmen and traders to save money; Lippo is among first casualties of this year's steep drop in Asian financial markets (S)

headline: World News Briefs; Japan Says It Will Sign Treaty on Land Mines
abstract: Prime Min Ryutaro Hashimoto, breaking ranks with United States, says Japan will sign international treaty banning antipersonnel land mines (S)

headline: NEC Raising Its Packard Bell Stake to 49%
abstract: NEC Corp will invest $300 million in Packard Bell NEC, increasing its stake in the privately held company to 49 percnt from 20 percent; this is latest step in NEC's effort to become a major player in American computer market; Packard Bell NEC, a market leader in PC sales for American home users, is trying to move into corporate market in order to raise its profitability, which has been under assault this year (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Amtrak and Union Agree On Outline of Labor Accord  Transportation Secretary Rodney E. Strong announced in Washington that Amtrak and a union representing 2,300 of the railroad's workers have reached what he called ''the basic terms of a new labor agreement.'' The terms of the settlement, reached after a 23-hour bargaining session, would be in force through 1999. But both sides were vague about how much the settlement would cost and how Amtrak would pay for it.

headline: Anguished Mexican Village Buries Its Dead
abstract: Mass funeral is held in Acteal, Mexico, for 45 people massacred by gang of armed men; victims, which included nine children and baby, bring to at least 300 number of people killed in state of Chiapas since clashes began in 1993 between Indian guerrillas fighting for greater rights and armed militia members opposed to their cause; Government of Pres Ernesto Zedillo has vowed aggressive investigation into killings, and Federal agents are reportedly questioning top security officials in area; survivors of attack say gunmen were local followers of Zedillo's party; photos; map (M)

headline: KOS SHARES PLUNGE ON NEWS OF SLOW SALES OF DRUG
abstract: Shares of Kos Pharmaceuticals fall 46 percent after company releases first-quarter results that show sales of its new cholesterol-lowering drug Niaspan are not rising as fast as analysts expected; shares drop $14.375, to $16.5625 (S)

headline: Woodrow Wyatt Dies at 79; Laborite Turned Thatcherite
abstract: Woodrow Wyatt, high-living onetime Socialist politician and journalist who later turned against the left as a television presenter and conservative tabloid newspaper columnist, died on Dec 7 at age 79; photo (L)

headline: Stanford Rook Shares Plunge on Drug Setback
abstract: Shares in Stanford Rook Holdings PLC lose more than half their value on news of setback in third-phase trials of company's tuberculosis drug SRL172 (S)

headline: Teheran Journal; Who Says There's No Fun in an Islamic Republic?
abstract: Teheran's New City neighborhood, den of prostitution during Shah's rule, has been transformed into Razi Park, vast public space with gardens, artificial lake and some amusement-park attractions; park reflects new spirit that has seized capital since election in May of Mohammed Khatami as President, compared with strict social restrictions that had existed since Islamic revolution of 1979 and hindered even healthy forms of recreation; photo; map (M)

headline: Now, Obstruction of Justice Is Focus of Milken Inquiry
abstract: US Government's long investigation of Michael R Milken is focusing on allegations that he obstructed justice; lawyers say Milken will face tremendous legal problems if allegations are proved; Milken is still on probation, having paid $1.1 billion in fines and served little more than two years of 10-year prison term after pleading guilty to six counts of securities fraud in April 1990; evidence of further illegal behavior since his release might cause Government to request further sanctions against Milken, including even his return to prison; Government officials will not comment on nature of possible obstruction (L)

headline: Deal by National City
abstract: National City Corp agrees to acquire Sterling Ltd for undisclosed terms (S)

headline: Fidelity Will Shut Its Singapore Office
abstract: Fidelity Investments plans to close its office in Singapore on Jan. 1, an executive of the mutual fund company said today.    The office's operations will be transferred to Hong Kong, said Selina Chung, Fidelity's Hong Kong-based retail marketing director. The Singapore office has one fund manager, Jeff Kung.

headline: SUMMIT CARE HIRES FIRM TO EXPLORE 'ALTERNATIVES'
abstract: Summit Care Corp says it hired Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp to help it evaluate 'strategic alternatives' and 'maximize shareholder value' (S)

headline: U.S. Team to Go to Kinshasa to Try to Restart Massacre Inquiry
abstract: Clinton Administration will send senior delegation to Congo to try to revive United Nations' probe into massacres and other atrocities during civil war; appointment of delegation, led by Amb Bill Richardson, signals growing United States frustration with Pres Laurent Kabila and underscores limits of US influence over him; Clinton aides are divided on tougher steps to isolate Congo; team may also visit Rwanda (M)

headline: In the New Europe, a Tilt To Using Wind's Power
abstract: Wind power is booming across Europe, encouraged by improved technology, falling costs and Government incentives like tax credits and guaranteed prices; 4,700 windmills in Denmark generate 6 percent of country's electricity; policymakers point to boom as key example of how pollution can be cut without jeopardizing jobs or economic growth (M)

headline: GROUP MAINTENANCE AMERICA SETS EXPANSION
abstract: Group Maintenance America Corp agrees to buy four heating and plumbing maintenance businesses for $38.3 million in stock and cash (S)

headline: Last Days of Kim Philby: His Russian Widow's Sad Story
abstract: Rufina Philby, Russian widow of Kim Philby, publishes memoir of life with British master spy who was most famous mole in history; Philby, charming and gifted, was shining star of Cambridge spies, privileged young Englishmen who were recruited to spy for Soviet Union in 1930's, and rose to top of British intelligence as they betrayed colleagues and country; widow adds attempted suicide to details about Philby's loneliness, depression and heavy drinking after he finally fled to Moscow in 1963; he died in 1988, age 76, was buried with full military honors and had face put on stamp in 1990; widow, whose apartment is book-filled shrine to Soviet hero, says he was privately disillusioned and guilty at the end (M)

headline: Wall St. Sex Bias Suit Is Said to Be Settled
abstract: Smith Barney is expected to announce a settlement of a class-action lawsuit contending sexual harassment at the firm. While not including any set amount of money, the settlement would allow women employees to take their claims to an independent arbitrator.    Business Day, D1.

headline: Ljubljana Journal; Though Still Dead, Tito Can Be Reached on Line
abstract: Martin Srebotnjak and Matija Marolt, university students in Ljubljana, Yugoslavia, create Web Page for Josip Broz Tito, late Yugoslav Communist leader, which offers variety of lore about his life; photo; map (M)

headline: BOMBARDIER PLANS TO ACQUIRE GERMAN RAIL CAR MAKER
abstract: Bombardier Inc says it will buy Deutsche Waggonbau AG, one of Germany's largest rail car makers, for undisclosed price; acquisition is Bombarider's first into former eastern Europe bloc and will increase its plants in Europe to 11 from six (S)

headline: FINGERHUT SAYS IT WILL SPIN OFF ITS 83% STAKE IN METRIS
abstract: Fingerhut Companies Inc plans to spin off its 83 percent stake in Metris Companies to shareholders (S)

headline: Smog Is Blotting Out Asian Economies, Too
abstract: SINGAPOREâ€”  As Southeast Asia enters a fourth successive month shrouded in smoke and smog, it is starting to count the economic costs in terms of falling tourism, disrupted transport, damaged crops and diminished investor confidence.

headline: CLOSINGS IN EUROPE AND WORKER DISMISSALS PLANNED
abstract: Kellogg Co to close three European plants and dismiss 400 workers, about 10 percent of its European work force, resulting in pretax charge of up to $150 million in fourth quarter (S)

headline: Strength in Economic Data Renews Fear of Fed Tightening
abstract: Industrial output rose strong 0.7 percent in Sept as operating rate rose 0.3 points to 84.4 percent of capacity; housing starts rose 7.9 percent in Sept; figures renew fears that Federal Reserve will tighten credit to slow growth and curb inflation; graph (M)

headline: 3 Agency Companies Make Acquisitions
abstract: WPP Group acquires 35 percent stake in Ibope Media Information in Rio de Janeiro; Cronin & Co acquires Synergy Marketing Solutions; BBDO Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group adds additional 29 percent to its stake in Gitam/BBDO in Tel Aviv (S)

headline: Publication Date Open to Dispute In Internet Age
abstract: Libel suit brought against Business Week magazine hinges on whether magazine should be considered published when it goes on line or when it becomes available on paper; suit was brought by Julian H Robertson Jr against Business Week's parent, McGraw-Hill Cos, Gary Weiss, author of cover article on Robertson, and Stephen B Shepard, Business Week's editor in chief; Business Week contends that libel claim was filed too late--one year and one day after article became available on America Online; magazine itself appeared on newsstands a day later; this appears to be first case in which publication rule has been applied to magazine that was initially published electronically (M)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY  The Treasury Department releases its October budget statement.    TUESDAY  The Conference Board releases its consumer confidence index for November.  The National Association of Realtors reports on home resales for October.  Mitsubishi Bank/Schroder Wertheim releases its weekly retail sales report.  LJR Redbook Research releases its weekly retail sales index.

headline: $48 Million Bank Deal
abstract: Union Planters Corp to acquire Capital Savings Bancorp of Jefferson City, Mo, for $48 million in stock (S)

headline: W. R. Grace Develops Asbestos Treatment
abstract: W R Grace & Co says it has developed chemical foam that can turn asbestos fibers in fireproofing material into various minerals (S)

headline: Chafing Faiths in Russia's Onion Dome
abstract: New Russian law strengthening dominance of Russian Orthodox Church has transformed Suzdal, with its imposing religious buildings, into battleground in conflict between church and smaller Orthodox factions; at issue is control of 15 churches breakaway Free Orthodox Church has been restoring; church critics hold it seeks to stifle dissent within its ranks and wrest religious property from minority Orthodox groups; map; photos (L)

headline: Petroleum Geo-Services In Awilco Shipping Deal
abstract: Petroleum Geo-Services ASA agrees to acquire floating oil production and storage business of Awilco Shipping AS of Norway for $860 million in stock (S)

headline: U.N. Chief Seeks Peace Force to Dampen the Brazzaville Flames
abstract: Sec Gen Kofi Annan, responding to sudden intensification of Congo Republic civil war that threatens to engulf other African nations in regional conflict, asks United Nations Security Council to impose sanctions on nation and prepare to send in peacekeepers; says fighting involves Angolan armored troops, soldiers from neighboring Congo and various mercenary armies; challenges United States not to block peacekeeping mission (M)

headline: New Offer Confirmed for Lin Television
abstract: Raycom Media Inc says it offered to buy Lin Television Corp for more than $1.7 billion, topping earlier bid from Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc; Raycom would assume $270 million in debt (M)

headline: Israel Demolishes 2 Palestinian Houses in the West Bank
abstract: Israel resumes demolition of Palestinian homes in West Bank, razing two unfinished houses near Al Arrub refugee camp after owner is refused building permit; acts despite calls by State Sec Madeleine K Albright for moratorium on such actions; Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu says Israel has released last of funds withheld from Palestinian Authority since July 30 suicide bombing in Jerusalem (M)

headline: Blacks in South Africa Find New Wealth but Old Biases
abstract: There are obvious signs of growing affluence among South African non-whites three years after nation's first elections open to all races; number of black families owning houses, cars and luxury goods has soared; life for many middle-class blacks is still punctuated by small humiliations as they confront way of life that was totally foreign to them when they were growing up; many describe with glee their access to 'finer things'; they are optimistic about future and willing to shrug off some of slights they face because they believe that South Africa, led by its first black President, Nelson Mandela, now belongs to them and whites will eventually lose their dominant position in society; photo (M)

headline: Patents ; A disposable plastic cover that fits over the diaphragm of a stethoscope to keep it clean.
abstract: Dr Isaac Wurzburger is granted patent for disposable plastic cover for stethoscope; patent is granted to Professor Elizabeth S Stuart, late Professor Alex Bruce MacDonald, immunologist Judith A Whittum-Hudson and chemical engineer William Mark Saltzman for developing vaccine for chlamydia (M)

headline: British Airways Posts 2d-Quarter Decline
abstract: British Airways PLC says its profit fell 44.4 percent in second quarter, to 153 pounds ($252 million) from year earlier; drop is second straight quarterly decline for airline (S)

headline: Russia's Former Head of Privatization Faces Bribery Charge
abstract: Alfred R Kokh, Russia's former privatization chief, is being accused of receiving bribe in politically explosive case that has cast cloud over Yeltsin Government's program to sell billions of dollars in state assets; Moscow prosecutor's office is investigating allegations that Uneximbank, Russia's most powerful bank, funneled $100,000 to Kokh through Swiss intermediary (M)

headline: ATRION TO BUY SOME PRODUCT LINES FROM QUEST MEDICAL
abstract: Atrion Corp agrees to acquire certain product lines of Quest Medical Inc's cardiovascular and intravenous fluid delivery operations for $24.5 million (S)

headline: I.M.F. to Consider Seeking More Capital
abstract: International Monetary Fund will take up proposal from its managing director, Michel Camdessus, to request more capital from its 181 member nations, seeking to insure that it has sufficient financial reserves to cope with crisis in another big country (S)

headline: It May Be Time for a Silver Lining in Air Pollution
abstract: Moribund air-pollution control stocks may be poised to stir; new smog and soot rules are in offing in United States, European and Asian nations are beginning to regulate air quality and consumers are snapping up air cleaners for their homes and offices; these stocks, which soared on promise of 1990 Clean Air Act, plunged as expected business-bolstering rules failed to arrive; table (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Joblessness at 24-Year Low In Strong Sign of Vitality   The United States economy last month created 404,000 jobs -- double what had been  forecast -- as the unemployment rate edged down to 4.6 percent, another 24-year low, the Labor Department said in a surprisingly strong report.  But the traditional worry that more jobs and higher wages would surely bring inflation was set aside, as little inflation continued to be seen. And the recent economic troubles in Asia are expected to put further downward pressure on consumer prices.   [Page A1.]    Good news for workers was, for a change, also good news for Wall Street. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 10.69 points, or 1.1 percent, to 983.79, its first record since before the market tumbled. Technology and oil industry stocks led the market rally.   [D2.]

headline: Going From a Crawl to a Run
abstract: Eliot Christian, computer specialist for United States Geological Survey, has spent last six years trying to get various government and commercial information providers around world to agree to global standard for providing access to information on World Wide Web; project, Global Information Locator Service (GILS), is wide-reaching collaboration by government, industry and academia in US and around world; photo (M)

headline: Consortium to Buy Oilfield
abstract: Enterprise Oil PLC says it is part of group that will buy North Sea oilfield from Conoco Inc for $92 million (S)

headline: How Tough Questions and Shrewd Mediating Brought Iraqi Showdown to an End
abstract: As an unarmed U-2 spy plane soared high over central Iraq two weeks ago, President Clinton was poised to order the biggest military operation of his Presidency.    In a military command center in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia, senior American and Saudi officers nervously tracked the progress of the flight, ready to unleash an overwhelming barrage of bombs and missiles against an array of targets if President Saddam Hussein carried out his threat to shoot down the plane.

headline: Diana's Brother Learns That the Tabloids Bite Back
abstract: Princess Diana's younger brother, Earl Charles Spencer, who bitterly denounced tabloid press during eulogy for his sister, is himself in midst of messy divorce, and press is having field day; one unflattering detail after another about him has emerged during court hearing in South Africa, where he lives, to determine if case should be heard there or in Britain; Earl's spurned mistress has joined forces with his estranged wife, and is telling press what a cad he is; photos (M)

headline: Shift in Direct Course; Catalogue Merchandiser J. Peterman Now Moving Into Retail Stores, Too
abstract: J Peterman Co, catalogue merchandiser, has seen its business increase since being parodied on hit TV sitcom Seinfeld; company faced choice of remaining niche business that serves loyal but limited audience, or exploiting its name and opening retail stores; Peterman opted for latter; it has only four retail stores, but recently raised more than $10 million from private investors, and plans to open 50 stores over next five years and 20 off-price outlets; quirky Peterman catalogue has loyal following, but sales last year were only $60 million; J Peterman himself, brains behind catalogue, has limited retailing experience; he brought in Arnold Cohen, veteran retailer, to bring in fresh capital and help company expand; photos (M)

headline: Treasuries Lose Their Haven Status as Stocks Recover
abstract: Prices of US Treasury securities decline sharply as stocks surge; price of 30-year bond drops 2 4/32, to 101 9/32, pushing its yield to 6.28 percent from 6.14 percent on Oct 27 (L)

headline: Health Agency Investigates a Fever in Kenya
abstract: World Health Organization dispatches team to northeastern Kenya to investigate mysterious disease with symptoms similar to deadly Ebola fever; at least 143 people reportedly have died in Garissa region, which has been heavily flooded for weeks; photo; map; victims apparently die of high fever, vomiting, diarrhea and hemorrhaging; medical speculation centers on contaminated flood waters or mosquito-borne illness (S) y

headline: Taking In the Sites; Environmental Issues Are Clarified
abstract: Growing debate over global warming, as well as El Nino phenomenon and intense smog over Southeast Asia, pushes environmental issues to forefront of news and onto many World Wide Web sites (M)

headline: Interpublic Unit To Change Name
abstract: Draft Direct Worldwide, part of Interpublic Group of Companies, says it will change its name to Draft Worldwide to reflect its recent expansion beyond direct marketing and into services like advertising and promotions (S)

headline: Thailand to Sell Shares in Airline
abstract: Thai Airways International board approves plan for Government to cut its stake to 70 percent, from current 93 percent, in series of share sales (S)

headline: A New Set Of Hurdles For Jumpers
abstract: Recent study found that investors who frequently jump in and out of mutual funds increase costs of funds, meaning lower returns for everyone; Dreyfus Corp has announced new policies to discourage excessive trading, and Fidelity Investments also reserves right to punish frequent traders; fund industry as whole is not rushing to follow suit, fearful of antagonizing shareholders (M)

headline: Welcome! And Thanks For Lunch
abstract: Letters by some employees on how their companies welcomed them whey were first hired; drawing (L)

headline: Czech Premier Steps Down After Havel Seeks Ouster
abstract: Czech Prime Min Vaclav Klaus, once revered at home and abroad as brilliant economist before popularity faded, resigns amid political scandal involving disclosures by political colleagues of secret slush fund held by his ruling party in Swiss bank; says he will not be part of new Government; corruption, brought on by lack of regulation in changeover of Czech economy from Communism to capitalism, is seen as contributing factor in downfall; Pres Vaclav Havel schedules talks for formation of new Government, composed of ruling, center-right Civic Democratic Party and junior coalition partners, Christian Democrats and Civic Democratic Alliance (M)

headline: China's Leader Is Rebuked By American Legislators
abstract: Chinese Pres Jiang Zemin meets with Senate and House members of both parties, who question him about human rights, nuclear proliferation, religious freedom and forced abortion; photo (M)

headline: Betting the U.S. Economy on a Rising Stock Market
abstract: Analysis of US economy and booming stock market; says big reason for shift to optimism about economy from pessimism appears to be stock market; holds sustaining Dow Jones industrial average to record levels is gradually becoming as much a priority among investors as fighting inflation (L)

headline: Messy Free-Market Plunge Rattling China's Businesses
abstract: China's plan to shift almost all its 300,000 state enterprises to private ownership has created treacherously unstable business climate; most businesses are small and inefficient and lack managers skilled at making business decisions; grave risk is that unrest will erupt among workers, since more than 100 million jobs are at stake in businesses that will be up for sale; workers at many companies are suddenly finding themselves obliged to buy shares if they want to keep jobs, and once Government support disappears they could be left with nothing if factories collapse; even greater concern, dramatized in small but ominous worker protests nationwide in recent months, is danger that corrupt factory managers will fail to pay workers in confusion caused by transition, and will abscond with company's assets; photo (M)

headline: DIARY
abstract: SOUTH KOREA  The Crisis Deepens  Barely a week after South Korea signed a record $57 billion bailout agreement, the nation plunged deeper into crisis when the Korea Development Bank, the largest state-owned bank, abruptly postponed a $2 billion bond offering that had been intended to help pay off billions of dollars in debt coming due within weeks. The postponement rattled the world's financial markets and raised fears that South Korea might become the first Asian nation to default on its debts since an economic crisis began spreading through the region in the summer. Earlier in the week, the Finance Ministry suspended the operations of five more banks and said it would put money into securities companies to help keep them afloat. Nevertheless, the South Korean won continued to plunge in currency markets.

headline: High-Profile Deals for Property Giant
abstract: Article on high-profile real estate deals conducted by 70-year-old Peter Munk, head of Trizec Hahn Corp and one of Canada's busiest entrepreneurs, during 1997; Munk comments; photo (L)

headline: Assessing The Role of Mutual Fund Investors
abstract: Mutual fund assets have grown eightfold in size and immeasurably in influence over market sentiment since stock market crash of 1987; fund industry has contended since 1987 that its investors' behavior has had little effect on stock prices; graph (L)9

headline: ALLIANCE BANCORP AGREES TO BUY SOUTHWEST BANCSHARES
abstract: Alliance Bancorp Inc agrees to buy Southwest Bancshares Inc in stock swap valued about $90 million (S)

headline: Oil, Oil Everywhere, but Few Rigs; A Glut of Fields, a Dearth of Workers and Drilling Gear
abstract: Along the muddy banks of the Mississippi, a huge oil-drilling platform is taking shape here at a newly revived shipyard. About 700 workers are busily assembling the drilling rig, which already towers over 300 feet and, when completed, will soar 552 feet toward the sky -- taller than the United Nations building.    But this is more than just another giant rig. For many in the oil-service industry -- which covers everything related to oil drilling, from rigs to helicopters for ferrying men and equipment -- it is also a dramatic symbol of just how much this business has been able to shake off a 10-year downturn.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: U.S. Commits $3 Billion To Indonesia Aid Package   The United States will announce today that it is committing roughly $3 billion in backup financing for an International Monetary Fund package to aid Indonesia.

headline: Crowley Buying 49 Winkelmans Stores
abstract: Crowley, Milner & Co will acquire 49 Winkelmans stores from Petrie Retail Inc (S)

headline: Occidental Pipeline-Unit Sale Realigns Natural Gas Industry
abstract: Occidental Petroleum Corp's agreement to sell its Midcon gas pipeline unit to KN Energy Inc for $3.49 billion in cash will move Occidental further into its core oil business and quadruple KN's assets; Occidental will use funds from sale, which was announced last October, to help pay for its $3.65 billion purchase of Federal Government's 78 percent share of United States Naval Petroleum Reserve, Calif; after purchase of gas pipeline unit, KN will assume $400 million in debt and will have $7.8 billion in assets, 26,000 miles of pipelines in 15 states and annual operating revenue of $4.7 billion (M)

headline: Woman From Ulster Expected to Win Irish Republic Vote
abstract: Ireland goes to polls on Oct 30 to elect new President to replace Mary Robinson, who left office after seven-year term to become United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights; Mary McAleese, law professor from Northern Ireland, is expected to win election; her photo (M)

headline: Patents; Checkout scanners may soon be ringing up fruits and vegetables based on their scent.
abstract: Alan Gelperin invents supermarket scanner that automatically rings up fruits and vegetables based on their scent; Henry Yuen and Elsie Leung receive patent for remote control that enables TV viewers to surf channels by theme; Claude Moughanni and Yui Kaye Ho receive patent for paging system that can receive message in one language and transmit it to beeper in second language (M)

headline: ARGENTINA CABLEVISION PLANS TO ACQUIRE A RIVAL SYSTEM
abstract: Argentina's Cablevision SA agrees to buy its smaller rival, Mandeville Cable Partners, for $515 million; acquisition will increase Cablevision's subscriber base to more than one million, moving it ahead of Argentina's No. 2 cable operator, Video Cable Communicaciones SA (S)

headline: Virginia Banking Deal
abstract: First Citizens Banc Shares agrees to acquire 15 branches in Virginia from Signet Banking Corp (S)

headline: Casino Owner Stops South Africa Book
abstract: International casino magnate Sok Kerzner, in early test of press freedom under South Africa's new Constitution, has delayed publication of Allan Greenblo's biography of him, Kerner Unauthorized, and is trying to ban it; Greenblo complains of chilling effect of mere threat of suit (M)

headline: Diana Coverage Said to Hurt Retail Sales
abstract: Telecheck Services reports that growth in retail sales during September was slower than expected because consumers stayed home at beginning of the month to watch television coverage of the death of Diana, Princess of Wales (S)

headline: South African Tycoons Apologize for Gaining From Apartheid
abstract: Chief executives of South Africa's biggest corporations and banks, in testimony at Truth and Reconciliation Commission hearings, are disclosing ways business supported apartheid or violated human rights during era of white rule (M)

headline: 10 Years After the Crash, Fall Is Not in the Air; Taking the Pulse Of Wall Street From Bottom Up
abstract: People who make their livings on Wall Street, including service providers, do not expect repeat of Oct 1987 stock market crash; district has finally rebounded from post-1987 downsizing; photos (M)

headline: Olivetti and Wang in Talks on Unit Merger
abstract: Olivetti SpA and Wang Laboratories Inc say they are talking about merging Olivetti's Olsy computer systems and services unit with Wang's operations; Wang says Olivetti would retain interest in combined business (M)

headline: This Personnel Training Is No Blackboard Jungle
abstract: Telekom Malaysia is one of dozens of large Malaysian corporations that have been sending employees on survival tests in the jungle to revitalize staff members; Outward Bound, British-based organization that organized Telekom's program, lists 34 companies, mostly blue-chip concerns, that participate in the program (L)

headline: Chairman of RJR Food Unit Will Retire
abstract: H John Greeniaus, chairman and chief executive of food subsidiary of RJR Nabisco, will retire at end of year because of health problem; he will be replaced by James Kilts (M)

headline: Up to 3,000 Jobs May Be at Stake in Latest First Union Deal
abstract: First Union Corp and Corestates Financial Corp discloses further details about their pending $17.1 billion merger, but still decline to quantify number of layoffs the deal would entail; Corestates chairman-chief executive Terrence A Larsen, in conference call with reporters, estimates net loss of no more than 3,000 jobs, but offers little guidance beyond that (L)

headline: Merrill Settles Bond Fund Suit
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co agrees to settle class-action suit involving shareholders of its Short-Term Global Income fund and Short-Term World Income Portfolio fund for $90 million in cash and coupons (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.89   5.50   5.67        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.11   5.07   4.98        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.19   5.22   5.04        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.54   3.53   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   5.85   5.86   6.05        30-YR. TREAS. headline: Specialty clothing retailers this fall want to let shoppers know that they, too, are a brand.
abstract: Specialty stores are attempting to build brand image for their own labels through new advertising campaigns; at Talbots Inc an extra $13 million has been earmarked this fall for ad campaign, created by Arnold Communications, to tell shoppers that the store is returning to its roots in classic styles; Ann Taylor Stores Corp executives say their fall campaign is biggest one ever for the retailer (L)

headline: So Far, Just 1929 and 1987 Are Under His Belt
abstract: Brief interview with Roy R Neuberger, founder of money management firm of Neuberger & Berman, on surviving stock market crashes of 1929 and 1987; photo (M)/

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  PREVETTI, FRANK A.
abstract: PREVETTI-Frank A. Passed away on October 20, 1997 in San Jose, CA. Survived by long time companion, Janice Prevetti; sister, Petranilla Prevetti; daughters, Laurel Prevetti & Lynn Bushman; and a granddaughter, Katherine Hawn. Born June 13, 1937 and raised in Milwaukee, WI. Regional editor of T.V. Guide Magazine for 37 years in San Francisco, Seattle, Los Angeles, Merced and San Jose. A Memorial Mass will be held at St. Thomas of Canterbury Catholic Church, 1522 McCoy Ave, San Jose, CA., Sunday, October 26, 1997 at 6:45 PM. In lieu of floral tributes the family prefers donations to Polycystic Kidney Research Foundation, 800-753-2873. Info: Darling & Fischer Chapel of the Hills, Los Gatos, California.

headline: DIARY
abstract: MARKETS  Tilting at Exuberance Again  Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, was wearing his Cassandra hat in public again last week. In testimony before Congress, Mr. Greenspan returned to the themes of his famous December ''irrational exuberance'' speech, calling any hopes that the stock market will continue to roar upward at its recent pace unrealistic and warning that inflation remained a looming threat. As usual, he avoided saying definitely whether an interest-rate increase was in the offing, but investors took his remarks to heart and pushed stock and bond prices down.    MORE IS MORE  Buying the Competition  Federal Express struck a deal to expand into trucking and logistics by agreeing to buy Caliber for $2.7 billion, thereby also acquiring RPS, a big competitor in the business-to-business end of the speedy delivery market. One reason Caliber may have looked especially tempting to the generally acquisition-shy Fedex: Like Fedex (but unlike U.P.S.), Caliber is nonunion. . . . Not long ago, the North Fork Bancorporation had a half-dozen branches and a chairman trying to control costs by telling workers to make do with one pen and one pencil apiece. With a deal last week to buy New York Bancorp for $800 million, its ninth acquisition in as many years, North Fork will become the biggest bank on Long Island, and a serious competitor in the retail backyard of the giant New York City banks -- maybe serious enough to get itself bought in turn.    LESS IS MORE  Addition by Subtraction  Fed up with trying to persuade the market that its highly profitable finance arm ought to make its stock worth a lot more, the Ford Motor Company decided to hand over its 80.7 percent stake in Associates First Capital to Ford shareholders. The almost $18 billion spinoff accounts for nearly a third of Ford's market value but less than one-twelfth of its second-quarter profits. . . . Champion International also felt the urge to become a purer play, saying it would sell off roughly a quarter of the company to concentrate on coated papers, unbleached paperboard, softwood timberland and distribution. Analysts said Champion could net about $1.1 billion, including the sale of 325,000 acres of timberland, much of it in the environmentally and politically sensitive Adirondack Park in upstate New York.    TECHNOLOGY STOCKS  Sell on 'Oops,' Buy on Thud  A tale of two losses: On Monday, Silicon Graphics brought investors up short with word that it expected to report a loss for the quarter ended Sept. 30. The market, noting that the company's previous quarter was gangbusters and its competitors in the client-server business are thriving, reacted by hacking a third off its share price. On Tuesday evening, the chip maker Advanced Micro Devices reported an even bigger loss than analysts had been expecting since the company gave warning a month ago. Did the market mind? Not for long. After a rough morning, the stock rallied to close higher and rose again the next day.    SAFETY  Lock and Unload  The stories are heartbreakers: Children find their parents' handgun in the dresser drawer, they play with it and one winds up maimed or dead. Those stories ought to be growing rarer by the end of next year, when the manufacturers of most handguns made in the United States say they will be shipping all new handguns with a child-safety lock. . . . Chrysler continues to be haunted by allegations of defective rear door latches in the 4.1 million of its mini-vans built before 1996. A Federal jury in Charleston, S.C., awarded $262.5 million to the family of a six-year-old boy thrown from a mini-van in a 1994 traffic accident. Chrysler has a program to replace the latches but has not formally recalled the mini-vans. The company says it will appeal the verdict.    CURRENCY UNION  The Euro's Bitter Medicine  Getting Europe's economies synchronized for the introduction of the planned common currency in 1999 is proving painful. Germany's central bank felt compelled to head off any hint of inflation with a surprise interest-rate increase, its first tightening in more than five years, despite slow growth and record unemployment rolls. Five neighboring countries swiftly followed suit. In Italy, the center-left coalition Government of Romano Pradi, struggling to trim its too-big-for-the-Euro budget deficit, found itself cutting social welfare spending too deeply for the Communist Party to tolerate. Loss of the Communists' votes in Parliament brought down the Government.    SOUTHEAST ASIA  Indonesia Calls for Help  Long discredited in geopolitics, the domino theory seems to be reappearing in geofinance. Some of the same pressures that toppled the Thai baht over the summer have since set Indonesia's currency to teetering. Indonesia still has substantial reserves of foreign exchange, but the writing on the wall looked dire enough last week to prompt a request for standby aid from the International Monetary Fund to help stabilize the rupiah. Two more hard-hit currency dominoes, the Malaysian ringgit and Philippine peso, managed gains last week.    ACCUSATIONS  All the Way to the Top?  The senior F.B.I. agent in the investigation of possible fraud at Columbia/HCA, the nation's biggest hospital chain, called what the Government has uncovered so far a ''systematic corporate scheme'' perpetrated by senior executives -- and not an isolated error or aberration. The chain's billing and accounting practices may not ultimately prove to have been criminally improper, analysts said, but at the least, the company's defenses against pending shareholder lawsuits appear badly undermined by the contents of a 75-page affidavit partly unsealed last week. Neither the company nor its battered stock showed much reaction.    COINCIDENCES  There's That Word Again  What's hot, black, caffeinated and seemed to figure in every other headline last week? In politics, the long-running Washington donnybrook over campaign finance flared up when videotapes, shot at the famous White House coffees for high-rolling contributors, materialized belatedly. In Silicon Valley, Sun Microsystems sued Microsoft and threatened to yank its license to use Sun's Java programming language on the assertion that Microsoft had twisted Java into another way to seal the hegemony of its Windows operating system. In media, the editor of The Los Angeles Times, Shelby Coffey 3d, resigned, denying that he was driven out by corporate plans to give marketing executives unprecedented sway in the newsroom. Even in the weather report, a hurricane bearing down on Mexico's coffee country made commodity traders jittery at midweek. The storm devastated the coast but largely spared the crop; by Friday the futures pits had calmed down and so had prices, closing up mere pennies from a week earlier and still far below their May peak.

headline: DIARY
abstract: RETAILING  Barely Merry  A sparkling economy failed to deliver the snappy holiday season that retailers were counting on. Analysts and merchants estimated that sales were up a scant 2 to 3 percent from December of last year. This was the third lackluster Christmas season in a row, despite the sterling economy and the wealth-generating gains of the stock market. Analysts said the disappointment underscored the harsh necessity for retailers to come to grips with the season's diminishing value to them. ''It took stores years to learn that Easter had disappeared as a selling holiday,'' said Peter Schaeffer, a retail analyst on Wall Street. ''They have to realize that you can't count on Christmas anymore either.'' And even where sales were strong, profit margins were often weak because of discounting. Economists cited high consumer debt, the diminishing tendency of extended families to gather around the Christmas tree and the simple exhaustion of working couples trying to muster the energy to go to the mall.

headline: Like TV Come to Life, Outlaw Lovers' Escapade Rivets Brazil
abstract: Brazilians are riveted by real life romantic adventure of Carla Coehlo, 29-year-old artist and former local beauty queen, who has absconded with 35-year-old impoverished suitor who courted her via computer, pretending he was rich; both have become fugitives since living high-life at country's northeastern resorts, leaving trail of bad checks (M)

headline: A Last 'To Do List' for the Year
abstract: With three business days remaining this year, there is still time for some tidying up of your financial affairs. Here is a list of moves to consider, as compiled by Jan M. Rosen, Edward Wyatt and David J. Morrow.    Taxes       Add up your losses. If you sold stocks or mutual funds at a gain during the year and are sitting on losses in your portfolio -- in, say, international or Pacific funds that have tanked with the Asian crisis -- a sale before year-end will offset the gain. What is more, if your loss positions exceed your gains, as much as $3,000 of net capital losses can be taken as a deduction against ordinary income. This will also work if you have made no trades but have paper losses you can take.

headline: Israeli Jew From Outlawed Group Is Convicted of Insulting Islam
abstract: Tatyana Suskin, member of Kach, outlawed anti-Arab group, is convicted in Jerusalem court of committing act of racism and trying to insult religious feelings for putting up posters depicting prophet Mohammed as pig; faces maximum penalty of 26 years in prison; posters caused rioting in Hebron in June and outrage in Muslim world (M)

headline: Quebec Journal; To Some Canadians, the Maple Leaf Is a Red Flag

headline: Gedung Sintuk Journal; In Indonesia, Where There's Gold, There's Squalor
