abstract: 15 Japanese women who have lived in North Korea for most of their adult lives arrive in Japan for brief return visit, result of unofficial 'wives for food' exchange between countries; women are among 1,800 Japanese women who moved to North Korea with their Korean husbands between 1959 and 1963; unofficial arrangement seems to be that North Korea will let some of wives return to Japan, at least for temporary visits, while Japan will resume food aid to North Korea; photo (M)

headline: Camelot Seeks Wall Music
abstract: Camelot Music Inc. said it agreed to buy W. H. Smith Group P.L.C.'s Wall Music Inc. unit for $47 million.    Camelot, which is operating under bankruptcy protection, would get a 153-store chain with revenue of $160 million. Camelot said it filed a motion for approval of the agreement with the United States Bankruptcy Court in Delaware.

headline: DEAL TO COMBINE 2 MANUFACTURERS OF MODEMS
abstract: Westell Technologies Inc will buy Amati Communications Corp for $394 million in stock (S)

headline: Worms Profit Climbed 55% in First Half
abstract: Worms & Cie says its first-half profit rose 55 percent compared with year-earlier period; profit rose to 1.18 billion French francs, or $197 million, from 761 million francs, or $127.8 million, in six months a year earlier (S)

headline: J. Crew Caught in Messy World of Finance as It Sells Majority Stake
abstract: J Crew Group Inc deal to sell 88 percent of company to Texas Pacific Group was jeopardized by belated cut in purchase price that led Texas Pacific to pull and revise bonds issued to finance deal; bonds had already been sold in private placement through Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc and Chase Manhattan Bank (M)

headline: Share Price Plunges 55% At British Office Supplier
abstract: Shares of Danka Business Systems PLC fall 55 percent after company says it will take charge of $20.5 million (US) and post lower-than-expected third-quarter earnings (S)

headline: REGENCY HEALTH SELLS 24 NURSING HOMES AND 2 HOSPITALS
abstract: Omega Healthcare Investors Inc buys 24 nursing homes and two rehabilitation hospitals from Regency Health Services Inc for $86 million (S)

headline: Microsoft Digs In Against a 'Poorly Informed' U.S.
abstract: Microsoft Corp, hardening its uncompromising stance against Govt, contends that Justice Dept's latest demand in escalating antitrust case is merely proof that 'poorly informed laywers have no vocation for software design'; Microsoft's stubborn position that it cannot comply with Federal Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson's order to unbundle its World Wide Web browser software from its popular Windows 95 operating system may be stirring backlash against company; criticism is coming even from people who are generally sympathetic to Microsoft (M)

headline: Joy in Mudville: The Resale Value of Minor League Teams
abstract: Investing in minor league baseball teams discussed; many team owners have done well, not necessarily because of team revenues, but because resale values have skyrocketed; photo (M)

headline: Golf Course Operator in Japan Seeks Protection
abstract: Nitto Life Co, a Japanese golf course operator, seeks court protection from creditors along with its parent, Nitto Kogyo Co (M)

headline: When Will Bells Be Allowed Into Long Distance? Maybe After Rivals Get Local Access
abstract: Residential local phone competition remains elusive two years after passage of 1996 Telecommunications Act, which called for regional Bell phone companies to be allowed to offer long distance service if they opened their local networks to rivals; Bells have been unable to persuade Federal Communications Commission that they have provided rivals enough access (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ULTRAMAR DIAMOND SHAMROCK CORP., Greenwich, Conn., said it planned to sell a stake in a 408-mile Texas pipeline to a subsidiary of Phillips Petroleum. Terms were not disclosed.    BERGEN BRUNSWIG CORP., Orange, Calif., the drug and medical products distributor, agreed to buy Besse Medical Services, Cincinnati, a supplier of vaccines, for undisclosed terms.

headline: Income Rose In November, U.S. Reports 0.8%
abstract: Commerce Department reports personal income rose eight-tenths of 1 percent during November, biggest gain since June 1996 and double size of month's increase in consumer spending; Labor Department says number of people applying for state unemployment benefits fell more than expected last week; first-time jobless claims declined by 13,000, to seasonally adjusted 307,000; in previous week, claims rose revised 6,000; graph (L)

headline: No Shields, Please, for E-Mail
abstract: Letter by Catherine Godbille on November 23 article on employers providing avenue for their employees to send confidential electronic messages; says it would be more reasonable for employees to assume that none of their memos, E-mail messages or telephone conversations issued from their place of work on company equipment is private at all (S)

headline: Boeing Startles Market With Delays Costing $2.6 Billion
abstract: Boeing Co says unexpected production delays in booming market for its commercial planes will cost $2.6 billion and erase good portion of company's profits, which it will announce on Oct 24; says it will take charge against earnings of $1.6 billion for third quarter, resulting in loss for period, and second charge of $1 billion for fourth quarter; demand for Boeing planes is at all-time high, and Boeing is struggling to meet ambitious targets to produce 43 planes a month from 18 a month last year; parts shortages and other production problems caused Boeing to halt production of 747's for 20 workdays and 737's for 25 workdays on early October; latest news sends Boeing shares tumbling 7.6 percent (M)

headline: Two forecasters predict spending on Madison Avenue should remain robust next year.
abstract: Robert J Coen, senior vice president and forecasting director at McCann-Erickson USA, and John Perriss, chairman and chief executive of Zenith Media Worldwide, see 1998 as year of somewhat slower--but still strong--growth in advertising industry (L)

headline: Taking In the Sites; Congress Remains in Touch on the Web
abstract: Congress has adjourned until late January, but Capitol Hill's corridors on the World Wide Web still hum with activity; growing number of lawmakers are posting sites letting them keep in touch with constituents, lobbyists and reporters wherever legislators may be; several Congressional committees post summaries or full text of bills (M)

headline: Nobuo Fujita, 85, Is Dead; Only Foe to Bomb America
abstract: Nobuo Fujita, Japanese pilot who flew bombing runs over Oregon in 1942, dies at age 85; photo (M)

headline: Ireland Premier Calls Support By Clinton Vital to Ulster Pact
abstract: Ireland's Prime Minister, Bertie Ahern, says he hopes Pres Clinton will help push for final agreement on peace accord with Northern Ireland; says Clinton's support is crucial (S)

headline: Father's Killing of Canadian Girl: Mercy or Murder?
abstract: Canadian judge will decide fate of Robert Latimer, 44-year-old Sasketchewan farmer convicted of second-degree murder for killing severely ill daughter to end her agony; jury which found him guilty recommended that mandatory sentence of 25 years without parole be ignored in favor of one-year prison term; case has opened wide and emotionally wrenching rift in Canada over mercy killing and rights of handicapped; photos (M)

headline: Mort Pye, 79, Longtime Newark Editor, Dies
abstract: Mort Pye, longtime editor who built Newark Star-Ledger into biggest newspaper in New Jersey and was leading champion of state, dies at age 79; photo (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Selfcare Inc., Waltham, Mass., to Warwick Baker O'Neill, New York, to handle advertising for a recently acquired line of vitamins, including Posture and Stresstabs. The account had been inactive when those brands were owned by the American Home Products Corp. Billings were estimated at more $5 million.

headline: Weeklong Postal Workers' Strike Snarls Deliveries in Canada
abstract: Canadians, after week without mail, are beginning to feel impact of nationwide postal strike (M)

headline: McDonald's Profit Up 1.9%, But U.S. Sales Are Still Slow
abstract: McDonald's Corp reports third-quarter earnings rose 1.9% to $448.9 million, up from $440.6 million in 1996 period (S)

headline: VIEWPOINT; Social Security's Black Box
abstract: Article by James H Smalhout on state of Social Security system; says Social Security is in deep trouble and so far, America has been keeping its head in the sand, tinkering around the edges and condemning us and our children to sky-high payroll taxes in the future; suggests that financing system privately either through mandatory individual retirement accounts or company plans (L)

headline: Judges Thwart State Dept. Increasingly, Experts Say
abstract: Legal experts say decision by Texas magistrate, Marcel C Notzon, to release Elizaphan Ntakirutimana, Rwandan indicted by international war crimes tribunal for genocide, adds unexpected chapter to fast-changing story of how American judges are dealing with foreign issues; judges are increasingly making extradition of suspects more difficult, and in process are creating serious problems for Federal Government, especially State and Justice Departments, as they try to carry out international obligations (M)

headline: LAND O'LAKES TO BUY ALPINE LACE BRANDS IN NEW JERSEY
abstract: Land O'Lakes Inc agrees to acquire Alpine Lace Brands Inc for $62 million (S)

headline: Gates Is Defensive on U.S. Antitrust Action
abstract: Microsoft Corp's chairman William H Gates says no magic antitrust line divides Microsoft's market-dominating Windows 95 software operating system from competitors' programs; Gates is on defensive in wake of Justice Department's petitioning a Federal court to bar Microsoft from requiring personal computer makers to include its Internet browser software when they install its Windows 95 operating system (L)

headline: U.S. Braces for Wider Trade Gaps and New Confrontations
abstract: Asian economic crisis seen having profound economic and political implications for the United States trade deficit; some American workers could lose their jobs, and employers may feel pressure to hold down wages; reverse side is that flood of cheap imports could help hold down US inflation rate and eliminate need for higher interest rates; graph on US trade deficit with Pacific Rim countries and overall trade deficit, 1992-1997 (M)

headline: Treasury Securities Fall in Price
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities fall as stocks gain on upbeat news from Korea over weekend; 30-year bond falls 21/32, to 102 6/32, with yield rising to 5.97 percent from 5.92 percent (M)

headline: Health Giant Says Earnings Fell Sharply
abstract: Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp says its earnings in third quarter were $97 million, compared with $311 million in year-earlier quarter, while revenue was $4.6 billion, unchanged from last year; much of 57-percent drop is associated with discontinuation of certain company operations in wake of widespread criminal investigation of some of company's business practices (M)

headline: Daimler Plans Switch To Euro in 1999
abstract: Daimler-Benz will adopt the euro as its corporate currency on Jan 1, 1999, becoming one of first German companies to switch to single European currency (S)

headline: Over the Din of New Media, a Voice for the Audio Arts
abstract: Interview with Elizabeth Cohen, president of Audio Engineering Society, on her drive to gain more attention and respect for sound technology in movies, television, computers, recording industry and elsewhere; Cohen is group's first female president, bringing unique perspective to field in which women are drastically outnumbered; table; photo (M)

headline: Japanese Stocks Bounce Back Day After Trading Was Curbed
abstract: Japan's long-suffering stock market enjoys rebound, sharing some of relief Wall Street experienced on Oct 28; Nikkei stock average rises 3.46 percent, gaiing 564.93, to close at 16,887.62 in Oct 29 morning session (M)

headline: REPUBLIC INDUSTRIES TO ACQUIRE GEORGIA DEALERSHIPS
abstract: Republic Industries says it will buy Sutherlin Automotive Management; terms not disclosed (S)

headline: In Brazzaville, a Triumphant Rebel Mocks His Ousted Enemy
abstract: Gen Denis Sassou-Nguesso declares himself victorious in Congo Republic's five-month civil war and mocks Pres Pascal Lissouba, whom he has just defeated (M)

headline: Emerging Markets' Slump Taking Toll on U.S. Banks
abstract: Slump in emerging markets is taking its toll on US banks; there is continued unease about continued exposure of large US banks to economic woes in Latin America and Asia; such uncertainty has dealt body blows to bank stocks over last few weeks and plummeling continued on Nov 12 (L)

headline: Mutual Insurers' Plans Gain a Formidable Foe
abstract: American International Group has entered fray on side of consumer advocates battling drive by some of largest mutual insurance companies to overhaul their corporate structures; AIG's clout could alter dynamics of debate over mutual insurers' efforts in state legislatures to ease curbs on their ability to convert to public stock ownership; at issue is insurers' desire to convert without distributing accumulated profits to policyholders (M)

headline: Wall St. Firms Weigh Video-Web Link
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co and two Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Co units reportedly near accords to have MSNBC Business Video provide video feeds for their Web sites (S)

headline: Pictures Speak Much Louder Than Words in Courtroom Animations
abstract: Computer graphics and animation have moved to fact-based world of investigations, forensic science and civil and criminal trials; evidentiary re-enactments are flooding courtrooms, and influence they have on jury is thought to be one of most persuasive tools available to trial lawyers; as technology becomes cheaper and more lawyers become familiar with such presentations, more visual consulting concerns are springing up; fully orchestrated courtroom presentations and original animations can cost hundreds of thousands of dollars, but some enterprising graphics companies have developed generic animations that can cost only few hundred dollars; American Bar Assn survey found 53.4 percent of large law firms say they use graphics as evidence or trial exhibits; photos (M)

headline: Striking State Workers Tightening Their Grip on Israelis
abstract: Three-day strike by public-sector workers disrupts lives of Israelis and is expected to widen on Dec 7 despite expected court order to union leaders to honor back-to-work orders; Histadrut labor federation halts strike for Sabbath; most serious problem is virtual halt of flights in and out of Israel, stranding thousands of passengers at Ben-Gurion Airport and preventing thousands more from coming to Israel; photo (M)

headline: ITEQ IN DEAL FOR MATRIX, AN OILFIELD SERVICES COMPANY
abstract: Iteq Inc says it agreed to buy Matrix Service Co for about $95 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: Terms of Bailout Vague on How Reluctant Koreans Will Enforce It
abstract: International Monetary Fund deal to bail out South Korea contains vague provisions that are raising doubts about how it will be enforced; presidential candidate Kim Dae Jung says he might renegotiate deal, reversing earlier pledge to honor it; pressure is building for prosecution of Government officials deemed to have mismanaged economy; Halla Group, nation's 12th-largest conglomerate, is declared insolvent by its main creditor, Korea Exchange Bank, and seeks bankruptcy protection for two units (M)

headline: U.S. Quarterly Refunding Is Set This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week features today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and the Treasury's quarterly debt refunding over three days. The refunding begins tomorrow with the sale of $14 billion of three-year notes, followed on Wednesday by $11 billion of 10-year notes and Thursday with the sale of $10 billion of 30-year bonds, accompanied by a $12 billion sale of 52-week bills.    At the close of the New York cash market on Friday the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.05 percent, the rate on the six-month issue was 5.09 percent, and the rate on a 52-week bill was 5.07 percent. In when-issued trading the three-year note was offered at a price to yield 5.66 percent, the 10-year note at 5.84 percent and the 30-year bond at 6.11 percent.

headline: For the Feel of Hanoi, Go With the Urban Cyclist Flow
abstract: HANOIâ€”  One of the great sights of Vietnam is guaranteed to disappear within a few years. Go any morning or evening to any major intersection in central Hanoi, a city of roughly three million people, and you will see thousands of bicycles plying their way to and from work and school.

headline: 'Red Scrub' Enjoys a Revival
abstract: TOKYOâ€”  Beauty treatment fads come and go in Japan like the seasons: with heady fanfare when they arrive and barely a whisper when the next one overtakes them. This decade alone, Indian and Thai massage, and a plethora of other treatments have come and been and slipped away.

headline: Geraldo Accepts Fox Offer, But NBC Vows to Match It
abstract: Geraldo Rivera, host of most popular interview program on cable network CNBC and longtime host of syndicated talk show, accepts offer to jump to Fox News network as host of both nightly newscast and interview program; top executives at NBC, which owns CNBC, say they will try to keep Rivera by fashioning matching offer to give Rivera much more exposure on NBC, possibly including NBC News programs (L)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 4/   The United States Mint started selling platinum coins just in time for investors to buy into the top of the market. By Jonathan Fuerbringer.    MUTUAL FUNDS /Page 6/   Performance data are a lagging indicator. Smart investors will look at a fund's fundamentals before deciding to buy.  By Kenneth N. Gilpin.

headline: Hong Kong to Inspect Mainland Farms for Bird-Flu Virus
abstract: Hong Kong officials say chickens imported from mainland China are probable source of bird-flu outbreak that has left four people dead; extend ban on chickens from mainland for at least several more weeks until elaborate new inspection system is installed to screen them (M)

headline: Accord Near On Atom Sales To the Chinese
abstract: US and China are reported very close to agreement for US companies to sell billions of dollars worth of civilian nuclear power plants to China, if China phases out nuclear cooperation with Iran; American officials hope agreement will be ready when Pres Clinton meets with Pres Jiang Zemin in Washington (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: -- Proscape Technologies Inc., Fort Washington, Pa., to Lois/EJL, New York, part of Lois/USA, as the first agency to handle advertising for Salesgod, a customized software program. Billings were estimated at more than $3 million.

headline: GALEY & LORD TO BUY FABRIC BUSINESSES FOR $480 MILLION
abstract: Galey & Lord Inc to buy from Polymer Group Inc for about $480 million denim and fabric businesses Polymer does not want from its acquisition of Dominion Textile Inc (S)

headline: In Alan We Trust. So Why Own Gold?
abstract: Faith in ability of Federal Reserve Chmn Alan Greenspan and other central bankers to curb inflation discussed as key factor in sharp drop in gold prices; graph (M)

headline: Fuji Bank Plans to Cut Assets by 4 Trillion Yen
abstract: Fuji Bank Ltd, one of Japan's 10 biggest commercial banks, says it will cut its assets by 4 trillion yen, or about $33 billion, in next two years to improve its return on equity (S)

headline: Cuba Buries Che, the Man, but Keeps the Myth Alive
abstract: Remains of Che Guevara, Cuban revolutionary, are buried in provincial capital of Santa Clara, where he is praised by Pres Fidel Castro as 'paradigm' of revolutionary; ceremony caps seven days of official mourning that began immediately after close of Communist Party Congress, at which he was repeatedly cited as example of sacrifice and discipline; map; photo (M)

headline: Monsanto Joint Venture
abstract: Monsanto Co and Empresas La Moderna SA agree to invest $30 million in Mendel Biotechnology Inc, in bid to accelerate their development of genetically enhanced plants (S)

headline: The Enemy Within
abstract: News analysis of Nigerian dictator Sani Abacha's arrest of aides after reoirted coup attempt; incident, seven months before long-promised return to democratic rule, underscores instability of Africa's most populous country, and adds to doubts about shaky transition program; those arrested include Abacha's second-in-command, Gen Oladipu Diya (S)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Pharmavite Corp., Mission Hills, Calif., to the Leo Burnett Co., Chicago, to handle advertising for the Nature's Resource line of herbs, which had been handled by Deerfield Corp., Ventura, Calif., and the Los Angeles office of Foote, Cone & Belding unit of True North Communications. Burnett already handles advertising for Pharmavite's Nature Made vitamins. Billings were not disclosed.

headline: Frank Graziano, 79, Former Crompton Chairman
abstract: Frank J Graziano, former chairman and chief executive of Crompton & Knowles Corporation, dies at age 79 (S)

headline: Point for True North In Publicis Battle
abstract: Executives of True North Communications obtain preliminary injunction from Federal District Court that blocks efforts by former partner, Publicis SA, to prevent True North from proceeding with plans to acquire Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt; Publicis says it will comply with terms of injunction but will seek emergency appeal and stay (M)

headline: VIEWPOINT; Why Asia's Tigers Will Roar Again
abstract: Article by Burton G Malkiel, Chemical Bank Chairman's Professor of Economics at Princeton and J P Mei, Prof at New York University, notes economic turmoil in Asia has led many investors to question wisdon of long-term investment in emerging markets; maintains, however, that while crisis will cause some structural adjustments in economies of Hong Kong, South Korea, Singapore and Taiwan, it does not affect their fundamental strengths; notes that even pessimists project that long-term growth rates in these economies, while slower than in recent past, will remain at least double those in developed world (M)

headline: Clinton and Allies Fall Short, Again Delaying a Trade Vote
abstract: Pres Clinton and Republican allies delay for second time House vote on measure to give fast-track authority to negotiate international trade deals after weekend of frenetic lobbying fails to produce needed support opponents of President, predominantly Democrats, predict they will prevail; Speaker Newt Gingrich expresses guarded optimism; holds open possibility of pulling legislation from floor if measure seems destined to fail; photos (M)

headline: Serb's Iron Rule: Belgrade Power Play May Light Fuse
abstract: Analysis: Pres Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia, in second and final round of presidential elections, hopes to consolidate his hold on power into next century despite profound fissures in his authoritarian edifice; vote for Presidents of Serbia and Montenegro will complete his metamorphosis from Serbian President, where he was barred from serving third term, to Yugoslav President (M)

headline: Walter James Levy, 86, Oil Consultant, Dies
abstract: Walter James Levy, New York-based oil consultant who was considered the dean of United States oil economists, dies at age 86 (S)

headline: DIARY
abstract: THE ECONOMY  Another Decline In Unemployment  Unemployment tumbled to a 24-year low amid brisk hiring in October, the Labor Department reported. ''It's a sign of a tremendously strong U.S. economy,'' said Allen Sinai, president of Primark Decision Economics of Boston. The rate fell two-tenths of a percentage point, to 4.7 percent, the lowest since 4.6 percent in October 1973. Most other data also pointed to a robust economy. Retailers reported unexpectedly strong October sales, underscoring the importance of Halloween goods; the Goldman Sachs retail composite index climbed 4.5 percent. The National Association of Purchasing Management reported that manufacturing unexpectedly strengthened in October, and the Conference Board said its index of leading indicators rose two-tenths of a percent in September. Also, personal incomes rose four-tenths of a percent in September, while factory orders rose for the fourth consecutive month. Demand for metals and high technology paced the gain of four-tenths of a percent. Construction spending fell unexpectedly in September, however, posting its biggest drop in almost a year, 1.1 percent.    MARKETS  A Rocky Recovery  Like many convalescents, the stock market had some good days and some bad ones. After being battered the previous week, the Dow Jones industrial average soared 232 points on Monday. By Friday, investors were selling -- reacting, again, to the uncertainties in Southeast Asia, as well as to the specter of inflation raised by the strong jobs data. The blue-chip average ended the week at 7,581.32, up 139.24 for the week. The Nasdaq composite index was up 8.79 at 1,602.40. . . . The New York Stock Exchange plans to drop its controversial rule No. 500, which makes it nearly impossible for a listed company to move to another market voluntarily. Nasdaq officials have long cited it, warning potential defectors that if they went to the Big Board, there would be no turning back.    TAXES  Vox Populi Is Heard  Were L. L. Bean's flannel shirts about to join the tea in Boston Harbor? Their phone lines jammed by angry consumers, mail order companies backed away from an agreement that the Direct Marketing Association had reached with state tax authorities to collect sales taxes. . . . Nor are Federal taxes any more welcome. The House voted by an overwhelming 426 to 4 to rein in the Internal Revenue Service, giving taxpayers new rights and authorizing the creation of a new board made up largely of private citizens to oversee the tax collectors. ''The I.R.S. is too big and too mean,'' said Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader. The agency is also getting a new boss, who has promised to tame it, as well as to rejuvenate its arthritic computers. The Senate confirmed Charles O. Rossotti, co-founder of American Management Systems, a computer systems and consulting company, as commissioner.    COMPANIES  Levi's Cutoffs  It's not that people finally have enough jeans. It's a matter of competing while paying American workers. Levi Strauss said it would cut a third of its American manufacturing jobs, affecting 6,395 workers and closing 11 factories in four states. But it promised a generous severance package. . . . City officials halted work on Donald J. Trump's $3 billion Riverside South project in Manhattan, below, because of defective concrete. Mr. Trump said the subcontractor that poured it, Laquila/Pinnacle, would have to bear the resultant costs. . . . AT&T is cutting to 3 from 33 the number of long-distance rates paid by residential customers who do not subscribe to a special calling plan. . . . General Electric is cashing in its 13 percent stake in Lockheed Martin for $2.8 billion. . . . Boeing plans to phase out the MD-80 and the MD-90, civilian jets that compete with its 737. Boeing inherited the planes when it acquired McDonnell Douglas.    DEALS  Gambling on ITT  Hilton Hotels raised its hostile bid for control of ITT, only to be countered on Friday with a sweetened offer from Starwood Lodging Trust. Shareholders are to meet on Wednesday. . . . The Justice Department recommended that BellSouth not be allowed to offer long-distance service in South Carolina. . . . Microsoft is close to an agreement to invest up to $1 billion in the cable television operations of U S West, according to several people involved in the negotiations.     PRICES  Ceilings Are Legal  Consumers can shop for that hot new car with less fear of having to pay a premium. The Supreme Court, in one of its most important antitrust decisions in years, ruled unanimously that a manufacturer or supplier does not necessarily violate Federal antitrust law by placing a ceiling on the retail price a dealer can charge for its products. The decision was widely welcomed by manufacturers, notably those in the auto and computer industries, who said it could lead to lower consumer prices. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor noted that it remained illegal for manufacturers to impose minimum prices on dealers.

headline: True North Pushes Fight With Publicis
abstract: Developments in takeover and legal battles between True North Communications and Publicis SA concerning True North's proposed acquisition of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt discussed(S)

headline: A Clinton adviser argues the economic case for self-regulation of sales pitches in cyberspace.
abstract: Ira C Magaziner, Clinton Administration's point person on Internet issues, is lobbying Madison Avenue to help insure that policy providing for self-regulation of cyberspace withstands strong, sustained challenges; Magaziner is advocate for self-regulation instead of government intervention; Magaziner claims he is concerned about government stepping in and overregulating, overtaxing and overcensoring Internet and strangling development (M)

headline: For Malaysia, Can One 'National Card' Do It All?
abstract: KUALA LUMPURâ€”  If the Malaysian government has its way, every person over 12 years old in this country of 20 million will soon have a piece of silicon in his pocket.

headline: Microsoft's Legal Problems Grow As States Join in Antitrust Effort
abstract: Attorneys general from some of most populous states met secretly in Chicago last week to assess their own strategy for possible antitrust action against computer software giant Microsoft Corp; have not disclosed which states are involved and which of Microsoft's business practices they want to remedy; California, Connecticut, Massachusetts and Oregon have each opened own probes and Texas is already suing company (M)

headline: CEDAR FAIR PLANS TO BUY KNOTT'S BERRY FARM THEME PARK
abstract: Cedar Fair LP will buy Knott's Berry Farm for undisclosed amount of cash and units, giving company its first year-round theme park and added protection from impact of bad weather on earnings (S)

headline: At a Swiss Airport, 36 Dead, Home From Luxor
abstract: Bodies of 36 tourists from Switzerland killed in terrorist massacre, Luxor, Egypt, are flown home; incident shocks Swiss, who see their passport as badge of nation's neutrality (M)

headline: Kish Journal; Island of Shocking Lyrics in a Sea of Disapproval
abstract: Kish, Iranian island, lures Iranian tourists by allowing live performance of popular music, banned elsewhere in nation, and other limited freedoms, along with duty-free shopping; photos; map (M)

headline: Japan's Chief Placates Foe Of Bank Plan
abstract: Japan's Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto tries to persuade skeptics of virtues of a plan to raise $77 billion (US) in life support for Japanese banking system; Koichi Kato, General Secretary of ruling Liberal Democratic Party, abandons his opposition to program after Hashimoto promises that none of money will be used for tax cut or some other economic stimulant that violates party's pledge of fiscal austerity (M)

headline: UNIVERSAL HEALTH SERVICES TO EXPAND INTO PUERTO RICO
abstract: Universal Health Services Inc to acquire Hospital San Pablo Inc and chain of hospitals owned by that company; deal is valued at $100 million (S)

headline: Poor Nations Reject Role on Warming
abstract: Poor nations attending world convention on global warming in Kyoto argue that cost and fairness dictate that they should not bear onus of reducing emission of greenhouse gases; Clinton Administration has warned that it will not submit accord on emission reductions to Senate unless developing countries agree to do more (M)

headline: Court Blocks Deal For Alarm Business
abstract: Federal appeals court blocks Ameritech Corp's purchase of assets of Circuit City Stores Inc's alarm systems division, striking down Federal Communications Commission ruling that would have allowed acquisition; last year's telecommunications law bars regional Bells and their subsidiaries from acquiring 'any equity interest in or financial control of, any unaffiliated alarm monitoring service entity' for five years (S)

headline: Stocks Surge As Fears Ebb About Asia
abstract: Sense that Japanese and Southeast Asian officials are moving quickly to address financial problems in their economies fuels rally in stocks around world, pushing Dow Jones industrial average up 2.4 percent to above 8,000-point level for first time in more than month; Asian and European markets are strengthened by reports that Japanese Govt is ready to inject public funds to thwart widespread financial crisis (M)

headline: SPECIALTY FOODS TO SELL ITS CHEESE UNIT FOR $405 MILLION
abstract: Specialty Foods Corp agrees to sell its cheese subsidiary, Stella Foods Inc, for $405 million to Saputo Group Inc (S)

headline: Trading Curbs Little Changed By Big Board
abstract: New York Stock Exchange backs away from making radical change in its circuit breakers, which halt trading when prices plunge; it proposes only minor changes but promises big ones early next year; only significant changes adopted are aimed at insuring that if circuit breakers are invoked, stock exchange would either not open at all later in the day or would open for at least 30 minutes; exchanges that trade options and other securities whose prices depend on stock prices say they would need at least 30 minutes of trading to allow their markets to react and set reasonable prices for their securities (L)

headline: Global Crisis in Population Is Far From Over, a Group Warns
abstract: Population Institute, liberal population-watch group, warns that global population crisis is far from over; seeks to dispel recent reports that population explosion is slowing and that next demographic crisis is actually declining birth rates in many developed nations (M)

headline: A major force in marketing to college students steps up its activities on the Internet.
abstract: Student Advantage LLC, which offers discounts to students through membership card program, is forming network of World Wide Web sites meant to appeal to college students; AT&T Corp is offering to pay annual Student Advantage fee for new long-distance, calling card or credit card customers (M)

headline: U.S. Says It Is Prepared To Use Force on Iraq
abstract: Clinton Administration, signaling growing frustration with diplomatic efforts, makes clear United States is prepared to retaliate with force if Iraqi Pres Saddam Hussein continues to defy United Nations; Defense Sec William S Cohen, emerging as Administration's strongest voice for retaliation, raises possibility of military strike, television interview; US has yet to put its forces in region on heightened state of alert (M)

headline: A Defiant Iraq Bars Entry To 3 U.S. Arms Inspectors
abstract: Iraq bars three American arms inspectors from entering country, ignoring threats of retaliation from US; Pres Saddam Hussein acts only hours after Security Council unanimously warned Iraq not to make good on its threat to throw out all Americans working for United Nations in Iraq (M)

headline: Malaysian Premier Sees Jews Behind Nation's Money Crisis
abstract: Malaysian Prime Min Mahathir Mohamad, facing economic crisis and plunge in value of currency, has unleashed series of verbal attacks on everyone from Jews to currency traders to unidentified 'sinister powers;' statements seem only to have heightened air of crisis (M)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY    Columbus Day. Stock markets are open, but the bond market, most government offices and many businesses are closed.    TUESDAY    Mitsubishi Bank/Schroder Wertheim and LJR Redbook Research report on weekly retail sales.

headline: Toy Makers To Sponsor Design Lab At M.I.T.
abstract: Massachusetts Institute of Technology Media Lab to announce that toy and entertainment companies--Hasbro, Mattel, Walt Disney and Lego--will underwrite five-year research project to design toys; research effort, called Toys of Tommorrow, will receive initial financing from companies, aiming for initial annual budget of $2 million to $4 million (M)

headline: Shaky Asia, New Shivers
abstract: Economic crisis sweeping through Asia raises question of whether United States's Asian partners may be weakened for several years, requiring US strategy shift; Pres Clinton's aides acknowledge risk that economic turmoil could lead to political fragility (M)

headline: Nextel Purchases 475 Phone Licenses
abstract: Nextel Communications Inc wins 475 US wireless phone licenses for $89 million, dominating auction of 525 licenses that ended on Dec 8 (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.75   5.44   5.15        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.16   5.11   5.03        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.16   5.12   5.07        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.52   3.53   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   5.83   5.86   6.19        30-YR. TREAS. headline: Brokers Making Amends for Trading Problems
abstract: Investors apparently will not end up shortchanged because of problems that stock-trading systems encountered handling last week's huge surge in volume; Merrill Lynch has said it will spend up to $10 million making investors whole for trades that were not executed promptly last week, and Fidelity Brokerage Services has said that it will adjust customer accounts, paying out up to $1 million because of problems with trades; Smith Barney, Prudential Securities and Charles Schwab & Co have made similar commitments to customers who placed orders that were delayed in execution last week (L)

headline: In MCI-Worldcom Theory, New View of Competition
abstract: Analysis of Worldcom Inc's proposed $36.5 billion takeover of MCI Communications Corp; says conventional wisdom emerging within telecommunications industry is that consolidation is good for competition; holds to some politicians and regulators, this deal-making has perverted purpose of Telecommunications Act of 1996, which was to create new choices in communications as many big companies battled head to head, with consumers picking the winners and enjoying lower prices (L)

headline: Technology Issues Lead Stocks Higher
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 13.18 points, or two-tenths of 1 percent, to 8,032.01; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 5.09, or half of 1 percent, to 976.77; Nasdaq composite index rises 8.76 points, or six-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,615.13 (M)

headline: Honors
abstract: * Wendy Riches, chairwoman for North America at Ogilvy One Worldwide, New York, part of the Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide unit of WPP Group, was named general chairwoman of the 33d annual Direct Marketing Days in New York, to be held June 1-3, 1998.

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Oct 12 article on increased popularity of cremation in US; article misstated affiliation of Wilson H Beebe Jr, who noted percentage of bodies cremated annually in New York area; he is executive director of Metropolitan Funeral Directors Association, not Cremation Association of North Americat

headline: John Stevenson, 76, Delegate To Law of the Sea Conference
abstract: John Reese Stevenson, international lawyer who represented United States at Law of the Sea Conference in 1970's and served as board president of National Gallery of Art until 1993, dies at age 76; photo (M)

headline: Little Panel That Could, Did, Posing Threat of Trade War
abstract: Federal Maritime Commission, which wielded considerable though little-known authority to bar Japanese cargo ships from American ports and to levy $4 million in fines on Japanese shipping companies, was slated for abolition by Republicans in budget battles two years ago on grounds it had outlived its usefulness; drastic step, which caught White House and other agencies unprepared and could have started trade war, reflects growing frustration with inability of diplomats to resolve longstanding dispute with Japan over better access for American ships to Japanese ports; agency, established in 1961, oversees web of statutes and laws regulating nation's ports and shipping industries, and regulates seaborne commerce to and from US, which totals more than $500 billion annually; photo (M)

headline: Updates/Media and Technology; Infoseek Revises Its Internet Search Engine
abstract: So-called search engines--Yahoo, Infoseek, Excite, Lycos and others--attract more people to Web than any other category of sites; these companies are eager to establish brand-name identities in hopes of attracting loyal audience they can sell to advertisers (S)

headline: Clinton Conditionally Supports U.S. Role in Bailout
abstract: Pres Clinton says that United States is prepared to contribute to bailout of South Korea, but only if South Korean Govt agrees to kind of painful economic changes being demanded by International Monetary Fund (M)

headline: New U.N. Estimate Doubles Rate of Spread of AIDS Virus
abstract: Medical experts working for United Nations say they grossly underestimated spread of AIDS virus worldwide, and they now believe that new infections are occurring almost twice as fast as they thought year ago; instead of 8,200 new infections a day, they now believe there are 16,000; table shows revised estimates of AIDS cases in various regions (M)

headline: Louis Loss, 83, Dies; Harvard Professor Defined and Interpreted Field of Securities Law
abstract: Louis Loss, professor of law at Harvard University who was widely viewed as father of securities law, dies at age 83; photo (M)

headline: Cuba's Communists Likely to Hold Line
abstract: Cuba's Communist Party will hold its first congress in six years on Oct 8; little change is expected on vital political and economic issues during three-day meeting in Havana (M)

headline: Seoul Tries to Calm Feelings; Brokerage Goes Under : Increasing Anger With West
abstract: SEOULâ€”  The South Korean government fought to head off anti-Western sentiment on Friday as its stock market hit a record low.

headline: As MCI Fight Grows, the Wall St. Entourage Builds
abstract: Growing multibillion-dollar struggle to acquire MCI Communications Corp highlights feeding frenzy in telecommunications industry for investment bankers and lawyers, those profit-hungry advisers who counsel both sides of merger; as British Telecommunications, Worldcom and GTE Corp all vie to spend tens of billions of dollars to buy MCI, a growing list of Wall Street's finest financiers and lawyers have turned up in the deals (L)

headline: Kimberly-Clark to Dismiss 5,000 Workers and Eliminate 18 Plants
abstract: Kimberly-Clark Corp, whose paper products such as Kleenex tissue and Scott paper goods face pricing pressure and stiffer competition, particularly in Europe, announces it will dismiss about 5,000 workers and sell or close as many as 18 plants; company will take fourth-quarter charge of $590 million; says plan will save $200 million a year by 2000 (M)

headline: Ex-Morgan Trainee Admits Stock Fraud
abstract: Roy Handojo, former analyst trainee at J P Morgan & Co, pleads guilty to insider trading in stocks of four banks that were takeover targets (S)

headline: WPP Buying Stake In Singapore Agency
abstract: WPP Group PLC will make initial cash payment of $4.6 million for 37.3 percent share in Batey Holdings in Singapore (S)

headline: Will Moscow's Gain Be a Loss For Investors?
abstract: Lexington Troika Dialog Russia has been best performer among all mutual funds in US for much of 1997, gaining more than 130 percent; outlook for shareholder, however, remains uncertain since Trokia Dialog will be sold early in 1998 to Bank of Moscow, whose majority owner is Moscow municipal Government; fund is currently managed by Troika Dialog Asset Management and New Jersey-based Lexington Management Corp; photo; graphs (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY   None

headline: Dollar Up vs. Yen on Doubts About Japan's Overhaul Plan
abstract: Currency Markets column; dollar surges to its highest level in five and half years against yen on speculation that Japan might not do enough to bail out ailing banks and securities firms (S)

headline: A Family's Hard-Candy Lessons
abstract: Relationship between John Osher, who owns Cap Toys Inc, and his stepson, Jay Tapper, who started Tapper Candies Inc to compete with candy division he built at Cap Toys, discussed as representative of psychological contests and day-to-day challenges that beset family businesses; both companies specialize in interactive candy, which combines toys and treats; table; photos; drawing (L)

headline: Merger in Switzerland Creates a Star in Chicago
abstract: Brison Partners, investment management firm, is likely to move into an echelon dominated by far larger companies such as Fidelity Investments and Merrill Lynch as result of recent merger of Swiss Bank Corp and Union Bank of Switzerland; Brison Partners, acquired by Swiss Bank two years ago, is slated to offer investment advice to some of wealthiest clients of new, giant United Bank of Switzerland; firm's Gary P Brinson could soon be controlling close to $1 trillion--more than any asset manager in the world; his photo; biographical sketch (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Play by Play Toys and Novelties Inc., San Antonio, to Anda & Scotti Advertising, New York, to handle its account, previously handled by Ziccardi & Partners, New York. Billings were estimated at $5 million.

headline: Market Place; Investors cheated in an accounting-fraud case will be compensated, but only some of them.
abstract: Market Place column scores way Securities and Exchange Commission plans to distribute $1.78 million in insider trading fines from Amre Corp chief financial officer Robert Levin to defrauded Amre investors; holds decision to compensate only investors who bought shares on Mar 23, 1988, day Levin sold shares, and to treat stock splits as irrelevant are unfair to some investors (M)

headline: In Latin America, Exchanges Follow the Dow Down, Down, Down
abstract: Stock prices plummet on exchanges all across Latin America as global investors, panicked by tumbling markets on Wall Street and in Asia, withdraw funds and local investors follow suit; in Mexico, market plunge is largest in 10 years and sixth biggesst in history of Mexican exchange (M)

headline: Dominicans Face Strike As Hardship Fans Unrest
abstract: Coalition of union and student groups in Dominican Republic, dissatisfied with what they describe as Government's inability to improve living conditions and its unwillingness to negotiate with them, has called two-day general strike next week that Pres Leonel Fernandez Reyna is treating as biggest threat to stability he has faced during his 15 months in office; at least dozen people have been killed, scores more injured, and hundreds arrested as result of wave of disturbances that has erupted in over dozen towns since protests began earlier this year (M)

headline: MARKET WATCH ; Panic Fighters Need a New J. P. Morgan
abstract: Floyd Norris column holds financial rescue plan for South Korea should determine what parts of Korean private sector are fundamentally sound; says hopelessly weak banks and companies should be allowed to fail, with international banks that lent to them suffering losses; opposes proposal for Korean Government to take over international debts of sick banks; graph (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent              Previous   Year       Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.44   5.45   5.26        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.21   5.31   4.94        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.24   5.27   5.05        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.64   3.64   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   5.74   5.69   6.33        30-YR. TREAS.
