headline: LORAL SPACE TO ACQUIRE ORION FOR $490 MILLION
abstract: Loral Space and Communications Ltd agrees to buy Orion Network Systems Inc for about $490 million in stock (S)

headline: Philadelphia Inquirer Names New Editor
abstract: Philadelphia Inquirer names Robert J Rosenthal as its next editor, succeeding Maxwell E P King, who will become editorial writer; Rosenthal will also be executive vice president of parent Philadelphia Newspapers Inc; William Ward will succeed him as executive editor (M)

headline: Gulf Alliance: A Falling Out
abstract: Analysis of shift in Arab coalition that helped oust Iraq from Kuwait during Persian Gulf war; same Arab governments that rushed troops to Saudi Arabia during war now oppose use of military might in US dispute with Iraq over arms inspections; renewed sense of Arab solidarity toward Iraq reflects feeling that basic understandings have been broken in US ties with Arabs since war (M)

headline: Baghdad Threatens to Withdraw Cooperation From U.N. on Arms
abstract: Iraq warns United Nations that if Security Council imposes any further sanctions on country it will stop cooperating with inspectors monitoring destruction of prohibited weapons (M)

headline: Pols as Stars
abstract: Comment on rejection by Federal judge of efforts by Mayor Rudolph Giuliani to remove New York Magazine ads poking fun at him from city buses, and on participation of former Russian Pres Mikhail Gorbachev in commercial for Pizza Hut with granddaughter; photo (S)

headline: The Fight In Mexico Over Big Oil
abstract: Interview with Joaquin Hernandez Galicia, leader of corrupt Mexican Petroleum Workers Union imprisoned for allegedly murdering federal agent in 1989; he is listed as prisoner of conscience by Amnesty International, which says he is innocent of charges and was jailed because of criticisms of Government's plan to sell off petroleum industry (M)

headline: Robert H. O'Brien, 93, MGM President in 60's
abstract: Robert H O'Brien, early member of SEC who later presided over Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer film studio in 1960's, dies at 93; photo (M)

headline: New Ad Themes Come With Tumult in Market
abstract: Financial services advertisers are reassessing their sales pitches after stock market's wild swings; some are changing how they talk to customers and potential customers, while others are sticking with their campaigns (M)

headline: Anatomy of a Bid: Less From GTE May Mean More
abstract: Analysis of takeover battle for MCI Communications; GTE says it would pay $40 a share to take over MCI, lower than Worldcom Inc's $41.50 a share but perhaps better for MCI shareholders, since GTE is offering cash and Worldcom is offering its stock; to win battle, GTE may have to sweeten price or convince MCI shareholders that Worldcom stock is not worth its current price; Worldcom stock lost 5 percent of its value over last week; graphs (M)

headline: Three States Investigating Sales Practices of Met Life
abstract: Metropolitan Life Insurance Co, nation's second-largest insurer, is being investigated by states of Florida, Texas and Massachusetts over its sales practices; company allegedly misled tens of thousands of life insurance customers, increasing costs of their coverage and promising benefits that many never got; investigations were launched as policyholders in several states filed suits against company; lawyers say case rivals recently settled one against Prudential Insurance Co of America; settlement of that case might cost company up to $2 billion; Lawrence A Vranka, Met Life vice president, says he is confident there was no widespread improper activity in his company (M)

headline: FRONTIER ACQUIRES MEDICAL MALPRACTICE BUSINESS
abstract: Frontier Insurance Group Inc will acquire Western Indemnity Corp for $48.5 million to bolster its medical malpractice insurance business; Frontier is owned by Galtney Group Inc (S)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  RISKIN, JACK
abstract: RISKIN-Jack. Jack, I will miss you, a great friend that I trusted impeccably. Andrew    RISKIN-Jeffrey Jack, 37. Of Teaneck, New Jersey. Beloved husband of Teresa, devoted father of Nathan, Zachary, and Naomi, cherished son of Beverly Goldberg of Ossining, and Sidney Riskin of Tarrytown, caring brother of Cynthia Riskin of Redmond, WA. Graveside service at 11:30 A.M., on Friday, October 24th, at Sharon Gardens Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. A memorial service to be announced. For information: Plaza Memorial Chapel, 1-800-227-3974.

headline: Old Man Bandwidth; Will Commerce Flourish Where Rivers of Wire Converge?
abstract: Article on Palo Alto, Calif, which, with its high capacity fiber optics network, hopes to attract industries that demand large amounts of internet bandwidth; fiber optics strands make up 15-mile long ring that snakes beneath city and culminates in Digital Equipment Corp's Internet exchange; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Auto Makers Offering Rebates as Sales Slump  The car industry saw a sales decline of 3.8 percent in September, as two of the Big Three auto makers reported their monthly results yesterday. General Motors said its sales increased 3.7 percent, while Ford Motor said sales slid 1.5 percent.

headline: INTERNATIONAL TELECOMMUNICATION BUYING TRIS UNIT
abstract: International Telecommunication Data Systems Inc will acquire Tris cellular telephone unit from Computer Sciences Corp for $100 million (S)

headline: SHARES OF SPECTRIAN PLUMMET BY 37%
abstract: Stock of Spectrian Corp plummets 37 percent after company says it expects lower sales to its most important customer, Northern Telecom Ltd (S)

headline: Taking In the Sites; Contests Galore on the Web, but Sales Pitches, Too
abstract: World Wide Web offers access to hundreds of contests of all kinds, including trivia quizzes, giveaways, lotteries, essay contests, raffles and scavenger hunts (M)

headline: Israeli-Palestinian Talks Get Off to a Shaky Start in Washington
abstract: New Israeli-Palestinian peace talks begin in Washington, with little chance of quick accomplishments since key Palestinian officials failed to show up; American officials are annoyed that Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat sent high-level officials but had not included those with expertise needed to help resolve specific issues that have blocked progress for nearly year (M)

headline: Accounts Awarded To DDB Needham
abstract: DDB Needham Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group is awarded Van Kampen American Capital account and Hershey Chocolate USA account (S)

headline: In Repairing the I.R.S., Big and Many Benefits
abstract: Rep Bill Archer letter, disputing Nov 2 article, holds House bill to reform Internal Revenue Service would protect millions of taxpayers (S)Â¼

headline: More Haggling In Bozell Deal
abstract: True North Communications files countersuit and begins arbitration proceedings against its former partner, Publicis SA, as two agency companies continue to battle over plans by True North to acquire Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt (S)

headline: Crisis Over Conversions to Judaism Flares Anew in Israel
abstract: Leaders of Conservative and Reform movements of Judaism in Israel say they will press ahead with legal action, renewing confrontation with Israeli Orthodox rabbinate over much-debated issue of who is a Jew under religious law (M)

headline: A Korean Company Town Suffers as Steel Mill Fails
abstract: Many residents in Tangjin, Korea, a typical Korean town of 40,000 residents, are still in shock over collapse of nearby Hanbo Steel, nation's second-largest steelmaker; it is economic disaster, felt by almost everyone in Tangjin; many residents say they are finding it hard to accept notion that big companies as a way of life may be a thing of the past; map; photo (L)

headline: Boston Edison Is Selling Off 12 Plants for $657 Million
abstract: Boston Edison Co sells 12 of its 13 power plants for $657 million and says proceeds will help finance 15 percent rate reduction to its 650,000 customers starting in March; that is when Massachusetts will open its utilities to competition, giving consumers right to choose their suppliers of power; buyer of plants is Sithe Energies Inc, French-controlled power producer that operates in US and Canada; deal will leave Boston Edison with one plant, nuclear-powered site in Plymouth, Mass (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Europeans Move to Banish All Tobacco Ads by 2006   Europe's health ministers agreed to prohibit all forms of tobacco advertising during the next nine years, going far beyond restrictions now in force in the United States.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Perrier Group, Greenwich, Conn., owned by Nestle S.A., to McCann Direct, New York, part of the McCann-Erickson World Group unit of the Interpublic Group of Cos., as agency of record for relationship marketing for six regional domestic water brands, including Deer Park and Poland Springs, which had been handled by Wunderman Cato Johnson, New York, part of Young & Rubicam Inc. Billings were not disclosed.    * French Culinary Institute, New York, to Warren/Kremer/CMP Advertising, New York, to handle its account, which had been handled in-house. Billings were not disclosed.

headline: AMERICAN ELECTRIC AND CONOCO PLAN 2 JOINT VENTURES
abstract: American Electric Power Co and Conoco Inc announce agreement to form two joint venture companies to provide energy management and capital (S)

headline: A campaign draws attention to the accountability factor in measuring visits to Web sites.
abstract: Audit Bureau of Circulations launches first campaign in its history, urging advertisers and agencies to audit visits to World Wide Web sites that carry advertising (M)

headline: For Asians, A Primer On IMF Bailouts
abstract: LONDONâ€”  The sense of financial crisis in the country is pervasive. The currency is sliding with seemingly no bottom in sight. Investors worried about the country's mounting debts are refusing to buy government bonds. And the government itself is bitterly divided on whether to bow to the demands of the International Monetary Fund or try to go it alone by imposing protectionist controls on trade and capital movements.

headline: Former Partner of Milbank, Tweed Indicted
abstract: John G Gellene, former partner in law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, is indicted on charges of perjury in connection with 1994 bankruptcy of Bucyrus-Erie Co; action stems from 1988 leveraged buyout of Bucyrus-Erie, now Bucyrus International Inc (S)

headline: From a Wimp to a Kingmaker in Battle for MCI
abstract: Analysis of bids by Worldcom, GTE Corp and British Telecommunications for MCI Communications; holds prevailing wisdom on Wall Street was that British Telecom had little choice but to cut a deal with Worldcom until GTE made its unsolicited $28 billion bid; says British Telecom is emerging as potential kingmaker; holds British Telecom now is in position to play Worldcom off against GTE, enrich itself in the process, and perhaps pick eventual winner (L)

headline: Thai Crisis Causes King To 'Fall Ill'
abstract: BANGKOKâ€”  With Thailand mired in political uncertainty, King Bhumibol Adulyadej's physician said Thursday that the monarch had fallen ill due to his concerns about the situation.

headline: Housing Starts Were High In October
abstract: Commerce Department reports housing starts rose 1.4 percent in October to annual rate of 1.528 million; it revises upward September gain in housing starts to 8 percent; for first 10 months of year, housing starts totaled 1.256 million, about 1 percent below where they were at same time in 1996; graph (M)

headline: Fears of a Sale By Swiss Send Gold Plunging
abstract: Gold prices plunge to lowest level in more than 12 years after Swiss Government panel recommends that country sell about half its gold reserves, raising fears that other countries would do the same and inundate the market; spot price of gold in New York falls $14.65 an ounce, or 4.5 percent, to $309 an ounce; graph (L)

headline: Please Hold for Ms. Euphemism
abstract: You're on the phone, trying to complain to the company about that new gizmo you just bought. But the switchboard operator puts you on hold, asking you to wait to speak to ''the chairman's office.'' Or, if you're trying to obtain account information, you're told to wait for your ''personal care representatives.'' Companies come up with all kinds of confusing titles for the people you need to reach. What are these labels, and what do these workers really do? Send your best stores to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. Or sent them by E-mail to onthejob@nytimes.com. Include your telephone number. All submissions become the property of The Times and may be republished in any medium.

headline: Updates/Media; Miami Herald Pulls Sunday Magazine Over a Headline
abstract: Miami Herald decides not to distribute its weekly Tropic magazine in its Dec 21 issue after some newsroom staff members complained that headline accompanying photograph in the magazine was offensive; headline, which read 'No Mas,' ran beneath photo of funeral procession of Jorge Mas Canosa, leader of Cuban-American National Foundation and virulent opponent of Fidel Castro; in Spanish, 'no mas' means 'no more,' but can also be interpreted as 'Enough!' (S)

headline: Hilton Predicts Disappointing Earnings
abstract: Hilton Hotels Corp says its fourth-quarter operating earnings will be below analysts' expectations (S)

headline: A New Set of Killings Deepens Belgium's Darkness
abstract: Belgians are appalled as Andras Pandy, 71-year-old Protestant pastor, is arrested for murders of two former wives and four of his children, whose body parts have been found in cellar of his home in central Brussels; discovery comes a year after murders of four young girls by Marc Dutroux, convicted child rapist, and again raises questions about judiciary, police and Belgian state as whole (M)

headline: Canadian Court Ruling Broadens Indian Land Claims
abstract: Canadian Supreme Court rules that claims of native peoples to vast areas of Canadian territory--and natural resources they contain-- are far broader than current law recognizes even without written treaties, complicating concessions for mines, timber and other resources throughout country (M)

headline: ZEIGLER COAL TO RETAIN INVESTMENT FIRM TO EXPLORE SALE
abstract: Zeigler Coal Holding Co is in process of retaining unidentified investment banking firm to help it evaluate business alternatives, including a sale of the company (S)

headline: Sidelining Candidates Is Seen as Risky : Dane Sounds Warning Over EU Enlargement
abstract: BRUSSELSâ€”  Foreign Minister Niels Helveg Petersen of Denmark has warned that the European Union risks creating dangerous divisions by inviting only selected East and Central European countries to become members.

headline: British Parliament's First Muslim Is Accused of Election Fraud
abstract: Mohammad Sarwar, first Muslim member of British Parliament, is charged with electoral fraud and obstruction of justice, Glasgow; he denies charges; Labor Party suspended him from party activity in June (M)

headline: RICKEL HOME CENTERS PLANS STORE CLOSINGS AND LAYOFFS
abstract: Rickel Home Centers will close its 49 home improvement stores and cut 2,800 jobs in New Jersey, Pennsylvania, New York and Delaware because it has run out of cash after almost two years in Chapter 11 bankruptcy (S)

headline: A Prescription To Keep P.& G. Growing Strong; Big Household Name Tries To Be a Drugstore Hit, Too
abstract: Procter & Gamble Co, nation's leading producer of household products, is aggressively trying to move into prescription pharmaceuticals business, where profit margins for successful drugs can be more than double those for some its current products; P&G has huge presence on supermarket shelves, but it is barely known in doctors' offices and health insurance companies, and it lacks track record and product range to command credibility it would need in prescription drug business; despite this, P&G executives see opportunities in developing drugs for aging population; in drug industry, challenge in staying ahead of innovation curve underscores difficulty P&G will have reaping kind of returns it is counting on from its drug division; Wall Street has shown mixed reaction to P&G's new effort; photos; charts (L)

headline: First Foreigner to Lead Japanese Company Retires
abstract: Mazda Motor Corp says Henry D G Wallace, first foreigner to head a Japanese company, is retiring as president; James E Miller, Mazda executive vice president, will replace Wallace, whose contract is scheduled to expire in June; Miller, an American who had been groomed for top spot, is former marketing executive at Ford Motor Co, which owns 33.4 percent of Mazda (M)

headline: Stocks Down in Tokyo
abstract: Stocks are lower in Tokyo on Oct 7; at midday recess in trading, Nikkei index of 225 leading issues is down 178.63 points, or 1 percent, at 17,646.15 (S)

headline: Iraq Says Attack Would Not Alter Its Ban on U.S. Inspectors
abstract: Iraq says its decision to expel American inspectors working for United Nations will not be reversed even by military attack; Foreign Min Mohammed Said al-Sahaf accuses US of seeking nothing short of toppling Pres Saddam Hussein (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Sun Sues Microsoft In Dispute Over Java  Sun Microsystems accused Microsoft of trying to steal its Java computer software language in a lawsuit that illustrates the struggle between the two computer industry giants over which will control the standards used by hundreds of thousands of programmers.     The suit seeks unspecified damages and a court order that would stop Microsoft from shipping its Internet Explorer 4.0 browser, which contains a version of Java. Microsoft rejected Sun's accusations. [Page D4.]

headline: Delays, Glitches, Unanswered Calls, but Nothing Like 1987
abstract: On the first day in history that New York Stock Exchange handled more than one billion shares, small investors bumped up against agonizing delays in getting through to their brokers; situation, however, was not like crash of 1987 when wall of silence greeted desperate sellers; brokers are now better prepared for onslaught of orders; more people are ready to man phones and on-line systems that did not exist a decade ago in order to process huge number of trades (L)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  GOLDSTEIN, MENEK
abstract: GOLDSTEIN - Menek. Caring friend leaves an irreplaceable void in our lives. Tuchman family.

headline: Land Rich, but Cash Poor, in the West
abstract: Nature Conservancy acquires Dugout Ranch in Utah from Heidi Redd and her former husband, Robert, who would otherwise have been forced to sell it to developers because neither of them had the money to buy out the other's interest in the ranch after their divorce; deal demonstrates many of the sophisticated financial, tax and estate planning tools that environmental groups are increasingly using to keep land pristine while giving owners a chance to cash out and, in the case of Mrs Redd, the right to live out her life on her beloved ranch; photos; map of ranch and map showing the regions of US undergoing rapid population growth and development (L)

headline: In Refinancing, Homeowners Find a Source for Saving
abstract: A MINI-BOOM of mortgage refinancings has occurred in recent weeks, in large part because of the recent turmoil in the stock market.    The percentage of total mortgage dollars that were devoted to refinancings rose to 43.2 percent for the week ended Nov. 6, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association of America. In the summer, that percentage was in the teens.

headline: U.S. Stocks Surge After Strong Rally in Japan
abstract: Strong rally in Japan spurs surge in US stocks; Dow Jones industrial average soars 125.74 points, to 7,698.22; Standard & Poor's 500 stock index gains 17.85 points, to 946.20; Nasdaq composite index gains 30.60 points, closing at 1,614.11, up 1.93 percent; stocks are slightly higher at midday Nov 18 in Tokyo; Nikkei average is up 19.78 points, or 0.12 percent, at 16,303.10; table (L)

headline: Business Travel; A special cell phone lets users far away tap into data from their own PC's and the Internet.
abstract: New cellular phone service introduced by Wireless Services division of AT&T Corp offers access to broad spectrum of information to help business travelers; called Pocketnet, service gives users remote wireless access to selected data from their own personal computers and from more than 20 providers of Internet content; cost is $29.99 a month, plus standard cellular voice service fees and activation charges; Shangri-La Hotels and Resorts, which owns and manages 35 hotels and resorts in Asia, is introducing its first loyalty program; for few weeks, participants in TWA's frequent-flier program will receive two miles for each dollar spent using American Express card to buy full-fare coach, business or first-class tickets on airline; promotion is in effect from Oct 15 through Nov 15 (Business Travel column) (M)

headline: China Vows Not to Overrule Hong Kong Officials
abstract: Chinese officials, faced with their first major crisis since resuming sovereignty over Hong Kong, respond calmly to free fall in stock market there and promise not to intervene or overrule Hong Kong authorities (M)

headline: Japan Premier Seeks Billions In Tax Cuts
abstract: Japan's Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto calls for two trillion yen cut in Japanese income taxes to help revive economy that has stagnated for much of decade; tax cut of that magnitude, worth $15.4 billion at current exchange rates, is more in line with what private economists say is needed to reinvigorate Japan; Nikkei 225-stock average closes up 555.85 points, or 3.48 percent, to 16,541.06 (L)

headline: INSIDE
abstract: INVESTING IT /Page 4/   Don't sell too soon. After turning in a stellar performance, many stocks return for an encore, new research shows. By Anne Tergesen.    INVESTING IT /Page 5/   The stock-picking style of the rich-and-famous Robin Leach? He likes telecommunications and emerging markets. By Kenneth N. Gilpin.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent        &nbsp   &nbsp   Previous   Year &nbsp   &nbsp   Yesterday   Day   Ago &nbsp     &nbsp   &nbsp   &nbsp   &nbsp &nbsp     PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25  &nbsp     DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00  &nbsp     FEDERAL FUNDS*   6.13   5.55   5.56  &nbsp     3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.07   5.02   4.76  &nbsp     6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.17   5.11   4.99  &nbsp     10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.57   3.55   N.A.  &nbsp     10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   5.77   5.72   6.36  &nbsp     30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   5.97   5.92   6.62  &nbsp     TELEPHONE BONDS   7.22   7.20   7.78  &nbsp     MUNICIPAL BONDS***   5.27   5.26   5.75 &nbsp &nbsp      *Estimated daily average, Dow Jones Markets  **Realized dollar amount rises with inflation  ***Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer  Sources: Salomon Brothers and Dow Jones Markets for Treasury's bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: 2 Canadian Agencies Agree to Combine
abstract: DDB Needham Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group says that it agreed in principle to combine its Canadian agency, DDB Needham Canada, with Palmer Jarvis Communications, a leading independent Canadian agency, to form an agency to be named Palmer Jarvis DDB (S)

headline: A Long-Distance Visionary
abstract: Profile of Worldcom Inc chairman-chief executive Bernard J Ebbers in light of Worldcom's $30 billion bid for MCI Communications; says his rise to become head of nation's fourth-largest long-distance telephone company is testimony to opportunities created in 1984 by opening long-distance market to competition; holds Ebbers has strung together roughly 50 acquisitions to make Worldcom a $7-billion-a-year company; charts; photos (L)

headline: A New Standard to Govern PC's With Multiple Chips
abstract: Developers of fastest hardware and software for scientific and engineering computing will announce new technical standard that is intended to make it easier for complex programs to operate on different types of computers; new standard, Open MP, is designed for computers that use either Unix or Windows NT software operating systems and employ multiple microprocessors for parallel computing; one effect of Open MP standard will be to increase shift of complex scientific and engineering software development from supercomputer world to high-end desktop work stations; computer makers that have agreed to support Open MP are Compaq Computer, Digital Equipment, Intel, IBM and Silicon Graphics; new standard was developed by researchers at Silicon Graphics and Kuck & Associates (M)

headline: Baku Journal; Awash in Oil Wealth, But Just for the Few?
abstract: If there is such a thing as a sure bet in the turbulent world of oil politics, it is that Azerbaijan is going to become fabulously rich.    Oil fields that extend into the Caspian Sea have been found to contain more crude than than anywhere else on earth other than the Persian Gulf. Foreign companies have signed more than $10 billion worth of drilling contracts with the state-owned oil monopoly, and much more is yet to come.

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Alamo Rent A Car, Fort Lauderdale, Fla., part of Republic Industries, to Ogilvy One Worldwide, New York and Miami, part of the Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide unit of WPP Group, to handle United States direct marketing, which had been handled by Wunderman Cato Johnson, New York, a unit of Young & Rubicam Inc. Billings were estimated at $10 million. Foote, Cone & Belding, New York, owned by True North Communications, was recently awarded the general advertising account.  * World Championship Wrestling, Atlanta, part of Time Warner Inc., to Ogilvy & Mather Atlanta, a unit of WPP Group, to handle its account, previously handled in-house. Billings were estimated at $7 million to $8 million.

headline: Laura Ashley Names New Finance Director
abstract: Laura Ashley Holdings PLC appoints J D Wetherspoon new finance director; also agrees to new loan terms with its banks as part of company's reorganization (S)

headline: Water-Shy Earth: New Outlook
abstract: Report by Population Action International, Washington-based research organization, warns fresh water supplies may be less than needed in middle of next century for world's population (S)

headline: NEIMAN MARCUS TO TEST CHAIN OF JEWELRY AND GIFT STORES
abstract: Nieman Marcus Group Inc plans to open three stores focusing on precious jewelry, gifts and home accessories as test toward creating national chain selling those items; Nieman Marcus plans to call stores Galleries of Neiman Marcus; first store will open outside Cleveland, Ohio (S)

headline: South Korea Currency Soars As Trading Restrictions End
abstract: South Korea's battered won surges by more than 8 percent after Government scraps longstanding artificial limits on how much value of curency can change; move is seen as serious effort to reverse rapid economic decline that led nation to reluctantly agree to record $57 billion bailout by International Monetary Fund; graphs; photo (M)

headline: Storm Hits Acapulco; Scores Die in Workers' Districts
abstract: Hurricane Pauline hits Mexico's Pacific Coast with unexpected fury, unleashing flash floods and landslides and drenching Acapulco; 100 people are reported dead, 40 of them in Acapulco; photo (M)

headline: Albright, at NATO Meeting, Tells of Peril From 'Eurasia'
abstract: NATO foreign ministers, meeting, Brussels, sign accords with Poland, Hungary and Czech Republic to bring them into alliance; State Sec Madeleine K Albright urges wider NATO strategy to deal with threat from nuclear, chemical and biological arms; holds threat emanates largely from Middle East and Eurasia, so Europe is especially at risk; ministers approve planning for probable continuation of NATO's American-led peace-keeping mission in Bosnia; Albright says Pres Clinton has not yet decided to extend presence of United States troops; holds Europe should shoulder more of cost (M)

headline: Montenegrins Land in Game Of Geopolitics
abstract: PARISâ€”  Western governments are hoping that Montenegro's change of leaders will make the country a heavier geopolitical domino in the Balkans than its tiny size might suggest, according to U.S. and European diplomats.

headline: Laura Ashley Dismisses Its Chief Executive
abstract: Ann Iverson is dismissed as chief executive of Laura Ashley Holdings PC; company's board replaces Iverson with chief operating officer David Hoare (L)

headline: CAMDEN PROPERTY IN $392 MILLION DEAL FOR OASIS
abstract: Camden Property Trust says it agreed to buy Oasis Residential Inc for $392 million in stock (S)

headline: Massacre Hobbles Tourism in Egypt
abstract: Massacre Hobbles Tourism in Egypt**Massacre that claimed lives of 58 tourists in temple in Luxor, Egypt, on Nov 17, 1997 is now taking broader toll; it can be measured in empty hotel rooms, unemployed tourist guides, and warnings of sharp slowdown in what had been Egypt's robust pace of economic growth; photo (L)m

headline: COMMUNITY BANKS TO BUY PEOPLES STATE IN STOCK SWAP
abstract: Community Banks Inc will acquire Peoples State Bank, East Berlin, Pa, in stock swap valued at about $55.9 million (S)

headline: Browser Short At Microsoft
abstract: Only those tapping into Microsoft Corp's Internet Explorer could view Microsoft's court documents against Justice Department; documents were not available on Netscape's Navigator until after noon; Microsoft says it was an honest if embarrassing mistake (S)

headline: New Jet Eases Travel Hassles For Bill Gates
abstract: Microsoft Corp's chairman, William H Gates, buys $21 million private jet with his own money; Gates has long been known for flying coach and barring his employees from flying first class (S)

headline: People
abstract: * David Haan was named to the new position of managing partner and chief operating officer of the Philadelphia office of Earle Palmer Brown. He had been president and chief executive of Foote, Cone & Belding Canada, Toronto, part of True North Communications. At the New York office of Earle Palmer, Alan Zorfas was named partner and chief marketing officer, a new post; he had been integrated marketing director at the DDB Needham New York unit of Omnicom Group.

headline: Children's movies, facing a tough market, find a home on a revived Disney series.
abstract: Oliver Twist, on Wonderful World of Disney on ABC, is part of Disney's effort to revive its old television showcase; it is spending heavily on original family fare for television, having decided, like many producers, to move their products to television rather than contend with increasingly difficult market for children's movies; economics of made-for-television movies are far different from theatrical movies; drawing (M)

headline: Kenya to Vote Next Month; Opposition Cries Foul
abstract: Kenya's electoral commission sets general elections for Dec 29; announcement kicks off what most analysts predict will be lopsided contest favoring Pres Daniel arap Moi over opposition splintered along tribal lines; opposition leaders charge Moi's allies rush elections to give challengers less time to campaign or take advantage of recently passed reforms (M)

headline: Court Rules Against CNN
abstract: US Appeals Court for Ninth Circuit rules that Government and CNN news crew violated rights of Montana rancher Paul W Berger when CNN recorded search for evidence that Berger had been poisoning eagles; case could restrict efforts by news organizations to accompany law enforcement officials on searches of private property; court says 1993 raid had been used to advance what it calls commercial and entertainment interests, not just law enforcement; ruling means Federal court in Montana will determine what damages, if any, Berger is entitled to; Berger and his wife, Erma, had sought $10 million (S)

headline: Turning Mom and Dad Into Managing Partners
abstract: Michael Kirsh letter on Oct 12 article on dispute between student and her parents over account set up under Uniform Gift to Minors Act (S)

headline: Bonds Are Back, but Be Wary When Buying
abstract: Bond analysts expect prices to keep rising; one reason is that they consider it unlikely that Federal Reserve will raise interest rates anytime soon; another is that supply of Treasuries and tax-free municipal bonds is shrinking as Federal budget deficit is pared and as public-sector privatization grows; with demand high and supply tight, bond prices tends to rise; drawing (L)

headline: U.S. FILTER RAISES ITS BID FOR MEMTEC TO $380 MILLION
abstract: US Filter Corp raises its offer for Memtec Ltd, a second time, making acquisition worth about $380 million (S)

headline: Sense of Crisis Over Banks Eases, but Japanese Are Still on Edge
abstract: Sense of crisis looming over Japan's vast financial system subsides, although investors, analysts and Government officials remain edgy; Yasuda Trust and Banking Co issues statement denouncing market rumors that have painted it as next of Japan's big banks headed for disaster; it asks Securities Exchange and Surveillance Commission to look into whether rumors have been intentionally spread to manipulate its stock; several banks have to pay high premiums to borrow money used to finance day-to-day operations, after failure of several banks (M)

headline: Hartmann Account Goes to Select
abstract: Hartmann Inc, division of Brown-Forman Corp, says it has named Select Communications to handle its advertising account, which had been handled by Hill, Holliday/Altschiller (S)

headline: Tenja Journal; In Balkan Enclave, Tolerance Is Fleeing for Its Life
abstract: Ethinic Serbs are pouring out of Eastern Slavonia, Croatia's last Serbian-held enclave, as United Nations prepares to return area to Croatian control; transition was supposed to herald successful integration of ethnic minority into nationalist republic, but there are increasing signs that half of 120,000 ethnic Serbs will soon flee to Serbia or Serbian-held parts of Bosnia; Serbs face death threats from Croats; map; photo (M)

headline: Gunman Slain in Attack on Mexican Editor Was Drug Gangster, Officials Say
abstract: Investigators identify gunman who died when he ambushed the journalist Jesus Blancornelas in Tijuana as David Barron Corona, alias CH, 'an important active member' of Tijuana Cartel, narcotics gang that controls city; Blancornelas, in the latest issue of his weekly, Zeta, identified CH as an assassin for the cartel and accused him in taking part of Nov 14 murder of two Mexico soldiers (M)

headline: McKesson-Costco Accord
abstract: McKesson Corp says it renewed a pharmaceuticals distribution agreement with Costco Cos for three years, estimating value of contract at as much as $750 million, or additional $50 million a year (S)

headline: For Fancy Titles, Press 1
abstract: Readers are urged to send to On the Job, Money and Business, The New York Times, their best stories on problems they experienced in obtaining information by telephone (S)

headline: Times Co. Appoints Technology Officer
abstract: New York Times Co names Raymond E Douglas vice president of systems and technology; photo (S)

headline: Mexican Partner For Hicks, Muse
abstract: Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc sets up partnership in which newly formed Mexican company will oversee Hicks, Muse's Mexican investments and help it acquire companies there (S)

headline: A Few Clicks, And Microsoft Has a Problem
abstract: Federal Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson schedules hearing for January 13 on Justice Dept's contention that Microsoft Corp is in contempt for insisting that removing its Internet Explorer browser for latest version of Windows would cripple operating system; Jackson notes that had conducted a little amateur research on his own: he had booted up new computer loaded with latest version of Windows 95, and then he had removed the browser, just what he had ordered Microsoft to do last week (M)

headline: France Trumps the U.S.
abstract: French team wins world bridge champiosnhip, defeating United States team led by Nick Nickell (S)0

headline: Beyond the Dow
abstract: Graph of selected stock indexes that are nowhere near as well known that the Dow and S&P 500

headline: Boeing to Raise Output and, Then, Cut Jobs
abstract: Boeing Co says that after it increases production of its jets in 1998 it then plans to eliminate 12,000 jobs by end of 1998; Boeing chairman Philip M Condit says job cuts will largely be made through attrition and will involve about 10 percent of 118,000 workers in Boeing's commercial airplane division; announcement surprises some analysts because Boeing is still recovering from snarls that forced it to halt production on its 747 and 737 line in October and take $2.6 billion in charges (L)

headline: Sihanouk Sadly Leaves Cambodia as Mediation Bid Fails
abstract: King Norodom Sihanouk of Cambodia, defeated in efforts over past two months to mediate conflicts in homeland, leaves for China, saying he does not know when he will ever return; photo (M)

headline: British Giant Cashes In, All Set to Shop Anew
abstract: British Telecommunications may be on prowl for new American partner after agreeing to sell its stake in MCI Communications; list of obvious partners include one of regional Bell companies or GTE Corp; graph (M)

headline: Glitter-Gulch From Givenchy As McQueen Goes Wild West : A Stellar Start for Chloe's Light-hearted Little Nothings
abstract: PARISâ€”  Paul McCartney jumped to his feet to lead the standing ovation at his daughter Stella's first fashion show for Chloe.

headline: Sumitomo Bank to Post Full-Year Pretax Loss
abstract: Sumitomo Bank Ltd says it will post full-year pretax loss of 470 billion yen ($3.8 billion) to write off bad debts; bank will close 30 branches and cut 700 jobs by fiscal year that ends Mar 1999 (S)

headline: Ready-to-Wear Labels From Spain Quietly Infiltrate Paris
abstract: PARISâ€”  "Without trumpets or drum rolls" â€” as the French say â€” Spanish ready-to-wear has quietly and quickly become a fashion force here with, in the vanguard, the Zara boutiques.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: GPU Will Buy in Australia And Sell Some U.S. Assets  The American energy company GPU, which has been expanding rapidly overseas, said it would buy the high-voltage electricity transmission network of the Australian state of Victoria for $2 billion.

headline: Fuji Deal Ending; Concord Stock Dives
abstract: Shares of Concord Camera Corp tumble after Fuji Photo Film Co says it will end agreement allowing Concord to use Fuji technology in its disposable cameras; Concord says it filed suit to prevent Fuji from terminating agreement on Jan 6; agreement, concluded in 1996, ended lawsuit and countersuit over Concord's supposed infringement of Fuji's American patent rights (S)

headline: Dow Falls 113.15 Amid Concerns Over Asian Turmoil
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average falls 113.15 points, or 1.4 percent, to 7.767.92, while broader Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks drops 16.42 points, or 1.7 percent, to 946.67; analysts expect stock market to stay volatile (M)

headline: Boccioleto Journal; In Italy's Remote Alps, a Priest's Lonely Ministry
abstract: Shortage of priests in some areas of Italy, particularly in north, has spurred major changes in how local parishes function; Rev Luigi Gugliemetti, one of few priests left in Sermenza Valley in remote Valsesia region, now serves area whose aging and shrinking population was once served by six priests; is aided by four nuns, including three missionary nuns from Africa and India; map; photos (M)

headline: U.N. Prosecutor Urges New Criminal Court
abstract: Louise Arbour, chief UN prosecutor for war crimes tribunals in Balkans and Rwanda, strongly recommends establishment of permanent international criminal court with considerable independent prosecutorial power--position that puts it at odds with Clinton Administration since Defense Department fears possibility of criminal proceedings against American soldiers abroad; map (M)

headline: Japan Suspends Daiwa From Bond Dealings
abstract: Japan's Finance Ministry suspends Daiwa Securities Co from bidding and underwriting Japanese Government bonds; ministry's punishment for Daiwa comes after four of its officials are arrested on suspicion of paying about 100 million yen to reputed racketeer Ryuichi Koike through illegal stock transactions (S)

headline: Managing the Grief
abstract: Guy Chance letter discusses Richard O Nemec's Aug 24 article on returning to work following personal tragedy (S)

headline: Updates: Media and Technology; U.S. and European Union Agree Not to Have Internet Tariffs
abstract: Clinton Administration has reached accord with European Union to impose no new tariff duties on Internet commerce; accord applies to computer software and other goods bought and delivered over Internet, trade that is currently duty free (S)

headline: Banks Facing a Cash Squeeze: Asian Troubles Spark Fears of Credit Crunch
abstract: BANGKOKâ€”  Global Market Turmoil / U.S. Stocks Claw Their Way Back

headline: C.I.A. Official Quits Nonproliferation Post
abstract: Interview with Gordon C Oehler, outgoing director of CIA's Nonproliferation Center, which coordinates all intelligence from various government agencies about dangers of nuclear weapons and missile development throughout world; he provided Congress with some of most diplomatically sensitive instances of illicit technology sales (M)

headline: JUDGE APPROVES SETTLEMENT OF FOXMEYER DRUG LAWSUITS
abstract: Avatex Corp, formerly Foxmeyer Health Corp, says judge has approved its $33 million settlement of suits by creditors of bankrupt Foxmeyer Drug Co charging it illegally transferred assets out of unit before declaring bankruptcy (S)a

headline: Israel Envoy Says He's Got Power to Negotiate
abstract: Israeli Foreign Min David Levy says he has won Government backing to discuss full range of issues at upcoming meeting in Washington with Palestinian negotiators, including suspension of Israeli settlement construction and troop withdrawals in West Bank (M)

headline: Koreas to Hold New Talks
abstract: The first talks in more than four decades to bring about a formal peace between North Korea and South Korea wrapped up today with negotiations planned to resume here in March. Even getting the two Koreas to meet together for the talks, mediated by China and the United States, was a breakthrough. The previous attempt in 1954, also in Geneva, collapsed. The agenda for the March talks will be hammered out in February at a meeting in Beijing.

headline: Taking In the Sites; With a Film Due, Homage To Bond. James Bond.
abstract: World Wide Web sites devoted to fictional character James Bond discussed in light of opening of new Bond film, Tomorrow Never Dies; table; drawing (M)

headline: Charge Against Investigator Muddles Apartheid Inquiry
abstract: South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission is stymied in its work after testimony that Dumisa Ntsebeza, head of investigations into apartheid era, was himself involved in terrorist attack four years ago; gardener who testified has now retracted allegation, and Abp Desmond Tutu sees effort to discredit commission; Pres Nelson Mandela names investigation panel under Judge Richard Goldstone (S)

headline: The Next Crash Foretold, or Maybe Not
abstract: Financial professionals Burton G Malkiel, Byron R Wien, Harald B Malmgren, Edward Yardeni, Ron Chernow, James S Chanos, G Kenneth Heebner, Richard C Breeden and software engineer Thom Rogers speculate on prospects of another stock market crash; photos (L)

headline: WALL STREET FAILS TO BUILD ON RALLY SEEN IN HONG KONG
abstract: Investors pound Dow Jones stock average for second consecutive day, even though Hong Kong exchange, which started worldwide plunge, rebounds from its blackest trading day in eight years; Japanese and European markets gain somewhat, but early American rally fizzles and emerging Latin American markets fall even further; Dow closes at 7,715.41, down 132.36 points; graph (M);

headline: AIR PRODUCTS IN IMPERIAL CHEMICAL DEAL
abstract: Air Products and Chemicals Inc, Allentown, Pa, to buy some chemical units from Imperial Chemical Industries PLC, London, for $111.2 million in cash (S)

headline: Hong Kong Raises Margin Minimums
abstract: Hong Kong raises margin requirements for trading futures contracts on its benchmark Hang Seng stock index by 20 percent (S)

headline: Foumban Journal; Inheritors of an African Kingdom, Come and Gone
abstract: Article profiles Bamoun, Cameroon ethnic group whose cultural rituals have hardly changed over 600 years of history; map; photo (M)

headline: GLOBAL WARMING: Around the Globe, Big Worries and Small Signs of Progress; Weary Africa Braces For More Extremes
abstract: Even though most of Africa is underdeveloped, contributing very little to greenhouse gases that have caused global warming trend, scientists say its 600 million people stand to lose most because endemic poverty limits their ability to cope with climate shifts (S)

headline: Manufacturers See Lack of Basic Skills
abstract: United States manufacturers see serious shortcomings in basic reading, writing and math skills among their workers, according to an industry survey released on Friday.    Although employers are investing more to educate and train their employees, a shortage of skilled workers seen since 1991 has not improved, said the study, conducted for the National Association of Manufacturers by Grant Thornton, the accounting firm.

headline: For Rap, Double Becoming Standard
abstract: Rap music is moving further into marketing mainstream with increasing number of double albums from its more famous performers; increasing popularity of rap double albums is contributing to rising sales of overall music industry; photos; chart (M)

headline: Acquisition by Pricellular
abstract: Pricellular Corp says it agreed to acquire cellular networking license for rural area of Tennessee for $73 million from Bachtel Liquidity LP (S)

headline: In U.S. Notes of Praise, Quavers of Doubt on Kim
abstract: Pres Clinton phones South Korean Pres-elect Kim Dae Jung for what aides describe as warm 15-minute congratulatory call; many of Clinton's aides are developing strategies to insure that transition over next three months does not send South Korea's battered economy over the cliff (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: DESKTOP DATA Inc. Burlington, Mass., agreed to acquire Individual Inc., a provider of personalized electronic news services, for about $84 million in stock. After the acquisition, the company will be called Newsedge Corp.

headline: HIDDEN HORRORS: A special report.; Uncovering the Guilty Footprints Along Zaire's Long Trail of Death
abstract: Rebellion in Congo that ended in spring was conducted largely out of sight of rest of the world; when it was over in May, victor, Laurent Kabila, presented himself to Congolese as liberator who had ousted corrupt dictator, Mobutu Sese Seko; evidence has emerged suggesting that Kabila and Rwandans who backed him were also fighting war of revenge, one intertwined with ethnic conflicts between Hutu and Tutsi groups that have tormented region; not single body has been unearthed by United Nations investigators, but they have been able to gather chilling accounts of mass killings that leave little doubt that Kabila's forces committed atrocities as they marched across Congo, then called Zaire; map; photo (M)

headline: Fidelity to Pay $10 Million To Settle Suit On Statements
abstract: Fidelity Investments agrees to pay $10 million to settle class-action lawsuit filed in late 1995 against the company and Jeffrey N Vinik, former manager of Magellan Fund, over statements by Vinik in fund's September 1995 report to shareholdes; in report, Vinik said that shares of Micron Technology were 'still relatively cheap'; but by time report was mailed to shareholders, in late October and November 1995, Vinik had started selling much of fund's Micron stake; David C Stewart, manager of Emerging Markets fund, will take over as fund manager on Nov 1, replacing Richard Hazlewood (S)

headline: Mercedes-Benz to Correct Design Problem in New Small Cars
abstract: Mercedes-Benz says it will spend 100 million marks ($57 million) a year to install electronic equipment on its new A-class subcompact cars to correct design problem that caused one car to flip on a test; design problem affects 13,000 A-class cars already produced and may lead to repairs on 3,000 already sold; Jurgen Hubbert, Daimler-Benz management board member, notes that in real or normal situations, car proved its safety (M)

headline: DURA PHARMACEUTICALS ENDS DEAL TO BUY SCANDIPHARM
abstract: Dura Pharmaceuticals Inc says that it ended its agreement to buy Scandipharm Inc for $93 million to $139 million in stock (S)

headline: In a Surprise, South Korea Ends Its Attempts to Defend Its Currency
abstract: South Korea suspends efforts to defend its currency with its own, fast-depleting financial reserves as American, Asian and European officials scramble to determine if world's 11th-largest economy--and one of America's largest trading partners--will become latest Asian nation needing economic bailout; table (L)

headline: AGOURON STOCK FALLS 22%; DRUG DEVELOPMENT DROPPED
abstract: Shares in Agouron Pharmaceuticals Inc. fell 22 percent yesterday after the company said it had dropped development of a new cancer drug and ended a cancer research collaboration with F. Hoffmann-La Roche Ltd. Agouron, a biotechnology company based in La Jolla, Calif., said human clinical trials of the drug, Thymitaq, did not show a sufficient improvement over existing therapies to warrant proceeding. The company's shares fell $8.50, to close at $31, in heavy trading.

headline: It's Official:Shopping Can Be Good for You
abstract: LONDONâ€”  Whoever said money can't buy happiness didn't know where to shop â€” a sentiment close to the heart of every fashion professional.

headline: Deep in Siberia's Forest, Finding Clues to the 'Missing Sink'
abstract: Russia's expanding forests offer hope to many climate scientists that unpredictable, natural mechanism will moderate trend toward global warming; researchers say Northern Hemisphere forests, fed by higher levels of carbon dioxice in air, seem to be retarding global warming by absorbing more carbon dioxide; warn mechanism is not understood and could reverse itself; map; photo (M)

headline: Market Place; Fidelity Critic Gets Tougher As a Deal Fails
abstract: Market Place column examines activities of David J O'Leary, financial analyst who softened his often strident criticism of Fidelity Investments when he began privately negotiating with company for permission to sell his research and investment recommendations to customers of Fidelity's discount brokerage firm; says that when Fidelity turned down O'Leary's proposal, he resumed his criticism; notes O'Leary feels he did not have to disclose his negotiations to institutional investors; says his situation serves as reminder that financial analysts often face conflicts of interest (M)

headline: Ireland Picks Ulster Woman as President
abstract: Mary McAleese, 46, a law professor from the British province of Northern Ireland, has won the Presidency of the Irish Republic, becoming the first northerner ever to hold the office, according to official results announced today.    At the start of the campaign, people wondered whether her northern upbringing and distinct northern accent would hurt her. But tonight it seemed clear that voters saw her as someone who could help the Northern Ireland peace effort. She was also an able television performer, more eloquent in debate than her four rivals in Thursday's vote.

headline: As U.S. Looks On, 120 Nations Sign Treaty Banning Land Mines
abstract: Leaders of over 120 nations gather, Ottawa, to sign comprehensive ban on global production and use of antipersonnel land mines; pledge resources and money to clear existing mines, which kill or maim thousands each year; citizens' groups and nongovernment institutions played lead role in drafting treaty, whose rapid success surprised even ban's most ardent advocates; United States, China and Russia took part in talks but will not sign treaty; photo (M)

headline: Another Year, Another Bundle; Billions in Bonuses Are Expected to Fall on Wall Street
abstract: Bonuses for Wall Street's top bankers and traders are expected to rise an average of 20 percent to 30 percent; top executives with skills in high demand may do better; common wisdom on Wall Street is that more than 1,000 people in the business will get bonuses of more than $1 million this year; chart; photo (L)

headline: PRUDENTIAL TO INVEST $10 MILLION IN WESTAR FINANCIAL
abstract: Prudential Insurance Co of America to invest $10 million in Westar Financial Services Inc to help it expand into new regions; will be firm's biggest shareholder (S)

headline: Coke's New Chairman Sees No Major Shifts in Strategy
abstract: M Douglas Ivester, in his first public appearance since his appointment as chairman and chief executive of Coca-Cola Co, announces no major changes in strategy of company, National Soft Drink Assn leadership conference; takes surprisingly conciliatory stand toward Coke's opponents in industry, saying that the task of increasing beverage volumes gives 'great opportunity and room for all of us'; his photo (M)

headline: Acquisition by Four Media
abstract: Four Media Co says it agreed to acquire Visualize Inc; financial terms not disclosed (S)

headline: U.S. Argument In S.& L. Case Draws Rebuke
abstract: Chief Judge Loren A Smith of United States Court of Federal Appeals angrily rejects what may have been Govt's final effort to avoid paying huge penalties to savings and loan industry because of sudden change in accounting rules in 1989 that left dozens of financial institutions struggling; industry analysts and Govt officials have said that penalties could add $10 billion to $20 billion to cost of cleanup of savings and loan industry, already estimated at $120 billion; Smith castigates Justice Dept for what he contends was willful misrepresentation of both law and facts in effort to avoid paying penalties (M)

headline: U.S. Lowers Goals on China After Glitches in Early Talks
abstract: Clinton Administration lowers goals on what to expect from state visit of Pres Jiang Zemin of China; senior officials say main importance of summit is to provide new beginning for what they concede has been single most badly handled foreign policy of Clinton Presidency; months of frenzied pre-summit negotiations between Chinese and American officials have failed to reach hoped-for progress on points of contention between both countries (M)

headline: PHELPS DODGE BEGINS TENDER OFFER FOR COBRE MINING
abstract: Phelps Dodge Corp begins tender offer for Cobre Mining Co, valued at $105 million (S)

headline: REGIONS FINANCIAL IS SET TO ACQUIRE KEY FLORIDA BANCORP
abstract: Regions Financial Corp acquires Key Florida Bancorp Inc for about $38.5 million in stock (S)

headline: Corporate News, Quickly
abstract: Letter by Neal Lipschutz, managing editor of Dow Jones News Service, discusses Ted Pincus's Sept 7 article on corporate insider trading (S)

headline: French Insurer's Board Backs Offer by Allianz of Germany
abstract: Board of Assurances Generales de France SA endorses takeover offer by Allianz AG of Germany that values French company at $10.4 billion, higher than unsolicited, $9.5 billion bid by Assicurazioni Generali SpA of Italy (M)

headline: IRANIAN PRESIDENT CALLS FOR OPENING DIALOGUE WITH U.S.
abstract: Interview with Iranian Pres Mohammed Khatami, who aims conciliatory message at US; he says he hopes to re-establish dialogue with American people, for whom he says he has 'great respect;' stops short of saying he expects renewed official contacts between both Governments; American officials remain skeptical; photo (M)

headline: Official Outlook Pessimistic in Japan
abstract: Bank of Japan says country's economic recovery is on shaky ground, with spending continuing to falter as consumers earn smaller paychecks and pay more in taxes; pessimistic outlook means bank will probably not be raising interest rates from their record lows until late 1998 (S)

headline: Russia Fails to Block Bosnian Serb Vote
abstract: Clinton Administration, using deft diplomacy and superpower might, vanquishes Russia's attempt to block parliamentary elections in Serbian region of Bosnia; parliamentary election is critical part of struggle by relative moderates in part of Bosnia controlled by Serbs, led by Pres Biljana Plavsic, to wrest power from Serb hard-liners, led by wartime leader Radovan Karadzic who has been indicted for war crimes (M)

headline: FINANCING ARM OF BOEING PLANS TO SELL DEBT SECURITIES
abstract: Boeing Co's Boeing Capital Corp unit registers to sell up to $1 billion in debt securities (S)

headline: A Mitsubishi Account To Be Joint Effort
abstract: Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America names two agencies to handle its consolidated regional dealer group account, with combined billings estimated at $70 million to $80 million (S)

headline: Poland Urges Sobriety on Road
abstract: Poland's national police, eager to slow sharp rise in drunken driving and soaring death toll on roads, have stepped-up a campaign to emphasize sobriety (M)

headline: Danilo Dolci, Vivid Voice Of Sicily's Poor, Dies at 73
abstract: Danilo Dolci, advocate of nonviolent social reform in Sicily, dies at age 73; photo (M)

headline: Blair Meets With Adams, I.R.A. Figure, In Belfast
abstract: British Prime Min Tony Blair meets with Gerry Adams, president of political wing of Irish Republican Army, in Belfast in highly charged gesture meant to symbolize his commitment to peace talks in Northern Ireland; meeting is first between British Prime Minister and Sinn Fein leader in 76 years and seems to signify new era in Northern Ireland's troubled history; he reportedly shook Adams's hand--symbolic move that infuriated members of province's Protestant majority; he urges people on all sides of Irish question to support peace talks and put end to decades of sectarian violence over province's future; photos (M)

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt     * Enron Corp., Houston, is selling $100 million of notes due in 2003 through Chase Securities Inc. The notes are priced at 99.88 to yield 6.625 percent. The issue is rated Baa2 by Moody's Investors Service, BBB+ by Standard & Poor's and BBB by Duff & Phelps.    * Fannie Mae is selling $100 million of notes due in 2000 through First Tennessee Bank and HSBC Securities Inc. The notes carry an interest rate of 6.22 percent and are priced at par.

headline: Meditrust Drops Out of Interstate Talks
abstract: Meditrust Corp chmn and chief executive Abraham Gosman says his company has withdrawn from talks about acquiring Interstate Hotels Corp (S)

headline: Is There a Pound of Wisdom in a Pennywise Strategy?
abstract: Fidelity Low-Priced Stock and other mutual funds that invest only in stocks costing less than set limit discussed; bigness can be problem for such funds, which can have difficulty as they grow buying significant amount of small stock without pushing up price; Fidelity, which initially had $15 per share limit, recently raised limit from $25 to $35; graph (M)l

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.69   5.54   5.46        3-MO.
