headline: French Court Refuses to Extradite American Convicted of Murder
abstract: French court refuses to extradite Ira Einhorn to US to serve out life sentence for murdering his girlfriend, Holly Maddux, in Philadelphia in 1977 (M)

headline: Feeling Abandoned by Israel, Many American Jews Grow Angry
abstract: Many American Jews of Reform and Conservative traditions say they are hurt and outraged at what they see as attempts by Orthodox rabbinate to cement its control over religious life in Israel, an issue that is barely a cause of controversy in Israel itself, where Reform and Conservative movements are small; some Orthodox Jews in US resent what they see as Reform and Conservative branches trying to impose watered-down standards on Jews in Israel; catalyst for controversy is legislation pending before Israeli Parliament that would write into law Orthodox control over religious conversions in Israel; photos (M)

headline: Tiny Turbine: The Next Generator?; Company Hopes Its Small Unit Will Dominate Power Market
abstract: Makers of microturbines hope that their small, on-site generators might revolutionize power industry just as microchip did computer industry; interview with Paul Craig, chief executive of Capstone Turbine in Tarzana, California, on his hopes for microturbine as low-cost, low-polluting way to generate electricity on site; skeptics contend that small-scale generation of electricity will never be economical; with deregulation of electric power beginning in California on Jan 1, power industry in state has virtually abandoned idea of continuing to build expensive central power plants that take years to build; photo of Craig; table shows how microturbines compare with some other energy sources (M)

headline: Pentagon Aide Warns Czechs to Upgrade Military for NATO
abstract: Asst Defense Sec Franklin D Kramer tells Czech Republic that it must upgrade its military forces if it wants to be integrated into NATO (M)

headline: Crusader Takes On the Postal Piggy Bank
abstract: Japan's Minister of Health and Welfare Junichiro Koizumi is pushing measures that would have post offices and banks compete more equally in financial services to dismay of many Japanese and their postmasters; Koizumi wants to privatize nation's 24,667 post offices, contending that no less than Japan's future role as world financial leader hangs in the balance; Japan's post office is also financial monolith, taking care of some $2 trillion in savings and $800 billion in life insurance policies; Koizumi says postal system is juggernaut threatening to strangle Japan's private financial institutions; privatizing postal system is seen as litmus test of Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto's resolve to reduce Government influence and unlease market forces on Japan's economy; graph; chart; photos (L)

headline: DIARY
abstract: TRADE  The Chinese Connection  The United States trade deficit deepened in August to $10.4 billion, the widest gap since January, driven by a record $5.2 billion gap with China. Benefiting from a strong economy and a higher dollar, American importers have been stocking up on Chinese toys and decorations for the Christmas shopping season. William M. Daley, the Secretary of Commerce, referring specifically to China, said, ''The mounting trade deficit remains a major concern for this Administration.''    BOEING  Business Is Good. That's Bad.  Boeing stunned Wall Street by announcing it was suffering from too much of a good thing. Deluged with orders for its commercial planes, the company has not been able to keep up, despite hiring 14,500 workers this year. Earlier, it halted production of 747's for 20 workdays and 737's for 25 workdays because of parts shortages and other production problems. Now Boeing, the leading aerospace manufacturer and the biggest United States exporter, says it will take a charge against earnings of $1.6 billion for the third quarter, resulting in a loss, and a $1 billion charge for the fourth quarter.

headline: A Run on Coffee Stockpiles Sends Prices to 4-Week High
abstract: Coffee rises to four-week high as strong demand and delays in shipping newly harvested beans from Latin America sends US exchange stockpiles to 11-month low; stockpiles of coffee in warehouses monitored daily by Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange plunged 36 percent on Nov 10 to lowest level since December 1996 (L)

headline: Oxford Says It Misjudged Cost of Care
abstract: Oxford Health Plans, a managed care company, acknowledges that it sorely underestimated cost of its health care; under pressure from New York State Department of Insurance, Oxford confirmed fears that it misjudged its costs, with announcement that it will take substantial charge to fourth-quarter earnings and show loss for the year; full size of charge is not disclosed, but at least $164 million of it will go just to bolster reserves for medical claims submitted on behalf of New York policyholders, core of its business (L)

headline: Hong Kong Jitters Send Dollar To 2-Week High Against Yen
abstract: US dollar climbs to two-week high against Japanese yen as currency dealers grow nervous about investing in Asia after Hong Kong's Hang Seng stock index plunges (M)

headline: Lazard in Forefront in Wave of Deals
abstract: Half dozen big European merger bids recently announced promise windfall for investment banks, led by three Lazard Freres & Co investment houses; Lazard clients include BAT Industries PLC, which is in talks with Zurich Insurance Co, Wolters Kluwer NV, which is merging with Reed Elsevier, Redland PLC, which has rejected bid from Lafarge SA; Assicurazioni Generali SpA is using Lazard as adviser for takeover bid of Assurances Generales de France SA; Merita Oy used Lazard as adviser in its merger with Nordbanken AB; Meyer International PLC is in talks to buy Harcos building materials unit of Harrisons & Crossfield PLC for about $483 million (M)

headline: S.& P. 500 Hits a High; Dow Finishes Ahead 98.97
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 98.97 points, to 8,149.13; Standard & Poor's 500 index rises 10.69 points, to record 983.79; table (S)

headline: French Trucker Strike Raises Specter of Chaos on Continent : War and Peace in European Labor
abstract: PARISâ€”  Striking French truckers began to blockade roads throughout the country Sunday for the second time in a year, threatening chaos in neighboring countries that rely on the trans-European highways running through France.

headline: Ad Group Chooses 6 For 1997 Honors
abstract: American Advertising Federation inducts six executives into Advertising Hall of Achievement (S)

headline: South Koreans Vote, Seeking Rescue From Economic Crisis
abstract: South Koreans vote amid economic crisis to choose President to preside over far-reaching industrial overhaul; candidates, including front-runners, Kim Dae Jung and Lee Hoi Chang, seek to portray selves as reassuring figures able to lead nation to recovery; Kim victory would mark first peaceful transfer of presidency to opposition party in modern Korean history; photo (M)

headline: A Regional Utility Is Sold in Brazil
abstract: Brazil says it has sold regional utility Empresa Energetica do Mato Grosso do Sul for $565 million (US) to Brazilian utility Espirito Santo Centrais Electricas SA, or Escelsa (S)

headline: O Smach Journal; On Its Last Legs, the Saddest Cambodian Army
abstract: Interview with Gen Nhek Bun Chhay, who leads remnant of Cambodia's royalist army, which is trapped in hinterlands near O Smach and operates at sufferance of Thai army and in shadow of Khmer Rouge; photo; map (M)

headline: Ad Spending Rises In Gay Publications
abstract: Survey by Mulryan/Nash finds that advertising spending in publications aimed at gay and lesbian consumers from July 1, 1996, through June 30, 1997, rose 35.9 percent from period a year earlier, to $100.2 million from $73.7 million; study surveyed 138 local and national newspapers and magazines (S)

headline: Pro Bono Accounts
abstract: * Juvenile Diabetes Foundation International/The Diabetes Research Foundation, based in New York, to Foote, Cone & Belding, New York, a division of True North Communications.

headline: World News Briefs; Japan Hints It Will Sign Pact to Ban Land Mines
abstract: Japanese officials are hinting that they may reverse stand and sign international treaty banning anti-personnel land mines, putting further pressure on United States to sign pact; public pressure seems to have led Prime Min Ryutaro Hashimoto to overrule Defense Agency, which opposes ban (S)

headline: Two Big Utilities In $6.6 Billion Merger Accord
abstract: American Electric Power Co to acquire Central & Southwest Corp in stock deal worth $6.6 billion; merger would create major low-cost producer of electricity to sell power as states open utilities to competition; analysts cite possible regulatory obstacles to merger; graph (M)

headline: In a New South Africa, Old Anti-Gay Bias Persists
abstract: Even though attitudes towards sexuality are changing in post-apartheid South Africa, achieving full legal protections for homosexuals is proving slow process; even though new Constitution prohibits discrimination on basis of sexual orientation, anti-gay attitudes persist on almost all levels; photo (M)

headline: Executive Jet Venture Is Set
abstract: Boeing, General Electric and Executive Jet Inc form joint venture that will allow businesses and individuals to buy partial shares of new $40 million Boeing business jets to be introduced late next year (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Stocks Bounce Back In Record Trading Volume  It was the busiest day ever on Wall Street, and one of the best.    One day after plunging 554 points, the Dow industrials roared back, gaining 337.17 points, to 7,498.32. More than 1.2 billion shares changed hands on the New York Stock Exchange, 75 percent more than the previous record, set on Monday, and roughly twice the level during the 1987 market crash. Much of the buying was done in small trades that are the hallmark of individual investors. By contrast, institutional-size orders appear to have been largely sales. [Page A1.]

headline: NATO's Salesman Finds the U.S. Tough Territory
abstract: Clinton Administration has enlisted NATO Sec Gen Javier Solana in its push for support for alliance's expansion; Pres Clinton has made expanding NATO centerpiece of his foreign policy, but he needs to sell idea to indifferent public; Solana photo (M)

headline: Producer Prices Exceed Forecast With 0.5% Rise
abstract: Bureau of Labor Statistics reports Producer Price Index rose unexpectedly steep 0.5% in Sept; graph (M)

headline: Selling the Golden Goose Before All the Eggs Are Laid
abstract: WHEN shares in Cisco Systems doubled in price between April and early December, Libby Olson did what many investors do: she took the money and ran.    ''It's pretty tough to get a stock to double again in a year or even in a two-year period,'' said Ms. Olson, an investing consultant who trades for her own portfolio from her home in Pewaukee, Wis. When a stock soars, Ms. Olson said, her rule of thumb is to ''pocket your profits and look for another investment.''

headline: Fox Said to Be Ousting Children's TV Pioneer
abstract: Margaret Loesch, who built television industry's leading children's network for Fox Broadcasting Co, will resign from Fox, in effect pushed aside by Haim Saban, chairman of children's network; in October, Saban hired Rich Cronin, executive from Nickelodeon, to take over Loesch's duties as head of domestic Fox Kids Network (M)

headline: Orange Juice Prices Climb As Cold Threatens Florida
abstract: Frozen concentrated orange juice futures climb to their highest level in three months on speculation that cold weather headed toward Florida might develop into freeze that could damage crops (M)

headline: Seeing Politics, and Mirrors, In the Coverage of Capitol Hill
abstract: Growing number of news outlets, including two highly competitive newspapers, several faxed newsletters and new on-line publications, offer almost instantaneous updates to and about Congress, quickening already frenetic pace of Congressional coverage; expansion has gone well beyond what was thought market would bear, with lobbyists willing to pay relatively high advertising rates to appeal to readers who make laws; drawing; photo (M)

headline: Money Starts to Show in Internet Shopping
abstract: Article contends that this holiday season may be first in which consumers give businesses that offer goods and services on Internet a significant amount of sales; many Internet merchants have found that volume is up sharply this year as more consumers learn how to find what they want and become comfortable that they will not be defrauded; American Express Co calculates that $4 billion to $6 billion will be spent making credit card purchases over Internet this year, with sales increasing at more than 400 percent pace annually; more conservatively, Forrester Research puts figure at $2.4 billion, double last year's total (M)

headline: On Russian-Iranian Oil Deal, U.S. Sanctions May Backfire
abstract: Clinton Administration faces key test of its threatened sanctions against foreign companies that invest in Iran's oil and gas industry; must take stand on bid by Russia's private Gazprom to raise $1 billion in bond markets, funds that would help finance its role in joint venture to pump natural gas off Iranian coast; move to block financing could interfere with delicate talks with European allies on sanctions and efforts to stabilize Russian economy and hurt underwriter, Goldman, Sachs & Co, big contributor to Pres Clinton; Sen Alfonse M D'Amato, author of sanctions act, plans hearings (M)

headline: Angola Plans Pullout Of Troops In Brazzaville
abstract: Angola promises to withdraw troops from Congo Republic, where civil war has been raging, after US representative to UN, Bill Richardson, meets with Angolan Foreign Minister and reportedly threatens to cut off aid (M)

headline: On Long Island, the Mall as History Book
abstract: Roosevelt Field shopping center, Long Island, NY, nation's seventh-largest mall, discussed in terms of way it reflects subtler demographic, financial and cultural swings of the country that best tell story of retailing in America during past 40 years--period during which malls have come to dominate shopping; over decades, Roosevelt Field's tenant lists and design, like malls in many American towns, has served as petri dish for suburban experience, which includes rise, fall and the rise of suburban department store, disappearance of the local merchant in face of relentless expansion by handful of national retailers, supplanting of homemaker by working woman as mall's prime target and breakdown of class distinctions in American tastes; photos; photos of Roosevelt Mall and its floor plans (L)

headline: U.S. Would Need to Cut Use of Fuel Drastically
abstract: Americans would have to make significant sustained cuts in use of fossil fuels in order for US to meet pollution-reduction goals promised at global warming conference in Japan; coal and oil consumption would have to decline by as much as 30 percent from levels now projected for 10-15 years from now; car makers would have to sell more efficient vehicles and consumers would have to be more careful in choosing light bulbs, air conditioners and appliances; Americans have never made such sacrifices, so that political obstacles appear far more formidable than technology challenges (M)

headline: Excite to Acquire Netbot for $35 Million
abstract: Excite Inc to buy Netbot Inc for $35 million in stock (S)

headline: Kingfisher Halts Talks On French Retailer Stake
abstract: Kingfisher PLC of Britain has recessed talks with But SA over increasing Kingfisher's 26 percent holding in But, a 235-store French retailer (S)

headline: P.& G. Consolidates TV Media Services
abstract: Procter & Gamble Co consolidates North American television media services at units of MacManus Group; Procter & Gamble Canada names Bensimon-Byrne/DMB&B as agency for English-language television in Canada; Leo Burnett Co unit had shared television account with Bensimon-Byrne/DMB&B (S)

headline: Insilco Seeks F.T.C. Approval for Mill Deal
abstract: Insilco Corp asks Federal Trade Commission for approval of its sale of two aluminum tubing mills; Insilco is seeking to sell South Carolina mills to Avins Industrial Products Corp and Lawrence Industries; FTC is demanding sale as condition of Insilco's purchase of five mills from Helmut Lingemann GmbH (S)

headline: National Westminster Reportedly May Sell Unit
abstract: National Westminster Bank PLC of Britain may sell its equities unit to Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, investment banking arm of Deutsche Bank AG (S)

headline: News-Ad Issues Arise in New Media
abstract: Some of biggest news organizations, scrambling to make huge investments in Internet pay off, have begun linking advertisements to news on their World Wide Web sites more closely than in mainstream print or broadcast media; examples cited (M)

headline: Financial Officer Leaving Oxford Health
abstract: Andrew Cassidy, chief financial officer of Oxford Health Plans, announces his resignation day after company announces wider-than-expected third-quarter loss; he will remain until replacement is found (S)

headline: The Eagle Platinum Coin Is Selling, but Not Soaring
abstract: New Platinum coin offered by the United States Mint is selling well, with more than 108,000 ounces of American Eagle platinum coins sold as of last week; problem for investors, however, is that no sooner had sales started than price of platinum began to plummet; as of Friday last, coins sold for $424 plus mint's 3 percent markup, but spot price of an ounce of platinum was just $356.50; graph (M)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY   None

headline: Gazli Journal; Free of the Russians, but Imprisoned in Cotton
abstract: Uzbekistan's long and continued reliance on single crop, cotton, discussed; nation, now independent, can find no easy way to diversify economy; maps; photo (M)

headline: HFS to Buy Tax Preparer, Jackson Hewitt, for $480 Million
abstract: HFS Inc agrees to pay $480 million in cash for Jackson Hewitt Inc, a tax preparation agency (M)

headline: Equity and Debt Offerings Expected This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Apex Mortgage Capital Inc., Los Angeles, an initial public offering of 10 million shares, 8 million in the United States and Canada. Merrill Lynch & Co.

headline: Finance Minister Dismissed In South Korea as Won Slides
abstract: South Korea's Pres Kim Young-Sam dismisses his Finance Minister Kang Kyung-Shik in move to overcome country's economic crisis, but announcement fails to calm financial markets as currency falls to new low; Kim names Trade Minister Lim Chang-Yuel as new Finance Minister (M)

headline: APPLE IS CUTTING THE NUMBER OF DOMESTIC DISTRIBUTORS
abstract: Apple Computer Inc says it is cutting number of its domestic distributors from five to two as of Dec 1 to more effectively manage company's shrinking sales; Ingram Micro Inc and Microage Inc will be remaining distributors of Macintosh computers in US; Techdata Corp, Inacom Corp ad Merisel Inc will sell Macs overseas (S)

headline: BRITISH RIVAL REJECTS A $1.8 BILLION HERCULES BID
abstract: Hercules Inc bids $1.8 billion in cash for Allied Colloids Group PLC, but Allied Colloids rejects offer as too low; analysts say offer could open bidding war for company (S)

headline: Market Place; Court Ruling May Change Companies' Disclosure
abstract: Market Place column examines Federal appeals court ruling reinstating part of shareholders' lawsuit against Quaker Oats Co; at issue in Quaker suit is company's acquisition of Snapple, during which Quaker raised its debt level without informing public; shareholder suit contends that Quaker had duty to disclose that it was changing its debt standard, and that failure to do so amounted to violation of securities law; case could have impact beyond Quaker; it could lead to companies becoming much more hesitant about disclosing any merger plans at all (M)

headline: Markets Shake Off Turmoil But Finish the Day Mixed
abstract: Stock market shrugs off early worries about rising interest rates and helps push some broad indexes to record highs, but overall results end mixed; Dow Jones industrial average closes down 33.64 points, to 8,061.42; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closes down 3.22 points, to 970.62; Nasdaq composite index rises 4.08 points, to record 1,745.85; Russell 2000 index gains 0.89 point, to record 464.55; table (M)

headline: FLUOR CHIEF TO RETIRE EARLY AFTER DISAPPOINTING YEAR
abstract: Fluor Corp says its chairman and chief executive Leslie G McCraw will take early retirement, effective Jan 1; Peter J Fluor, who is chairman and chief executive of Texas Crude Energy Inc, will serve as nonexecutive chairman of Fluor until replacement can be found for McCraw (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Global Pact Bans Bribery In Victory For U.S. Business  Industrialized nations agreed to follow the United States' lead and formally outlaw the practice of bribing foreign government officials.

headline: U.N. Takes Up Iraqi Refusal On Inspections
abstract: UN Security Council resumes discussion on Iraq's refusal to open all sites requested by arms inspectors, but there is no indication that Council members are prepared to take any action to end standoff (S)

headline: Bond Unit Chiefs At Merged Firm
abstract: Salomon Smith Barney Inc names its various bond unit heads (S)

headline: The Tale Of the Secret Tapes
abstract: Documents from court, corporate and Government files describe how events in Archer Daniels Midland price-fixing saga unfolded; they provide unprecedented look inside largest price-fixing cartel ever brought down by law enforcement; they also portray inquiry riddled with troubles from the start, one that began almost by accident; chronology of events; photos; chart (L)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: WESTERN WATER CO., San Diego, a water seller, agreed to buy Vidler Water Co. from Global Equity Corp. for $98.9 million in stock.     POPE & TALBOT INC., Portland, Ore., a wood-fiber products company, agreed to pay $53 million to raise its stake in Harmac Pacific Inc., Vancouver, British Columbia, to just over 50 percent.

headline: Midwest Banks In Mega-Merger Of $6.7 Billion As Deals Go On
abstract: National City Corp, in banking's latest mega-merger, agrees to acquire First of America Bank Corp in $6.7 billion deal that would create 13th-largest bank in country; combination of First City, which is based in Cleveland, and First of America, based in Kalamazoo, Mich, would be significant step toward consolidating banking in Midwest, which remains one of nation's most fragmented banking markets; Ohio and Michigan are considered to be two most 'over-banked' states in region (M)

headline: Hong Kong Stocks Plunge but Then Recover
abstract: Hong Kong stocks plummet as concern grows that higher interest rates and oversupply of land and housing will hurt developers' earnings, but they rally in afternoon; Hang Seng index falls as much as 658.9 points, or 5.3 percent, to 11,744.12--lowest since Sept 26, 1996; by afternoon, index is down 149.92 points, or 1.2 percent, to 12,253.18 (S)

headline: U.S. Effort to Cut Its Dues Dies at an Angry U.N.
abstract: US effort to lower its UN dues is doomed for now, making it even less likely that Congress will release more than $1 billion in back dues; Congress has linked paying arrears to reduction in dues, while other UN members refuse to even reconsider American assessment until dues are paid up; US is now assessed 25 percent of UN budget; US is also opposing third-world attempts to inflate UN budget, as well as drastic lowering of dues of poorest nations; US envoy Richard Sklar comments on intense negotiations over dues issue (S)

headline: Once-Buoyant Hopes Sink in Indonesia's Slump
abstract: Indonesia's economy--after prolonged economic boom--has sharply slowed; as country's macro-economic ills trickle down to workers who have seen friends and colleagues lose their jobs, many are bracing themselves for period of rising prices, high unemployment and social unrest; photo (L)

headline: Columbia Healthcare Strives for New Image
abstract: The scandal is everywhere at the Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corporation -- in the chitchat in employee lounges, in the news articles clipped by nurses.

headline: Correction
abstract: Correction to Business Best Sellers list on Dec 7, which, in citing Donald J Trump's book Trump: The Art of the Comeback, referred incorrectly to his finances

headline: London Journal; All Is Not Lost: Art of Insult Survives 'New Britain'
abstract: Salman Rushdie and John le Carre, two of Britain's best-known writers, are engaged in war of words--hurling cascade of abusive comments at one another at time when many Britons are lamenting country's loss of its special touch for literary invective; exchanges have taken place on pages of The Guardian, time-honored arena for mudslinging, and follows le Carre's complaint that he has become victim of witchhunt by zealots of political correctness in US aimed at portraying him as anti-Semitic for portrayals in his 1996 novel, The Tailor of Panama; Rushdie, who has called le Carre 'an illiterate pompous ass,' says le Carre should have had same concern for him when he became target of fatwa declared by Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini of Iran following publication of his book, The Satanic Verses, that was perceived as slight to Islam; le Carre says Rushdie is self-canonizing and arrogant, and has been blinded by pursuit of increased royalties for himself from physical danger that sales of his book poses to others; photos (M)

headline: Thailand Eases Curbs On Foreign Holdings
abstract: Bank of Thailand says restrictions on foreign holdings in domestic financial institutions will be eased (S)

headline: Stocks Fall in Hong Kong and Malaysia
abstract: Stocks tumble in Malaysia and in Hong Kong as turmoil continues to sweep Asian markets; Malaysian stocks fall 6 percent in trading on concerns over country's weakening currency, higher interest rates and slowing economy; in Hong Kong, stocks fall for third day as local interest rates rise sharply (S)

headline: Microsoft Flouts Court Order, U.S. Charges
abstract: Justice Department accuses Microsoft Corp of 'disobedience' and of 'jerry-rigging its own products' in response to Federal judge's order to allow makers of personal computers to license Microsoft's Windows operating system without being forced to also load its Internet browsing software; comments are made in filing in US District Court in Washington, as antitrust battle between Government and Microsoft intensifies (L)

headline: INVESTING WITH: David K. Schafer; Strong Schafer Value
abstract: Interview with Strong Schafer Value fund manager David K Schafer on his investment strategy; graphs; photos (M)

headline: Stacked Up At Boeing; Plane Giant Tries to Recover From Its Snarls in Production
abstract: Boeing Co's ambitious plan to more than double its monthly jet output, to 43 planes from 18, has spun out of control; in early October, overwhelmed by part shortages and other foul-ups, Boeing temporarily halted production of 747 as well as smaller 737; few weeks later, Boeing posted $1.6 billion third-quarter charge and its first operating loss in 28 years; problems will cost another $1 billion next year; Boeing shares have slipped more than 8 percent since early October; company has been deluged with shareholder lawsuits asserting that top executives deliberately soft-pedaled problems to prop up Boeing's share price before $16.3 billion acquisition of McDonnell Douglas Corp in August; graphs; photo (L)

abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.63   5.75   5.28        3-MO. headline: FUNDS WATCH
abstract: Elaine Garzarelli closes her recently opened Garzarelli Balanced Fund; says she does not have time to market it (S)

headline: Free Namibia Stumps the Naysayers
abstract: Little has changed in Namibia in the seven years since it achieved its independence from South Africa, which still dominated the economy; donor countries are unhappy that Sam Nujoma wants a third term as President, but his credibility from 23 years as guerrilla leader is seen as balancing competing factions; black-white relations are peaceful, but those between Ovambo-speaking people, who dominate Nujoma's party, and Hereros and Namas are tense; map; photo (M)

headline: CONMED SHARES UP ON DEAL WITH BRISTOL-MYERS
abstract: Conmed Corp shares rise 19 percent on Nov 28, after company says that it will buy Linvatec Corp, Bristol-Myers Squibb Co's surgery equipment unit, for $370 million (S)

headline: Could Japan Be Next?
abstract: Clinton Administration officials are concerned about whether contagion in Asian markets could spread to Japan; few officials will discuss matter publicly, except to recite reasons why Japan is different and will not succumb; reasons they cite are compelling: Japanese have prodigious national savings, war chest of $230 billion in United States Treasury bonds and industrial strength that is rivaled only by United States (M)

headline: FOUNDATION HEALTH REDUCES PRICE FOR PHYSICIANS HEALTH
abstract: Foundation Health Systems Inc says it cut price of its acquisition of Physicians Health Services to $271 million from $280 million after Physicians Health failed to amend certain joint venture agreements (S)

headline: To the U.S. Envoy in Hanoi, the Future Is Paramount
abstract: For Pete Peterson, a former Air Force pilot who spent six and a half years as a prisoner here during the Vietnam War, coming to Hanoi six months ago as the Ambassador of the United States was ''the final act in a cathartic process.''    ''You have to make the decision to heal after an experience like that,'' he said of his long incarceration in Hoa Lo Prison here after his plane was shot down in 1966.

headline: China:Too Strong a Yuan
abstract: As the currencies of developing and newly industrialized countries across East Asia came tumbling down in recent months, one remained immovable: the Chinese yuan.

headline: Women Hold 10.6% of Fortune 500 Board Seats, Study Says
abstract: Director seats held by women at nation's largest 500 companies rose last year to 10.6 percent of total, although rate of increase slowed compared with previous years; figures are from census conducted by Catalyst, nonprofit women's research group; Catalyst says survey showed progress in several areas: that 84 percent of Fortune 500 companies have woman on their board, compared with 69 percent in 1993, and that 36 percent of companies have two or more women directors; Catalyst even finds large company with equal number of men and women directors: Golden West Financial Corp (M)

headline: Have Pump, Will Travel: Combining Breast-Feeding and a Career
abstract: Many women are overcoming difficulties associated with breast feeding their children and working by using breast pumps and having greater flexibility in their work schedules; scheduling techniques used by some mothers discussed; photo of Dr Jacqueline Cosme who takes advantage of her drive time to use breast pump (M)

headline: Catching Up With the Web
abstract: Are you going on line to do business with your mutual fund? If so, you've joined a rapidly growing club of investors, according to a new study.     In its second annual look at Internet use, American Century Investments, the fund group based in Kansas City, Mo., found that fund investors are becoming more knowledgeable about the Internet. ''While our 1996 data indicated that mutual fund Web site proliferation was slightly ahead of investor demand, this year's study points to the beginning of a trend toward increased utilization of fund information and services available via the World Wide Web.'' wrote Mary Witwer, American Century's director of electronic commerce, in a statement with the study's results.

headline: Teachers Strike in Ontario, Closing Thousands of Schools
abstract: Most of 126,000 public and Catholic school teachers in Ontario go on strike in largest teachers' strike ever in North America; nearly all of province's 4,742 schools are closed; teachers are protesting provincial government proposal to overhaul education system by weakening local school boards and giving government power to determine class size and tax rates (M)

headline: Group Says China Is Holding Leader of Underground Church
abstract: Supporters of underground Catholic movement in China say authorities have detained Bishop Su Zhimin, prominent church leader who has repeatedly defied Government attempt to control religious worship; Bishop Su's disappearance adds another sensitive political issue to obstacles faced by Pres Jiang Zemin when he visits Untied States in late October; he is scheduled to meet members of Congress, many of whom have raised concern about religious freedom in China (M)

headline: As Hedge Funds Grow, Their Walls Don't Look So High
abstract: Hedge funds, which have been investment vehicles for the rich, are now becoming both more common and modestly more accessible; those changes may be timely because stock market's stunning swings last week may make these investments far more attractive; although their returns lag behind other investments during good times, hedge funds significantly outperform the market when it declines; graph (L)

headline: $26 MILLION INVESTMENT IN ENGINE UNIT SET
abstract: Deutsche Lufthansa A.G. said yesterday that it had agreed to invest $26 million for a 20 percent stake in the Heico Corporation's engine parts subsidiary, Heico Aerospace. The German airline's investment includes $16 million to partly finance accelerated development of replacement parts for jet engines. Lufthansa had pretax profit of 119 million marks, or $69.3 million, for the first six months of 1996. Heico, based in Hollywood, Fla., is an aerospace and aviation products maker.

headline: Bond Prices Falter a Bit On Sales Data
abstract: Treasury securities slip after Commerce Dept report indicates retail sales last month were stronger than expected; 30-year bond falls 16/32, to price of 99 25/32; its yield rose to 6.39 percent, from 6.35 percent previous day (S)

headline: S.E.C. Staff Accuses KPMG Peat Marwick of Securities Violations
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission accuses accounting firm KPMG Peat Marwick of violating Federal securities laws by auditing Porta Systems Corp that was being managed by KPMG consultant; case's focus is unit called KPMG Baymark, created in January 1995 to provide troubled companies with management help and investment banking services; about two years ago, SEC officials warned KPMG Peat Marwick that it lacked independence from the company because of consulting arrangment; KPMG Baymark partner, Edward R Olson, became acting operations officer at Porta, just as KPMG began auditing its 1995 financial statements (L)

headline: Kyoto Meeting Moves Closer to an Agreement to Cut Greenhouse Gases
abstract: Negotiators from over 150 countries, in meeting in Kyoto, Japan, move closer to agreement requiring reductions in emission of heat-trapping greenhouse gases by industrial countries, but firm deal continues to elude them (M)

headline: Market Place; AT&T's soaring stock is doing the talking for the company.
abstract: Market Place column on rise in stock of AT&T Corp; says since July 18 the company's shares have risen to $59.125 from $34.375; holds AT&T's announcement that it has agreed to sell its credit card business to Citicorp for $3.5 billion in cash is just most recent and visible component of aggressive turnaround strategy that has upgraded company's reputation and stock for first time in years (L)

headline: Sanofi and Bristol-Myers Will Market Drug
abstract: Sanofi SA and Bristol-Myers Squibb Co receive approval from Food and Drug Administration to market Irbesartan, anti-hypertension drug (S)

headline: ASSOCIATES FIRST CAPITAL TO BUY AUTO LEASING OPERATION
abstract: Associates First Capital Corp agrees to buy commercial auto fleet leasing operation of AT&T Capital Corp, to expand its existing fleet management unit; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Netanyahu Defiantly Defending Botched Assassination Attempt
abstract: Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu defends Israeli assassination attempt against Hamas leader, Khaled Meshal, in Jordan as just and vital fight against terrorism, and vows to carry on; does not specifically acknowledge Israeli role, but charges that Meshal is responsible for recent suicide bombings, and says he is proud of agents who do Israel's 'secret work' against terrorists; statement comes after Sheil Ahmed Yassin, founder and icon of Hamas, is flown from Jordan to ecstatic welcome in Gaza; two Mossad intelligence agents involved in botched assassination are also flown back to Israel; Israel releases 20 more Palestinian prisoners with promise of 50 more; US mediator Dennis Ross arrives to preside over first formal Israeli-Palestinian meeting in six months (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.69   5.53   5.58        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.00   4.95   4.97        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.17   5.14   5.10        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.60   3.59   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.12   6.12   6.54        30-YR. TREAS. headline: GE CAPITAL TO BUY LENDER FROM SWISS BANK
abstract: GE Capital Services agrees to buy Bank Prokredit, consumer credit and auto lender, from Swiss Bank Corp for undisclosed amount (S)

headline: Split Over Poorer Countries' Role Puts Cloud on Global-Warming Talks
abstract: Elements of possible agreement on cutting industrialized countries' emissions of heat-trapping waste gases begin to emerge from intensive negotiations in Kyoto, but there is no such movement apparent on immediate role to be played by developing countries in controlling the gases; that poses threat to overall prospects for success in talks or for US acceptance of any agreement that is worked out (M)

headline: Bre-X Is Facing a New Suit in Alberta
abstract: Bre-X Minerals Ltd faces another class-action suit on behalf of as many as 100 Bre-X shareholders; suit will join others filed by investors eager to recoup losses in Bre-X, one of most spectacular stock market frauds in history (S)

headline: Save Now, Pay Later And Come Out Ahead
abstract: New tax law might seem to create incentive to take tax bite now on pay that might otherwise be deferred, so that balance can be invested and its growth taxed at new lower capital gains rate; but for earners in top salaried tax bracket, numbers prove otherwise; chart (M)

headline: American Home To Sell 2 Units
abstract: American Home Products Corp is seeking buyer for its medical device units Sherwood Davis & Geck and Quinton Instrument Co (S)

headline: Treasury Securities Fall in Price
abstract: US Treasury prices fall in shortened session, first decline in bonds in five sessions; price of 30-year Treasury bond falls 19/32, to 103; yield rises to 5.91 percent from 5.87 percent on Dec 23; graph (M)

headline: Edwin Mansfield, 67, Scholar Of Economics and Technology
abstract: Edwin Mansfield, a leading scholar of the economics of technological change, dies at 67; photo (S)

headline: Nabisco Offers to Buy $1.23 Billion in Notes
abstract: Nabisco Holdings Corp offers to purchase $1.23 billion of Nabisco Inc notes due in 1999 and 2000, as it seeks to secure lower interest rates on its debt; RJR Nabisco Holdings Corp owns 80.5 percent of Nabisco's shares and has said it would seek spinoff before end of 1998 (S)

headline: Removing the Suspense From Your Trades
abstract: Minding Your Business column answers question whether it is best to use a market or limit order when buying or selling stocks? photo (L)

headline: Accounting Magic Erases Big Loss
abstract: Article on 3Com Corp's decision to count six goods months of US Robotics Corp earnings twice to erase losses at 3Com; says accountants say practice is completely legal under bizarre merger accounting rules now in force; questions financial health of 3Com; table (L)0

headline: EASTERN BANK IN DEAL TO BUY EMERALD ISLE BANCORP
abstract: Eastern Bank Corp agrees to acquire rival Massachusetts bank, Emerald Isle Bancorp Inc, for $80 million (S)

headline: BANK OF NEW YORK ADDING ESI SECURITIES AND B-TRADE
abstract: Bank of New York Co agrees to buy ESI Securities Co and its affiliate, B-Trade Services, for undisclosed sum (S)

headline: Will Asia's Malady Infect the World?
abstract: Complacency in international bond market that greeted Asia's economic woes has evaporated; managers who shifted assets to Latin American bonds are now scrambling to get out, as are stock fund managers who bought Latin equities, fearing Asian malady may spread; increased investor aversion to emerging markets could make it harder for even nations with good economic conditions to attract capital and could have positive implications for American markets; graph (M)

headline: Briton's Dream of Glory Is Gone With the Wind
abstract: Richard Branson is about to begin first non-stop, round-the-world balloon voyage ever made when his balloon is freed by gust of wind and ascends crewless into skies over Morocco; map; photo (M)

headline: Bonds Rally as 30-Year Treasury's Yield Slips to 6.14%
abstract: Treasury bonds end mostly higher, deriving strength from another decline in wobbly stock market and diminished fears that Federal Reserve will raise interest rates anytime soon; price of benchmark 30-year Treasury bond increases 27/32, to 103 7/32; yield eases to 6.14 percent from 6.20 percent; graph (M)

headline: In Japan, Tricky Course on Bailout Calls for Double Reverse
abstract: Analysis of Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto of Japan's instruction to ruling Liberal Democratic Party to devise plan for using public funds to bail out Japan's shaky banking system; says Hashimoto's instructions were 180-degree reversal of his position on Nov 19, which in turn was reversal of comment he made on Nov 18; at that time, he indicated support for using taxpayer money to help banks unload trillions of yen in bad debts that they have carried since bubble in Japanese economy burst in early 1990's (L)

headline: VIEWPOINT; Making the Giants Nimbler
abstract: Article by Charles Sirois, chairman and chief executives of Telesystem Ltd and Teleglobe Inc, on bidding war for MCI Communications; holds large telecommunications companies must change way they approach partnerships and strategic alliances with smaller ones; holds they should focus on their power of distribution, not on controlling infrastructure (M)

headline: S.E.C. Staff Sees Plan as Flawed
abstract: Staff of Securities and Exchange Commission is critical of paper written by American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, which proposed that accountants should police themselves; mergers by large accounting firms make issue urgent by increasing likelihood that single firm is doing consulting work as well as auditing for particular client (S)

headline: Lazard Pays $12 Million In Settlement
abstract: Lazard Freres & Co agrees to pay $12 million to settle civil charges related to fraud reportedly committed by former executives Richard P Poirier and James E Eaton involved in municipal securities offerings; two executives are charged with conspiracy and fraud for secretly paying former Stephens Inc executive Michael S deVegter, former Lazard partner, to steer municipal bond business in Georgia to Lazard in 1992; Federal investigators say agreement and payments defrauded Fulton County government; Lazard's settlement also covers civil charges over municipal bond offering in Duval County, Fla, where Securities and Exchange Commission said firm paid consultants and lobbyists to help it obtain business although county's school board had forbidden such practices (L)

headline: WESTERN WIRELESS TO SELL 19.9% STAKE TO HUTCHISON
abstract: Western Wireless Corp agrees to sell 19.9 percent stake in its Western PCS Corp unit to Hutchison Telecommunications Ltd for $248 million; Hutchison will also buy 5 percent interest in parent company for about $74 million (S)

headline: For Reluctant Shoppers, A Turn Toward Tailors
abstract: Small but growing number of young professional women are turning to custom-designed clothes; many of them loath shopping and complain of fit, quality and styling available in ready-to-wear clothing; are seeking out small, independent tailoring operations; photo (M)

headline: Czech Banker Named Premier in a Move to Calm Political Storm
abstract: Pres Vaclav Havel names Czech National Bank governor Josef Tosovsky Prime Minister, replacing Vaclav Klaus, who resigned over campaign finance scandal; suggests Tosovsky, nonpartisan technocrat, can bring much-needed stability to roiling political situation (M)

headline: AIRTOUCH TO PURCHASE CELLULAR STAKES FOR $245 MILLION
abstract: Airtouch Communications Inc agrees to acquire cellular phone operations from Telephone and Data Systems Inc and a subsidiary, United States Cellular Corp, for more than $245 million (S)

headline: Fund to Aid Technology in Schools Facing Big F.C.C. Cuts
abstract: Federal Communications Commission, under pressure from big long-distance phone companies, reportedly plans to cut fees carriers must begin paying in Jan to help schools, libraries and health care institutions invest in Internet technology and other advanced communications; new FCC Chmn William E Kennard reportedly backs cutting maximum beneficiaries will get under 1996 Telecommunications Act by $750 million from act's ceiling of $2.65 billion; FCC decided to reduce charges after AT&T and MCI Communications Corp said fees could lead to higher rates and threatened to specify charges on customers' bills (M)

headline: Stocks Down, With the Dow Falling 31.64
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average falls 31.64 points, or four-tenths of 1 percent, to 7,660.13; Nasdaq composite index falls 10.38 points, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,499.53, and Standard & Poor's 500 Index drops 6.43 points, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 932.70; chart (M)

headline: Bavarian Companies Buy 95% of Grundig
abstract: Group of Bavarian companies buys 95 percent stake in Grundig AG, unprofitable consumer electronics maker (S)

headline: As Asia Teeters, IMF's Critics Call for New Battle Plans
abstract: BANGKOKâ€”  Despite an agreement to accelerate $10 billion in aid to South Korea, economists warn that economic conditions in Asia have deteriorated so steeply that radical new policies may be needed to pull the region from beneath its mountain of debt.

headline: U.S. Alliance Brings Prestige To Argentines
abstract: Pres Clinton's recent decision to name Argentina non-NATO ally of US is seen as latest proof for many Argentines that country is finally returning to prominence in industrialized world after decades of social and economic ruin; while distinction of non-NATO ally is largely symbolic, Argentina is first country in hemisphere to receive it (M)

headline: A Shipping Dispute Flares With Japanese
abstract: A long-running trade dispute with Japan, over American access to its ports, worsened suddenly yesterday.    The Federal Maritime Commission in Washington told the Coast Guard to bar most Japanese cargo ships from American ports, and to detain any Japanese ships currently in port.

headline: U.S. Official Assails China On Trade Gap
abstract: US Commerce Sec William M Daley attacks China's growing trade imbalance with US; Daley, visiting China for trade talks, tries to pressure China's leaders to open their markets further or do anything that will reverse widening gap between what China sells to America and what it buys (M)

headline: Albright Quest: A Silver Lining in the Middle East
abstract: News analysis of US State Sec Albright's meeting with Israeli Prime Min Netanyahu; American officials are eager to point up bright side of Israeli-Arab negotiations, noting Middle East is viewed as important test of Albright's stewardship as Secretary of State (M)

headline: Indonesian Currency Slides 12% vs. Dollar
abstract: Indonesian rupiah tumbles as much as 12 percent on expectations that burden of repaying foreign loans will deepen country's debt crisis (S)

headline: NEXTLEVEL SYSTEMS TO SHUT PUERTO RICO OPERATIONS
abstract: Nextlevel Systems Inc to close it Barceloneta, PR, plant at end of 1998, resulting in loss of 1,100 jobs, about 13 percent of work force (S)

headline: Donna Karan Plans to Trim Expenses and Operations
abstract: Donna Karan International chief executive John D Idol outlines his plans to return fashion company to profitability; plan calls for reduction of expenses, paring of certain operations in all of company's divisions and increased focus on licensed products and stores; company has lost money since it went public in June 1996 (M)

headline: Chairman Outlines Blueprint For a Slimmed-Down Pepsico
abstract: Craig E Weatherup, chairman and chief executive of Pepsi-Cola Co, offers blueprint for Pepsi's slimmed-down, more focused future; tells conference of National Soft Drink Assn that after shedding fast-food restaurants, focus will be on Pepsi and Frito-Lay; vows substantial increases in company's advertising and marketing budget and renewed competitiveness in fountain-syrup business in restaurants; hints at introduction of new lemon-lime beverage to compete with Sprite and 7-Up; claims that internationally Coca-Cola had made 'overt--even covert' attempts to drive Pepsi out, or buy Pepsi out; Coca-Cola spokesman declines to comment on Weatherup's speech (M)

headline: Jordan's King Still Angry but Netanyahu Gains Support
abstract: Public opinion poll, two weeks after bungled assassination attempt by Israeli agents against Hamas leader Khaled Meshal in Jordan, suggests affair has not hurt Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu politically at home, but that King Hussein remains furious at what he regards as betrayal of his friendship (M)

headline: Marlins Star Is a Hero Cuba Ignores
abstract: Cubans from one end of island to other are exulting in exploits of Livan Hernandez, Florida Marlins pitcher who defeated Cleveland Indians, 7-4, in first game of World Series; Hernandez and other Cuban baseball players who have defected to US are officially regarded by Government as traitors to Cuban Revolution (M)

headline: Winnie Mandela's Next Hurdle: Truth Panel
abstract: Winnie Madikizela-Mandela, fighting to win South Africa's deputy presidency against opposition of governing African National Congress leadership, must face Truth and Reconciliation Commission probe of her role in up to dozen killings during late 1980's; several members of her former soccer team are expected to portray team as squad of hired killers who helped discredit or kill her political rivals; photo (M)

headline: NABISCO AGREES TO BUY CORNNUTS, SNACK FOOD PRODUCER
abstract: Nabisco Holdings Corp says it agreed to purchase Cornnuts Inc for undisclosed price; says it will eventually close Cornnuts headquarters in Alameda, Calif, where about 30 people work (S)

headline: Kodak Raises Its Job-Cut Total Sharply
abstract: Eastman Kodak Co drastically raises company's planned number of job eliminations to 16,600, saying 10,000 figure announced only a month ago was just estimate and that managers had since found more positions they could cut; company also increases its previously announced charge against fourth-quarter earnings by $500 million, to $1.5 billion, to reflect severance costs for more terminated employees (L)

headline: ACTIVISION BUYS 2 GAME DISTRIBUTORS FOR $48.6 MILLION
abstract: Activision Inc said it acquired two closely held video-game distributors--Centresoft Ltd of Britain and NBG Distribution of Germany--for $48.6 million in stock (S)

headline: INSURER IN AGONY: Behind the Bleeding at Oxford -- A special report; Giant H.M.O. Becomes the Victim of Its Own Ambition
abstract: Article on financial problems plaguing Oxford Health Plans Inc; says while computer trouble may be one of company's biggest irritants, it is becoming clear that it also suffers from much more serious and fundamental problems; Oxford's critics says company seems to have poor grasp of how much it costs to deliver care it is promising; holds current leadership, headed by company's founder, Stephen F Wiggins, is, by many accounts, doing poor job of crisis management; says some doctors, tired of excuses, are defecting, filing complaints or otherwise acting up, putting chink in one of company's most valuable assets: its network of blue-ribbon physicians, many from New York area's most prestigious teaching hospitals; graph; photos (L)

headline: Israel's Controversy Over Religion Affects Donations by Jews in U.S.
abstract: Leaders of Jewish organizations say, while American Jews are contributing record sums to Jewish causes at home and abroad, thousands are withholding or diverting up to $20 million in donations in 1997, partly in protest against religious and peace policies of Israel's conservative Government; Bernard C Moscovitz, chief operating officer for United Jewish Appeal, primary fund-raising vehicle for Jewish social welfare in Israel and US, says Jewish giving is currently 2 percent higher than in 1996, but that giving had been running 8.5 percent of 1997 until some leaders urged that donations be withheld or diverted; others warn withholding or redirecting of contributions could turn into major philanthropic rebellion if Orthodox Jews succeed in cementing their control over religious life in Israel; say shortfall of $15 million to $20 million in projected donations in year of huge Wall Street profits is significant; dispute over Orthodox control, or 'who is a Jew,' points to deeper changes under way in Jewish philanthropy--such as aging Jewish population and generational shift in giving patterns, high rate of religious intermarriage and social integration among Jews, changing relationship to Israel and fraying of some of most successful Jewish fund-raising systems in history (M)

headline: Rome Talks Seek to Defuse Trade Disputes
abstract: Dismantling hidden barriers to increased trans-Atlantic trade is focus of two days of discussions in Rome, Italy, by European and American business leaders with government officials from both sides of Atlantic; participants in discussions plead with US and European Union for a 'globally harmonized and market-driven legal framework' for electronic commerce, and make proposals aimed at defusing trans-Atlantic conflict that threatens estimated $4.5 billion of annual pharmaceutical trade (L)/

headline: Iraq Extends Deadline for American Arms Inspectors to Leave
abstract: Iraq extends its deadline for expelling American arms inspectors while diplomatic delegation sent by UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan tries to get expulsion order lifted; UN team of about 40 inspectors includes 6 Americans (S)

headline: In Cambodia, Wars End, But the Dying Continues
abstract: Land mines continue to take high toll in Cambodia, where as many as 40,000 people have lost limbs to mines and civilian deaths and injuries continue at rate of over 200 a month; mine-clearing agency says it will take 30 years to clear farmland and populated areas of mines, while those in remote forests will probably never be cleared; Vietnam Veterans of America Foundation runs rehabilitation center for amputees; photo (M)

headline: Car Makers Voice Complaints About Limiting Gas Emissions
abstract: Chief executives of General Motors, Ford Motor and Chrysler Corp, meeting with Pres Clinton, voice complaints about the Administration's interest in limiting the emissions of gases that may contribute to global warming (S)

headline: A New Leash On an Old Tax Strategy
abstract: Taxpayer Relief Act, enacted last summer, was widely reported to have killed technique long used by investors to preserve stock gains today but defer paying capital gains taxes on them for years; Congress has not forbid technique, known as shorting against the box; new law just limits its use so that taxes can be deferred for only one year; in shorting against the box an investor borrows number of shares equal to number whose gains investor wants to preserve; investor then quickly sells borrowed stock, creating short position to match long one (L)

headline: Now, a Pure Play Among Top Battery Makers
abstract: Rayovac Corp goes public in $93.8 million offering, providing investors with first large 'pure play' among battery makers; company, which has 10 percent of battery market and earned $432.6 million in sales for year ending in September, has a team of new managers and boasts a brand name that has been around since 1921; however, it carries high debt owing to leveraged buyout by Thomas H Lee Co, and until recently it wasted time and money promoting its rechargeable alkaline batteries at expense of its regular alkaline batteries; photo of Michael Jordan, who appears in its ads; table (M)

headline: Confidence Of Consumers Is Surging
abstract: Conference Board's overall confidence index jumped to 134.5 in December from 128.1 in November, with consumers' appraisal of both present situation and their expectations for six months ahead posting substantial gains; consumer confidence is at its highest level since mid-1969; graph

headline: Stocks Lower in Tokyo
abstract: Japan's Nikkei index is down 196 points, or 1.17b percent, at 16,490.51 at midday Dec 10; on Dec 9, Nikkei rose 554.94 points, or 3.44 percent (S)

headline: PREMIER OF INDIA QUITS, DEEPENING POLITICAL BEDLAM
abstract: I K Gujral resigns as India's Prime Minister, deepening country's political chaos and economic uncertainty; move comes in wake of Congress Party's withdrawal of support for Gujral's 14-party coalition; few can say who might succeed Gujral or what his departure will mean for issues that have been stalled for months; photo (M)

headline: Glaxo Sells Drug Lines
abstract: Glaxo Wellcome Inc sells several prescription drug product lines to closely held King Pharmaceuticals Inc; deal includes Septra, used to treat infectious diseases, Neosporin ophthalmic ointment, for eye infections, and Neosporin irrigant, to help prevent catheter-related problems (S)

headline: Equity and Convertible Debt Set to Be Offered This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Alaska Air Group Inc., Seattle, 3 million shares, 2.6 million in the United States and Canada. Merrill Lynch & Co.

headline: HS RESOURCES TO PAY AMOCO $333 MILLION FOR PROPERTIES
abstract: HS Resources to acquire oil and natural gas exploration and production properties in northeast Colorado from Amoco Corp in deal worth some $333 million (S)

headline: Talk of Tougher Medicine for Korea's Ills
abstract: Analysis of South Korea's worsening economic problems; says a week after world came to South Korea's rescue with $57 billion in emergency aid, country's economic problems have worsened so rapidly that US officials fear that far more drastic steps may be needed to stop financial hemorrhaging that is already threatening world markets; South Korean currency, the won, has fallen 34 percent since Dec 3, the day bailout was announced; graph (L)

headline: Paid Notice: Memorials  ELAHI, CYRUS
abstract: ELAHI-Cyrus. One with love in his heart never dies.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: MACERICH INC., Santa Monica, Calif., a real estate investment trust, acquired the Citadel, a shopping mall in Colorado Springs, for $108 million.    KIMBERLY-CLARK CORP., Irving, Tex., completed its purchase of Tecnol Medical Products and will eliminate about 400 jobs, mostly administrative positions, while increasing manufacturing capability.

headline: KLM Forms an Alliance With Japan Air System
abstract: KLM Royal Dutch Airlines agrees to form alliance with Japan Air System Co, Japan's third-largest airline (S)

headline: In West Bank, 'Time' for Settlements Is Clearly Not 'Out'
abstract: Israeli settlers in Ofra, West Bank, oppose Sec of State Madeleine K Albright's suggestion that Israel take pause in settlement construction to break deadlock in peace negotiations with Palestinians; Peace Now, Israeli organization that monitors settlement activity, says 4,714 housing units are now under construction in 61 of 140 West Bank settlements; map; photo (M)

headline: For Europe, Greenhouse-Gas Issue Is How Much to Cut
abstract: European efforts to cut emissions of greenhouse gases implicated in global warming discussed in light of European pressure on United States in Kyoto, Japan, talks for emissions cuts; Europe, which releases half the volume per person of such gases as United States, has been aided by some one-time factors and will have hard time meeting own ambitious goals as economy grows; graph; photo (M)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERNAN, LESLIE HADDEN
abstract: KERNAN-Leslie Hadden on October 21, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Walter Avery Kernan; mother of Anita Halton, Mary Rutherfurd, Emily Rafferty, Nancy Chamberlain, Beatrice and Charles; grandmother of Anita Halton; Leslie Coleman, Lily and Emily Rutherfurd, Nicholas and Sara Rafferty, and Katherine Chamberlain; and sister of Anita Hadden Page and the late Hamilton Hadden Jr. Funeral Mass, 10:30 A.M., Friday, October 24th, at Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue at 84th Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Interfaith Neighbors, Inc., 247 East 82nd Street, New York, New York 10028.

headline: No Accord, and Little Optimism, at Bonn Talks on Global Warming
abstract: Delegates from 143 countries ended their preliminary talks on global warming here today with no agreement on key issues and growing concern about the prospect for success at the concluding meeting, to be held in Kyoto, Japan, in early December.     The United States' long-awaited proposal for cutting emissions of heat-trapping greenhouse gases has been scornfully attacked as too weak by delegates and environmentalists from around the world. And there is no sign that American negotiators are about to yield. Still, the Americans themselves said there was more than a little cause for hope, and they have been lobbying their counterparts here, urging them to take a closer look at the American proposal.

headline: Britain Getting That Left-Out Feeling
abstract: ''People who are married do not want others in the bedroom.''    With these arch words, the Finance Minister of France, Dominique Strauss-Kahn, rebuked the British Government earlier this month, saying that the British would not be welcome to join in some of the increasingly intimate discussions of the European Union.

headline: Another Brokerage Firm In Bankruptcy in Japan
abstract: Maruso Securities Co, midsize Japanese brokerage firm, files for voluntary bankruptcy after it is unable to obtain new loans amid worsening scarcity of credit; chmn Masahisa Hayashi comments; photo (S)

headline: A Dissident Speaks: 'I Don't Want to Wait' for Democracy
abstract: Excerpts from interview with Wei Jingsheng, recently released Chinese dissident, on his plans to promote democracy in China from abroad; photo (M)

headline: Acapulco's Workers Dig Out After 120 Die in Hurricane
abstract: Residents of Acapulco, Mex, dig out from mud and debris left by Hurricane Pauline, which killed at least 141 people; nearly all of victims are Mexicans who live in precariously built communities high in hills surrounding Acapulco Bay; map (M)

headline: U.S. FILTER SWEETENS BID FOR MEMTEC TO $379.5 MILLION
abstract: US Filter Corp sweetens its unsolicited bid for Memtec Ltd to about $379.5 million from $330 million (S)

headline: William Smalley, 74, Linguist for the Hmong
abstract: William A Smalley, who helped Hmong people of Laos develop their first permanent written language; dies at age 74 (M)

headline: Burson-Marsteller Names a Chairman
abstract: Burson-Marsteller names Graham Phillips as chairman succeeding Harold Burson, who becomes founding chairman; company announces acquisition of Mead Point Group (S)

headline: MASCOTECH WILL MAKE A BID FOR THE REST OF TRIMAS
abstract: Mascotech Inc will offer to buy remaining 63 percent of Trimas Corp that it does not already own for $900 million (S)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: A partial list for this week.    MONDAY   Agree Rlty  General Mls  Harnischfeger   Pitney Bowes  Summit Pptys

headline: Gunpei Yokoi, Chief Designer Of Game Boy, Is Dead at 56
abstract: Gunpei Yokoi, chief designer of Game Boy and other products that helped transform Nintendo into worldwide colossus in video games, was killed in traffic accident in Japan on Oct 4; he was 56 years old; diagram; photo (L)

headline: Rubbermaid Picks Martin/Williams
abstract: Rubbermaid Inc names Martin/Williams to handle its consolidated domestic advertising account, with billings estimated at $10 million; majority of account had been handled by Meldrum & Fewsmith Communications (S)

headline: Carlos the Jackal on Trial For French Killings in 1975
abstract: Ilich Ramirez Sanchez, international terrorist known as Carlos, goes on trial in Paris on charges of killing two French security officials and a Lebanese informant 22 years ago; asks court to bar a terrorist victims' group named SOS-Attentats from proceedings because he says it is an agency of Zionist and American imperialism; photos (M)

headline: Espinosa de Henares Journal; The Nuns' Sad Story Inflames a Village in Spain
abstract: Last nuns at Roman Catholic convent in Espinosa de Henares, Spain, yield to threat of excommunication and move out on Oct 6; Bishop Jose Sanchez, who has been trying to shut convent for a year and imposed Oct 24 deadline, had to be protected from villagers during recent visit; map; photos (M)

headline: Clinton Plans a Visit To Bosnia Next Week
abstract: The President intends to visit American troops in Bosnia before Christmas and to begin building a public case for keeping some forces there past the current deadline of June, Administration officials said.     Details are not finalized, but Mr. Clinton may leave as soon as Sunday night for Tuzla and Sarajevo. The trip is described as a whirlwind visit, and the President will not stay overnight before returning to Washington.

abstract: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization           Dec. 5   Nov. 28   Dec. 6       1997   1997   1996       Gasoline production, daily   7.9   7.7   8.1       Distillate production, daily   3.8   3.5   3.7       Gasoline stocks   198.2   199.9   194.6       Distillate stocks   134.9   134.4   122.2       Crude imports, daily   8.0   8.0   8.0       Product imports, daily   1.8   1.7   1.7       Crude stocks   316.8   321.9   300.6       Crude production, daily   6.4   6.4   6.4       Refinery utilization (%)   94.8   96.0   94.2          Source: American Petroleum Institute

headline: As two new rides show, every special effect counts in Las Vegas.
abstract: Two motion-simulator rides are scheduled to open in Las Vegas; Race for Atlantis, Imax three-dimensional ride at Caesars Palace, relies heavily on three-dimensional effect that is signature of films created by Imax Corp; Star Trek: The Experience, at Las Vegas Hilton, is actually piece of traditional theater, in which actors provide big part of experience; drawing (M)

headline: Jerome H. Lemelson, an Inventor, Dies at 74
abstract: Jerome H Lemelson, prolific inventor who forced giant corporations to pay him for his ideas, dies at age 74; photo (M)
