headline: Dilbert walks and talks, and he bobs his head. On TV. For office products. Yes, office products.
abstract: Cartoon character Dilbert will make his television debut on Thanksgiving Day, as star of $30 million advertising campaign for Office Depot Inc; and for first time, Dilbert has been animated and given a voice; commercials were created by Wyse Advertising; cartoon (L)

headline: PRI AUTOMATION TO PAY $172 MILLION FOR EQUIPE
abstract: PRI Automation Inc says it will acquire Equipe Technologies Inc for $172 million plus additional $10.3 billion to cover options held by Equipe employees (S)

headline: Dim Asian Economies Casting Shadows in U.S.
abstract: Cumulative effect of Asia's financial crisis on American economy as whole could be harsh in the end; prices for Asian goods sold in America are falling, but more Asian imports could swell United States trade deficit to damaging level and shrink American operations that make similar goods, or push companies to move more operations abroad; many forecasters expect Asian crisis to slow growth of American economy by only half a percentage point, but some talk of decline of one percentage point, enough to cut back job creation and make low unemployment rate edge up gradually; photo (M)

headline: MCDONALD'S PLANS TO INVEST $1 BILLION IN LATIN AMERICA
abstract: McDonald's Corp will invest more than $1 billion in next three years to double its restaurants in Latin America (S)

headline: Hard Times Weaken a Malaysian Powerbroker
abstract: Malaysian Prime Min Mahathir Mohamad is facing unaccustomed criticism as his country encounters economic hardship; Mahathir has sought to take a place on world stage as leader among developing nations and proponent of liberal brand of Islam; photo (M)

headline: U-Turn or Merely A Jog in the Road?
abstract: President Clinton's conclusion that he could not win the votes he needed for broad trade authority marked a resounding change. Since the New Deal era, Congress has always concluded that freer trade benefits more American workers than it harms.

headline: U.S. Is to Help Army in Colombia Fight Drugs but Skeptics Abound
abstract: US approves sending more than $50 million in equipment to help Colombian military fight guerrillas involved in drug trafficking in southern part of country; aid is granted after military promises to protect human rights; US says nonlethal materiel is only to fight drug trafficking, but Gen Jose Manuel Bonett insists it could be used to fight insurgents; Gen Barry R McCaffrey, in Colombia, says Clinton Administration has not changed policy; photo; map; describes leftist militias as 'narcoguerrillas' (M)

headline: Easter Seal Society Selects Recipients
abstract: National Easter Seal Society to honor communications judged to enhance independence of people with disabilities (S)

headline: In Europe, a Flurry Of Corporate Deals
abstract: With mergers and acquisitions slowed in the United States because of Columbus Day, corporate buccaneers from France to Italy to Britain showed that they had discovered the free-wheeling ways of business in America.    In the insurance industry, an Italian company, Generali, made a $9 billion hostile bid for AGF of France, which only two weeks ago had been part of an Italian-French bid for a separate French insurer. Generali's offer came just one day after the Zurich Group of Switzerland and B.A.T. Industries of Britain announced that they were talking about merging their insurance and financial service businesses.

headline: Soros to Donate Millions More to Help Russia
abstract: Financier George Soros says he will donate as much as $500 million in next three years in Russia in effort to improve health care, expand educational opportunities and help retrain military for civilian jobs, interview; latest gift would make him leading philanthropist in Russia, as well as donor whose presence exceeds that of US, which gave Russia $95 million in aid in 1996; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: ADVANCED MICRO DEVICES INC., Sunnyvale, Calif., a maker of integrated circuits and microprocessors, said it had invested in the closely held Digital Anvil, Austin, Tex., a digital-game maker. Financial terms were not disclosed.

headline: Waste Management Chairman Quits, the Second in 9 Months
abstract: Waste Management Inc says its chairman and chief executive, Ronald T LeMay, has quit; he is second chief executive to leave troubled company in nine months; Robert Miller, turnaround specialist, will become acting chairman and chief executive; LeMay is returning to Sprint Corp, resuming his post as president and chief operating officer (M)

headline: Swiss Bank Net Called 'Significantly Higher'
abstract: Swiss Bank Corp says its net income in first nine months was 'significantly higher' than year earlier and that it expects higher full-year net (S)

headline: Philip Morris Plans Food Unit Shake-Up
abstract: Philip Morris Companies announces that it will cut 2,500 jobs in its international food division and close some factories in makeover that will cost $630 million (M)

headline: Japanese Domestic Auto Sales Slide
abstract: Japanese domestic automobile sales post their steepest drop in more than 23 years in November, and with no consumer-spending recovery in sight, auto makers are likely to continue to rev up exports; automobile sales fell 23.5 percent, to 388,247 vehicles in November, compared with corresponding month year earlier (S)

headline: Arnold Acquires Houston Herstek
abstract: Arnold Communications says it acquired Houston Herstek Favat; terms not disclosed (S)

headline: Consumers Likely to Keep On Spending Unless . . .
abstract: Analysis: 554-point plunge in Dow Jones industrial average seems unlikley to have much impact on people's spending--as long as stock prices do not plunge much further; there has been vast change over last decade in prism through which stock-holding Americans view reversals in market; crash of October 1987 prompted worst fears of a repeat of 1929 Depression; selloff this month, in contrast, draws comparisons not with 1929, but 1987; that crash was damaging, but there was no immediate recession, and stocks soon embarked on long bull market that lasted until now (M)

headline: Two Boards Back Takeover Bid by Paribas
abstract: Supervisory boards of French financial concerns Compagnie Bancaire and Cetelem decide to recommend acceptance of takeover bid for all outstanding shares in two units by their parent company, Paribas (S)

headline: A Caution Light Remains for Union Pacific's Stock
abstract: Union Pacific Corp stock languishes about 20 percent below its 52-week high in July, and much of the blame is put on company's haste to cut operating costs to demonstrate that it could wring profits quickly from its acquisition of Southern Pacific; that left railroad with crews, engines, switching-yard capacity and computer systems that were not up to the demand; company reports progress in unclogging traffic, but doubts persist about how long recovery will take and how much overtime and other expenses it will cost; graph (M)

headline: Fed Vice Chairwoman's Comments Calm Wary Investors
abstract: US Treasury securities tumble early before they rebound on remarks by Federal Reserve vice chairwoman Alice M Rivlin on outlook on Fed policy; 30-year bond is up 6/32, to price of 100 10/32; yield falls to 6.35 percent, from 6.36 percent (M)

headline: Nobel in Economics For Pricing Pioneers
abstract: Two North American scholars who helped devise a formula for accurately pricing financial market options have won the Nobel Memorial Price for Economic Science.

headline: Tracinda to Buy a Larger Stake in MGM
abstract: Tracinda Corp will invest another $75 million in Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer as part of entertainment company's initial public offering; MGM plans to market its shares to public at $20 to $23 each and will set exact price on day of initial offering (S)

headline: Family Channel Names New Chief
abstract: Family Channel cable network names Rich Cronin as its new president and chief executive; he will also head Fox Kids Network; parent Fox Kids Worldwide is joint venture of News Corp and Saban Entertainment; Cronin says Family Channel will carry children's programming by day and family programming at night (S)

headline: Asia's Surrender
abstract: Analysis: Asian countries that just two years ago balked at opening their financial markets to global competition have now bowed to most of Washington's demands, in most vivid example yet of how Asia's sudden reversal of fortunes may also shift world's financial balance of powers; Charlene Barshefsky, United States Trade Representative, says countries knew they would compound their own problems if they continued to close off parts of their market to foreign investors; some of biggest concessions have come from countries forced to turn to International Monetary Fund and to US for emergency financial aid; deal struck under auspices of World Trade Orgn falls somewhat short of clean win for Washington or Wall Street, but US clearly sees chance to use Asia's crisis to score economic points and some philosophical ones as well (M)

headline: Dollar Falls Against Pound On Surprise British Rate Rise
abstract: Dollar tumbles against British pound after Bank of England raises interest rates; dollar is little changed against yen (M)

headline: Daimler Delaying Debut of Small Car
abstract: Daimler-Benz AG delays production of new class of very small cars, dubbed Smart car, to solve stability problem; also says it is reassigning creator of Smart car, Johann Tomforde, to other duties (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Forecasting Gauge Shows Recession Unlikely in 1998  An important measurement of future economic activity suggests the expansion that began halfway through the Bush Administration will reach its seventh anniversary in the early spring and that a recession is unlikely next year.    The Conference Board, a business-sponsored research group, said the index of leading indicators advanced two-tenths of 1 percent in October, the sixth consecutive increase. [Page D2.]

headline: ARTS AND CRAFTS COMPANY SELLS 2.7 MILLION SHARES
abstract: A C Moore Arts and Crafts Inc sells 2.7 million shares for $40.5 million, or $15 each, in an initial public offering of its stock (S)

headline: Rebels, Backed by Angola, Take Brazzaville and Oil Port
abstract: Rebel forces loyal to Marxist former Pres Denis Sassou Nguesso gain full control of Brazzaville, Congo Republic's capital; are backed by tanks and troops from Angola; Pres Pascal Lissouba has fled city; rebels also take Pointe-Noire, nation's economic capital, with little resistance from troops loyal to Lissouba; are quietly backed by France and several former French colonies in Africa; France decides not to evacuate oil workers and other French citizens from Pointe-Noire; map; photo (M)

headline: SOFTBANK OF JAPAN TO MERGE 2 U.S. AFFILIATES
abstract: The Softbank Corporation, a Japanese publisher and computer wholesaler, said yesterday that it will merge two United States affiliates on Wednesday to streamline part of its United States operations. Softbank said Softbank Holdings Inc., a Massachusetts-based holding company, will absorb California-based Softbank America Inc., an American agent for the parent company. Softbank Holdings had a current, or pretax, profit of 471 million yen ($3.6 million) in the year ended December 1996.

headline: Survey Shows Manufacturers Optimistic
abstract: National Association of Purchasing Management's annual forecast shows US manufacturers are optimistic about coming year despite uncertainty over Asia's financial crisis, expecting stronger revenues, increased employment and stable prices (S)

headline: Market Place; Standard & Poor's buys a fund-research firm, the better to compete with Morningstar and Lipper.
abstract: McGraw-Hill Companies says it will buy Micropal Group, a British mutual fund research company that has been expanding in US (Market Place column); financial terms undisclosed; McGraw-Hill is seeking to tap deeper into worldwide market for mutual fund data; acquisition will immediately make Standard & Poor's, McGraw-Hill unit, a formidable competitor to Morningstar Inc and Lipper Analytical Services, two leading mutual fund tracking companies; McGraw-Hill reports third-quarter net income rose 25 percent, to $143.5 million from $114.5 million a year earlier (L)

headline: CARIBINER AGREES TO ACQUIRE VISUAL ACTION OF LONDON
abstract: Caribiner International Inc says it will buy Visual Action Holdings PLC for 148 million pounds ($247 million) in cash (S)

headline: Boeing Loss Is Worse Than Expected Despite Sales Boom
abstract: Boeing Co reports 26.2 percent rise in quarterly revenue but suffers larger-than-expected loss; Boeing says it lost $696 million in third quarter, after profit of $466 million in year-earlier period; total sales were $11.4 billion, up from $9 billion last year; chart (L)

headline: Thai Prime Minister Quits, a Casualty of Economic Crisis
abstract: Thai Prime Minister, Chavalit Yongchaiyudh, resigns, becoming first political casualty of Southeast Asia's economic crisis; had been in office for 11 months, during which he failed to control Government's relentless infighting or to stem economy's rapid slide; photo (M)

headline: Corporations Still Flocking to Delaware
abstract: With its friendly business laws and renowned Chancery Court, Delaware has continued to draw corporations -- on paper at least, if not in person.     On Wednesday, Applied Digital Access Inc. of San Diego announced that its shareholders had approved moving the legal domicile of the telecommunications software company to Delaware. The report came a week after the Hewlett-Packard Company said it was considering incorporating in Delaware, too.

headline: F.B.I. Men Sent to Karachi To Investigate the Slaying
abstract: Federal counterterrorism officials say they have no hard evidence to link killing of four Americans in Karachi to conviction of Mir Amal Kansi, a Pakistani, on charges of murdering two Central Intelligence Agency workers in Virgina; Federal Bureau of Investigation sends team of agents to Karachi to gather evidence, not to conduct full-scale terrorism probe; reportedly is concerned that slayings were aimed at luring agents to Pakistan for attack to avenge Kansi's arrest there by FBI and return to United States without hearing; Kansi's lawyers seek mistrial, holding jurors, who must weigh imposing death sentence, are terrified; judge denies bid; orders jury sequestered to shield them from news of slayings (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Vendome Group, Paris, to Ammirati Puris Lintas, Hamburg, part of the Interpublic Group of Cos., to handle advertising for its Montblanc pens account, which had been handled by KNSK/BBDO, Hamburg, part of the BBDO Worldwide unit of Omnicom Group. Billings were estimated at $15 million to $25 million.

headline: Pro Football to Expand I.B.M. Partnership
abstract: National Football League will expand partnership that began last year with International Business Machines to sponosr World Wide Web site devoted to Super Bowl; terms not disclosed (S)

headline: Many PC Buyers Prefer Power to Sub-$1,000 Tag
abstract: Recent survey of consumers finds that ballyhooed sub-$1,000 personal computer could prove to be disappointment for computer industry this holiday season; survey, conducted by Odyssey LP, suggests that potential personal computer buyers may be more interested in power than in price (M)

headline: You Say You Didn't Buy It. But Did You Read the Tiny Type?
abstract: Consumer advocates say more and more companies are finding ways to obscure unpalatable details in fine print of disclaimers, often inducing consumers to sign up for products or services without realizing what they have done; say they have had limited success in restraining marketers; just how far marketers can go is often decided after the fact, in court; Florida Asst Atty Gen Todd B Grandy claims reason marketing device such as tricky fine print persists is that too few people report it (M)

headline: Toshiba Joins Forces With Alcatel Alsthom
abstract: Alcatel Alsthom SA says Toshiba Corp will invest undisclosed amount in its $3.5 billion multimedia satellite project; project aims to offer broadband telecommunications services (S)

headline: SEALY TO BE SOLD TO MANAGEMENT AND AN INVESTOR GROUP
abstract: Sealy Corp says company will be sold to management and an investment group led by Bain Capital; terms of sale not disclosed (S)

headline: Waste Management, Under Pressure, Plans Wide Revamping
abstract: Waste Management Inc announces broad reorganization plan that will eliminate 20 percent of its corporate and support staff, about 1,200 employees, and save $100 million annually; moves follow unexpected departure last month of Ronald T LeMay as chief executive (M)

headline: Cambodian Says He May Bar U.N. From Vote if Denied Seat
abstract: Cambodian Prime Min Hun Sen says that if his Government, which seized power from coalition partner in July, is not given country's United Nations seat, he will have to consider whether organization will have any role to play in national elections scheduled for May 1998 (M)

headline: COGNEX AGREES TO BUY APPLIED INTELLIGENT SYSTEMS
abstract: Cognex Corp offers to buy Applied Intelligent Systems Inc for $105 million in stock (S)

headline: HASBRO AND GALOOB ARE GRANTED 'STAR WARS' RIGHTS
abstract: Hasbro Inc and Galoob Toys Inc say they have been granted right to make certain 'Star Wars' toys and games for the three new 'Star Wars' movies; toy manufacturers win rights from Lucasfilm Ltd (S)

headline: Irish Medical Company To Buy American Rival
abstract: Elan Corp agrees to acquire Sano Corp for $375 million in stock; graph (S)

headline: Publishers Look to New Medium To Rekindle Sales in Older One
abstract: Article on increasing number of magazine publishers and their direct-mail subscription agents going on line to sell magazines; Brian Hecht, president of Electronic Newsstand, discusses expanding his company's Web Site to categorize more 3,000 magazines by topic; photo (M)

headline: Union Vote In Mexico Illustrates Abuses
abstract: Mexican Government labor board refuses to announce results of election by workers at Korean-owned automobile factory in Tijuana who voted to oust labor union affiliated with governing Institutional Revolutionary Party and recognize one of their own choosing; American trade unionists and other sympathizers, as well as several members of US Congress, say case points to labor abuses that are routine despite Mexico's pledges under terms of NAFTA to respect right of workers to form independent unions; photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Polaroid Sunglasses, Norwood, Mass., to Eisner & Associates, Baltimore, to handle the American introduction of the [X]oor brand. Billings for a three-city market test were estimated at $2 million; billings for a national rollout, scheduled for 1999, are being estimated at $8 million to $12 million.

headline: Convicted Neo-Nazi's Lecture At Army School Shocks Germans
abstract: Germany's top military officials, recently embarrassed by home videos of soldiers making Hitler-style salutes and denigrating Jews, are struggling to explain how convicted neo-Nazi terrorist Manfred Roeder got invited to give lecture at elite military academy in 1995 (M)

headline: A World of Christmases, Not Just for Christians; In Prague, Time for Carp
abstract: Favorite Christmas delicacy in Prague is carp; photo (S)

headline: U.S. Gas Output Is Rising
abstract: Energy Department reports US emissions of greenhouse gases grew 3.4 percent in 1996, highest rate since nation pledged to cut them back in 1992; attributes rise to strong economic growth, unusually severe weather and increased use of coal by electric utilities (S)

headline: HOECHST WINS F.D.A. APPROVAL OF ALLERGY DRUG
abstract: Hoechst AG wins US approval to sell its new combination allergy drug, Allegra-D, allowing it to take Seldane, its once highly successful product line, off the market; Seldane came under fire from Food and Drug Administration earlier this year because of problems with dangerous drug interactions (S)

headline: Leap Consolidating Ethnic Agencies
abstract: Leap Partnership unit of Leap Group is combining its two New York agencies that specialize in ethnic advertising and marketing -- YAR Communications and Kang & Lee -- into unit named One World Communications (S)

headline: Kool Cigarettes' New Campaign
abstract: Brown & Williamson Tobacco Corp will introduce advertising campaign that takes sensual, sultry tack to sell Kool menthol cigarettes; campaign is created by Grey Advertising (S)

headline: ASIA PACIFIC TALKS VOW TOUGH ACTION ON ECONOMIC CRISIS
abstract: Leaders gatherd for Asia Pacific economic summit meeting declare that stringent domestic economic policies and closer international monitoring are only way to contain financial emergencies that have crippled South Korea, Indonesia and Thailand in recent months and have endangered Japan's already weakened financial system; conference, which ends tonight, was dominated by talk of Asian crisis; in morning session, leaders cast aside their agenda to focus on financial situation and keep wary eye on currency and stock markets throughout region for new signs that financial virus had spread; plan endorsed by leaders is based on document drafted last week in Manila by group of financial officials from United States and several countries in region; individual nations do not pledge financial help, but United States and others do commit to make individual contributions if IMF package proves inadequate; instead, arrangement calls on countries experiencing financial difficulties to take responsibility for resolving them by belt-tightening domestic economic policies, propping up their currencies, rooting out corruption and strengthening oversight of banks (M)

headline: PITTSTON BURLINGTON TO ACQUIRE DISTRIBUTION SERVICES
abstract: Pittston Burlington Group agrees to buy Distribution Services Ltd and affiliated company for $76 million in cash (S)

headline: Paid Notice: Memorials  GRABER, SHIRLEY U.
abstract: GRABER-Shirley U. Remembering you on our birthdays and every day before and every day after. Judith

headline: A Bid for Wells Fargo? Chief Says He's Open
abstract: Stock of Wells Fargo & Co rises five percent after bank's chief executive Paul Hazen offers run-of-the-mill statement at banking conference that he is willing to entertain takeover bid if price is right (M)

headline: COACH USA TO ADD 8 GROUND TRANSPORTATION COMPANIES
abstract: Coach USA acquires eight bus and ground transportation companies with $55 million in total annual revenues; financial terms undisclosed; companies are Metropolitan Transportation Services and Yellow Cab of Kansas City, Mo, Niagara Scenic Bus Lines of Hamburg, NY, Pittsburgh Transportation and Yellow Cab of Pittsburgh, Ace Express of Golden, Colo, Le Bus of Miami and Orlando, Fla, Classic Lines of Hialeah, Fla, Arizona Bus Lines of Phoenix, and American Tour Connection of New York (S)

headline: Pierre Peladeau, 72, Leading Quebec Newspaper Publisher
abstract: Pierre Peladeau, the Quebec tabloid publisher who read Balzac and revered Beethoven while building one of the most powerful communications empires in Canada, died on Wednesday at Hotel-Dieu Hospital in Montreal. He was 72.     Mr. Peladeau had been in a coma since suffering a heart attack Dec. 2. When doctors confirmed on Monday that Mr. Peladeau's condition was deteriorating, a new management team was put in place to run Quebecor Inc., his holding company, which had $6.3 billion (Canadian), or $4.3 billion (United States), in revenue last year.

headline: Aghalee Journal; The Story of Bernadette: Ulster's Ultimate Victim?
abstract: Current scene in Aghalee, Northern Ireland, described; village has unwanted distinction of being site of last sectarian murder: July slaying of Bernadette Martin, 18, Catholic girlfriend of Protestant man, presumably by Protestant paramilitary group; map; photos (M)

headline: Outlook for Profits: Asia Is Clouding the Picture
abstract: Stock analysts and corporate executives are warning of difficulty of predicting effects of spreading Asian economic turmoil on American corporate profits; say impact will show up more sharply in reports for first quarter than in those to be issued in Jan and Feb; executives of closely-watched Intel Corp and Applied Materials comment (M)

headline: GERMANS SURPRISE WORLD ECONOMIES WITH A RATE RISE
abstract: Germany's central bank raises key interest rate for first time in five years, move that deflates stock markets across Europe and knocks down value of US dollar; action quickly leads to rate increases in France, Netherlands and Belgium; other countries are expected to follow Bundesbank's move, which is made in part to insure that inflation does not emerge as economy improves; broader significance of move is what it says about Western Europe's march toward single currency; economists say German bank has been driven largely by need to align its relatively low interest rates with higher ones that prevail in most other countries (M)

headline: Beijing's New Face: Better Image for Jiang
abstract: Analysis of Pres Jiang Zemin's recent eight-day visit to US finds that succeeded in grand style, from Chinese point of view, in bolstering his image as statesman and as modern-minded leader interested in education and technology; visit achieved informal goal of making him look good, both to audiences in China and US, where general stiffness and bland bearing as politician gave way to moments of humor and relaxed confidence; Jiang played it both ways on critical question of human rights, affirming official position that China handled 1989 Tiananmen Square uprising appropriately while admitting that China may have shortcomings and may make mistakes (M)

headline: FIRST CHICAGO TO BUY DETROIT BROKER FOR $95 MILLION
abstract: First Chicago NBD Corp acquires Roney & Co, regional brokerage firm in Detroit, for $95 million in cash; First Chicago has formed partnership with Tokio Marine and Fire Insurance Co of Japan to sell derivatives and other products for companies in Asia (S)

headline: Serbs Pull Out of Talks on Bosnia to Protest Warning on Kosovo
abstract: Yugoslav and Bosnian Serbs walk out of Peace Implementation Council meeting in Bonn to protest reference in communique to 'increasing ethnic tensions' in Kosovo; region is ruled by Belgrade but has majority Albanian population, and is considered tinderbox of ethnic passions; protest overshadows decision to set deadlines for measures to unify Bosnia, such as common license plates (S)

headline: South Korea Delays Plans To Inject Money Into Banks
abstract: South Korean Government postpones plans to inject money into six of country's biggest banks, meeting demand of International Monetary Fund one day before agency is to decide whether to release second installment of $57 billion rescue package; Seoul has promised to let ailing financial institutions fail or be taken over as condition for receiving loans arranged by IMF; Government is still proceeding with plans to provide emergency financing for brokerage firms, which are also swamped in debt; it is unclear whether that commitment would be viewed as inconsistent with South Korea's pledges to IMF; graphs (M)

headline: Estee Lauder Is Acquiring Maker of Natural Cosmetics
abstract: Estee Lauder Companies will buy Aveda Corp for $300 million in cash in effort to strengthen its position as diversified producer of powders and perfumes (L)

headline: Winnie Mandela Discredited Herself, Police Official Says
abstract: Paul Erasmus, official of apartheid-era South African police unit assigned to discredit African National Congress supporters, testifies at Truth and Reconciliation Commission hearing on alleged reign of terror run by Winnie Madikizela-Mandela; says unit spread rumors about her but did not try to embroil her in criminal charges or have her arrested because it felt she was herself a detriment to ANC; other witnesses add to emerging picture of chaos in Madikizela-Mandela's home (M)

headline: SCOTTS BUYS LEVINGTON HORTICULTURE FOR $78 MILLION
abstract: Scotts Co says it has bought Levington Horticulture Ltd for $78 million in cash (S)

headline: Bankruptcy Filing Off 4%
abstract: CDB Infotek says number of people filing for bankruptcy protection declined 4 percent, to 335,218 in third quarter; adds bankruptcy applications reached high of 349,281 (S)

headline: DIARY
abstract: THE ECONOMY  For Workers, Slim Wallets . . .  A Federal Reserve survey has found what workers already knew: The bulk of the American labor force is not winning sizable wage increases, even as employers are driven to extraordinary lengths to find qualified personnel. Indeed, the Labor Department reported that the unemployment rate slid to a fresh 24-year low of 4.6 percent in November as payrolls surged. But providing evidence that wage-related inflationary pressures remain largely in check, the Labor Department reported that worker productivity rose at an annual rate of 4.1 percent in the third quarter, the best rate in five years, and that unit labor costs fell 0.2 percent. . . . The National Association of Purchasing Management reported that its closely watched factory index declined to 54.4 last month, from 56 in October. It was the index's third fall in three months, but still showed a strong economy. . . . The outlook was bolstered by a report from the Conference Board that the index of leading indicators advanced 0.2 percent in October, the sixth consecutive increase.

headline: ARCO CHEMICAL TO TAKE $116 MILLION CHARGE
abstract: ARCO Chemical Co unit of Atlantic Richfield will take third-quarter charge of $116 million for plant closings, job cuts and write-offs as part of plan to reduce costs and raise its stock price (S)

headline: Smiling on Smaller Stocks
abstract: Small stocks have greatly outperformed larger stocks in third quarter, leading most of money managers who created hypothetical retirement portfolios for New York Times to add small-stock funds; tables; photos (M)

headline: CANADIANS EXPORT A TYPE OF REACTOR THEY CLOSED DOWN
abstract: On the blustery shore of Lake Ontario, in Canada's most heavily populated region, four aging nuclear reactors bedeviled by leaks, failures and operators who sometimes drank beer or smoked marijuana on the job are being shut down because they cannot be safely run by one of the largest utility companies in North America.     At the same time, workers are busy excavating a huge site in China, about 60 miles south of Shanghai, where two Canadian reactors similar to the troubled ones in Canada are being built under Canadian supervision.

headline: Stocks Drop a 3d Day as Dow Falls 70.87
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average closes down 70.87 points, to 7,978.79; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index drops 5.99, to 969.79; Nasdaq composite index falls 23.94, to 1,596.61; table (M)

headline: Religious Symbols' Removal Ends Auschwitz Dispute
abstract: Group of large stars of David and Christian crosses is removed from main burial ground at Auschwitz and Birkenau death camps, ending a dispute that has held up plans to preserve sites where more than one million Jews were killed during World War II; symbols were erected by Polish Boy Scouts in 1983 in what international Jewish groups have long argued was an inapproporiate gesture (M)

headline: Jesse Jackson, in Kenya, Links Benefits to Fair Elections
abstract: Rev Jesse Jackson arrives in Kenya on first visit as special US envoy for democracy; delivers strong message to Pres Daniel arap Moi, warning that upcoming elections must not be rigged or marred with violence if Kenya hopes for good relations with US; praises recent changes by Kenyan Parliament, making it easier for Presidential challengers to campaign; photo (M)

headline: PILOTS CONTRACT DEAL HELPS NEW PURCHASES
abstract: US Airways Group Inc. pilots ratified a new five-year labor contract with the airline yesterday, opening the way for the company to lower costs and proceed with the purchase of new Airbus Industrie planes. The Air Line Pilots Association, which represents 4,800 US Airways pilots, said 84 percent of the pilots voting approved the contract. About 88 percent of the union members voted, a spokesman said. After 18 months of sometimes stormy labor negotiations, the agreement may allow the airline to enter a period of relative labor calm. US Airways shares rose $1.0625, to $46.9375, on the New York Stock Exchange. The airline, based in Arlington, Va., is the nation's fifth largest. It is now expected to confirm the purchase of 120 Airbus Industrie planes.

headline: Updates: Media and Technology; New Outlet for Hamill
abstract: Pete Hamill to write regular column for Digital City NY, entertainment and city on-line guide that will start on America Online and World Wide Web early in 1998 (S)

headline: Marketing 'Flight Simulators for Business'
abstract: Article notes that computer scientists have made strides in creating so-called artificial life inside computers and they have begun to apply ths work to real-life business situations; notes that while numerous Fortune 500 companies have invested in research, models have not as yet yielded bankable results; photo (M)

headline: A Growing Clash of Visions At The Los Angeles Times
abstract: Efforts of Times Mirror Co chief executive Mark H Willes, new publisher of Los Angeles Times newspaper, to shake up company's lackluster business performance are raising ethical concerns in journalistic community; Shelby Coffey 3d, resigned hastily as paper's editor to make way for new system; Willes has set reorganization that will let editors and journalists consult regularly with advertising and marketing executives, breaching wall that has long separated two at most major newspapers (M)

headline: People
abstract: * David S. Egan, executive vice president and account management director at Ketchum Advertising Pittsburgh, part of Omnicom Group, was promoted to president, succeeding Jim Ficco, who took a medical leave of absence.    * Laura McEwen was named publisher at New Woman, New York, succeeding Mary Quinlan, who left when Rodale Press acquired the magazine in August from K-III Communications Corp. Ms. McEwen had been vice president and publisher at Snow Country magazine, New York, which is being sold by The New York Times Company Magazine Group to Miller Publishing Group L.L.C.

headline: Platinum and Palladium Rise On Shipment Halt by Russia
abstract: Platinum and palladium prices surge on New York Mercantile Exchange after traders say that Russia, leading producer of both metals, has halted shipments; platinum for January delivery rises 11.40 an ounce, to $366.40; March palladium rises $6.00 an ounce to $191.15 (S)

headline: Of Chinese Painting, and the Art of a Book Deal
abstract: Yale University Press and Foreign Languages Press in Beijing embark on 75-volume joint venture project covering art, language and culture; project is unusual in both its scope and in nature of its collaboration, which involves both Chinese and Western scholars; venture holds lessons for any American publisher interested in doing business in China; photo (M)

headline: Gene Therapy Company Is Set
abstract: New company is formed to pursue gene therapy that could form new blood vessels and heal ulcers in patients with blocked arteries; concern, Vascular Genetics Inc, will try to commercialize work of Dr Jeffrey M Isner, who showed that gene therapy with vascular growth factors could result in formation of new blood vessels; new company is being formed by Human Genome Science Inc, Cato Holding Co, St Elizabeth's Medical Center of Boston and Isner (M)

headline: Douglas MacArthur 2d, 88, Former Ambassador to Japan
abstract: Douglas MacArthur 2d, diplomat who was Ambassador to Japan from 1957 to 1961, dies at age 88; photo (M)

headline: Bozell, Jacobs Quits Accountants' Review
abstract: KPMG Peat Marwick reshuffles roster for review of its domestic account, with billings of $12 million to $15 million, after Bozell Worldwide withdraws because of client conflict (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Hong Kong Rebounds, But Not U.S. Stocks  Investors sent stocks sharply lower for a second day on Wall Street, despite a partial recovery in Hong Kong from the previous day's 10.4 percent drop. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 132.36 points, to 7,715.41, a drop of 1.7 percent atop Thursday's 2.3 percent fall. Many investors shifted into Treasury bonds, which rose for a second day.

headline: Ex-MCA Holders Win Right to Sue
abstract: Group of former shareholders of MCA Inc win right to pursue trial to collect as much as $1.4 billion in damages from Matsushita Electric Industrial Co; US Appeals Court rules that MCA stockholders who tendered their shares when chairman Lew Wasserman and president Sidney Sheinberg sold MCA to Matsushita for $6.1 billion in 1989 had right to trial; shareholders contend that separate agreements that Wasserman and Sheinberg made with Matsushita allowed two executives to reap tens of thousands of dollars in profit not available to other shareholders (S)

headline: Schwab Unit Agrees to Pay $200,000 Fine
abstract: Mayer & Schweitzer Inc, one of largest wholesale dealers on Nasdaq stock market and unit of Charles Schwab Corp, agrees to pay $200,000 fine to settle charges that it failed to arrange best possible trades for several customers; brokerage firm neither admits nor denies allegations by National Association of Securities Dealers (S)

headline: India's Parties Seek Coalition To Rule Out New Elections
abstract: India's main political parties maneuvered feverishly today to cobble together a new coalition to replace the 14-party Government that collapsed on Friday, but days of horse-trading seemed likely before the country would learn the outcome.     The resignation of Prime Minister I. K. Gujral, the fourth prime minister in 18 months, set off a new round of gloomy forecasts of a kind that have been common in recent months as India celebrated the 50th anniversary of its independence in August.

headline: Gore, in Japan, Signals That U.S. May Make Some Compromises on Climate
abstract: Vice Pres Al Gore arrives, Kyoto, Japan, for international conference on global warming and signals that US may make some compromises; tells American delegation to be flexible in negotiations; indicates he remains committed to Clinton Administration's original position on reducing rich countries' emissions of heat-trapping greenhouse gases by 30 percent, to 1990 levels, between 2008 and 2012 (M)

headline: Computers and the Disabled
abstract: Letter by Prof Victor H Margolis on Sept 14 article on so-called adaptive or assistance technical devices that allow people to sidestep their disabilities and perform at peak levels (S)

headline: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
abstract: CNET INC., San Francisco, an Internet information provider, named Douglas N. Woodrum its chief financial officer, succeeding Shelby Bonnie, who will retain the position of chief operating officer.     TEXAS INSTRUMENTS INC., Dallas, said its vice chairman, William P. Weber, was planning to retire in April after 35 years at the company.

headline: Russians Fear Oil Spills (but Need Oil Money, Too)
abstract: Plans for 900-mile oil pipeline from the Caspian to the Black Sea promises jobs and a chance at prosperity for Novorossisk, a Russian port on the Black Sea; but critics argue that plan poses environmental threat to local waters and that promised economic gains will not be felt locally; map; photos (M)

headline: Prices of Heating Fuels Soar After Season's First Big Storm
abstract: Natural gas futures surge to 10-month high and heating oil also rises on New York Mercantile Exchange as unusual autumn snowstorm in central United States lifts demand for heating fuels; in other markets, gold rises, in part because of plunge of stocks (M)

headline: SKIN CARE COMPANIES AGREE TO A $60 MILLION MERGER
abstract: Medicis Pharmaceutical Corp of Phoenix agrees to acquire Genderm Corp for $60 million (S)

headline: 4 Times Executives Get New Jobs In Advertising and Circulation
abstract: New York Times announces executive changes in its advertising and circulation departments, effective Jan 1; Lauretta Prestera, vice president for circulation, will move to advertising department as vice president; her home delivery responsibilities will be taken over by Harold F Woldt Jr, now circulation vice president for sales and marketing; John O'Reilly, president if City and Suburban Delivery Systems, wholesale-distribution affiliate of The Times, will become circulation vice president, taking over Woldt's marketing and sales responsibilities while also retaining responsibility for City and Suburban; Donna C Miele, now vice president and project administrator, will join circulation department in new position of vice president for customer service; photos (M)

headline: Qufu Journal; Not Equal to Confucius, but Friends to His Memory
abstract: Few thousand devotees of Confucius, sage and spiritual father of Chinese culture, gathered in his birthplace, Qufu, on Sept 28 to celebrate his 2,548th birthday; map; photos (M)

headline: Polaroid in Stock Buyback
abstract: Polaroid Corp is planning to buy back as much as 11 percent of its stock, or as many as 5 million of 45.6 million shares outstanding, in next three years (S)

headline: Excerpts From Fed Chief's Statement
abstract: Excerpts from Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan's testimony to House Banking Committee on state of the economy (L)

headline: More Choose Creation, Though Cost Can Rival Burial
abstract: Cremation is becoming increasingly popular in United States, in part because of high cost of full-service funeral and burial; high-end cremation can also be expensive, including almost all elements of intricate burial; ways to cut costs discussed; table; photo (M)

headline: Enthusiastic give-and-take about literary classics in an on-line salon.
abstract: Series of literary luminaries are playing host at on-line Salon magazine Web site to two-week-long salons on New York Public Library's publication of new editions of literary classics; salon hosted by Erica Jong described; drawing (M)

headline: At the U.N., a New Voice Stresses Balance in Approaching Human Rights
abstract: United Nations' new High Commissioner for Human Rights, Mary Robinson, has become world's official conscience at time when human and civil rights issues have moved nearer to center of debates on international security or global trade; she has tried to stress sense of balance: weighing country's social and economic gains as well as its progress in civil and political rights; but in her first weeks in office, she has already upset and angered various countries (M)

headline: Economic Analysis; Can America Buy Time for Asia?
abstract: Economic analysis of financial shakeout in Southeast Asia, and whether American consumer are willing to buy more goods from countries in region to help revive their economies; lure would be lower prices, because of weakened currencies, but Prof Jeffrey Garten warns of downward pressure on US wages in industries that compete with Asian imports, and political ramifications of continually rising US trade deficit (S)

headline: Market Place; Hilton may regret its ITT offer to guarantee a share price.
abstract: Market Place column notes Hilton Hotels, now locked in battle to acquire ITT Corp, has offered 'money-back guarantee' that its stock will rise at least certain amount at time of merger; notes that history of such guarantees is consistent: stock that was guaranteed weakened year after guarantee expired, presumably because companies did all they could to support price of stock during guarantee period, but found it difficult to keep price high after guarantee expired; says this could mean that Hilton's stock is likely to perform poorly after guarantee expires, regardless of whether Hilton can keep its promise (M)

headline: In U.S., Brokers Gaining Upper Hand : A Besieged Industry Battles to Keep Clients
abstract: NEW YORKâ€”  All is not what it seems in the plush confines of U.S. private banks. Beneath the euphoria shared in recent years by private bankers across America, and beneath all their talk of double-digit annual revenue growth, lies a deeply troubling trend â€” a steadily eroding market share.

abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.56   5.65   5.17        3-MO.
