headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  LUSTICA, STEVAN
abstract: LUSTICA-Stevan of NYC on October 20, 1997 at the age of 39, after 15 years of endless battles against AIDS. His unending courage, outlook and optimism will always remain an inspiration to all who knew him. He is survived by his loving mother Edeltraud and step father Anthony Deorato, Lakewood, N.J. Devoted brothers Klaus of Seattle, Wash., Tee, Middletown, N.J., sisters Lori of Red Bank, N.J., Sharon Bachi and Deborah of S.I., NY and Susan Black of Merrick, L.I. Adored uncle of eight nephews and two nieces. He will be missed by all. Contributions can be made to the Bailey House, 180 Christopher St., N.Y.C. 10014.    LUSTICA-Stevan. To find a ''cure'' one must be ''a part of the cure'', and because of you who truly lived and fought with ''love, valor and compassion'' the ''cure'' will be yours and our dream come true. Stevan we will keep up that battle for you. With love and pride. John Dugdale and Stanley Hura    LUSTICA-Stevan. For your courage and being, you are a man amongst men, and for loving me as a son to a father, I will always love and miss you so. Stanley

headline: Economic Scene; Clinton may soon tackle the devilish Social Security issue.
abstract: Peter Passell Economic Scene column says Pres Clinton may soon add Social Security to his agenda; notes that experts on whom Washington is depending for answers are deeply divided on how to eliminate $8 trillion in unfunded pension liabilities; says all sides agree that safety net must remain intact, and that reforms cannot be built around permanent increases in payroll tax; expects Clinton to name advisory commission that will include many senior Congressional leaders, to provide nonpartisan cover; drawing (M)

headline: Fourth-Biggest Brokerage House In Japan Is Considering Closing
abstract: Yamaichi Securities Co, most troubled of Japan's four largest securities firms, weighs whether to liquidate its business or to try to reorganize under protection of bankruptcy court; recently disclosed previously unknown liabilities that are expected to exceed $1.6 billion; if Yamichji fails, it would be largest corporate bankruptcy in Japanese history and most stark evidence to date that ties that bind Government and business together are becoming undone; chart on Japan's four largest brokerage firms (M)

headline: Clear Channel Buying 3 Ohio Stations
abstract: Clear Channel Communications Inc agrees to buy three radio stations in Dayton, Ohio, from Great Trails Broadcasting Corp for undisclosed amount of cash; stations are WING-FM, WING-AM and WGTZ-FM (S)

headline: EMERITUS EXPECTS INVESTMENT FROM SOROS-BACKED FUND
abstract: Emeritus Corp says investment fund backed by Soros Fund Management LLC has agreed to invest $25 million in the company (S)

headline: KPMG Says S.E.C. Will Bring Charges
abstract: KPMG Peat Marwick says it will be charged by Securities and Exchange Commission with failing to insure its independence from Porta Systems Inc when auditing company in 1995; KPMG says it will contest charges; SEC is focusing on $100,000 loan by KPMG to executive who later became interim president of Porta (M)

headline: Market Place; A U.S. fund manager in Prague has found privatization corrupt.
abstract: FROM a distance, says Howard I. Golden, the president of a mutual fund that invests in Central Europe, the Czech Republic looked like a great place to do business: an educated work force, English-speaking colleagues, and according to the World Bank, an undervalued currency.     But when he started to invest here two years ago, the close-up view was different.

headline: Taiwan, Korea and Thailand Suffer Domino-Like Losses
abstract: Thailand's currency falls 2.3 percent against dollar, hurt by concern about resignation of its Finance Minister; elsewhere in Asia, currency turmoil continues, with South Korean won recording biggest one-day decline against dollar in 14 months (M)

headline: Africa Finds Old Borders Are Eroding
abstract: News analysis of Africa's descent into political chaos, slipping into one of most violent phases of its post-independence history; tide of democratic change that begun at turn of decade has been blunted by change to rule by the gun; political struggles have spilled across borders of Central African nations, with each intervening militarily in neighbors' affairs in ways that were once uncommon; recent events in Rwanda, Uganda, Congo, Congo Republic, Angola, Sudan and Nigeria discussed; map; photo (M)

headline: Land Rights of Aborigines Set Off Australian Battle
abstract: Australian Prime Min John Howard's conservative-leaning coalition seeks to redress what it says are imbalances favoring Aborigines in wake of 1992 and 1996 rulings recognizing Aborigine land rights; has won approval in lower house of Parliament to take away these so-called native title rights; upper house, where coalition's strength is more diluted, has amended bill in ways unacceptable to Howard, creating possibly that he will dissolve Parliament and call general election (M)

headline: Mexicans Join Huge March As a Protest Against Crime
abstract: In a capital where political marches are frequent, loud and rowdy, tens of thousands of Mexicans wearing white ribbons and waving blue flags joined an orderly and silent parade to the central square today to protest the wave of violent crime that has overwhelmed much of the country.    The demonstration, demanding an end to police corruption and violence, was strikingly different from those that routinely snarl traffic, close stores and send air pollution soaring in downtown Mexico City. It was not organized by any political party, union or known grass-roots group.

headline: Buoyed by Japan Gains, Dow Rises 28.35
abstract: Buoyed by Japan Gains, Dow Rises 28.35**Dow Jones industrial average rises 28.35 points, to 7,823.13 on Nov 28 (M)

headline: Agnelli Family and Insurer Top a Bid for Worms & Cie
abstract: Agnelli family of Italy and Assurances Generales de France SA, French insurer, bid $5.4 billion for Worms & Cie, French sugar, paper and insurance company, topping earlier offer from investor Francois Pinault; Worms, which rejected Pinault's hostile bid, expresses interest in new offer (M)

headline: Iraqi Action Halts Effort To Curb Arms
abstract: Iraq's expulsion of six American weapons inspectors brings effective halt to effort that has been at center of United Nations mission in Iraq for nearly seven years; Richard Butler, head of United Nations team charged with ferreting out Iraqi efforts to acquire weapons of mass destruction, says that only skeleton staff will be left in place after all UN inspectors are withdrawn on Nov 14; map; photo (M)

headline: Thompson Official Leaves Unexpectedly
abstract: Susan Gianinno, top administrative executive of flagship New York office of J Walter Thompson Co, is leaving immediately; Gianinno cites philosophical differences with management (S)

headline: An Accord With Communists Ends Latest Italian Political Crisis
abstract: Italian Prime Min Romano Prodi reaches new accord with Communist Refounding Party, ending crisis that threatened his center-left Government; party agrees to back his budget and he agrees to offer bill to cut legal working week to 35 hours by year 2001 (M)

headline: The Soul of a New Economy
abstract: Sampling of history and highlights of life in Silicon Valley, 4-county area of California with heavy concentration of computer industry entrepreneurs; drawing; graphs (M)

headline: Echlin Plans Acquisition
abstract: Echlin Inc acquires General Automotive Specialty Co; price undisclosed (S)

headline: For the Czechs, The Fairy Tale Is All Over Now
abstract: Czech Republic's cozy, fairy-tale image has been dented by political and economic woes, which have forced resignations of Prime Min Vaclav Klaus and Government of Pres Vaclav Havel; Klaus, once regarded as smart economist who knew best how to move country from Communism to capitalism, has been been forsaken by international financial community and turned on by political colleagues, who accuse him of arrogance and disclosed details of slush fund of party contributions held in Swiss bank; many politicians conclude that economic stability that distinguished country from rest of Central Europe since collapse of Communism hasa been lost; photo (M)

headline: Children's TV Pioneer Officially Quits
abstract: Margaret Loesch announces that she is resigning as vice chairwoman of Fox Kids Network, effective Nov 21 (S)

headline: Winnie Mandela Is Defiant, Calling Accusations 'Lunacy'
abstract: Winnie Madikizela-Mandela testifies before South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission for over 10 hours, dismissing all evidence that she ordered murders and took part in beatings in late 1980's; says none of more than 30 witnesses who recounted her role in 'reign of terror' are to be believed; photos (M)

headline: Pollution Flow In U.S.-Canada Called Mutual
abstract: Report by Commission for Environmental Cooperation says air pollution from factories and power plants in Canada and US flows both ways across border and will get worse unless abatement efforts reflect international nature of problem (S)

headline: Economic Scene; Speculators are finding that the Hong Kong dollar is different.
abstract: Peter Passell Economic Scene column on why authorities in Hong Kong will not follow path of Southeast Asian neighbors and devalue its currency; Hong Kong, unlike its neighbors, is no longer major manufacturing center that survives on its ability to assemble goods for fewer yen, dollars or marks than its neighbors; collapse of Hong Kong's currency would be serious embarrassment to its new parent, China; China might quietly use its own foreign reserves to buy Hong Kong dollars; drawing (M)

headline: Taking In the Sites; Vantages On Markets For Expert And Novice
abstract: Roundup of World Wide Web sites maintained by securities exchanges; sites offer nonprofessionals another tool to track their portfolios and learn about financial markets; table (M)

headline: An Uncomfortable Winnie Mandela Faces Cleric She Accused
abstract: Paul Verryn, South African Methodist minister who Winnie Mandela tried to ruin with accusations of sexual misconduct, confronts her in testimony before Truth and Reconciliation Commission examining her role in dozen murders and many assaults; appeals to her to reconcile with him as step toward healing in post-apartheid South Africa; confrontation makes her uncomfortable, in contrast to testimony by others when she appeared annoyed or amused (M)

headline: Winnie Mandela's Ex-Bodyguard Tells of Killings She Ordered
abstract: Jerry Richardson, Winnie Madikizela-Mandela's chief bodyguard and key aide in late 1980's, tells South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission of killings, tortures and beatings he carried out on her orders; is serving life sentence for 1989 killing; says Madikizela-Mandela participated in beatings, but never did any of killing; admits he became police informer in 1987 (M)

headline: Fidelity Records Incorrect Prices For 18 Funds
abstract: Newspapers of Oct 29 carry incorrect prices for 18 funds managed by Fidelity Investments and no prices for hundreds of other mutual funds; problems stem in part from heavy stock trading on prior day, particularly on Nasdaq market, where two computer glitches led to cascade of problems; problem with Fidelity is particularly troubling, since company has had difficulties pricing its mutual funds before; Fidelity calls errors unintentional, but such mistakes could shake confidence of investors who make decisions based on reported prices (M)

headline: Saudi Buys $50 Million Stake in Daewoo
abstract: Saudi Prince Walid bin Talal, through his company Kingdom Holding, says he has made $50.5 million investment in Daewoo Corp of South Korea, convertible into 5.9 percent stake in the company (S)

headline: Korea Nuptials Suffer a Bliss Crisis
abstract: On a desolate winter's day, the dull brown and yellow grounds at the Toksu Palace were deserted. Only a few scattered ginkgo trees hinted at any green, like tiny remnants of a grander era when an emperor lived here and the country was wealthy and proud.     A handful of brides and grooms turned up this morning anyway, to use Korea's imperial if forlorn monument as a backdrop to mark passage into a new stage of life. Posing for wedding photos here is supposed to capture the happiest day of one's life in a magnificent way.

headline: International Briefs; 2 Big Czech Companies Post Weak Earnings
abstract: The extent of the Czech Republic's economic woes was underlined yesterday when Komercni Banka A.S., the largest Czech bank, reported that its third-quarter net fell 92 percent because of losses in its securities portfolio while the state-controlled electric company CEZ A.S. said profit plummeted on lower demand.

headline: Walgreen Profits to Be Cut
abstract: Walgreen Co says that costs associated with complying with new accounting rules would lower fiscal first-quarter profits by $43 million, or 5 cents a share (S)

headline: BellSouth Profit Increases 11.7%
abstract: BellSouth Corp says its third-quarter earnings rose 11.7 percent, to $705 million, from year earlier; revenue increased 7.5 percent, to $5.19 billion (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: MCI Draws Rival Bid Valued at $30 Billion  Worldcom, an upstart telecommunications company from Mississippi, upped the ante for MCI with a $30 billion unsolicited offer, seeking to break up MCI's trans-Atlantic merger agreement with British Telecommunications.    Worldcom's offer is $9 billion richer than British Telecom's bid, which was previously revised downward. But swallowing MCI would be a breathtaking gulp for the upstart company, even though it has made a sport of buying larger competitors. [Page A1.]

headline: Mainstreet to Buy Regency
abstract: Mainstreet Bankgroup Inc says it has agreed to purchase Regency Bank unit of Regency Financial Shares Inc for $17 million in stock (S)

headline: Test Marketers Use Virtual Shopping to Gauge Potential of Real Products
abstract: Consumer food products are being test marketed in consumer-simulated shopping trips; virtual consumers, drawn from shoppers leaving supermarkets in seven cities, are put in front of computers running program that mimics trip down aisles stocked with supermarket products; test shoppers can pull boxes of image of shelf to read ingredients, and chose to 'buy' item by touching shopping cart symbol; ultimately, this technology could find way into home and help eletronic grocery services like Peapod Inc greatly expand tiny sliver they currently control of $400 billion grocery business; photo (M)

headline: Clinton Offers Programs, Seeking Votes in House for Trade Bill
abstract: Pres Clinton, scrambling to win Democratic votes in House to enhance his trade negotiating authority, offers programs to aid workers and communities hurt by future trade accords; aides say package, worth about $4 billion over five years, would pay for job training, community development and environmental repair; package includes about $1.5 billion in new money, with rest representing existing or previously proposed spending (M)

headline: JP FOODSERVICE TO REDUCE AMOUNT OF STOCK FOR RYKOFF
abstract: JP Foodservice Inc says it will reduce amount of stock it issues in its acquisition of Rykoff-Sexton Inc, valuing food service company at $1.4 billion, including debt; amendment reflects $3 increase in share price of JP Foodservice since deal was made in June (S)

headline: An Initial Public Decanting For a Top California Vintner
abstract: Profile of Beringer Wine Estates Holdings in light of company's initial public stock offering; company makes both inexpensive wines and premium wines popular with expanding pool of so-called discerning wine drinkers; table; photo (M)7

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  PRICE, LEONARD
abstract: PRICE-Leonard. October 20, 1997. The New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants mourns the loss of its Past President. A member since 1936, he received the Society's Distinguished Service Award in 1962 for a lifetime of dedicated service to the CPA profession. We extend deepest sympathy to his family.

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Ernst & Young Is Expected To Announce KPMG Deal   The Big Six accounting firms appear to be rushing to become the Big Four. Ernst & Young is expected to announce as soon as today that it plans to combine with KPMG Peat Marwick, creating accounting's largest player, with about $15.3 billion in revenue.

headline: Voyage Round the Female Body for Fashion's New Blood
abstract: PARISâ€”  Two stories are dominating the new fashion season: a fresh take on the female body and the regeneration game.

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING ; G.M. sponsors a maker of documentaries and reaches PBS viewers 15 seconds at a time.
abstract: Advertising column on General Motors Corp's sponsorship of Ken Burns's documentaries on PBS, latest of which is Lewis and Clark: The Journey of the Corps of Discovery; GM, which has spent $15 million to $20 million in the last 10 years on Burn's production, sees projects as opportunity to reach PBS audience, which typically watches little commercial television, where GM puts most of its ads (M)

headline: People
abstract: * Julian Boulding was named to the new position of president of the international division of N. W. Ayer & Partners, London, a unit of MacManus Group. He had been international director for client service at Salles D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Brazil, Sao Paulo, also owned by MacManus.

headline: Poor Oversight Said to Imperil World Banking
abstract: Asian economic turmoil reveals remarkable extent to which individual nations and even worldwide economy are put at risk by inability of national bank regulators to keep pace with rapid development of global financial marketplace; there is no global regulatory body and United States and other powers have been unable to impose changes on often-reluctant governments and banks in nations at risk; Currency Comptroller Eugene A Ludwig informally warned World Bank in 1994 that banking practices in fast-growing Asian economies resembled practices that led to collapse of US savings and loan associations (M)

headline: Sunbeam Chief Says Company, Now Stable, Is Ready for Deal
abstract: Sunbeam Corp chairman Albert J Dunlap says company will consider 'any and all types of transactions,' including acquisitions, or a sale or merger, following tumultuous 15-month overhaul of company; on Oct 21, Sunbeam announced third-quarter net income of $34.5 million compared with loss of $18.1 million in year-earlier period; revenue increased 25 percent, to $289 million from $231.8 million (M)

headline: Mexico City Police Block Arrests Of Fellow Officers in 6 Killings
abstract: Rebellious policemen from elite unit barricade selves inside barracks to block arrests of fellow officers in connection with notorious case involving abduction and execution of six Mexico City youths; revolt follows arrest of three high-ranking military officers, including unit's commander, Gen Jose Lamberto Ponce Lara, on suspicion of covering up killings; killings have cataylzed fears that police violence against civilians has spun out of control; Police Chief Gen Enrique Salgado Cordero seeks to settle standoff between unit and dozens of officers from other units reportedly sent to arrest at least 14 officers (M)

headline: 200 TO LOSE JOBS AS UNIFI SHUTS TWO FACTORIES
abstract: Unifi Inc. said it would dismiss 200 employees, or 3.5 percent of its work force, when the company closes two yarn factories to cut operating costs. After the job cuts, Unifi will have 5,500 employees, the company said. Unifi, which is based in Greensboro, N. C., said it would close two older yarn plants in Graham and Lincolnton, N.C., by Feb. 1 to concentrate on running its 14 remaining plants more efficiently. Unifi took ownership of the two factories, which make yarns used in socks, women's hosiery and waistbands, when it acquired Spanco Yarns last month. Unifi also makes textured polyester and nylon. The company had revenues of $1.70 billion for the year ended June 29. Its shares rose 18.75 cents yesterday, to $37.75.

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  LAMB, SUSAN
abstract: LAMB-Susan, LCSW, 61, a psychotherapist in private practice and with Jewish Family Service of Union County, died on October 22nd at her home in Plainfield, New Jersey, after a long illness. Mrs. Lamb was a licensed clinical social worker and a graduate of Hunter College, Columbia University School of Social Work, and the Institute for the Study of Psychotherapy. The Lambs maintain a second residence in Cape Elizabeth, ME. Her husband Rick Lamb, her mother Helen Frank, her brother David Freund, her sister Elizabeth Fideler, and her golden retriever, Bear survive her, along with beloved sisters-in-law, nieces and nephews. A memorial service is planned for 3 PM, on Sunday, November 2nd, at the Friends Meeting House in Plainfield, NJ. In lieu of flowers, please send contributions to the Cancer Institute of New Jersey.

headline: Lockheed-Hewlett Pact
abstract: Lockheed Martin Corp agrees to buy Hewlett-Packard Co work stations and servers in two-year agreement valued at $60 million; deal also includes support services (S)

headline: In Congo, Province's Dreams of a Better Life Fade
abstract: People of East Kasai, Congo, benefit only modestly from its mineral wealth and they have begun to openly question whether Pres Laurent Kabila's Government can improve their lives; map; photo (M)

headline: Yeltsin Offers to Curtail Powers of Embattled Deputy Premier
abstract: Russian Pres Boris N Yeltsin, seeking to squash growing ethics scandal that could derail economic reforms, offers to stip embattled Deputy Prime Min Anatoly B Chubais of second post of Finance Minister; Prime Min Viktor S Chernomyrdin makes offer to parliamentary leaders; proposal, couched as move to eliminate dual Cabinet posts, would also narrow portfolio of fellow reformer, Deputy Prime Min and Energy Min Boris Y Nemtsov; both men would retain vast influence over economic policy (M)

headline: Canada Rig Concerns Join
abstract: Canada's Petro Well Energy Services Inc agrees to acquire Crown Well Servicing Ltd for stock valued at about $11.2 million (Canadian), or $8 million (US); both companies make drilling rigs (S)

headline: BELLSOUTH TO REORGANIZE MANAGEMENT STRUCTURE
abstract: BellSouth Corp says that it is reorganizing its management structure to create separate focuses on telephone and wireless businesses (S)

headline: H.M.O. Switches to Flat Fee For Treatment by Specialists
abstract: Oxford Health Plans, one of country's biggest health maintenance organizations, has signed up hundreds of medical specialists to diagnose and treat expensive medical conditions for set fees, rather than piecemeal payments; move is sharp departure from industry practice; Oxford says it has contracted with over 700 specialists to take full charge of cases from start to finish; economists and health care experts say new approach is latest development in trend to give more authority to doctors and replace managed-care restraints that have enraged many doctors, frustrated patients and spurred lawmakers to scrutinize industry's billing practices (M)

headline: PETRIE RETAIL TO CLOSE 96 STORES IN BID FOR SOLVENCY
abstract: Petrie Retail Inc will close 96 of its women's clothing stores, mostly in Midwest, as company seeks to return to solvency by focusing on the East and the South (S)

headline: Levi Strauss Planning Review Of Ad Agency Handling Jeans
abstract: Levi Strauss & Co announces it has placed in review its Levi's brand account, with billings estimated at $87 million, after 67 years at Foote, Cone & Belding and a predecessor (M)

headline: U.N.'s Envoys Fail To Budge the Iraqis On Inspection Issues
abstract: Defiant Iraq tells visiting United Nations delegation that it will not change policy of barring American arms inspectors and renews threat to attack United States U-2 spy planes flying over Iraq as part of arms monitoring; stand throws crisis back to Security Council; disarmament commission head Richard Butler tells Council that Iraq barred inspectors from replacing needed air samplers; says Iraq removed obstructions from some remote cameras and turned lights back on in some areas under surveillance, but in some cases only after removing equipment; photo (M)

headline: Stocks Plunge But Then Trim Their Losses
abstract: Stock prices plunge but later regain ground, closing down 90.21, to 7,756.29, after falling as much as 269 points; Asian malaise, as well as quarterly expiration of stock options and futures, contribiutes to volatility in what is second-busiest day ever on the New York Exchange; 793.2 million shares are traded; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index is off 8.52, to 946.78; graph on principal indexes around the world (M)

headline: Economic Scene; Some Experts Say Inflation Is Understated
abstract: Peter Passell Economic Scene column outlines position of some experts that inflation is understated and that current rosy economic picture may prove transitory; says experts believe that inflation has been camouflaged by onetime factors such as strong dollar, stable health costs and changes in way price index is put together; notes that if their message is convincing, it could bring pre-emptive strike in form of increase in interest rates; says there is no evidence that Federal Reserve has yet adopted their pessimistic position; graph (M)

headline: Japanese Stocks Higher
abstract: Stocks are higher in Tokyo with Nikkei index of 225 issues up 128.38 points to 17,583.42 (S)

headline: Turkey, Irked by Europe, Seals Boeing Deal
abstract: Turkish Government, irked by European Union's deferral of action on its membership bid, rapidly approved Turkish Airlines plan to buy up to $2.5 billion in medium-range planes from Boeing Co and told airline not to proceed with planned purchase of long-range planes from Airbus Industrie, European consortium; Boeing order is part of effort to improve United States ties (M)

headline: Two Reports Show Strength in Economy
abstract: Two economic reports show that manufacturing unexpectedly strengthened in October and personal incomes rose in September, signs that economy might not be slowing enough to keep Federal Reserve from raising borrowing costs; third report shows that construction spending fell unexpectedly in September, but even with decline most analysts expect construction to proceed at high level for months to come; National Assn of Purchasing Management index rose to 56 in October from 54.2 in September; Commerce Dept reports income climbed four-tenths of percent in September and consumer spending rose two-tenths of percent; graphs (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Fire Sale to Foreigners Expected in South Korea   Already humbled by an international bailout, South Korea is now confronting another serious blow to its national pride: the prospect that American and other foreign companies will snap up valuable domestic companies that took generations to build.

headline: Several blue-chip brands announce account winners after a hectic week on Madison Avenue.
abstract: Several blue-chip brands announce account winners; they include Bausch & Lomb Inc expanding its relationship with Bozell Worldwide, Levi Strauss & Co naming CKS Group as its interactive agency, and Footquarters unit of Woolworth Corp naming DiNoto Lee to handle its account (M)

headline: Dow Rises, but Nasdaq and S.& P. Indexes Fall
abstract: Stocks ended mixed yesterday, after computing companies warned of disappointing profits.    The Dow Jones industrial average rose 5.72 points, or one-tenth of 1 percent, to 8,018.83. But the Nasdaq composite index, packed with computer shares, dropped 24.35, or 1.5 percent, to 1,606.37. The Standard & Poor's 500 Index dropped 3.10, or three-tenths of 1 percent, to 971.68.

headline: Japanese Stocks Surge
abstract: Japan's Nikkei index closes up 483.52 points, or 3.27 percent, at 15,528.74 on Dec 30 (S)

headline: Auto Maker to Build Cadillac of Sport Utility Vehicles
abstract: Cadillac announces it will offer luxury sport utility vehicle next autumn; engine, suspension system and rest of underbody of new Cadillac vehicle will be based on General Motors' existing designs for full-size light trucks (M)

headline: How Much Has Texaco Changed?
abstract: Article on Texaco Inc one year after being charged with discrimination against minorities; says Texaco has bought more services from minority-owned companies and instructed its big suppliers to follow suit; it has set five-year goals to expand minority ranks at all levels; it has tied part of executives' bonuses to their success in meeting targets for hiring and promoting minorities in their departments and to their scores in employee surveys about company's 'respect for the individual'; it also has enrolled its 20,000 employees in US in two-day 'diversity' workshops; it has placed more advertising in black-owned magazines; Texaco's chief Peter I Bijur sees progress on diversity efforts, while others are not sure; photo (L)

headline: CLINTON IS SENDING 2D CARRIER TO GULF
abstract: Pres Clinton announces dispatch of second aircraft carrier, the George Washington, to join the Nimitz in Persian Gulf, as warning to Iraq to allow UN team to resume weapons inspections; deployment also bolsters US ability to strike Iraq even if neighboring countries do not cooperate; photo; map; Clinton adds that Saddam Hussein's expulsion of American inspectors insures that international sanctions will continue 'till the end of time, or as long as he lasts'; Clinton also meets with King Hussein of Jordan, who 'loosely relates' lack of support from Arab allies; Sec Madeleine Albright discusses issue with British Sec Robin Cook in Scotland; Britain orders carrier Invincible to Mediterranean (M)

headline: WAL-MART EXPECTS TO OPEN 185 STORES NEXT YEAR
abstract: Wal-Mart Stores Inc says it will open about 185 stores in fiscal year beginning Feb 1, 1998 (S)

headline: Treasury Prices Rise on Benign Industrial Production Report
abstract: US Treasury prices move higher, after benign industrial production report for October alleviates some fears of inflation among investors; 30-year bond gains 14.32, to price of 100 27/32; yield drops to 6.06 percent, from 6.10 percent on Nov 14; graph (L)

headline: Brazil Backs Its Currency In Austerity
abstract: Brazil announces drastic program of tax increases and spending cuts aimed at slashing budget deficit and restoring international confidence in its currency and economy; move comes following more than 6 percent plunge in Sao Paulo stock market; Government is gambling that Brazilians will accept belt-tightening and even recession so long as inflation that devaluation would usher in does not return (M)

headline: Fresh and Familiar Faces in Poland's New Center-Right Cabinet
abstract: Polish Prime Min Jerzy Buzek announces his center-right Cabinet; names Bronislaw Geremek Foreign Minister, Janusz Onyszkiewicz Defense Minister and Leszek Balcerowicz Finance Minister (M)

headline: Bosnian Muslims Are Reported to Rearm Secretly
abstract: Muslim-led Government in Sarajevo appears to be intensifying clandestine program to arm and train its military, and senior NATO officials say it may already be able to mount crushing offensive against Bosnian Serbs; senior European NATO commander says only way to prevent such an attack is for peacekeeping mission to extend its mandate; peacekeepers are scheduled to leave in June 1998, but Clinton Administration has recently joined other allies in favoring extension of NATO force; map; photo (M)

headline: Westinghouse Moves to Sell Its Power-Generation Units
abstract: Westinghouse Corp may sell its power-generation units, and is said to be talking to potential buyers, including Siemens AG, GEC Alsthom and Framatome SA; units could fetch as much as $4 billion; sale of units, along with pending sale of its Thermo King refrigeraiton unit, would be end of Westinghouse as industrial company, 111 years after its founding; company has been transforming itself into media company with purchase of television networks (M)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY  The Federal Reserve reports on industrial production and capacity utilization for October.    TUESDAY  The Labor Department reports the Consumer Price Index for October.  The Commerce Department reports business inventories and sales for September.  Mitsubishi Bank/Schroder Wertheim releases its weekly retail sales report.  LJR Redbook Research releases its weekly retail sales index.

headline: Daiwa Securities Sets Buyback of Its Stock
abstract: Daiwa Securities Co will spend up to 25 billion yen ($192 million) to buy back 50 million of its shares, which have plunged 35 percent since collapse of Yamaichi Securities Co on Nov 24 (S)

headline: Georgia-Pacific Gets Stock Plan Approval
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission approves Georgia-Pacific Corp's application to create separate class of stock for its timber business; company says move would free timber operations from financial gyrations of company's pulp, paper and building products businesses (S)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  SUBKOFF, DOROTHEA BARY
abstract: SUBKOFF-Dorothea Bary. On October 21, 1997 at home. Beloved sister of Leona, James and Jeanne. Devoted aunt of Richard and Clair, Michael, David and Reva, Jeffrey and Margaret, Andrew and Karen, and great-aunt. A New York City school teacher for many years, Dot was bright, spirited and had a wonderful sense of humor. Her family and friends will miss her dearly. A memorial service is planned for late November.

headline: Mexico City Mayor's Honeymoon Lasts 3 Days
abstract: Mexico City Mayor Cuauhtemoc Cardenas, who was inaugurated on Dec 5, accepts resignation of newly appointed Police Cmdr Jesus Carrola Gutierrez, who has been accused of past brutality and ties to drug traffickers (M)

headline: Study Predicts Food Gap for Poor Countries
abstract: World Bank survey of what people will be eating, and feeding animals, into first two decades of next century finds that problems from rising consumer demands to falling water tables could create huge food gaps in poorest countries despite their economic growth (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Shake-Up at General Cable Wins Raves on Wall Street   When Stephen Rabinowitz took over as chief executive of General Cable three years ago, he was shocked to find the company divided into rigidly delineated feifs, each believing it was entitled to its own huge sales and marketing infrastructures. Mr. Rabinowitz shook things up at General Cable, sharply cutting costs and staff, and integrating the three separate businesses. As a result, the company has become solidly profitable.

headline: John Fitting Jr., 81, Executive At Dreyfus and a Fund Pioneer
abstract: John Fitting Jr, a Dreyfus Corp executive and pioneer in creation of no-load mutual funds in early 1970's, died on Dec 10 at age 81 (M)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY  Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin addresses the Bond Market Association in New York.    TUESDAY  The Federal Reserve reports on consumer credit for August.  Mitsubishi Bank/Schroder Wertheim issues its weekly retail sales report.  LJR Redbook Research releases its weekly retail sales index.

headline: Doing Right by B.A.T. Bondholders
abstract: BAT plans to assign all of its debt to its tobacco operations, to be spun off as British American Tobacco, when it merges its insurance businesses with those of Zurich Group; will buy back its existing bonds, which have been downgraded by Standard & Poor's; graph (M)6

headline: On South Africa's Roads, A Grim Harvest of Death
abstract: South Africa's polarized mix of flashy wealth, grinding poverty and suppressed anger combine to turn its glass-smooth roads into deathtraps; nation has about 10,000 highway fatalities a year, one of highest per capita death rates in world; high-speed driving, unlicensed driving, drunk driving, drunk pedestrians and low use of seat belts contribute to toll; Transportation Department has begun $12 million crackdown that combines education with dozens of roadblocks (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: NASHUA CORP., Nashua, N.H., an imaging products and mail-order film-processing company, said it would sell its specialty coated products and non-United States photofinishing units.     GREENBRIAR CORP., Addison, Tex., has retained Schroder & Co., the investment banking firm, to explore acquisitions or other measures after the company spins off its real estate unit to shareholders this year.     SEAGATE TECHNOLOGY INC., Scotts Valley, Calif., increased its stake to 35 percent from 25 percent in Dragon Systems Inc., Newton, Mass., a closely held developer of advanced speech recognition technology. Terms were not disclosed.

headline: Yamaichi to Dismiss 7,500 by Late March
abstract: Yamaichi Securities Co president Shohei Nozawa says firm will dismiss nearly all of its 7,500 employees, return assets to customers by end of March and then seek approval to liquidate (S)

headline: U.S. ECONOMY GREW AT A STRONG PACE IN THE 3d QUARTER
abstract: The American economy grew at a vigorous pace over the summer and a key measure of inflation dwindled to a level not seen since 1964.    The extraordinary economic performance, reported today by the Commerce Department, provided a bit of reassurance after a week of turmoil on Wall Street and in the world's financial markets.

headline: Canada Raises Key Rate
abstract: Bank of Canada raises its benchmark overnight lending range to commercial banks by 25 basis points, to 3.25 percent to 3.75 percent, to help ward off inflation (S)

headline: Home Resales Off Last Month After 3 Rises to Record Levels
abstract: National Association of Realtors says home resales fell two-tenths of 1 percent in November, breaking string of three months in which they rose to records; decline lowered home resales to annual pace of 4.38 million (M)

headline: Patents; A way for commercial paper recyclers to get rid of sticky adhesives and other residues.
abstract: Patent is issued for process for removing adhesives on Post-It notes and mailing labels before paper is recycled; Nipun Marwah and Allen A Gold of Westvaco Corp receive patent; Dr Daniel S Arick receives patent for device that performs tracheotomy by puncturing air passage with sharp, steel tip and inserting straw-like tube to ventilate airway; Harlan J Brothers receives patent for portable ashtray; Hong C Na recieves patent for Christmas card that also serves as ornament for automobile (M)

headline: Major Recipients of Gifts From a $350 Million List
abstract: Article notes financier George Soros's network of nonprofit organizations currently spends about $350 million annually promoting 'open society' concept developed by his former professor, philosopher Karl Popper (S)

headline: ENDURING LOVE
abstract: ENDURING LOVE .By Ian McEwan. Jonathan Cape. 247 pages. Â£15.99.

headline: SIX EXAMINED ITT'S WORLD DIRECTORIES BUSINESS
abstract: ITT Corp attracted at least six companies that were interested in buying its telephone book business, which ITT is keeping as part of proposal to separate into three companies; GTE Corp, BellSouth Corp, VNU, Tele Danmark AS and Deutsche Telekom all approached ITT earlier this year (S)

headline: Lucent Ships a Digital Television Chip
abstract: Lucent Technologies is shipping prototype versions of chip designed to serve as signal receiver in digital television sets, computers and cable boxes; chip is part of five-chip package for digital televisions that Lucent's Microelectronics Group is developing along with Mitsubishi Electric Corp (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY   Industrial Production Oct.  Capacity Utilization Oct.

headline: ACC TO BUY U S WATS FOR $46 MILLION
abstract: ACC Corp to buy US Wats Inc, Bala-Cynwyd, Pa, for about $46 million (S)

headline: Showcasing the Bull Market, One Share at a Time
abstract: Demand for stock market-related merchandise is hot; One Share of Stock Inc offers framed single shares of stock sold as art; Wall Street Creations, catalogue company, offers variety of merchandise; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Hong Kong Stock Drop Unnerves Global Markets   Hong Kong stocks suffered the worst decline in nearly a decade, a 10.4 percent drop that caused painful selloffs in every major global market. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 186.88 points, or 2.3 percent.

headline: Business Best Sellers
abstract: HARD COVER    THIS MONTH/LAST MONTH

headline: The Inquirer's Top Editor Plans to Step Down
abstract: Maxwell E P King, editor and executive vice president of The Philadelphia Inquirer since 1990, says he will resign those posts at end of year to become editorial writer on regional issues; publisher Robert J Hall says search for King's successor will be conducted both inside and outside the paper (M)

headline: Market Place; A New Chief Suddenly Quits, and Shareholders Are Wondering Why
abstract: Market Place column examines Ronald T LeMay's sudden resignation as chief executive of Waste Management Inc after less than four months on job; many analysts say he resigned out of anger about questionable accounting he discovered; others say he no longer believed his own plans to revitalize company would work, plans he had promised to disclose by Nov 18; shareholders issue their own vote of no confidence on news of LeMay's departure, sending shares down 20 percent in one day; graph (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.56   5.92   5.09        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.09   5.11   4.88        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.18   5.19   4.98        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.54   3.54   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   5.84   5.85   6.05        30-YR. TREAS.
