headline: Market Place; How are sales at Gadzooks? The company joins the reticent.
abstract: Gadzooks Inc's decision to stop giving analysts updates on holiday shopping season sales discussed; spurred sharp drop in company's stock; underscores how skittish retailers have become each holiday season in face of increasingly unpredictable sales (M)

headline: 11 Deaths in 3 Train Blasts Fan Indian Fears of Election Violence
abstract: Three bombs kill 11 people and injure 54 on trains in southern India, raising fears that campaign for general election in February 1998 could be marred by violence; police reportedly find note on one of trains from Islamic Defense Force, previously unknown group, claiming responsibility; group reportedly blames Government for failing to punish leaders of Hindu mob that destroyed one of oldest Mosques in India, in northern town of Ayodhya, in 1992 (M)

headline: Success and the Black Magazine; As Readers Prosper, Advertising Still Eludes Publishers
abstract: Edward Lewis, who helped found Essence magazine, life-style magazine for black women, has built Essence Communications Inc into $100 million publishing business; American Magazine Conference in Scottsdale, Ariz, names Lewis chairman of Magazine Publishers of America, making him first black to head 78-year-old trade group; Lewis takes helm of publishers association at a time of both promise and frustration for black magazines; mainstream magazines are paying increasing attention to blacks, but black publishers say much of advertising industry remains stubbornly resistant; photos (L)

headline: Tibetans and Christians Speak Out
abstract: Wearing a dapper blue suit, Guo Binzhao, a Chinese graduate student from Yangzhou, went down to Wall Street yesterday for a glimpse of his President, Jiang Zemin, and found himself arguing in rapid-fire Chinese with a cluster of Tibetan exiles who had come to protest Mr. Jiang's visit.    ''There's no freedom in Tibet,'' a young Tibetan named Phapka said. ''You can't even hang a picture of the Dalai Lama. What kind of freedom is that?''

headline: Dear Mom and Dad: At Camp We Started Our Own Company
abstract: MOST people think of summer camp as a place where children spend lazy days at the lake, roasting marshmallows and playing tug-of-war. Discussions of entrepreneurship, business and finance may seem out of place in such a carefree environment and, frankly, of little interest to most teen-agers.    But then there are young people like Heisi Figueroa, who started selling Avon cosmetics at age 16 -- when most children are starting to drive -- and now, a year later, oversees the work of two adults. For her, commerce is a hobby. And for Katy Meyer, 18, who devised a business plan to make hand-painted silk scarves at 14, and started selling them at a local store soon after, capitalism takes the place of high school sports.

headline: For U.S. Troops in Bosnia, Dreary Life on the Line
abstract: American troops, after two years in Bosnia, have been able to help only few refugees to return to their homes, as nation remains starkly divided along ethnic lines; find mission dreary mixture of boredom, routine and confinement in base camps; map; photo (M).

headline: Yen Falls on Economy Woes; Mark Up on Rate-Rise Talk
abstract: Currency Markets report; dollar climbs against Japanese yen (M)

headline: FURTHER PROBLEMS OF SAFETY FOUND FOR LIGHT TRUCKS
abstract: Auto industry regulators and engineers at conference in Dearborn, Mich, say that sport utility vehicles, mini-vans and pickups--so-called light trucks--pose serious safety problems to their occupants while increasing risk for other drivers on the road; say sport utility vehicles roll over so often that their occupants are just as likely to die in accident as car occupants; say brakes on light trucks are generally not as effective as car brakes, partly because Federal safety standards for trucks are slightly more lenient than those for cars; say sport utility vehicles are nearly three times as likely as cars to kill drivers of other vehicles during collisions (M)

headline: Index Move Lifts Stock
abstract: Stock of BB&T Corp rises 16 percent after it is disclosed company will move to Standard & Poor's 500-stock index; shares rise $8.9375, to $65 (S)

headline: Switzerland Economy Grows as Exports Soar
abstract: Switzerland's economy grew at annualized rate of 1.7 percent in third quarter as exports soared; gross domestic product was up eight-tenths of 1 percent; exports rose 14.8 percent (S)

headline: Investment Firm Buys Siemens Wholesale Unit
abstract: Siemens AG says it sold its electronics wholesale division, Elektrogrosshandel GmbH, to Industri Kapital for undisclosed amount (S)

headline: In the President's Words: Toward 'a Lasting Peace'
abstract: Transcript of new conference at which Pres Clinton announces commitment in principle to extend stay of US troops in Bosnia beyond June 1998; photo (M)

headline: Stocks Climb Modestly, With Dow Up 27.01
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 27.01 points, to close at 8,072.22 and Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbs 1.12, to 968.10; Nasdaq composite rises 3.09 points, to 1,742.12, and Russell 2000 index rises 0.18 point, to record 465.21; table (M)

headline: Japan Rivalry Puts Banking Plan in Limbo
abstract: Japanese Government seems committed to bolstering nation's ailing financial system with public funds, but mystery is intensifying over precisely how such money will be used; proposal to raise money for financial-stabilization package by issuing 10 trillion yen in Governemnt bonds founders; it runs into problems on hints that money raised--currently equivalent to $77.5 billion--might not go entirely to strengthening weak banks and other financial institutions; lawmakers say some of funds might help finance tax cut or some other economic stimulant, contradiction of Government vows not to use deficit financing to cure Japan's economic problems (L)

headline: Sheik Vows to Continue the Hamas Holy War Against Israel
abstract: Sheik Ahmed Yassin, delivering his most militant and impassioned speech since his return to Gaza three weeks ago, vows not to abandon holy war against Israel; photo (M)

headline: Canada to Preserve Vast Pristine Area in West
abstract: British Columbia reaches accord with oil and mining companies, environmentalists and Indian groups to protect over 2.5 million acres of nearly untouched Rocky Mountains wilderness from all development; area, known as Muskwa-Kechika, will be protected by vast buffer zone where limited development can take place under strict guidelines; plan guarantees exploration companies access to buffer zone, where natural gas has been found; map (M)

headline: Cartoons On the Web, From an Iconoclast
abstract: Interview with John Kricfalusi, who has developed one of first original cartoons for Internet, to be made available on his Spumco Inc's Web site; had also been developing cartoon to be distributed by Microsoft Network, but Microsoft has dropped much of its entertainment programming and decided not to use cartoon; seeks sponsors for cartoon and hopes to earn money by selling related merchandise; hopes to form distribution hub on site to promote work of other cartoonists; photo; drawing (M)

headline: ONE VALLEY BANCORP AGREES TO BUY FFVA FINANCIAL
abstract: One Valley Bancorp Inc acquires FFVA Financial Corp for about $204 million in stock (S)

headline: Four A's Forms Special Committee
abstract: American Association of Advertising Agencies in New York has formed Hispanic Advertising Committee dedicated to member agencies that specialize in campaigns aimed at Spanish-speaking consumers; Adolfo Aguilar is elected chairman of committee (S)

headline: SHARES OF FIRST DATA FALL 16% ON EARNINGS NEWS
abstract: Stock of First Data Corp drops 16 percent after company lowers its full-year earnings expectations (S)

headline: Centocor Drug Wins F.D.A. Approval
abstract: Centocor Inc says Food and Drug Administration has approved its heart drug Reopro for preventing complications in two new groups of patients, those receiving angioplasty and those suffering from unstable angina (M)

headline: Across Asia, a Pollution Disaster Hovers
abstract: Poisoned Lands, first of two articles on growing environmental catastrophe all across Asia; cost of Asia's 'economic miracle' is rising tide of pollution proving burden not just for Asia but for entire earth; many experts say Asia already has dirtiest water in world, filthiest air, most worrisome overfishing, and fastest-disappearing coral reefs; United Nations study suggests that 13 of 15 cities with worst air pollution in world are in Asia; World Health Orgn and World Bank estimate that more than 1.56 million Asians die each year from effects of air pollution alone, while 500,000 more die from dirty water and bad sanitation; Asia's industrialization is taking place at triple pace of industrial revolution in West; delegates from 150 countries who will meet in Kyoto, Japan, for conference on global warming must consider how to accommodate economic rise of Asia; China is already second-biggest source of greenhouse gases linked to global warming, and China and India are two fastest-growing sources of these emissions; photos; map; graph (L)

headline: U.N. Tells How Taliban Were Killed By the 100's
abstract: United Nations team probing reports that over 2,000 Taliban fighters held prisoner in Afghanistan were killed reports finding hundreds of bodies in wells and shallow graves; says many were thrown into wells alive or shot at close range; also probes reports that Taliban itself killed civilians of Hazara people, Shiite Muslims who have resisted Taliban rule; Security Council, responding to disorder in Afghanistan, urges two sides to find political solution; map (M)

headline: E.D.S. Earnings Decline 7.4%
abstract: Electronic Data Systems Corp says third-quarter earnings fell 7.4 percent to $246.8 million, from year-earlier $266.4 million; says asset write-downs in most recent quarter of $25.9 million resulted in net income of $230.2 million; revenue in latest quarter rose 4.6 percent, to $3.73 billion (S)

headline: Warsaw Journal; Old Cold War Enemies Exhume One Battlefield
abstract: Unusual seminar on political crisis in Poland in 1980 and 1981 is held in Warsaw, attended by protagonists of tense era when martial law was imposed and members of Solidarity labor union were arrested; is attended by former Soviet military officers and White House officials, who raise questions about whether Gen Wojciech Jaruzelski, Polish leader, was forced to impose martial law to save country from invasion as he claimed at time, and about mixed signal that may have been sent by former US President George Bush; photo (M)

headline: Judge Backs a Dow Jones Libel Award
abstract: Federal Judge Ewing Werlein Jr lets stand $22.7 million libel judgment against Dow Jones & Co stemming from 1993 article about MMAR Group Inc, Houston brokerage firm, that appeared in The Wall Street Journal, company's flagship newspaper; Dow Jones says it will appeal (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: An Accord to Open Up World's Financial Markets   The United States and more than 100 other countries signed a global trade agreement to open up the world's banking, insurance and securities markets.

headline: Colina Journal; Latin America's Disabled: Unsafely Hidden Away
abstract: 20 bodies lay unclaimed at morgue in Colina, Chile, poignant illustration of how Chileans treat mentally and physically handicapped; they are among 30 children and adults who died when fire engulfed Los Ceibos home for mentally retarded on Sept 29; in Chile and elsewhere in Latin America, people often react to disabled with sense of shame, leading many families to abandon them in institutions operated by well-meaning but overburdened private foundations and church groups; photos (M)

headline: People
abstract: * Richard O'Brien, vice chairman and worldwide client services director at Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide, New York, a unit of Cordiant P.L.C., left to join Special Olympics International, Washington, in the new position of executive vice president.    * Rick Britton, partner and technology/information resources director at Arnold Communications, Boston, was named to head its Richmond agency, the Arnold Agency, as president. He succeeds Robert Barocci, who left to become a consultant.

headline: Uncertainty Puts Thailand in a Political and Economic Vacuum
abstract: Thailand's top leadership has all but ceased to function, as welter of parties battle for power after Prime Min Chavalit Yongchaiyudh announces resignation; management of ailing economy is in effect suspended; nervousness is heightened by rumors that 69-year-old King Bhumibol Adulyadej, revered constitutional monarch, is undergoing tests for irregular heartbeat (S)

headline: Without Frenzy, Sprint Outdoes Its Competitors
abstract: Sprint Corp, with no blockbuster mergers and stable management led by William T Esrey, is outdoing its competitors, including AT&T Corp, MCI Communications and Worldcom Inc; reason for Sprint's success, and reason investment bankers would love to get company sold, is that Sprint may now come closest to offering that vaunted bundle of telecommunications services that has become goal of almost every large communications company: local and long-distance telephone service, Internet access, wireless communications and respectable international presence (L)

headline: Marco Polo: Is a Rivalry Just Fiction?
abstract: Academic attacks widen against City of Light, book written by former Oxford University professor David Selbourne and said to be translation of secret manuscript of medieval voyager who allegedly beat Marco Polo to China; many scholars are dismissing book as clever forgery, and its release in US has been delayed as debate intensifies; manuscript, allegedly written in 13th century, is said to chronicle journey of Jacob of Ancona, Italian Jewish merchant, to southeastern China (M)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY  The National Association of Realtors reports on home resales for November.    TUESDAY  The Conference Board issues its consumer confidence index for December.   The Agriculture Department reports farm prices for December.

headline: The Magic Word for Italians: Europe (Pain and All)
abstract: News analysis of national consensus in Italy, strongest in Europe, in favor of participating in start of common European currency in 1999; Italians across political spectrum fervently support euro even after feeling painful effects of stringent budget policies that have squeezed deficit down to required levels; workers at Perugina chocolate factory in Perugia talk of 'joining Europe' as fact of life, even though there has been steady loss of full-time jobs since Perugina became part of Nestle's international conglomerate; photo; map; Prof Patrick McCarthy notes Italians still associate notion of Europe with modernity and prosperity (M)

headline: Heavy Bets on a Few Stocks Pay Off
abstract: ON a list of the 100 best-performing domestic stock funds of the last 12 months, those that buy the shares of small and midsize companies dominate. Only a handful that focus on large companies are scattered throughout this stratosphere. But flying highest among these, and eighth on the overall list, is a young fund that hails from an insurance company family and favors big, fast-growing businesses.    Transamerica Premier Equity, the largest of seven funds started since October 1995 by the Transamerica Corporation, has returned 52.9 percent for the 12 months through Thursday, well above the 31.3 percent gain of the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the average 24.0 percent total return of its peers in the ''large growth'' category, according to Morningstar Inc., the fund research firm in Chicago. Since its inception on Oct. 2, 1995, it boasts an average total return of 33.9 percent a year through Thursday, compared with 28.9 percent for the S.& P. 500 and 23.2 percent for its peers.

headline: Dean Foods to Buy Dairy
abstract: Dean Foods Co agrees to buy H Meyer Dairy; terms not disclosed (S)

headline: Tamil Tigers Are Linked To Fatal Blast In Sri Lanka
abstract: Sri Lankan officials and Western diplomats link Colombo blast that killed 18 people and wounded over 100 to Tamil Tigers, despite disclaimer by separatist group; officials see end of 15-month lull in bombings linked to inclusion of group in State Department list of terrorist organizations; attack is first to cause extensive injuries among foreigners, mainly tourists and business travelers at two top hotels near bomb site; photo (M)

headline: Honda Predicts Output Will Rise 3.3% in 1998
abstract: Honda Motor Co forecasts its global production will rise 3.3 percent in 1998 as it starts building its popular Odyssey mini-van in Canada and shifts production of its Acura luxury sedan in US (S)

headline: Anna's World; In Industry of Glamour, Editor of Vogue Turns a Lot of Heads
abstract: Profile of Anna Wintour, editor in chief who has taken Vogue to whole new blockbuster level as bible of fashion; no other magazine editor wields as much influence over industry her magazine covers, and no other magazine editor is as personally involved in publication's subject matter; advertisers have spent $124 million in Vogue so far this year, and Vogue expects 1997 to be its best financial year in its 105-year history; some say Wintour's visibility and mystique are integral to magazine's success; although Wintour freely admits to giving special editorial consideration to magazine's big advertisers, she is also known for helping struggling newcomers by repeatedly showing their clothing in Vogue; Vogue's circulation is 1.1 million; it has highest ratio of advertising to editorial content of leading fashion magazines; photos; chart (L)

headline: J. P. Morgan Sees Earnings Hurt Abroad
abstract: J P Morgan & Co says earnings in October and November were hurt by 'unsettled market conditions' abroad; Morgan declines to quantify damage, only saying downturn resulted from decreased client activity and lower trading revenue; analysts and traders say Morgan's trading and client problems are centered in Asia, Europe and US and revolve around bank's equity derivatives and fixed-income business; result of Morgan's announcement is 4 percent drop in its stock, which helps pull down other bank stocks and contributes to downturn in broader market (L)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  COOPER, DONALD J.
abstract: COOPER-Donald J., 79. Of South Orange, New Jersey, Thursday, October 23, 1997. Beloved husband of Fay. Cherished father of Arlene and Richard. Adored grandfather of Jonathan, Ariane and Gregory Brainin. Devoted brother to Arnold, Burton and Raymond. Funeral service will be held at 12:30 p.m. on Sunday, October 26, 1997 in the Bernheim-Apter-Goldsticker Suburban Funeral Chapel, 1600 Springfield Avenue, Maplewood, New Jersey. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution to the UJA-Federation or the Parkinson's Disease Foundation, 710 West 168 Street, NYC, 10032.

headline: 4 Americans Slain in Pakistan; Link to Killing at C.I.A. Is Seen
abstract: Gunmen kill four American auditors for Union Texas Petroleum and their Pakistani driver during morning rush hour in Karachi business district in what police call terrorist attack; dead are Americans Ephrahim C Egbu, Joel B Enlow, William L Jennings and Tracy L Ritchie and driver Anwar Mirza; police say attack was probably linked to conviction of Mir Amal Kansi in 1993 murders of two Central Intelligence Agency worker outside CIA's Langley, Va, headquarters; militants vowed reprisals when Kansi was seized in Pakistan in June and taken to United States without hearing; State Department warned Americans in Pakistan to be on alert after verdict; Prime Min Nawaz Sharif expresses condolences; photos (M)

headline: Court Backs Egypt's Ban On Mutilation
abstract: Egypt's highest court upholds ban on genital cutting of girls and women; women's rights groups say ruling will resonate throughout Islamic world, giving lie to charges that only outsiders are intent on ending practice (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: AVIATION SALES CO., Miami, an aircraft spare parts company, agreed to acquire the assets of Kratz-Wilde Machine Company, a Cincinnati-based manufacturer of jet engine, auto and faucet components, for about $42.5 million.     COVENANT TRANSPORT INC., Chattanooga, Tenn., a long-haul truckload carrier, has agreed to acquire Bud Meyer Truck Lines Inc., a provider of temperature-controlled transportation services, for an undisclosed amount of cash.

headline: RUSSIA IS SEEKING MORE WESTERN AID FOR FINANCIAL ILLS
abstract: Russia is quietly seeking American support for expanded program of Western assistance, concerned that global economic turmoil could overwhelm its financial system; is seeking aid to strengthen confidence in Central Bank, which is using up reserves in anxious effort to prop up ruble; prompted by crisis that has rippled through Asia, foreign investors have been fleeing from emerging markets, and have already moved to withdraw approximately $4 billion from Russian treasury bill market; charts; graphs (M)

headline: Book jacket blurbs are, by definition, shameless. Want attention? Pan your own author.
abstract: Traditional hyperbole in blurbs used by publishers to promote books has spurred some publishers to react by using acid blurbs; Verso, small publishing firm, is using negative commentary to call attention to progressive and radical books; drawing (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: GE CAPITAL SERVICES, Stamford, Conn., a unit of the General Electric Co., will acquire Industrial Risk Insurers, Hartford, a privately held provider of risk property insurance, for undisclosed terms.    METALS USA INC., Houston, a metal processor, bought Royal Aluminum Inc. and R. J. Fabricating Inc. and agreed to buy Independent Metals Co. for stock, cash and assumed debt. The three companies have total annual revenue of $113 million.

headline: Chrysler Reports 4.4% Rise In Auto Sales for November
abstract: The Chrysler Corporation today turned in better-than-expected sales results for November, an increase of 4.4 percent compared with results from the month a year earlier.    ''The numbers are stronger than they were hinting at,'' said David B. Healy, an analyst at Burnham Securities. ''It is the best year-to-year comparison they've had in several months because of the sales of the new Durango and some strong fleet sales.'' Chrysler has been slowly increasing the production of its new Dodge Durango sport utility vehicle for the last two months.

headline: Reversing Course, Hilton Raises Its Offer for ITT
abstract: Hilton Hotels Corp reverses earlier position and raises its hostile bid for control of ITT Corp, hoping to counter friendly deal that ITT has accepted from Starwood Lodging Trust; Hilton raises its bid to $80 a share from $70, and seeks to acquire 55 percent of ITT's stock in cash, up from 50 percent; Hilton's offer, excluding ITT's debt, is worth $9.6 billion; this is still less than Starwood's $9.8 billion cash and stock offer, but revised Hilton offer carries far higher cash component than Starwood's, fact that could prove key to ITT shareholders when they vote on two proposals on Nov 12; analysts expect Starwood to increase its bid in wake of Hilton's move; graph (M)

headline: A Prize Emerges in Merrill's British Deal
abstract: Profile of Carol Galley, vice chairwoman of Mercury Asset Management Group, one of Europe's largest investment firms; Galley, as one of few women to reach top executive ranks in Britain, has been a favored target of male-dominated tabloid press as well as of jealous male colleagues in City, London's hub of investment banking; Merrill Lynch & Co's announcement that it will acquire Mercury Asset Management for about $5.3 billion means that 48-year-old Galley will soon become only woman to sit on Merrill Lynch's executive management committee; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Trade Sanctions Appealed by NEC
abstract: NEC Corp says it has appealed United States trade sanctions to Court of International Trade; United States International Trade Commmission found that Cray Research, unit of Silicon Graphics Inc, had been financially injured by pricing practices of NEC and another Japanese supercomputer producer, Fujitsu Ltd; NEC says commission's finding excluded supercomputer sales by IBM and other computer makers (S)

headline: Toy Market Sees Green and Purple Holidays
abstract: Toy industry has high hopes for holiday season; unusually wide range of hot toys is on market this year, including some updated classics and several newcomers; action figures tied to blockbuster movies are already vanishing from store shelves, and plush toys have made comeback; industry is counting on broad mix of playthings to keep merchants from pinning their hopes on few standout toys that may be out of stock long before Christmas; Toy Manufacturers of America says it expects value of toys shipped to exceed last year's $14.5 billion by at least 5 percent; photos (M)

headline: EXABYTE PLANS TO CUT 250 JOBS AND POST LOSS
abstract: Exabyte Corp says it will cut 250 jobs, nearly 15 percent of its work force, in effort to save $12 million a year; says it will post loss of 55 cents to 65 cents a share for quarter that ended Sept 28, compared with profits of 17 cents a share year earlier (S)

headline: Thai Official Is Ready to Quit
abstract: Thailand's Finance Minister, Thanong Bidaya, says he will quit as part of planned Cabinet reshuffle by Prime Min Chavalit Yongchaiyudh after just four months in office; is reportedly angered by reversal of politically unpopular fuel tax increase approved three days earlier; tax increase was part of Thanong's plan to meet requirement attached to $17.2 billion economic rescue package from International Monetary Fund (S)

headline: A Ticket to the Fast Lanes Of Money Management
abstract: INVESTORS looking to ride the wave of mergers sweeping the money management business can look forward to getting a new vehicle this week. Affiliated Managers Group, a company whose main business is buying money managers like the mutual fund firm Tweedy, Browne, is scheduled to sell shares to the public on Thursday.    The offering represents the first opportunity for investors to gain exposure to a company associated with the money management business since 1992 when the St. Paul Companies sold 20 percent of the John Nuveen Company to the public. Since then, Nuveen stock has appreciated 100 percent.

headline: 2 of the Big 3 Swiss Banks To Join to Seek Global Heft
abstract: Union Bank of Switzerland and Swiss Bank Corp formally announce that they will merge; stock-swap deal will form huge new bank, United Bank of Switzerland, with total assets of more than $590 billion; uniting the banks will create world's largest money manager, with equivalent of $910 billion in assets under management; table (L)

headline: U.S. Contends Billing Fraud At Columbia Was 'Systemic'
abstract: Government investigators obtain evidence that Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp engaged in 'systemic corporate scheme' perpetrated by its executives and managers in at least four states; affidavit filed by senior agent with Federal Bureau of Investigation for first time implicates managers at many levels of Columbia system in complex scheme to defraud Government; states that witnesses told Government that senior executives in Nashville were aware of elements of fraud involving reporting of hospital costs to Medicare and other Federal health programs; unnamed executives from company's headquarters were allegedly involved in scheme to defraud $800,000 from Government; 74-page affidavit was partly unsealed in criminal proceedings involving accusations of cost reporting fraud at one Columbia hospital; 28 pages of information remain under seal (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Deficit Falls to $22.6 Billion As Tax Revenues Surge   President Clinton will announce today that the Federal budget deficit for the just-completed fiscal year fell to $22.6 billion, its lowest level in decades, largely as a result of strong economic growth that has created a surge in Federal tax revenues. The Administration started the year expecting a deficit of $128 billion.

headline: Zambia Says a Coup Is Over In 3 Hours, Without Injury
abstract: Zambian Government reports that coup attempt that lasted three hours was suppressed without bloodshed, and that handful of military officers were arrested; map (M)

headline: Europe Heads a Very Short List Of Foreign Investment Prospects
abstract: Mutual funds that invest in European stocks turn in solid third-quarter performance, as problems elsewhere keep internationally minded investors gravitating to Europe; graph; table (M)

headline: Paying for Advice, if Not for Load Funds
abstract: Mutual fund investors are now buying more no-load funds than funds that have upfront sales charges and are bought through brokers who provide investment advice; many are turning to financial planners, who charge investors annual management fees and buy no-load funds through mutual fund marketplaces that provide consolidated balance sheets; trend seen likely to grow when stock prices eventually fall; table; graphs (M)

headline: Modest Start For Options On Funds
abstract: Recently introduced option contracts on open-end mutual funds offered by Lipper Analytical Services and Salomon Brothers discussed; options on the Chicago Board Options Exchange are based on two new indexes: Lipper/Salomon Growth Mutual Fund Index and Lipper/Salomon Growth and Mutual Fund Index; two indexes contain the 30 biggest mutual funds in Lipper's 'growth' and 'growth and income' categories, respectively (M)

headline: G.M.'s Check Is in the Mail, No Kidding
abstract: Saturn and Chevrolet, General Motors Corp units, are mailing refund checks to people who bought 1998 cars before recent price cuts; analysts laud move (S)

headline: Baghdad Risks New Sanctions Or Even an Attack, U.S. Says
abstract: United States Defense Sec William Cohen asserts that Iraq continues to 'evade and deceive' United Nations weapons inspectors and that its defiance could lead to still-tighter sanctions or military attack; calls confrontation over Iraq's suspected caches of biological and chemical weaponry 'a long-term problem,' one that will last as long as Saddam Hussein 'adopts the attitude that he's going to try to inhibit or restrict' the inspectors (M)

headline: Turkey, at Islam Conference, Makes a Point of Israeli Ties
abstract: Pres Suleyman Demirel of Turkey leaves Islamic summit meeting in Iran day before it ends in move widely interpreted as signifying his country's rejection of Islamic protests against its ever-stronger ties with Israel (M)

headline: Eight Nikko Executives Resign Over Scandal
abstract: Nikko Securities Co chairman Takuya Iwasaki, president Kichiro Takao and six other executives resign to apologize for payoffs to racketeer Ryuichi Koike in scandal that has already seen top executives from rest of Japan's Big Four brokerage firms resign (S)

headline: $7.4 Billion in Revenues, but No Name
abstract: Ernst & Young, giant accounting firm that plans to merge with KPMG Peat Marwick, reports $4.4 billion in domestic revenues for fiscal year ended September 30, while KPMG reports revenues of $3 billion; merger partners have yet to agree on a name (S)

headline: Two commercials, meant only for Connecticut, run nationally and win praise for a small agency.
abstract: Advertising column describes how small agency, Cronin & Co, prepared two commercials on breast cancer awareness to run only in Connecticut, then saw them run nationally during episode of CBS sitcom Murphy Brown that dealt with subject; Cronin gained larger stage because Ford Motor Co decided to run them as public service announcements (M)

headline: Irish Girl, 13, To Abort Baby In England
abstract: Irish Supreme Court, after several days of emotional debate on volatile issue of abortion, affirms that 13-year-old girl, who said she became pregnant after being raped, is free to travel to Britain for abortion; situation re-opened debate on abortion in overwhelmingly Roman Catholic country, recalling similar case in 1992 involving 14-year-old girl who was first refused, then granted permission to travel to Britain for abortion (M)

headline: Palestinians Free a Critic From Prison
abstract: After nearly five grueling months in the prisons of the Palestinian Authority, Fateh Sobeh returned last week to his wife and five children, in their home among the sandy alleys and cinder-block dwellings of the Tufah neighborhood of Gaza.    The Authority says its main suspicions against Mr. Sobeh involved espionage and lewd behavior. But no formal charges were ever filed, and Mr. Sobeh, 44, a professor of education at Al Azhar University here, says his imprisonment was punishment for asking students exam questions about corruption in the Authority and at the university.

headline: A Shift to Diplomacy and Coexistence
abstract: Pres Clinton came into office executing policy toward Iraq that he had inherited: keep Saddam Hussein cornered and respond to provocations with force; Clinton Administration adopted much tougher line, plotting Iraqi leader's ouster with covert operations and planning ahead for Iraq without him; US, in its handling of recent crisis with Iraq, seems to be entering new stage, unstated but apparent: compromise and co-exist, at least in short run (M)

headline: Financial Crisis Leaves Asian Leaders Shaky
abstract: SINGAPOREâ€”  The forced resignation of Thailand's prime minister is a warning to other leaders in the region that they need a strong base of political support and a credible policy to weather an economic downturn, especially since the International Monetary Fund and investors are insisting on painful reforms, officials and analysts say.

headline: French Truckers Ease Siege As a Settlement Is Reached
abstract: French truck drivers begin lifting five-day siege of nation's highways after members of their biggest union approve accord with trucking companies calling for 6 percent raise; three other truck unions, including Communist-led group, reject accord and say drivers will maintain barricades (M)

headline: Patents; Resolved for 1998: Get in better shape, eat more wisely and, for heaven's sake, get organized.
abstract: Stephenson Trotman has patented kick bag court game, in which competing sides kick two-inch kick bag across net; Carolyn Gump has patented hand-held personal nutrition calculator that tracks calorie intake and percentages of protein, fat and carbohydrates consumed; Rodney Carl Christensen has patented funnel for mining gold; John Skibik has patented combination document organizer, seat cushion, lap desk and rain hat, designed mainly for students (M)

headline: ILC TECHNOLOGY TO BE ACQUIRED BY BEC GROUP
abstract: ILC Technology Inc., a maker of specialized light sources for lasers and other equipment, said yesterday that it had agreed to be acquired by BEC Group Inc. for about $120 million in stock. Shares of ILC rose 19 percent on the news, gaining $2.25, to $14, in Nasdaq trading. Shares of BEC rose 18.75 cents, to $5.8125, on the New York Stock Exchange. As part of the deal, BEC plans to spin off its Bolle Inc. sunglasses unit to shareholders, allowing it to focus on lighting products. It will also conduct a reverse 1-for-2 stock split, which will halve its outstanding shares but double their value. BEC, to be renamed Lumen Technologies Inc., will exchange 4.36 of its shares, or 2.18 when taking into account the reverse split, for each ILC share.

headline: INTERNATIONAL GAME MAKES A MOVE IN AUSTRALIA
abstract: International Game Technology agrees to buy Olympic Amusements for about $170 million (Australian), or $114 million (US) (S)

headline: Montgomery North To Close Its Doors
abstract: Montgomery North advertising agency to close after losing its sole client (S)

headline: Gasoline Climbs on Forecast Of Heavy Holiday Traveling
abstract: Gasoline futures prices jump almost 2 percent amid forecasts for record highway travel during Thanksgiving week; in other markets, natural gas declines and pork bellies fall (M)

headline: PHYSICIANS RESOURCE GROUP DISMISSES CHIEF EXECUTIVE
abstract: Physicians Resource Group Inc dismisses is chairman-chief executive Emmett Moore; company will be managed by three executives while it looks for replacement; reports third-quarter profit fell 6.1 percent, to $3.3 million from $3.5 million in year-earlier quarter (S)

headline: Post-Plunge Layoffs Start in New, Lean Era : Grim Financial Reality Depresses Hong Kong
abstract: HONG KONGâ€”  Empty stockbroker bars and polite real estate agents?

headline: Gains for Treasury Bonds Are Pared by Stock Rally
abstract: Gains for US Treasury bonds are pared by rally in stocks; price of 30-year Treasury bond ends unchanged at 100 13/32, leaving its yield at 6.10 percent; graph (L)

headline: Milken Probation Is Extended Yet Again
abstract: Federal Judge Kimba M Wood extends probation of Michael R Milken for sixth time while regulators consider whether he is complying with court-ordered ban from securities industry (S)

headline: Wall Street Sets the Tone
abstract: Market Place column on record 554.26 drop in Dow Jones Industrial Average on October 27 and its effects elsewhere; says, for better or worse, US is setting tone for world stock markets since circuit breakers designed to minimize market swings in US did not prevent panic elsewhere, but only caused stocks to plunge further and faster abroad that at any time in recent years out of alarm over events in New York; says world markets rebounded only after Dow Jones Industrial Average posted record one-day gain of 337.17 points--day after plunge of 554.26 points (M)

headline: New Korean Leader Agrees to Pardon of 2 Ex-Dictators
abstract: South Korean Pres-elect Kim Dae Jung, seeking to unite nation to better face its economic woes, agrees to pardons of former dictators Chun Doo Hwan and Roh Tae Woo, who had tried to kill him, by Pres Kim Young Sam; gesture indicates he is unlikely to use state security apparatus to retaliate against those who persecuted him (M)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.50   5.60   5.17        3-MO. headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: BOEING CO., Seattle, received a $475 million order from Australia's Qantas Airways Ltd. for three of its 747 passenger planes.    ONEOK INC., Tulsa, Okla., an oil and natural gas concern, agreed to acquire the closely held energy company Washita Production Co. for an undisclosed amount of cash and stock.

headline: Independents' Day  ; For Smaller Publishers, Sales Are Rising as Returns Dwindle
abstract: Article discusses how small, independent publishers are finding success in niches not covered as well by larger houses; while most top New York publishing houses continue to struggle with two-year downturn in hard cover sales, many independent publishers, from medium-size houses to smaller specialty publishers, are flourishing with rising sales and dwindling returns of unsold copies of books; Morgan Entrekin, publisher of Grove/Atlantic, comments; photo; chart (M)

headline: The Card, at Least, Isn't Torn in Half
abstract: Most of commentary on judge's ruling that ended marriage of Gary C and Lorna J Wendt was about her crusade for cause of executive wife and estimated $20 million she will collect; Lorna J Wendt will also get Gary Wendt's Macy's credit card and its lifetime 45 percent discount; Wendt received card when he was Macy's director; experts in governance say Macy's card is type of executive perk; photo (M)

headline: A New Leader For Vietnam Who Is Wary Of Markets
abstract: Vietnam announces appointment of Gen Le Kha Phieu, law-and-order hardliner with no formal economic training, as General Secretary of Communist Party, country's top post; he replaces 80-year-old Do Muoi, who steered Vietnam through economic transformation of 1990's that opened its markets and encouraged free enterprise while maintaining party's grip on political and economic affairs (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Financial Giants Report More Strong Earnings  J. P. Morgan, Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette and Smith Barney -- as well as its parent, the Travelers Group -- all reported strong profits, extending Wall Street's dizzying ride on the back of buoyant stock and bond markets.    Those market gains have been fueled by strong corporate profits, record merger activity and a fair amount of optimism, though a few possible clouds have now appeared on the horizon. [Page D2.]

headline: CLINTON RETREATS ON TRADE POWER; PROSPECTS SLIGHT
abstract: Pres Clinton fails to win enough support, mostly among Democrats, for bill granting him fast-track trade authority and concedes his quest for legislation, which he says is crucial to nation's global leadership, is dead for remainder of year; House Republican leaders shelve bill at his request, rather allowing measure to be defeated, marking Clinton's most severe legislative setback since 1994; decision follows long weekend of desperate lobbying by White House, and considerable efforts by House Speaker Newt Gingrich, that still left supporters short by handful of votes; Clinton's defeat suggests that, despite his high popularity, he has been unable to sell his vision of trade expansion to either American public or significant section of his own party; is seen by many as beginning of his lapse into lame-duck status, and marks first time in decades that any President has lost major Congressional initiative toward freer trade; organized labor and House Democrats, who overwhelmingly opposed fast-track request, are jubilant; Democratic leaders predict their strength will force Clinton to rethink his approach to global economy and use power of trade sanctions to keep developing nations from lowering labor and evironmental standards to win in global marketplace; Senate majority leader, Sen Trent Lott, says chances are remote that any revived measure can be passed in 1998, when Congress is up for re-election; photo (M)

headline: Canadian Study Says Tainted-Blood Victims Deserve Payment
abstract: Canadian Federal inquiry concludes that thousands who contracted AIDS virus and Hepatitis C from contaminated blood in one of worst public disasters in Canada's history should be compensated without having to file lawsuits; report, written by Ontario Court of Appeals Justice Horace Krever, blames health system for tainted blood and blood products administered in early 1980's; sharply criticizes Federal health officials, as well as Canadian Red Cross Society, for delays in using methods to screen donated blood sooner; more than 1,000 residents were infected with HIV through blood supply, and unknowingly infected others, while tens of thousands were infected with Hepatitis C (M)

headline: S.E.C. Sees Tangled Dealings at High-Tech Company
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission charges that former Ferrofluidics Inc chief executive Dr Ronald Moskowitz and others carried out complex fraud to inflate value of company's stock and hide actions from auditors detailed; case is unusual both because of scope of alleged fraud and because company has real products, revenues and earnings; graph (M)a

headline: Sunbeam Dances With Mr. D; Is Albert Dunlap Saving the Company or Setting a Sale?
abstract: Profile of Sunbeam Corp, where Albert J Dunlap has sharply cut costs, slashing payroll and closing plants; Dunlap comments on his plans for company to be acquired or make own major acquisition, interview; table; graphs; photo (L)

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt  -- Dean Foods Co., Franklin Park, Ill., is selling $150 million of debentures due 2017 through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The noncallable debentures are priced 99.258 to yield 6.9 percent. The issue is rated A3 by Moody's and A by Standard and Poor's.    -- Fannie Mae is selling $250 million of notes due in 2002 through J. P. Morgan Securities. The noncallable notes carry an interest rate of 6.06 percent and are priced at par.

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: PHOENIX INTERNATIONAL LIFE SCIENCES INC.,  St. Laurent, Quebec, agreed to buy a drug-testing unit, IBRD-Rostrum Global, from Kuraya Corp. of Japan for $28.5 million.    PACIFIC GULF PROPERTIES INC.,  Newport Beach, Calif., a real estate investment trust, acquired four industrial properties for a total of $23.5 million from Northwestern Mutual Life, Milwaukee.

headline: Dow Rises 61 as Broader Indexes Set Records
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average gains 61.64 points, to 8,100.22, and Standard & Poor's 500-stock index closes up 7.66 points, at 972.69 (M)

headline: U.S. Acts to Bar Chancellor Media's L.I. Radio Deal
abstract: Justice Dept files suit to block plan by Chancellor Media Corp to acquire four popular Long Island radio stations from SFX Broadcasting, saying it would undercut competition, drive up radio advertising fees and result in higher costs to consumers in area; Chancellor, which now owns two stations on Long Island, says acquisition would help it compete with other media and with larger stations based in New York City; proposed deal is part of wave of mergers resulting from Telecommunications Reform Act of 1996 (M)

headline: Jobs Outlook Lifts Bonds; 30-Year Yield Falls to 6.30%
abstract: Credit markets report; 30-year Treasury bond yield falls to 6.30 percent; graph (M)

headline: In Venezuela, Clinton Promotes Hemisphere Trade Zone
abstract: Pres Clinton arrives in Caracas, Venezuela, on first leg of week-long South American trip that will also take him to Brazil and Argentina; praises region's quiet transition to democracy and its growing free-market economies; photo (M)

headline: VIEWPOINT; When Victimhood Runs the System
abstract: Comment by Doug Bandow on tobacco lawsuits; says lawsuits represent demise of traditional negligence law; hodls consumers eschew responsibility for their own actions, liability lawyers search for deep pockets, legislators overturn standard notions of fault and state attorneys general prostitute their efforts in search of publicity; drawing (L)

headline: Simone Duvalier, the 'Mama Doc' of Haiti
abstract: Simone Duvalier, wife of Haitian dictator Francois Duvalier and mother of his successor Jean-Claude Duvalier, dies; photo (M)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: WESTINGHOUSE ELECTRIC CORP., Pittsburgh, said it completed the sale of its Thermo King refrigeration unit to Ingersoll-Rand Co., of Woodcliff Lake, N.J., for $2.56 billion in cash.

headline: Economic Scene; A new look at bank reforms to cut inefficiencies and risk.
abstract: Economic Scene column on US Treasury Department report, American Finance for the 21st Century, which summarizes where financial services industry has been and compellingly argues for where it ought to go; report's recommendations for reforming banking industry discussed; drawing (L)

headline: U.S. Respects Brazil, Clinton Assures Latin Giant
abstract: Pres Clinton, visiting Brazil, stresses that United States takes Brazil seriously and does not seek to dictate relations in hemisphere; tries to dispel Brazilian suspicions of American attitudes, news conference with Pres Fernando Henrique Cardoso; Cardoso lauds US ties; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Korea's Troubles Worsen As Pressure for Aid Grows  South Korea said it would seek help from the United States and Japan to rescue its faltering economy, which represents the biggest threat yet in Asia's infectious financial crisis.     But American officials said the International Monetary Fund must orchestrate any aid, and it appeared that South Korean officials were becoming more receptive to that alternative as their currency plummeted further and the country's financial paralysis spread. [Page A1.]

headline: Updates/Media and Technology; Westinghouse to Switch Home City and Name Today
abstract: Westinghouse Electric Corp to become CBS Corp and move its headquarters from Pittsburgh to New York City (S)

headline: Yeltsin Opens Door He Once Closed to a 3d Term
abstract: Russian Pres Boris Yeltsin surprises political analysts when he fails to rule out possibility that he will run for third term in 2000; photo (M)

headline: On Black Friday, a B+ (for Bargains); At High and Low End, Season Starts With Quest for Good Price
abstract: Shoppers from all over country pile into stores on first official day of holiday season--known to retailers as Black Friday, because they hope it will push their bottom lines into black; while retailers tend to monitor activity obsessively over Thanksgiving weekend, kickoff to crucial holiday buying period has lessened in importance in recent years as more and more shoppers choose to buy closer to Christmas; Thanksgiving weekend can also be deceiving; last year, season started with bang and ended on mediocre note; graph; photo (M)

headline: Barney's May Get New Bidder, DFS, as Business Strengthens
abstract: DFS Group reportedly plans bid for bankrupt Barney's Inc; interest follows strong sales and better cost controls at Barney's (M)

headline: Host Marriott Acquisition
abstract: Host Marriott Corp says it will buy Coronado Island Le Meridien in Coronado, Calif, for $54.4 million; hotel will be renamed Coronado Island Marriott Resort and be managed by Marriott International Inc (S)

headline: Seoul's Heroic Failure: Departing Chief, Kim Young Sam
abstract: Kim Young Sam, South Korea's departing President, is widely regarded as nation's greatest failure; Kim, reviled since International Monetary Fund bailout, was democracy campaigner under military dictatorship and consolidated democratic rule in Korea; had already lost much of his popularity by last year because of scandals and perception that he offered little leadership (M)

headline: In Afghan Refugee Camp, Albright Hammers Taliban
abstract: Sec of State Madeleine K Albright scores mistreatment of women and children by Afghanistan's Taliban movement, speech to Afghan refugees, Nasir Bagh, Pakistan; recalls own experience as wartime refugee; urges women to demand education and seek equality; map (M)

headline: SMART CHOICE TO ACQUIRE 2 FORD DEALERSHIPS IN FLORIDA
abstract: Smart Choice Automotive Group Inc acquires two Ford dealerships in east-central Florida; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: Talk Show Host Joins Cancer Fight
abstract: General Motors Corp reaches agreement with Rosie O'Donnell to promote company's 'Concept: Cure' efforts to fight breast cancer with monthlong broadcast of her show during which GM's Chevrolet division will be sole sponsor (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: MONDAY   Industrial Production   Nov.     TUESDAY   Consumer Prices   Nov.  Housing Starts   Nov.

headline: KN Energy Seals Deal for MidCon
abstract: Occidental Petroleum Corp agrees to sell its Midcon natural gas pipeline unit to KN Energy Inc for about $4 billion in cash and assumed debt (S)

headline: Petersen Publishing Plans Initial Offering
abstract: Petersen Companies plans to go public with seven million shares at $17.50 a share (S)

headline: Hong Kong Follows U.S., Staging a Strong Rebound
abstract: Stocks rebound in Hong Kong after Wall Street's explosive rally; other Asian markets are also sharply higher at midday; Hong Kong's Hang Seng index is up 1,512.42 points, or 16.69 percent, at 10,572.31 points at midday Oct 29 (L)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: WASHINGTON MUTUAL INC., Seattle, said it would close 85 branches in California early next year as part of its consolidation after its $8 billion merger with Great Western Financial Corp.    AMERICAN EXPRESS BANK LTD., said it would buy a 50 percent stake in Banco S.R.L. of Brazil for about $37 million.

headline: Top Hill Journal; At Polls in Jamaica, Kissing Cousin From America
abstract: Retired Gen Colin Powell gets warm welcome in Jamaica, birthplace of his parents, when he returns as one of 55 international monitors checking on fairness of island's elections; photo with Jimmy Carter at polling place; map; Powell is greeted by relatives in Top Hill, where his father was born (Top Hill Journal) (S)

headline: Emerging From Chaos, Blue-Chip Paragons
abstract: Small but growing number of blue-chip Russian companies embrace ideas like shareholder rights, open disclosure and bottom-line management; Trade House GUM was one of first companies to make transition; table (S)

headline: Information Technology Field Is Rated Largest U.S. Industry
abstract: Study sponsored by American Electronics Assn and Nasdaq stock market shows sales by computing and telecommunications industries have grown 57 percent during 1990's, to $866 billion, making those businesses increasingly important force in nation's economy; study is based on Commerce Department data (L)

headline: $5,000 on My Credit Card? But Mom, It's for Tuition
abstract: College students and their parents are increasingly charging tuition and room and board on credit cards; some schools have been accepting credit cards for tuition for decade or more and practice is spreading rapidly; some find savings through automation, added to fee reductions negotiated with banks, can produce gains, while others find they cannot afford bank fees; college officials imply well-to-do parents use cards for frequent-flier miles and incur little or no interests, but statistics2

headline: SEAGATE SAYS IT WILL CLOSE DISK-DRIVE PLANT IN IRELAND
abstract: Seagate Technology Inc will close disk-drive manufacturing plant in Clonmel, Ireland, eliminating all of plant's 1,100 full-time jobs; company attributes closing to overcapacity and pricing pressures that have plagued disk-drive industry (S)

headline: A Toll of 'Disappearances' In Mexico's War on Drugs
abstract: Scores, perhaps hundreds of people, including some US citizens, have disappeared at hands of Mexican security police in northern Mexico in recent months, possibly as part of dirty war against suspected drug traffickers, and also at instigation of traffickers seeking to eliminate competition or punished debtors; nearly 90 people have vanished in gritty border town of Ciudad Juarez, including Manuel Hernandez, Texas drywall contractor and former marijuana dealer who waas dragged away by uniformed federal police in full view of local police; officials have denied knowledge, and US Embassy has not helped; human rights groups say nowhere in world have so many people disappeared in context of drug-related violence, and with such official stonewalling; two Americans, Jaime F Hervella and Saul Sanchez, formed association of relatives of missing persons after fruitless three-year search for Saul Sanchez Jr, 35-year-old US Navy veteranwho disappeared in Juarez while selling communications equipment to Mexican federal police; group meets in El Paso for fear of Mexican police; photos; map; Clinton Administration has turned blind eye, continuing to praise Mexico's anti-drug efforts; many of abductions apparently are at behest of Juarez-based cartel of late Amado Carillo Fuentes; Juarez mayor says 'we can't hope' that corrupt officers will act like police in other places (M)

headline: Taking the Hint
abstract: Readers are invited to submit anecdotes on how their companies handle dismissals; drawing1

headline: Leading Indicators Up 6th Month in a Row
abstract: An important gauge of future economic activity shows the outlook remains bright, suggesting the long expansion that began halfway through the Bush Administration will reach its seventh anniversary in early spring.    Only two postwar expansions have been so long and both by this time were marked by rising inflation, in sharp contrast to the price deceleration that prevails today.

headline: Even if Gambling Wanes, Hilton May Be Worth a Bet
abstract: Decline in stock price of Hilton Hotels Corp reflects broad decline in gambling business; while push for legalized gambling remains strong, industry experts are starting to see saturation; some analysts view Hilton as an attractive buy; stock price graph (M)

headline: Another Giant South Korean Conglomerate Falls
abstract: Halla Group, South Korea's 12th-largest conglomerate, collapses, spurring new fears of a wave of corporate bankruptcies under strict financial rules dictated by International Monetary Fund; six of country's 30 largest chaebol have failed this year, saddling banks with huge amounts of bad debts; Halla's bankruptcy could in turn hurt Hyundai Group, which lent money to it (M)

headline: FROM THE DESK OF; Mother Teresa's Economics Lesson
abstract: Prof John E Schwarz article on plight of poor in United States; holds shortage of adequate jobs blocks upward mobility of millions of persevering families; drawing (M)

headline: Former Executive Sues Columbia
abstract: Former hospital administrator for Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp, Valinda Rutledge, claims in Florida whistle-blower lawsuit that she was dismissed after informing company lawyers about possible document destruction by executive in wake of Federal raid on company; Rutledge's lawyer says she will cooperate with Federal Bureau of Investigation, which is working on broader investigation into company's business practices (S)

headline: Wall Street Sneezes and the Russians Catch a Chill
abstract: Stock market plunge on October 27 sent shock waves through Moscow, prompting frantic efforts by top aides of Russian Pres Boris Yeltsin to head off panic selling of stocks and Government bonds; even so, efforts failed to stop precipitous fall in fledgling stock market, where shares fell approximately 40 percent from August highs (M)

headline: Fuji and Presstek Plan to Collaborate
abstract: Presstek Inc and Fuji Photo Film Co plan to develop printing products in their first significant collaboration; Presstek's technology allows images from computer to be scanned directly to printing plate, eliminating need for photo-developing chemicals; agreement comes as Fuji and Eastman Kodak Co battle over digital imaging and printing technologies (S)

headline: Schwab Name Used in Fraud, U.S. Says
abstract: US Attorney and Securities and Exchange Commission say Mark Shkolir, described as Russian emigre from Brooklyn, NY, raised $195,000 from investors by falsely contending that Charles Schwab & Co was selling shares in his computer software company, Millennium Software Solutions Inc; Shkolir's only connection with Schwab was that he opened account with Schwab and deposited his victims' checks there; Shkolir is arrested with associate, Eric Vainer, on charges of conspiracy to commit securities fraud (M)

headline: WITH KOREA CRISIS WORSE, U.S. SEEKS WAY TO LIMIT HARM
abstract: US looks for ways to contain South Korea's financial crisis, as evidence mounts that two-month attempt to restore stability is failing; World Bank releases $3 billion intended to reshape banking system, saying money can be used instead to pay short-term loan obligations; commercial banks owed billions by South Korean companies and banks negotiate with Government in hopes of converting those private loans into debt owed by nation itself, which could create basis for repayment negotiations like those used to save Latin countries in 1980's; main goal is to buy time, as Korean stocks and currency plunge; investors are not reassured by Pres-elect Kim Dae Jung's statement that he is 'stunned' by severity of crisis and does not know if country will go bankrupt 'tomorrow or day after tomorrow'; World Bank is anxious that crisis not erase South Korea's remarkable economic progress over last three decades (M)

headline: 2 Swiss Executives Talk Of Benefits of Bank Merger
abstract: Mathis Cabiallavetta and Marcel Ospel, who will be chairman and chief executive of Swiss bank merger, say greater capital cushion will allow them to take on larger risk; they say their far-flung offices will give the bank a 'global reach' neither institution has today; photo (L)

headline: Hong Kong Stocks Plunge as Rates Soar
abstract: Stocks in Hong Kong plunged, as the financial forces wreaking havoc across Southeast Asia have now turned full force on that market.    Hong Kong's main index fell as much 14.6 percent in morning trading today in one of the steepest drops in its history. The plunge came after Hong Kong authorities pushed interest rates up sharply in an effort to defend the Hong Kong dollar from currency speculators.

headline: Canadian Court Puts Bre-X in Bankruptcy
abstract: Bre-X Minerals Ltd is put into bankruptcy by Court of Queen's Bench of Alberta, which also orders appointment of Arthur Andersen & Co as receiver for Bre-X affiliate; lawyers representing Bre-X shareholders have sought its bankruptcy to preserve its assets; company is being sued by shareholders attempting to recoup money they lost when Bre-X's gold discovery turned out to be fraud (S)

headline: Prague Journal; The Czechs' New Haunt, Hauntingly Like the Old
abstract: Century-old Cafe Slavia in Prague, favorite of Czech writers, actors and painters, has reopened after seven-year closing and complete overhaul; photo of Pres Vaclav Havel and his wife at cafe (M)

headline: Deere to Acquire Cameco
abstract: Deere & Co to acquire 49 percent stake in Cameco Industries, Thibodaux, La, for undisclosed terms (S)

headline: The Ultimate Obsession; What Will People Pay to Enter His World?
abstract: Richard Garriot, creator of popular 18-year-old Dungeons and Dragons-style computer games, is poised to benefit from rise of Internet and rapid growth in popularity of multiplayer personal computer games; his 'Ultima Online' is one of first illustrated Internet games that thousands of people can play at once; he sold 40,000 units of Ultima Online, at $64.95 each, in first three weeks; early success of Ultima is being taken as sign in computer game industry that Internet is arriving as standard feature built in to all computer games; chart comparing Ultima Online with Quake, enormously popular action shooter game; photos; diagrams (M)

headline: National Power Reports Profit Surge Abroad
abstract: National Power PLC of Britain says profits from international operations rose to 67 million pounds, or $113.2 million, in first six months ended Sept 30, from 20 million pounds a year earlier; net profit from company's domestic business fell to 226 million pounds from 235 million pounds a year earlier (S)

headline: Burnett to Sell Stake In Its Headquarters
abstract: Leo Burnett Co agrees to sell majority ownership of its world headquarters building in downtown Chicago to affiliates of real estate investment and development companies Starwood Capital Group LLC and John Buck Co; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: ABB Will Cut 10,000 Jobs And Switch Focus to Asia
abstract: Swiss-Swedish engineering company ABB Asea Brown Boveri to cut 10,000 jobs in Western Europe and US to invest in Asia instead; revamping will cost ABB $850 million and impact is likely to be heaviest in Europe (L)

headline: Belgrade and Moscow Stall Bosnia Vote Desired by U.S.
abstract: Russia and Serbia continue to resist United States pressure for election in Serbian-controlled region of Bosnia to shore up Pres Biljana Plavsic in her struggle with Radovan Karadzic; she has called for Parliamentary election in hopes of winning enough seats to gain control of Government; her opponents want presidential vote as well, believing that Momcilo Krajisnik, Karadzic loyalist, can oust her; Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe, which is responsible for conducting elections, is set to take up issue (M)

headline: Latest Reports Give Economy A Little Chill
abstract: National Association of Purchasing Management's manufacturing index fell to 54.2 in September, from 56.8 in August, as orders, production and backlogs declined; Conference Board's index of leading economic indicators rose two-tenths of 1 percent in August; Commerce Department reports spending on construction declined three-tenths of 1 percent in August; graphs (L)

headline: People
abstract: * Mark Linder was named to the new post of worldwide client service director on the Ford Motor brand business at Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide, Detroit, a unit of WPP Group. He had been vice president for marketing at Mainspring Communications, Cambridge, Pa. Also, Ross Sutherland, senior partner and creative director at Ogilvy, New York, was named to handle new duties as the lead creative director on the Ford business.

headline: Bailout for Korea Is Left Unresolved As Seoul Hesitates
abstract: Agreement for financial bailout of South Korea's economy unravels as Seoul resists taking severe austerity measures, such as closing insolvent banks, advocated by International Monetary Fund; Finance Min Chang Yuel says issues remain to be resolved; stock market and currency plummet further, indicating concern that strict conditions set by IMF could produce sharper-than-anticipated economic slowdown; Finance Ministry orders nine ailing banks to suspend business until end of year, and Korea Stock Exchange suspends trading in shares of eight; photo (M)

headline: THE ASIAN CRISIS: Watchful Waiting on Japan ; For U.S. and European Markets, a Steady Course So Far
abstract: Nikkei index of 225 Japanese stock issues rises 178.02 points, or 1.12 percent, to 16,045.55 on Wed, Nov 26; rise leaves investors debating whether Asian turmoil will undermine United States and European stock markets or whether rebound in both those markets will bring some stability to Asia; Dow Jones industrial average rises 41.03 point on Nov 25, to 7,808.95, despite earlier 5.1 percent dip in Japanese stocks; graphs; table (M)

headline: CBS News wants to pay newspaper reporters for tips on stories.
abstract: CBS News has taken informal connection between television news and print journalism to new level; it has sent E-mail to newspaper police and court reporters offering money for news tips that get on the air, with proviso that news reports cannot have already been broadcast elsewhere on TV, and with strong preference for news that has not even run in reporter's newspaper; newspaper editors take umbrage, claiming they have first rights to their reporters' tips (M)

headline: MUTUAL FUNDS; Streamlining a Big Small-Cap Lineup
abstract: Interview with Charles M Royce, small-capitalization value investing pioneer; he defends performance of his Royce Funds, which have underperformed many peers; cites stress on risk-adjusted absolute returns; table; photo (M)

headline: Subsidy Cuts Threaten To Darken Opera Houses
abstract: MUNICHâ€”  A high regard for music in general and opera in particular runs clear across the political spectrum in Germany, and both sides of the once-divided nation used to spend very substantial sums subsidizing concert halls and opera houses. Opera companies could routinely expect 80 percent or more of their budgets to come from government subsidies.

headline: Audit Firms' Partners Back Deal, but U.S. Must Act, Too
abstract: Partners at Price Waterhouse and Coopers & Lybrand have voted to merge their practices into one; merger must be approved by Justice Dept, which is looking at whether four or five major accounting firms are enough to audit nation's public companies (M)

headline: COVENTRY TO ACQUIRE PRINCIPAL HEALTH FOR $375 MILLION
abstract: Coventry Corp agrees to buy Principal Health Care Inc for about $375 million in stock (S)

headline: FROM THE DESK OF; Be Patient, And I'll Be A Loyal Customer
abstract: Article by Marilyn A Gelman, who suffered brain injury in auto accident, urges workers dealing in business setting with people who suffered traumatic brain injury and with sick and aged to show more patience; cites ways in which she has modified consumer behavior and ways workers can change their behavior to ease dealings; drawing (M)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY  House Commerce panel holds a hearing on the proposed tobacco settlement.    TUESDAY  Mitsubishi Bank/Schroder Wertheim releases its weekly retail sales report.  LJR Redbook Research releases its weekly retail sales survey.

headline: A Banking Powerhouse of Cards; MBNA Continues to Build on Its Foundation of Plastic
abstract: MBNA Corp has been second-largest bank credit card issuer for several years; as its competitors have scaled back their ambitions, worried about mounting consumer debt and defaults on loans, MBNA has stepped up its growth, while keeping its own loan problems in check; corporate strategy of MBNA head Charles M Cawley detailed; Cawley comments; charts; photo (L)

headline: Stocks Soar as Turmoil in Asia Seems to Ease
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average is up 101.87 points, or 1.3 percent, to close at 7,826.61; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rises 14.39 points, or 1.52 percent, to 958.98; chart (L)

headline: IXC COMMUNICATIONS TO GET NETWORK LONG DISTANCE
abstract: IXC Communications Inc, Austin, Texas, to acquire Network Long Distance, Newport News, Va, Inc for about $125 million in stock (S)

headline: Time to Press Redial?
abstract: Some stock market analysts say France Telecom, which will go public on Oct 20 with $7.3 billion initial public offering, will probably perform better than its German counterpart, Deutsche Telekom; table; photo (L)

headline: In Hong Kong, Runs on Banks and Cakes
abstract: Series of small-scale panics have been afflicting Hong Kong in the last month--first bank runs, then unfounded rumors that Saint Honore Cake Shops was closing with crowds racing to cash in gift certificates, and then arcade runs, with people rushing to use prmotional tickets they acquired over the years--all signs of deeper economic problems; photo (L)

headline: Aid From Rich Nations to Poor Fell in 1996
abstract: Report by private relief groups finds that foreign aid to world's poorest countries has fallen to its lowest point in 50 years; report is released in US by Interaction, Washington, DC, coalition of 150 US agencies (M)

headline: Honda, Beating Out G.M., Plans to Build Cars in China
abstract: Honda Motor Co, beating out competing bid by General Motors Corp, announces that it has won right to manufacture passenger cars at plant in southern China; Honda executives say venture, their first auto assembly operation in China's car market, will involve $200 million investment with two local partners, Guangzhou Auto Group Corp and Dongfeng Motor Corp, to produce model resembling Honda Accord; Honda will take 50 percent stake (L)

headline: Anxiety at The Star Tribune
abstract: Minneapolis Star Tribune has been operating in kind of limbo since Cowles family trustees announced in Sept that they are weighing sale of Cowles Media Co and paper; possible suitors noted; graphs; photo (M)

headline: LAZARD FRERES FUND AGREES TO BUY NURSING HOME OWNER
abstract: Lazard Freres & Co's Prometheus Senior Quarters LLC fund agrees to buy Kapson Senior Quarters Corp, a nursing home owner, for $250 million (S)

headline: Retailers Report Sales Gain Of Only 2.1% in September
abstract: Goldman, Sachs & Co's same-store sales index shows retail sales were up 2.1 percent in September, compared with same month a year earlier; graph; chart (L)

headline: Penny-Stock Fraud by 58 Is Charged
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission charges 58 defendants with penny-stock manipulation in one of largest stock fraud cases ever; SEC files four civil fraud suits in New York and one in Salt Lake City; suits contend penny-stock promoters and officials of small, publicly traded companies bribed brokers to get them to sell stocks to brokerage customers; agency contends five separate schemes caused unsuspecting investors to overpay for stocks whose prices were being secretly controlled by the defendants; seven stocks the defendants are accused of manipulating listed; some defendants noted (L)

headline: IRAQ AND RUSSIANS DRAFT A PROPOSAL TO END GULF CRISIS
abstract: Foreign Min Yevgeny M Primakov says Russia and Iraq have drafted proposal to end Iraqi-United States standoff over arms inspection; says plan would let United Nations carry out inspections, presumably with Americans taking part; says open-ended search for chemical, nuclear and biological arms should end swiftly; outlines how Iraq might win end to crippling economic sanctions; discusses proposal with State Sec Madeleine K Albright; United States continues military buildup in Persian Gulf area; flies U-2 reconnaissance planes over Iraq without incident; says Iraq is moving around air defenses in way that could be threatening; photo (M)

headline: Timing A College Tax Credit
abstract: Taxpayer Relief Act of 1997 provides two education tax breaks; Hope Scholarship tax credit that takes effect Jan 1 amounts to 100 percent of first $1,000 college tuition and fees and 50 percent of next $1,000, or maximum of $1,500 each year for first two years of post-high school education; second break is lifetime learning credit, which takes effect July 1, amounting to 20 percent of first $5,000 in annual education expenses, with corresponding courses required to begin by end of first quarter of following year (M)

headline: Georges Marchais, 77, Dies; Led France's Communists
abstract: Georges Marchais, whose rigid leadership of French Communist Party from 1972 to 1994 was blamed for reducing it to margins of French political life, dies at age 77; photo (M)

headline: Caraustar Floats an Offer for Britton Group
abstract: Caraustar Industries says it might offer about $270 million in cash for Britton Group PLC, bid that Britton rejects as inadequate (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Surge in Jobs Last Month Raises Inflation Fear  The nation's unemployment rate declined to 4.7 percent in October, the lowest since 1973, the Labor Department said in a report that provided compelling evidence of further stamina in the United States economy.

headline: Amid Mixed Profit Reports, Intel Talks of Its Fastest Chip
abstract: Top chip designers give first public briefing on ultrafast microprocessor chip that companies hope can dominate computing in next decade the way Intel chips controlled market in 1980's and 1990's; Intel, looking to expand beyond personal computer market, has teamed up with Hewlett-Packard Co to develop chip architecture known as IA-64 that would be used first for machines capable of handling complex corporate and engineering computer tasks; Intel reports net income in third quarter rose to $1.57 billion from $1.31 billion in quarter a year earlier; revenue climbed nearly 20 percent, to $6.16 billion from $5.14 billion; profit was below what many analysts had expected; chart (L)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Toys 'R' Us Colluded On Prices, Judge Rules  Toys ''R'' Us, the biggest retailer in the nation's cutthroat toy business, violated Federal trade laws by colluding with manufacturers, including Mattel and Hasbro, to keep prices for toys like Barbie and Mr. Potato Head artificially high, a judge ruled.    Upholding F.T.C. charges, the judge, James P. Timony, agreed that Toys ''R'' Us used its market muscle against its emerging chief competition, warehouse clubs like Price/Costco, BJ's and Sam's Club. Toys ''R'' Us said it would appeal the ruling. [Page A1.]

headline: Jean Pasqualini Dies at 71; Told of China's Penal Horrors
abstract: Jean Pasqualini, author of harrowing account of seven years he spent as political prisoner in China's labor camps, dies at age 71; photo (M)

headline: Telesoft to Sell Its Internet Unit
abstract: Telesoft Corp agrees to sell its Internet subsidiary for more than $20 million; Telesoft does not identify acquirer (S)

headline: INVACARE TO BUY A RIVAL HOME HEALTH CARE CONCERN
abstract: Invacare Corp agrees to acquire Suburban Ostomy Supply Co for more than $130 million; acquisition is expected to produce combined revenues of more than $860 million (S)

headline: Coupons to Condiments: Goodies for Shareholders
abstract: Number of companies offer perks to shareholders perks, such as discount coupons for their products; analysts warn that it is foolhardy to buy a stock for perks alone, noting investor's primary interest should be company's prospects; gifts offered by number of companies to their shareholders noted (M)

headline: Warm Globe, Hot Politics
abstract: James Bennet analysis contends that under Kyoto agreement, US will have to take more drastic steps than Clinton Administration had hoped to reduce greenhouse emissions; maintains that walking away from treaty, as Vice Pres Gore said he was willing to do, would have enraged environmentalists who are key constituents for him and Pres Clinton; asserts that it would have isolated US as leading emitter of greenhouse gases and only industrial nation unwilling to address problem jointly (M)

headline: The BBC Adds 24-Hour News in Britain
abstract: British Broadcasting Corp starts 24-hour news channel in Britain, part of its effort to position itself for multimedia world of 21st century; BBC's all-news BBC World channel has been beamed via satellite to 144 countries since 1994; new domestic BBC News 24 service will allow it to take on CNN International and News Corp's Sky News on home ground; all-news concept rankles many people long associated with BBC who fear network's reputation for incisive, in-depth reporting will be eroded by need to fill airwaves 24 hours a day (M)

headline: After First Sinking With Asia, Europe Recovers With U.S.
abstract: European stock markets recover in part from early selloffs, lifted at end of their trading sessions by upturn on Wall Street; photo (L)

headline: The Wonders of Day 1
abstract: New York Times is looking for articles on what was included in your company's package on your first day of work; drawing (S)

headline: COLONIAL PROPERTIES TO BUY MALLS AND SHOPPING CENTERS
abstract: Colonial Properties Trust agrees to buy six shopping malls, five shopping centers and apartment complex for $197 million in cash, securities and assumed debt in separate transactions; properties are in Georgia, North Carolina, Tennessee, Virginia and South Carolina; Colonial says it will sell four apartment complexes to help finance its purchases (S)

headline: Harold Evans of Random House To Be Zuckerman Editorial Czar
abstract: Harold M Evans, colorful president and publisher of Random House's trade group, will leave publishing house to head Mortimer B Zuckerman's publications, which include The Daily News of New York, U.S. News & World Report and The Atlantic Monthly; Zuckerman, in naming Evans editorial director, says that Evans will essentially take over large portion of his duties at various publications; Evans will have a say in everything form hiring to story ideas to design at magazines and at The Daily News; photo of Evans (L)

headline: Big Japanese Securities Firm Falls, Putting the System on Trial
abstract: Yamaichi Securities Co, Japan's fourth largest brokerage firm, plans to go out of business, leaving some $24 billion in liabilities to clients and putting 7,000 people out of work; Japan assures global markets that it plans orderly overhaul of shaky financial system; shutdown is largest business failure in Japan since World War II; could signal new era in Japanese business; Fuji Bank has challenged system by refusing to rescue longtime customer; Min Hiroshi Mitsuzuka says failure is not likely to require use of compensation fund for securities firm's clients, but plans to strengthen fund (M)

headline: Satellite Broadcasters Face Higher Programming Fees
