abstract: United States Copyright Office ruling issued Oct 27 would quadruple rates that satellite broadcast companies pay to transmit network television signals; rate increase would benefit owners of television programming, like networks, Hollywood studios and major sports leagues, at expense of direct broadcast satellite companies; Congressional and industry opponents vow to fight new rules; Copyright Office has delayed effective date of new rates to Jan 1, giving satellite industry time to ask Congress or courts to roll back increase (M)

headline: PRUDENTIAL REAL ESTATE TO BUY $100 MILLION OF BRE STOCK
abstract: Prudential Real Estate Investors agrees to buy $100 million in BRE Properties Inc stock (S)

headline: U.S. to Look Into Fees for 401(k) Services
abstract: US Labor Department is concerned that some employers who offer 401(k) plans may be paying 'excessive' fees to outside administrators and wants to look into issue (S)

headline: 3 Presidents Defend Bid To Belong To NATO
abstract: Presidents of Poland, Hungary and Czech Republic defend bid to become NATO members in magazine interview; warn against American isolationism, stress ability to pay their way and play down threat of Russian opposition to NATO expansion (M)

headline: One Chief Leaving Pagano, Schenck
abstract: Robert Pagano, co-chairman and managing partner of Pagano, Schenck & Kay, says he will leave advertising agency at end of October; Woody Kay, the other co-chairman and agency's creative director, will assume Pagano's duties, purchase his stake in agency and take titles of president and executive creative director (S)

headline: Lally, McFarland Revamps Leadership
abstract: Lally, McFarland & Pantello Euro RSCG says it has reorganized its top-level management following departure of three top executives to form another shop; says Diane Harri has become president, Michael Norton will join company as chief creative officer, and Lydia Canizares will be president of new division, LM&P IQ (S)

headline: On the Deadly Roads of India, A Bus Claims 29 Young Lives
abstract: At least 29 children are killed and over 60 others hurt when overloaded school bus skids off bridge into river, on outskirts of New Delhi, India; rescuers pull at least 30 children to safety, but are unable to help those trapped in submerged part of bus; bus accidents are common in India, where reckless driving by bus and truck drivers and overloading buses are also common; photo (M)

headline: CADENCE DESIGN SHARES FALL ON RESIGNATION OF CHIEF
abstract: Shares of Cadence Design Systems Inc fall in wake of unexpected resignation of its chief executive, Joseph B Costello; Jack Harding will succeed Costello (S)

headline: Ace Hardware Selects Bozell Unit
abstract: Ace Hardware Corp consolidates its advertising account, with billings estimated at $22 million, at Chicago office of Bozell Worldwide; account had been divided between Bozell and Impact Communications (S)

headline: Israel Frees Founder Of Hamas Movement
abstract: Israel released the imprisoned spiritual leader of the Islamic movement Hamas, Sheik Ahmed Yassin, and flew him to Amman, in response to a request from King Hussein of Jordan for ''positive steps to help the peace process.''    Article, page A5.

headline: S.E.C. Chief Defends Accounting Board
abstract: Securities and Exchange Commission chairman Arthur Levitt Jr, on eve of Congressional hearing on proposed accounting rule, defends Financial Accounting Standards Board, panel of accountants established by commission to come up with standard way for companies to report to their investors how much they earn, own and owe; at issue is proposed rule that would force companies to tell their shareholders more about value of transactions they enter involving derivatives, investments whose value is derived from some underlying asset or index (L)

headline: LINCOLN NATIONAL TO TAKE CHARGE FOR LOSSES IN BRITAIN
abstract: Lincoln National Corp will take $287 million after-tax charge in fourth quarter to cover pension sales practices liabilities and reinsurance losses in Britain (S)

headline: Trying to Get A Job? Check Yes or No; Tests Are Becoming Common in Hiring
abstract: Job applicants across nation increasingly face taking a psychological test as part of hiring process; companies large and small are turning to psychological tests, developed by virtually unregulated test-publishing industry, to try to determine who is too impulsive, who falls short in integrity department or who is too self-absorbed to make the cut; companies are using tests to weed out undesirable applicants, even for entry-level jobs; some sample questions cited (M)

headline: Victim Fund Gets Pledges From U.S. And Britain
abstract: More than 50 years after Hitler's armies plundered Europe of its gold, the United States and Britain today announced modest contributions to a new fund to benefit Holocaust survivors, but many other countries withheld immediate donations.    The fund is supposed to be based on money raised from 5.5 tons of Nazi gold held in the United States and British central banks since World War II. Britain and the United States want the 10 European nations with claims on the gold -- which historians say may include gold stolen from Holocaust victims -- to forego their demands and instead contribute some or all of their share.

headline: Billing Problem Leads to Losses For Big H.M.O.
abstract: Oxford Health Plans says that it has been losing money because it fell behind in sending bills to customers and underestimated how much it owed doctors and hospitals; says it will take big writeoff in third quarter because of problems; move startles investors on Oct 27; Oxford shares fall $42.875, or 62.4 percent, to $25.875, in Nasdaq trading, making its stock biggest decliner on day when stocks in general plunge by about 7 percent; market value of Oxford, whose 49 million shares traded make it day's most active issue, plummets by over $3 billion, ending day at slightly more than $2 billion; Oxford says it will report loss of 83 cents to 88 cents a share for third quarter; much of loss will be caused by charge against earnings of $47 million to $53 million to increase reserves, as revenue for quarter comes in estimated $111 million less than expected (M)

headline: Pen in Hand, Raul Salinas Denies Murder and Theft
abstract: Raul Salinas de Gortari, who has spent much of last three years in prison, says he amassed his fortune legitimately when his brother Carlos Salinas de Gortari was President of Mexico, but acknowledges that he did it by seizing 'huge opportunities' for business deals afforded sibling of nation's leader; denies homicide charges and allegations that he was paid by Mexico's drug barons to protect their multi-billion dollar enterprises; provides new details of how Citibank and Bankers Trust handled his money, over $100 million of which was deposited in Swiss bank accounts; photo (M)

headline: Jerusalem Journal; Who in Israel Loves the Orthodox? Their Grocers
abstract: Supermarket chains in Israel have found that catering to Orthodox Jews, with their large families and high expenditures on food and household supplies, is highly profitable; phot (M)

headline: People
abstract: * Bernadette E. Murray was named executive vice president and senior account director at BBDO New York, part of Omnicom Group, succeeding Richard A. Pounder, who left to join Ammirati Puris Lintas, New York, part of the Interpublic Group, as executive vice president and managing director. Ms. Murray had been senior vice president for marketing at Brooks Brothers, New York, part of Marks & Spencer P.L.C.; she was succeeded by Derek Ungless as senior vice president and creative director.

headline: On Foreign Affairs, U.S. Public Is Nontraditional
abstract: Informal survey of opinion across the country tends to support finding of public-opinion researchers that ordinary Americans are very interested in international issues that they believe directly affect their lives, including immigration and trade negotiations, global warming and similar environmental issues, health threats and drug-trafficking and other cross-border crime; there is less interest in foreign political or military developments; researchers ar also finding persistent or even widening gap between opinions of general public and those of people who make, think or write about foreign policy (M)

headline: Updates/Media and Technology; Microsoft Repairs Glitches That Vexed Its On-Line Service
abstract: Microsoft Network works out some glitches that recently prevented prospective members from signing and deterred existing members from upgrading their on-line service and checking their accounts (S)

headline: Harrah's in $519 Million Deal to Buy Showboat
abstract: Harrah's Entertainment Inc to acquire Showboat Inc for $519 million in cash, strengthening its hold on gambling markets in Atlantic City and Chicago area; will also assume $635 million in debt; says acquisition will make it world's largest gambling company; some industry experts say acquisition comes at time of intense competition and raises question as to whether there are too many casinos in the United States (M)

headline: Mexico's Legislators Finally Get Taste of Real Budget Authority
abstract: Finance Min Guillermo Ortiz presents new federal budget to Mexican Congress; opposition, which controls lower house, says it intends to make broad revisions to proposed $105 billion budget (M)

headline: Thomson Science Unit Sale
abstract: Thomson Corp will sell its Thomson Science publishing unit to Dutch publisher Wolters Kluwer NV; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: A World of Christmases, Not Just for Christians; In Baghdad, Far Less Fizz
abstract: Christmas in Baghdad, Iraq, is subdued as families struggle under economic sanctions and since 1993 ban on public consumption of alcohol; many Muslims celebrate Christmas along with the country's four percent Christian minority (S)

headline: Hankook to Build Plant
abstract: Hankook Synthetics Inc will spend $1.2 billion to build its first plant in US, in Augusta, Ga; project will create more than 1,800 jobs in next decade (S)

headline: Peronists Lose Congress Election
abstract: Graciela Fernandez Meijide, former human rights activist, leads center-left alliance to victory against governing Peronist Party in Argentina's congressional elections; upset will make it difficult for Pres Carlos Saul Menem to continue pace of economic and social changes that have been widely applauded for producing fiscal growth and stability; photo (M)

headline: Accounts
abstract: * Schering-Plough Health Care Products, Liberty Corner, N.J., to B.J.K.& E. Media Group, New York, a unit of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt, to handle broadcast media buying for brands like Coppertone and Dr. Scholl's, which had been handled in-house. Billings were estimated at $50 million.    * Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, New York, a part of the Equitable Cos., which is majority-owned by AXA Group, to Seiter & Miller Advertising, New York, to handle its account, which had been handled by Griffin Bacal, New York, a unit of Omnicom Group. Billings were estimated at $13 million for the fourth quarter and $20 million for 1998.

headline: Treasury Sales This Week
abstract: The Treasury's schedule of financings this week comprises today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills; a sale of two-year notes today and an auction of five-year notes tomorrow.    At the close of the New York cash market Friday, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.21 percent and the rate on the six-month issue 5.23 percent. In when-issued trading, the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 5.62 percent, and the five-year note at a price to yield 5.66 percent.

headline: Mood Is Grim as Israeli-Palestinian Negotiations Resume
abstract: Israeli and Palestinian negotiators define sharply contradictory goals for new round of peace talks in Washington; Israel is seeking postponement of troop withdrawal from rural areas of West Bank and accelerated talks on final status of settlement between Israel and Palestinians; says talks should focus on differences over carrying out of 1995 accord calling for creation of safe-passage between Palestinian-governed territory and West Bank and in Gaza Strip, as well as for building airport and seaport in Gaza; Palestinians insist that troop withdrawals go forward before final status talks begin; call on Israel to demonstrate good will by declaring halt to settlement activity in West Bank; Yasir Arafat says that talks are a waste of time and that he agreed to send negotiator only because Sec of State Madeleine K Albright asked him to do so (M)

headline: Mastercard hopes to become the credit card of choice for ordinary, middle-class consumers.
abstract: Mastercard International is trying to carve out niche in crowded field of credit and charge card marketers, with emotional campaign, starting Oct 22, that emphasizes its image as card for ordinary, middle-class consumers; ad campaign is first by McCann-Erickson Worldwide Advertising (L)

headline: Short Positions Are Up 3.1% on Big Board
abstract: New York Stock Exchange reports open positions of short sales rose 3.1 percent, or 111.8 million shares, to record 3.67 billion in most recent period; American Stock Exchange says short interest declined 1.8 percent, to 189.8 million shares; charts, including securities showing largest increases and largest decreases (M)

headline: Deutsche Bank Profits Increase 55%
abstract: Deutsche Bank AG says its nine-month profit surged 55 percent, to 2.38 billion marks ($1.37 billion), from year ago; cites strong sales of investment products (S)

headline: Patents; A new device helps emergency workers find people who use a mobile phone to call for help.
abstract: Dr Dan Schlager receives patent for way to equip wireless telephones so they can broadcast their location when calling for emergency assistance; Roy Curtiss 3d and Guy Cardineau receive patent for edible vaccines (M)

headline: 2 Ex-Dictators Leave Korea Jails, Pardoned After 2 Years
abstract: Former Presidents Chun Doo Hwan and Roh Tae Woo are released from South Korean prisons where they were serving sentences for roles in 1979 military coup, for violent suppression of democracy protesters and for collection of millions of dollars in bribes; photos; two, who spent only about two years behind bars, were pardoned after decision by Pres-elect Kim Dae Jung; both offer praise for former dissident whom they once sentenced to death (S)

headline: Two Swiss Banks Plan a Merger, Forming Global Financial Giant
abstract: Union Bank of Switzerland and Swiss Bank Corp will merge, creating world's second-largest bank and world's biggest money-management company; new entity, United Bank of Switzerland, will control $592 billion in total assets; Marcel Ospel, Swiss Bank Corp executive, is named chief executive and Mathis Cabiallavetta, Union Bank chief executive, is appointed chairman; deal involves exchange of stock in which Union Bank shareholders will own 60 percent equity, and Swiss Bank shareholders remainder; will lead to cuts of as many as 13,000 jobs worldwide; banking industry analysts say deal will encourge other large global financial companies to pursue mergers of own to remain competitive (M)

headline: In Some Small-Stock Funds, A Haven From the Turmoil
abstract: Article on some small-stock mutual funds that weathered stock market's downturn better than most (M)

headline: Illinois Vineyards, Out of the Cellar
abstract: SNOW often covers the ground this time of year in the wine country of Illinois. But that is just another climatic hurdle for this part of the Midwest, and it does not stop Paul Renzaglia from testing a sample of his latest batch of red table wines.    Ten years ago, when Mr. Renzaglia's father, Guy, opened Alto Vineyards here, near this town of 400 residents about 100 miles southeast of St. Louis, the Renzaglia spread in effect was the Illinois wine country. Today, the state's fledgling wine industry, concentrated in the rolling hills of southern Illinois just below Carbondale, is still more like a wine county than a country. But with four operating wineries and more on the way, the owners cannot help but be optimistic about the future of home-grown wines.

headline: 9 Police Officers Among 11 Slain in Egypt
abstract: Nine police officers and two Coptic Christians are shot and killed by suspected Islamic militants in southern Egypt (S)

headline: Turkey May Free Activist Before Prime Minister Visits U.S.
abstract: Turkish Government may free 36-year-old Leyla Zana, country's most prominent political prisoner, before visit of Prime Min Mesut Yilmaz to US; Zana, former member of Parliament convicted of supporting Kurdish terrorism and sentenced to 15-year jail term, is often cited by critics of Turkey's human-rights record; she has vowed to remain in jail until laws banning separatist speech are repealed (M)

headline: Clinton Hails Iran Overture but Isolation Policy Is Unchanged
abstract: Pres Clinton hails conciliatory remarks toward US by Iranian President Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, but Administration remains committed to policy of isolating Iran as punishment for its behavior; says he would like nothing better than to have dialogue with Iran, but lists concerns over Iran's sponsorship of terrorism, its violent attacks on peace process and its development and acquisition of weapons of mass destruction (M)

headline: FOUNDATION CUTS 6% OF WORKERS AT 9 HOSPITALS
abstract: Allegheny Health, Education and Research Foundation dismisses 6 percent of its workers at nine hospitals in Delaware Valley, cutting about 1,200 jobs as it seeks to reduce costs; also says it has cut compensation for all of its executives by average of more than 20 percent, as it will seek to reward highly productive faculty and reduce compensation for others (S)

headline: Charges by Mexico Link PRI Mayor to Killings
abstract: The Attorney General's office said tonight that there was a link between the local government and the massacre of 45 people earlier this week in southern Mexico. The federal officials charged the top regional administrator not only with murder but also with providing a paramilitary group with the high-caliber weapons used in the killings.    Few details were released last night, but Everardo Moreno, the Deputy Attorney General in charge of the investigation, said Jacinto Aria Cruz, municipal president of Chenalho, a region of Chiapas, had confessed to sending the weapons in a municipal car. Mr. Moreno spoke at a news conference in the Chiapas capital of Tuxtla Gutierrez.

headline: London Journal; Blair's 'Rebranded' Britain Is No Museum
abstract: British Prime Min Tony Blair says Britain's image, which used to be bowler hats and very old-fashioned and very stuffy, has been replaced by something far more dynamic and forward-looking; this modernizing impulse is challenging number of British symbols already facing extinction from new harmonizing standards being established by European Union; decades ago, it was Beatles that showed world that Britain was not as fusty as it was portrayed; this time, style offensive is being undertaken by Labor Government at suggestion of Demos, social policy research center close to Blair; photos (M)

headline: Business Travel; The American Airlines pact with Asiana is part of a strategy to increase a Pacific Rim presence.
abstract: American Airlines' new code-sharing and frequent-flier partnership with Asiana Airlines--which is based in Seoul, South Korea, is part of long-range strategy by American Airlines to heighten its presence in the Pacific Rim; one way to travel inexpensively through Asia is to purchase Cathay Pacific's All Asia Pass, available only to individuals who have registered on carrier's Web site; Hyatt Hotels and Resorts has consolidated details of all current promotional offers at its 107 hotels and resorts in US, Canada and Caribbean into program called Hyatt Extras, and is offfering these data through special telephone number and on its Web site (Business Travel column) (M)

headline: AMERICAN TOPICS : An 'Epidemic of Incivility' Rages in Local Politics
abstract: The words "civility" and "politics" have never fit very comfortably in the same phrase, and a good political fight is a time-honored American tradition. But in recent years a rise in incivility in town and county council meetings and school board assemblies has become so grave as to raise national concerns.

headline: WINSTAR PLANS TO ACQUIRE BULK OF MIDCOM ASSETS
abstract: Winstar Communications Inc agrees to buy most of assets of Midcom Communications Inc for $92 million in cash; agreement must be approved by bankruptcy court where Midcom filed for Chapter 11 protection on Nov 7 (S)

headline: People
abstract: * James Meyer, senior vice president and executive group account director at the New York office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles Communications, part of MacManus Group, and Gail Hollander, senior vice president and group account director, were promoted to the additional new positions of business development director and client services director, respectively. Also, David Hackworthy, vice president and planning director at the New York office, was promoted to the new position of senior vice president and strategic planning director.

headline: A New Method of Trading Is Proposed for Nasdaq
abstract: National Association of Securities Dealers proposes allowing investors seeking to buy or sell shares at specific price, known as limit order, to post offers in new centralized book run by Nasdaq, move that would drain business from market makers; plan would let big professional investors like mutual funds trade electronically with Nasdaq firms, if sponsored by brokerage firm; would also merge Nasdaq's two electronic order systems; some dealers oppose limit-order book, holding it would put them in competition with organization that regulates them (M)

headline: With Approving Nod, I.M.F. Wires $3.5 Billion to South Korea
abstract: International Monetary Fund releases further $3.5 billion of $21 billion it has pledged to keep South Korea afloat; action reflects approval of Seoul's handling of crisis so far, and vote of confidence to Pres-elect Kim Dae Jung (S)

headline: An Outsider in Turkey Who, in Fact, Knows It Inside Out
abstract: John Freely, who has spent nearly half his 71 years in Istanbul, has come to know and love his adopted home more fully than most natives; he has written two dozen authoritative books about Istanbul and other parts of Turkey and is now at work on three-volume guide to Turkey and history of private lives of Sultans (M)

headline: Avon Calls On a Man to Lead It; Female Cosmetics Executives Passed Over for Top Post
abstract: Avon Products Inc, which built its reputation on its identity as a women's company, unexpectedly, names Charles Perrin its next vice chairman and chief operating officer; Perrin is expected to replace James E Preston as Avon's chief executive sometime next year; Preston also announces that Andrea Jung, executive vice president, is being elevated to become president of Avon's worldwide operations, putting her in line to be Perrin's successor some day; executive vice president Christina A Gold is passed over; Susan J Kropf, president of North American operations, is not promoted but is named to board of directors; Preston's appointment of Perrin is greeted with disappointment by some female executives, who see it as missed opportunity; chart; photos (L)

headline: Treasuries Up In Optimism On Economy
abstract: Investors buy Treasury securities amid optimism that economic growth is slow enough to keep inflation at bay; 30-year bond gains 10/32, to price of 101 19/32, with yield at 6.26 percent; graph (M)

headline: U.N. Blocks Rights Move By North Korea
abstract: United Nations human rights committee tries to keep North Korea from backing out of pledge to honor international human rights standards by taking position that such pledges are for all time; The committee passes resolution declaring that country cannot withdraw once it has signed International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which North Korea has been party to since 1981 (M)

headline: For Old Films, the Ending Almost Always Comes Out the Same
abstract: Article notes that millions of pounds of old film stock holding thousands of copies of movies must be destroyed each year; most of it goes to recycling plant operated by Eastman Kodak in Mountain City, Tenn; drawing (M)

headline: Uzbeks Offer Plan to End Afghan War
abstract: Uzbekistan offers proposal aimed at ending civil war in Afghanistan and will present it to UN; Foreign Min Abdulaziz Kamilov says Government wants to forge coalition in Kabul that would include fundamentalist Islamic Taliban movement but not allow it to impose policies opposed by other factions; map (M)

headline: For White Goods, A World Beckons; But New Markets Are Tough Going
abstract: Makers of major home apliances, or 'white goods,' stumble as they try to go global; white goods market may be among toughest for corporations with global ambitions; there are countless variations in what consumers in different countries want from cooking, washing and refrigeration products based on how they live; also, in most countries there are already well-established local competitors that cater to those preferences; multinational appliance companies find themselves in nation-by-nation trench warfare; despite difficulties, they persevere because developing countries are only places in world where major appliance sales are growing at double-digit percentage rates; they are also attracted by potential cost savings in global procurement and manufacturing; charts show how Whirlpool, Maytag, Electrolux and GE have fared in their globalization efforts (M)

headline: New Motorola Task Goes to Leo Burnett
abstract: Motorola Inc's Semiconductor Products Sector names Leo Burnett Co to create worldwide image advertising for its semiconductors (S)

headline: MEDAPHIS REPORTS DOWNWARD REVISION IN 1995 EARNINGS
abstract: Medaphis Corp decreases its fiscal year 1995 earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization by about $2.8 million (S)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: First Union and Corestates  Create Banking Behemoth  First Union will purchase Corestates Financial for $17.1 billion, a record deal in a wave of bank mergers that is sweeping the nation and redefining how banks service the financial needs of customers.    The branch network of the two banks would span the East Coast, with one of the largest shares of the region's deposits. The merger comes only a few weeks after Corestates rejected First Union's overtures. [Page A1.]

headline: Visa prepares an early and aggressive campaign to capitalize on its ties to the Olympic Games.
abstract: Visa USA Inc is preparing early and aggressive advertising campaign to capitalize on its ties to 1998 Olympic Games in Nagano, Japan, which begin on Feb 7; promotional blitz will begin Nov 22 with splashy television commercial (L)

headline: French Grocery Concern Buys Retailer in Portugal
abstract: Promodes SA, France's number 2 publicly traded supermarket company, agrees to buy discount retailer Portuguesa de Lojas de Desconto from Auchan for undisclosed sum; Promodes announces purchase of Simago, a Spanish supermarket operator; some analysts say purchases might signal that Promodes is withdrawing from its fight with Rallye SA for Casino Guichard-Perrachon SA, unit of Groupe Casino (S)

headline: Patents; Holiday gifts with U.S. identification numbers: baggy pants, suspenders, a vest to aid exercising.
abstract: Items patented this year discussed as possible holiday gifts (M)

headline: Beyond Self-Serve: Robots and Magic Wands
abstract: BUYING gasoline is a chore; drivers want to get in and out of the gas station as quickly as possible and be on their way.    To help ease the process, some big gasoline retailers are experimenting with new gadgets, including radio transmissions, robot arms and scanner technology. All are intended to move motorists along -- and maybe even without the smell of gasoline on their hands.

headline: Nippon Life Buys American Express Stake
abstract: Nippon Life Insurance Co is converting $355.6 million of Lehman Brothers Holdings Inc preferred stock into 4.4 million common shares of American Express Co, Lehman's former parent; exchange gives Nippon stake of nine-tenths of percent, worth about $396 million, in American Express (M)

headline: The National Enquirer turns to a consultant to improve its sales at supermarkets.
abstract: Publishing industry executives are intrigued by work of Qualpro, quality control consulting firm that examines how companies can improve their performance by testing for number of factors, approach known as multivariable testing; National Enquirer, which employed Qualpro, reports 20 percent increase in newsstand sales and greater than 50 percent increase in subscriptions; photo of two different covers of same issue of National Enquirer that Qualpro evaluated (M)

headline: AIDS a Major Threat / Some Progress in Family Planning : In Tanzania, Many People and Many Woes
abstract: NG'IRESI, Tanzaniaâ€”  Sareyo Lothi struck a match and held it close to the single, tiny lamp that hung over his dirt-floored living room. As the room brightened, so did his face. A wide smile of caramel-colored teeth said it all: See, it works!

headline: QUANDARY FOR U.S.: ADVISER ON TIBET
abstract: Week before state visit of Chinese Pres Jiang Zemin, Clinton Administration finds itself in diplomatic predicament of own making over pledge to appoint special coordinator to oversee American policy toward Tibet and is scrambling to avoid confrontation during Jiang's week-long tour; decision has brought protests from Beijing, which regards planned office as interference in its internal affairs, while members of Congress are accusing State Department of dithering; White House and State Department have strongly suggested that appointment will be postponed; while Administration has sought to engage China's Communist Government on variety of fronts, vocal faction in Congress has accused it of putting pragmatic concerns like trade over issues of principle involving human rights and religious freedom (M)

headline: More Geek, Less Chic; After a Tryout at Microsoft, the Hip Gives Way to the Really Useful
abstract: Microsoft Corp, after spending $1 billion chasing evanescent business of on-line entertainment and media, is nudging its new-media efforts closer to company's old utilitarian tradition; unprofitable on-line 'shows' are giving way to money-making 'services;' photos (L)

headline: U.S. Maritime Agency Moves to Bar Most Japanese Cargo Ships From American Ports
abstract: Federal Maritime Commission, in unexpected intensification of trade dispute with Japan, orders Coast Guard to bar most Japanese cargo ships from American ports and to detain any Japanese ships currently in port; move comes after Japan's three largest shipping companies--apparently on orders from their Government--refuse to pay $4 million in fines imposed in Sept (M)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  KERNAN, LESLIE HADDEN
abstract: KERNAN-Leslie Hadden on October 21, 1997. Beloved wife of the late Walter Avery Kernan; mother of Anita Halton, Mary Rutherfurd, Emily Rafferty, Nancy Chamberlain, Beatrice and Charles; grandmother of Anita Halton; Leslie Coleman, Lily and Emily Rutherfurd, Nicholas and Sara Rafferty, and Katherine Chamberlain; and sister of Anita Hadden Page and the late Hamilton Hadden Jr. Funeral Mass, 10:30 A.M., Friday, October 24th, at Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue at 84th Street. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to Interfaith Neighbors, Inc., 247 East 82nd Street, New York, New York 10028.    KERNAN-Leslie Hadden. The Board of Directors and Staff of the Visiting Nurse Service of New York deeply mourns the loss of Leslie H. Kernan, a former Director and devoted friend. She served the agency with distinction in many capacities and will be sorely missed. Our sympathy is extended to her children and other members of her family. Carl H. Pforzheimer III Chairman of the Board Carol Raphael President and CEO    KERNAN-Leslie. The families, staff and Board of Directors of Interfaith Neighbors extend their deepest sympathy to the Kernan family. A gentle, wise soul, a fellow board and council member, and a dear friend, Leslie (Coupie) will be sorely missed. Her dedication to Interfaith Neighbors will continue to make a huge difference in the lives of New York City children and families.    KERNAN-Leslie. The Board of Directors of 1105 Park Avenue expresses their profound sorrow over the death of Leslie Kernan, a past member of the Board and long-standing resident of 1105 Park Avenue. On behalf of the residents of the building, we offer our deepest condolences to her family.

headline: FIRMS ACQUIRE KINETIC CONCEPTS STAKES
abstract: Kinetic Concepts Inc agrees to sell most of company to investment firms Richard C Blum & Associates LP and Fremont Partners LP for as much as $875 million (S)Â¼

headline: F.D.A. Panel Recommends Approval of a Chiron Drug
abstract: Federal Drug Administration (FDA) advisory panel recommends that Chiron Corp's drug Proleukin be approved to treat metastatic melanoma, fatal skin cancer; same panel also recommends against approval of Depocyt, an anti-cancer agent; panel's negative recommendation sends shares in Depotech Corp, Chiron's partner in Depocyt, plummeting; Chiron's shares also decline in price (M)

headline: The Bank Of America
abstract: David E Sanger analysis contends that South Korea's call for billions of dollars in direct financial help from US and Japan, and immediate rejection by US is latest example of brewing tensions between US and its ailing Asian allies over how to quell financial crisis that refuses to be tamed; maintains that throughout Asia, and particularly in South Korea, Washington's insistence on setting tough conditions for financial changes and its refusal to put much of its own money at risk is breeding hostility (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Bailing Out of the Bailout Game; Tokyo Does the Unthinkable and Lets a Big Bank Fail
abstract: Analysis of failure of Hokkaido Takushoku Bank, first of Japan's big banks to collapse under weight of bad loans, says it is latest--and strongest--sign yet that Japanese Government is prepared to encourage market forces to reconfigure domestic financial landscape; holds with at least 3 other banks among Japan's 20 largest in little or no better shape than Hokkaido Takushoku, and many regional banks in worse straits, once-sacrosanct financial system is being pushed to modernize and consolidate; says bank's failure signals that Government, while it remains cautious on some fronts, will at least grudingly stand aside in more such cases and let market take over; table; photos (L)

headline: Iran Opens Big Gas Pipeline to Neighbor, Defying U.S.
abstract: Iran opens 125-mile natural gas pipeline to Turkmenistan giving it access to world's largest untapped energy reserves; new pipeline also weakens one of strongest levers US has wielded in its attempts to punish Iran for supporting terrorist groups and trying to acquire nuclear weapons; has helped break blockade by Russia, which in 1993 shut pipelines as part of reassertion of Soviet-era dominance of Caspian Sea; photo; map (M)

headline: Adil Carcani, 75, a Leader In Albania's Stalinist Twilight
abstract: Adil Carcani, last Prime Minister in Albania's Stalinist era, dies at age 75; photo (M)

headline: Encore Media Adds Richards to Roster
abstract: Encore Media Group, which offers satellite and cable movie services, names Richards Group to handle creative duties for account of its Starz!, Encore Movie Networks and Movieplex brands, with billings estimated at $45 million; those duties had been handled by Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor; media services are handled by SFM Media Corp; Siemens Wireless Terminals, division of Siemens Business Communication Systems unit of Siemens AG, selects Long Haymes Carr as first advertising agency to handle its American account; billings estimated at $10 million to $15 million (S)

headline: Levi Strauss campaigns become pieces at an exhibition.
abstract: Art Directors Club to open extensive exhibit devoted to almost a century and a half of advertising, graphic design and blue-jeans products by, for and from Levi Strauss & Co; exhibit is to commemorate club's presentation to Levi Strauss of 1997 Management Award for achievement in brand advertising and design communications; photo (L)

headline: Zimbabwe Faces Showdown On Unfinished Issue of Land
abstract: Showdown is coming in Zimbabwe between white farmers and Pres Robert Mugabe, who threatens to seize their land without compensation; Mugabe, in big political trouble, has revived attacks on white farmers he has used before in troubled times; map; photo (L)

headline: CLINTON CAUTIONS IRAQIS ON OPTIONS IN HUNT FOR ARMS
abstract: Pres Clinton warns Pres Saddam Hussein he will consider other options if Iraq continues to bar United Nations arms inspectors from so-called presidential sites, news conference; holds Hussein miscalculates in seeing opportunity to split Persian Gulf War allies; insists international community is now much less likely to ease sanctions; Richard Butler, chief UN inspector, leaves Iraq; says he sees no way out y of impasse; Clinton, at news conference, says United States, Japan and other wealthy nations might have to do more to stem mounting Asian financial crisis; insists International Monetary Fund must continue to take lead in all bailout efforts; lauds South Korean steps to promote national unity; urges Congress to approve added funding for IMF; photo; Treasury Sec Robert E Rubin cites importance of currency crisis, particularly in South Korea, to United States security, interview (M)

headline: WASTE MANAGEMENT STOCK FALLS ON EARNINGS PREDICTION
abstract: Waste Management Inc shares fall sharply after company predicts lower-than-expected third-quarter earnings (S)

headline: RECKSON ASSOCIATES ADDING STAKE IN MORRIS COMPANIES
abstract: Reckson Associates Realty Corp agrees to invest $150 million and to acquire controlling interest in Morris Companies (S)

headline: MOVIE REVIEW : Live Flesh
abstract: Directed by Pedro Almodovar. Spain.

headline: Caribbean Nations, Ignoring U.S., Warm to Cuba
abstract: Cuba and English-speaking Caribbean nations are moving rapidly to renew their ties after nearly 15 years of American-induced separation; Jamaica, convinced that Communism represents no threat to region, leads efforts to reach out to Cuba; photo (M)

headline: Rwanda's Paralyzing Wound: Hutu-Tutsi Killings
abstract: Analysis of situation in Rwanda, where Hutu-Tutsi violence continues to stifle progress; Hutu guerrillas, who recently massacred 270 Tutsi refugees, do not yet seem to have organization, arms or manpower to defeat Government's Tutsi-led army, but violence could make it impossible for Tutsi-controlled Government to heal rift with Hutu majority, rebuild economy and move nation toward democracy; map; photo (M)

headline: P.&G. to Increase Stake in China Venture
abstract: Procter & Gamble Co is planning to increase its stake in Chinese joint venture with Hitchison Whampoa Ltd to 80 percent from 69 percent for $650 million; agreement gives Procter & Gamble's management control of venture called P & G Hutchison (S)d

headline: In Adoption, New Help From Employers
abstract: ADOPTIVE parents don't get morning sickness or swollen ankles, and they can dine out to celebrate the night their child is born. But they face some hardships that other parents do not: costly travel, complex legal proceedings and visits from social workers to determine whether they are fit for parenthood -- all of which can cut into a career.    Increasingly, companies are providing adoption benefits for employees, recognizing that the accumulated costs can be comparable to those of traditional childbirth.

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of Nov 2 article on bill to overhaul Internal Revenue Service (S)

headline: Most Major Stock Indexes Hit Record Highs
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average rises 78.09 points, or nearly 1 percent, to close at 8,178.31; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbs 10.43 points, or 1.07 percent, to close at record 983.12; Nasdaq composite index gains 15.36 points, to close at record 1,737.27; table (L)

headline: Hotel Group Said To Seek Bids
abstract: Interstate Hotels Co reportedly has gotten offer from Meditrust Corp valuing company at $1.3 billion and is talking to other possible suitors (S)

headline: Iran Sees Pistachio Ban As Foul Play by Enemies
abstract: European Union has banned imports of Iranian pistachio nuts after discovering shipment that was contaminated by cancer-causing toxin; Iran is largest exporter of pistachios in world; ban has left in limbo thousands of tons of nuts that were enroute to Europe and has left farmers completing their annual harvest with little to do but wait; photo (M)

headline: That Unwritten Code Against Fraternization
abstract: Few companies have written policies on employee fraternization, although some have less formal rules on office romances; some experts hold companies should bar relationships between supervisor and subordinate; in-house romances that involve adultery are especially disconcerting to companies; photo (M)

headline: THIOKOL PLANS TO RAISE STAKE IN HOWMET INTERNATIONAL
abstract: Thiokol Corp will buy 13 million shares of Howmet International from Carlyle Group affiliate for between $175 million and $200 million, increasing its ownership in Howmet to 62 percent from 49 percent (S)

headline: Market Place; ITT soars as its suitor, Hilton Hotels, and traders anticipate a court-ordered vote.
abstract: Market Place column notes price of ITT Corp stock jumped more than 8 percent on day after Federal judge ruled that company's board could not split ITT into three companies without shareholder approval; security analysts note ITT must hold shareholder meeting in November, to comply with Nevada laws, and that company would find it hard to push its stock price much above Hilton's $70-a-share offer, meaning shareholders might look favorably on bid (M)

headline: FUNDS WATCH
abstract: Mutual Fund Education Alliance, nonprofit trade association of direct-marketed funds, is devoting its World Wide Web site through year-end to investing for children; it lists funds with features that make it easier to start investing for children, like reduced minimums if fund is set up in child's name or with automatic monthly investment program (M)

headline: Nomura Combines Units In Deregulation Move
abstract: Nomura Securities Co will merge its asset management and mutual fund units, creating Japan's biggest money manager (S)

headline: John N. Trainer, 88; Led Investment Firm
abstract: John N Trainer, former head of investment counseling firm, dies at age 88 (S)

headline: U.S. and Iran Cooperating on Ways to End Afghan War
abstract: Iran and US are working together in low-key meetings, exploring ways to end civil war in Afghanistan; talks are offering not only rare chance for direct contact between Iran and US, but also opportunity to establish longer-term relationship between Washington and Pres Mohammed Khatami, who recently offered olive branch to US (M)

headline: Paid Notice: Deaths  FRIEDMAN, SAMUEL M.
abstract: FRIEDMAN-Samuel M. 87, retired partner of A.L. Eolis & Associates, Certified Public Accountants, on October 22, 1997. Beloved husband of Lucille T. Friedman, loving father of Jerold, Nina, and Karen, father-in-law of Linda, grandfather of Brett and Jennifer, brother of Pauline Slotnick. Funeral services Sunday at 10:30 AM at Sinai Chapels, Fresh Meadows, NY, 718-445-0300.

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.75   5.81   5.24        3-MO. TREAS. BILLS   4.95   4.95   4.88        6-MO. TREAS. BILLS   5.04   5.05   5.07        10-YR. TREAS. INFL.**   3.62   3.61   N.A.        10-YR. TREAS. NOTES   6.03   6.09   6.58        30-YR. TREAS. BONDS   6.32   6.39   6.84        TELEPHONE BONDS   7.40   7.48   7.82        MUNICIPAL BONDS***   5.43   5.47   5.84          *Estimated daily average, Dow Jones Markets  **Realized dollar amount rises with inflation  ***Municipal Bond Index, The Bond Buyer  Sources: Salomon Brothers and Dow Jones Markets for Treasury's bellwether bonds, notes and bills

headline: Oktyabrsky Journal; How to Amuse Rich Russians: Odds on the Horses
abstract: Russian oil equipment industry entrepreneur Daud Naloyev is hoping to make Russia competitive force in breeding of thoroughbred race horses; seeks to lure nation's new socialites into breeding business; is working with Mohammed Rashid al-Makdoum, United Arab Emirates Defense Minister and noted breeder; map; photo (M)

headline: October Auto Sales Weak Except for Newest Designs
abstract: Auto makers report lackluster sales in October, first month of new model year, for all but hottest new or redesigned models; Chrysler Corp says sales fell 8.3 percent, but its newest sport utility vehicle sold briskly, as did its new four-door version of Dodge Ram pickup truck; Honda's redesigned 1998 Accord sold briskly, helping company's sales increase 11.2 percent; General Motors Corp and Ford Motor Co are expected to report declines of up to 5 percent; Nissan says its sales rose 4 percent, Subaru's sales rose 17 percent, Volvo's rose 9.7 percent and Kia's rose 55.7 percent; those posting sales declines include Isuzu, down 24.8 percent, Mitsubishi, down 16.5 percent and Land Rover unit of BMG AG, down 24.6 percent (M)

headline: Mao's Heir Finds Path: Wall Street
abstract: President Jiang Zemin of China trod a capitalist road yesterday from Wall Street to the suburban campuses of hi-tech American industry.    Free of all the irksome talk about human rights he had had to endure in Washington, Mr. Jiang concentrated in his trip through New York yesterday on a matter closer to his heart: money. It was an interest enthusiastically reciprocated by American business executives eager to cash in on the world's most populous market.

headline: Omnicom to Acquire Harrison, Young
abstract: Omnicom Group agrees to acquire Harrison, Young, Pesonen & Newell Inc of Toronto; terms not disclosed (S)

headline: Italy to Sell Shares In Alitalia to Cut Stake
abstract: Italy says that it will reduce its stake in Alitalia SpA to about 60 percent from about 85 percent by selling shares to private investors rather than injecting more Govt money into airline (S)

headline: Turkish Judge Scolds U.S. for Opposing a Ban on an Islamic Party
abstract: Turkey's highest-ranking judge, Yekta Gungor Ozden, strongly criticizes United States, accusing it of trying to discourage Turkish court from banning country's pro-Islamic political party; prosecutor is seeking to have party outlawed on ground that it is working to undermine secular basis of Turkish state; some of Turkey's friends in West dread decision that would ban party, fearing it would set back Turkey's continuing effort to portray itself as fully democratic country; some American officials are reported to have discussed matter with Turkish officials, and State Department spokesman voiced American concern publicly (M)

headline: Seagate Posts Huge Loss On Charges
abstract: Seagate Technology Inc reports unexpected and large fiscal first-quarter loss; Seagate lost $240 million for its quarter ended Oct 3, compared with profit of $129 million in year-earlier quarter; revenue fell to $1.90 billion from $2.06 billion; Compaq Computer Corp reports 41.6 percent gain and Digital Equipment Corp reverses loss of a year earlier, but Sun Microsystems Inc earnings fell 12.2 percent; Compaq says earnings were $517 million, compared with $365 million in year-earlier quarter; sales rose to $6.47 billion from $4.95 billion; Digital earned $25 million, compared with loss of $66 million a year earlier; sales rose 4 percent, to $1.58 billion, from $1.52 billion a year earlier; service revenue dipped to $1.38 billion from $1.39 billion; total operating revenue was $2.96 billion, compared with $2.91 billion; Sun Microsystems earned $108.4 million, down 12 percent from $123.4 million a year earlier; revenue rose 13 percent, to $2.01 billion from $1.86 billion (M)

headline: GENERAL DYNAMICS TO ACQUIRE A UNIT OF CERIDIAN
abstract: General Dynamics Corp says it will buy Ceridian Corp's Computing Devices International unit for $600 million (S)

headline: Gunmen Take Microsoft Items in Scotland
abstract: Microsoft Corp says masked gunmen broke into plant in Scotland last week and stole estimated 200,000 certificates of authenticity, 100,000 CD-ROM's and computer equipment; Microsoft says certificates of authenticity could be worth up to $16 million if they are attached counterfeit Windows 95 operating system-based products (S)

headline: Anger at the Israelis Is the Theme as Islamic Conference Closes
abstract: Muslim leaders from around world wrap up three-day meeting in Iran by criticizing Israel for what they call 'state terrorism' and demanding that it stop building settlements on Arab land (M)

headline: MARKET WATCH ; What ITT And Castro Have in Common
abstract: ITT Corp, which formerly controlled Cuban Telephone Company but suffered from Cuban expropriation, will receive millions of dollars under terms of agreement with Telecom Italia, company active in Cuba that is paying up to avoid effects of Helms-Burton Act, which seeks to punish foreign companies that do business on island; photo (M)

headline: WACHOVIA AGREES TO A $71 MILLION DEAL FOR AMERIBANK
abstract: Wachovia Corp acquires Ameribank Bancshares of Hollywood, Fla, for $71 million in stock (S)

headline: Ciba SC Sales Beat Analysts' Estimates
abstract: Ciba Specialty Chemicals AG, Swiss chemicals company, says nine-month sales rose higher-than-expected 20.4 percent, fueled by weak Swiss franc and growth in Europe, Asia and US; sales rose to 5.94 billion Swiss francs ($4.08 billion), from 4.93 billion francs in year-earlier period (S)

headline: At NATO, Russia Voices Opposition to Any Raids Against Iraq
abstract: Russian Foreign Min Yevgeny M Primakov tells NATO foreign ministers, meeting, Brussels, that Russia still opposes use of force to get Iraq to permit full international inspection of suspected biological and chemical weapon stockpiles; says Russia will continue to contribute to NATO peacekeeping force in Bosnia if mission is extended beyond June 1998; State Sec Madeleine K Albright, who met privately with Primakov, urges ministers to develop strategy for dealing with nations like Iraq that acquire weapons of mass destruction; urges continuing diplomatic efforts to secure Iraqi compliance, without ruling out other options (M)

headline: Owner of Rolls-Royce Plans Sale of Luxury Auto Maker
abstract: Vikers PLC says it will sell its Rolls-Royce Motors Cars PLC subsidiary to concentrate on core businesses of armored vehicle and propulsion technology products; potential suitors said to include BMW, Ford Motor Co, Ferrari unit of Fiat Group and Daimler-Benz AG; Rolls-Royce has been Britain's last major luxury car maker to remain independent of one of large auto manufacturers; its sale will almost certainly pass it into foreign hands (M)

headline: Change of Heart About Joining the Euro Hands Blair a Setback
abstract: Labor Government of British Prime Min Tony Blair appears to have suffered major setback over contradictory statements about how soon it would abandon pound to join euro, unified European currency; Finance Min Gordon Brown, who recently favored joining system early, says too many obstacles remain to be overcome and strongly suggests Britain will be unlikely to join before current parliamentary term ends in 2002 (M)

headline: Japan, Economic Power Aside, Seems Paralyzed by Asia Crisis
abstract: Japan, with economic power to ease Asian economic crisis, has instead contributed to it by long ignoring its own problems; few analysts expect Japan to move decisively to fix its own problems or Asia's, despite its announcement of $16 billion in tax cuts and plans for $77 billion bailout of its own financial mess; foreign critics charge Prime Min Ryutaro Hashimoto has adopted contractional fiscal policy that threatens world economic growth; graphs (L)

headline: Dividend Meetings
abstract: MONDAY   Eccolab  Roc Communities

headline: Paris Journal; Gasping for Air, the City of Light Takes a Breather
abstract: Unusually warm and windless weather has wrapped Paris in haze of smog; authorities on Oct 1 order half cars--those with even-numbered license plates--off road in Paris area and recommend that infirm and young stay indoors; decision to apply tough new anti-pollution laws takes almost everyone by surprise; photo (M)

headline: Panel Hears Evidence Winnie Mandela Sought Doctor's Death
abstract: One of two men convicted in slaying of Abu-Baker Asvat, Soweto doctor, testifies before South Africa's Truth and Reconciliation Commission that Winnie Mandela, former wife of Pres Nelson Mandela, ordered killing because doctor was hindering her political work and offered $8,000 for doing job; Cyril Mbatha testifies that he and accomplice met at Mandela's home, where she gave them gun to use; testimony comes on sixth day of hearings into Winnie Mandela's role in numerous assaults and killings in late 1980's (M)

headline: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS: Many Players, Many Losers; How and Why Asian Currencies Tumbled So Quickly
abstract: Article on how and why Asian currencies tumbled so quickly; says Japanese officials, concerned about decline of yen, hinted that they might raise interest rates in early May; threat never materialized, but it proved to be first sign of Asian flu that six months later is still spreading and has already prompted around $100 billion in international pledges of foreign aid; holds Japanese threat shifted decisions of global investors, who immediately began to sell Southeast Asian currencies, setting off tumble not only in currencies but in local stock markets as well; says leapfrogging from Thailand, to Indonesia to Hong Kong, financial shivers eventually shook Wall Street, sending Dow Jones industrial average down record 554 points on Oct 27; economic and currency problems of Thailand, Malaysia, Indonesia, South Korea and Hong Kong detailed; graph; photos (L)

headline: Dallas Tower to Be Sold
abstract: Crescent Real Estate Equities Co and Trizec Hahn Corp agree to acquire Banc One Center, 60-story Dallas office tower, from affiliates of Teacher Retirement System of Texas and Cigna Corp for $238 million (S)

headline: Stocks End Mixed in Moderate Trading as the Dow Rises 6.14
abstract: Broad equity indexes in US end mixed despite overnight gains among Asian markets; Dow Jones industrial average closes at 7,558.73, up 6.14 points, after trading up as much as 47.15 points; table (L)

headline: AFFILIATED COMPUTER UNIT TO PAY $52 MILLION FOR A FIRM
abstract: Technical Directions, unit of Affiliated Computer Services, plans to buy professional services firm for $52 million in stock and assumption of $10 million in debt to expand its information technology staffing business; name of firm undisclosed (S)

headline: Honeywell Unit Is Sold
abstract: General Signal Corp buys North American control-valve business of Honeywell Inc for undisclosed price (S)

headline: Stocks Fall Sharply in Japan On Debt and Economy Fears
abstract: Japanese stocks fall more than 5 percent after food-trading company, Toshoku Ltd, seeks court protection from heavy debts, raising fear that more bankruptcies and business failures will plague already frail economy; Nikkei index is down 811.59 points, or 5.02 percent, at 15,350.05 in early afternoon trading on Dec 19 (S)

headline: Bull Market's Glitter May Be Blinding Investors
abstract: Survey by Montgomery Asset Management finds investors expect average annual return of 34 percent over next 10 years, figure that shocks many financial advisers because it is so far above historical averages; Dow Jones industrial average rises 139 points, or 1.75 percent, to close at 8,060.44; Standard & Poor's 500-stock index surges 16.67 points, or 1.74 percent, to 972.28, and Nasdaq composite index jumps 27.09 points, or 1.61 percent, to 1,712.54; chart; graph (L)

headline: Albright Sizes Up Chances For Pullback on West Bank
abstract: US Sec of State Madeleine K Albright returns to Paris for meeting with Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu following session with Palestinian leader Yasir Arafat in Geneva; will meet again with both in mid-December in Europe after return from African trip and NATO meeting in Brussels; reportedly hopes for clearer answers by then on how willing both are to compromise on issues that separate them--such as further Israeli withdrawal from West Bank and its size and timing, Palestinian efforts to fight terrorism, US call for freeze on Israeli settlement activity, and Israeli and American desire for rapid move to accelerated negotiations on final setttlement between Israelis and Palestinians; photo (M)

headline: Senate Inquiry On Fate of Pilot Lost Over Iraq
abstract: Sens Rod Grams and Robert C Smith ask Senate Select Committee on Intelligence to inquire into fate of Navy Lieut Cmdr Michael Scott Speicher, only Persian Gulf war pilot who remains unaccounted for; say they may have been mislead by Pentagon officials who told them there is no evidence that Speicher may have survived (M)

headline: Italy's Barbed Political Jester, Dario Fo, Wins Nobel Prize
abstract: Dario Fo, Italian playwright-performer known for mixing social farce with sharp political satire, is awarded Nobel Prize in Literature; Swedish Academy, in its announcement of $1 million prize, likens Fo to 'jesters of the Middle Ages' who relied on wit, irreverence and slapstick humor to poke fun at authority while 'upholding the dignity of the downtrodden'; Roman Catholic Church has been frequent target of Fo's satire, and Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano says it is 'flabbergasted' by his selection; photos (M)

headline: U.S. Steps Up Patrols in Iraqi No-Flight Zone
abstract: US jet fighters step up their patrols over US-enforced no-flight zone in southern Iraq after Iraqi planes breach zone several times (M)

headline: ST. JOE NO LONGER SEEKING ALL OF FLORIDA EAST COAST
abstract: St Joe Corp says it is no longer seeking to acquire 46 percent of Florida East Coast Industries that it does not already own; news follows decline in share price of both companies (S)

headline: Wall St. Plans For Trading By the Billions
abstract: Heavy trading activity in recent days prompts Wall Street executives to accelerate their plans to increase capacity of their computer systems; Richard A Grasso, chairman of New York Stock Exchange, says goal is capacity to handle five times current average daily volume, which has been 520 million shares; despite all the planning over last decade, some of most disruptive slip-ups last week were same ones Wall Street faced 10 years ago, when trade-reporting system at New York Stock Exhcange froze after reaching its maximum limit of trades; last week, same thing happened at Nasdaq (M)

headline: Leo Burnett Quits Fruit of the Loom
abstract: Toronto office of Leo Burnett Co resigns North American Fruit of the Loom account, with billings estimated at $20 million to $25 million, rather than participate in a review (S)

headline: Equity Issues Scheduled For Offering This Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:

headline: GGT Group to Merge Its London Agencies
abstract: GGT Group PLC will merge its two London-based ad agencies, GGT Advertising and BST-BDDP, to form BDDP GGT, a shop that would be ranked among 15 largest in Britain (S)

headline: Black-Owned Bookstores Defend Niche
abstract: Joann and Feron Roberts have built Phenix Information Center, San Bernardino, Calif, into one of nation's top 10 black bookstores by regularly drawing high-profile black writers; store still struggles for credibility with some publishers, despite its marketing flair; sampling of African-American bookstores around nation; photo (M)

headline: 2 KEY POSTS FILLED AND REORGANIZATION PLANNED
abstract: Lucent Technologies Inc names Dan Stanzione executive vice president and chief operating officer; he will remain president of company's Bell Labs unit; it also names Ben Verwaayen executive vice president and chief operating officer; Lucent also announces that it will reorganize itself into smaller business units (S)

headline: China to Set Up Secondary Boards
abstract: China's two exchanges in Shanghai and Shenzhen will set up secondary boards for poorly performing listed stocks in attempt to prevent them from dragging down the indexes; share prices of downgraded companies will also be restricted to daily swings of 5 percent, down from normal 10 percent limit on listed companies (S)

headline: Abortion Issue Imperils $3.5 Billion U.S. Payment to the I.M.F.
abstract: Senate Republicans, angered over Clinton Administration's stand on abortions overseas, are threatening to withhold $3.5 billion Administration wants to use to deal with financial crises, like those in Southeast Asia; Pres Clinton says $3.5 billion financing for International Monetary Fund is 'high priority' (M)

headline: TIME WARNER TO SELL 3 CABLE SYSTEMS TO PARTNERSHIP
abstract: Time Warner Inc agrees to sell some cable systems in three Southern states to partnership of Renaissance Media Partners LLC and Morgan Stanley Capital Partners, a unit of Morgan Stanley, Dean Witter, Discover & Co, as part of effort to trim $17 billion of debt; financial terms undisclosed; cable systems are in southeastern Louisiana, Picayune, Miss, and Jackson, Tenn (S)

headline: Nouveau Number, No Cachet
Union Begins to Dismantle Blockades : French Truck Strike Ending With a Pact
abstract: PARISâ€”  The union representing the majority of striking French truck drivers signed an agreement Friday with the trucking companies, effectively ending a dispute that has caused chaos in France and beyond.

headline: In Letter, Rubin Warns Japan It Must Bolster Limp Economy
abstract: US Treasury Sec Robert E Rubin wrote private letter to his Japanese counterpart, Hiroshi Mitsuzuka, last week warning that health of Japan's banking system is deeply imperiled and urging strong action to spur Japanese economy; reports about letter's content appear to reflect Administration's fears that choking off of Japan's long-delayed economic recovery, worsened by sharp fall in Japanese stock market, could set off crisis like one that moved from markets of Southeast Asia to those of New York and Latin America last month; Rubin's letter does not directly refer to weakening Japanese yen, which makes Japanese goods more affordable overseas; but Rubin repeats his warning that Japanese officials should not be tempted to export their way out of their troubles--move that would greatly increase America's trade deficit; it is increasingly clear that Administration's immediate worry centers on what Japan might do in response to potential financial collapse of South Korea, Japan's closest neighbor and one of its fiercest regional competitors; photo (L)

headline: Many Laotians in U.S. Find Their Hopes Betrayed
abstract: Laotian-American spokesmen say recent cutoff of welfare benefits has led to sense of betrayal, despair and suicide among legal refugees; much of Laotian-American community consists of mountain tribesmen who emigrated with their families after being recruited by Central Intelligence Agency to help United States fight Vietnam war; photo (M)

headline: Ernst & Young Approval
abstract: Partners at accounting and consulting giant Ernst & Young overwhelmingly approve firm's merger with KPMG Peat Marwick (S)

headline: Nigerian Dismisses Cabinet and Says He Will Release Detainees
abstract: Nigeriuan military leader, Gen Sani Abacha, dissolves Cabinet and promises to release number of political prisoners in apparent move to consolidate his power (M)

headline: Dollars Are in the Details
abstract: Robert Silvers and his Photomosiacs are in great demand as magazine covers and for advertising posters; his work uses thousands of tiny pictures to create digital pointillist portrait; his company, Runaway Technology, is worth $1 million; photo (M)

headline: Phelps Group Buys Cohen/Johnson
abstract: Phelps Group acquires and absorbs Cohen/Johnson; names Howie Cohen chief creative officer and Mark Johnson vice president for strategic marketing, new posts (S)

headline: Dow Jones Is Said to Discuss Deal for Data Services Unit
abstract: Dow Jones & Co reportedly has met with potential partners or buyers of its troubled financial information services unit, Dow Jones Markets (M)

headline: Surprisingly Warm Greetings For Several Initial Offerings
abstract: Handful of companies that went public on Oct 29, so soon after market crash, are generally warmly received by investors, with shares of most closing higher for day; analysts say activity in initial public offerings, or IPO's, signal sharp reversal in sentiment from start of week, when they feared new issues might come to halt for week or more (M)

headline: 2 Deals for Halter Marine
abstract: Halter Marine Group Inc has received two contracts with total value of $136 million to build two jack-up drilling units for Chiles Offshore LLC (S)

headline: Bond Prices Rally Further On Asia Woes
abstract: US Treasury securities rally for third day; 30-year Treasury bond gains 31/32, to price of 101 24/32; yield falls to 6 percent, from 6.07 percent on Dec 10; graph (L)

headline: A Novartis Executive From SmithKline
abstract: Novartis AG names SmithKline Beecham executive vice president Jerry Karabelas as chief executive for health care; Karabelas succeeds Pierre Douaze, who will retire (S)

headline: MYRIAD GENETICS EXPECTS TO MAKE $3 MILLION ON OPTION
abstract: Myriad Genetics Inc to buy and sell option for 400,000 of its own shares, move it expects could make it up to $3 million if stock price rises more than 13 percent in next 14 months (S)

headline: PLAYTEX TO BUY CHILDS UNIT FOR $182 MILLION
abstract: Platex Products Inc says that it agreed to acquire Personal Care Group Inc from J W Childs Equity Partners LP for $182 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: WPP Unit Shuffles Top Management
abstract: Rebecca McPheters leaves as Simmons Market Research Bureau chief executive; Geoff Wicken to succeed her (S)

headline: Securities Prices Lose Early Gains
abstract: Prices of US Treasury securities rise early, briefly sending yield on 30-year bond down to nearly 6 percent--lowest level in about two years--before investors cash in profits; by late in day price of 30-year bond backs into negative territory, falling 11/32, to 100 31/32; yield rises to 6.06 percent, from 6.03 percent on Nov 19; graph (L)

headline: Swiss Struggle to Understand Killings at Luxor
abstract: Coffins of 35 Swiss tourists who died in massacre in Luxor, Egypt, arrive at Zurich airport; victims will be given state funeral; photo (M)

headline: Pizza Hut Sets a Revamping at a $425 Million Cost to New Owner
abstract: Tricon Global Restaurants, fast-food business spun off by Pepsico two months ago, announces sweeping changes for its Pizza Hut restaurants; it will shut down more than 700 of worst-performing outlets and sell off hundreds of franchises at cost to company of $425 million after taxes (L)

headline: PRESIDENT-ELECT IN SEOUL SUGGESTS TALKS WITH NORTH
abstract: Kim Dae Jung, newly elected President of South Korea, says he may seek summit meeting between two Koreas, and he proposes broad dialogue between two countries as first step toward reconciliation; diplomats and other analysts say that in particular, Kim's election and formal ascent to power by Kim Jong Il in North Korea make this an opportune time for movement on both sides; economic crisis ravaging South may also help ease tensions; North, on edge of famine, was often humiliated by comparisons to prosperous South, and now may feel that a dialogue could proceed on more equal footing; photo of Kim with his wife, with document confirming his victory (M)

headline: Two Exchanges Post Rises In Uncovered Short Sales
abstract: New York Stock Exchange reports that open positions of short sales rose 3.9 percent, or 133.3 million shares, to record 3.55 billion shares in month ended Nov 10; American Stock Exchange says short interest rose 6 percent, to 192 million shares, also a record; charts (L)

headline: Pornography Case Against Lawyer Ended
abstract: Canadian prosecutors drop child pornography charges against Kenneth D Murray, Ontario lawyer who was charged in connection with grisly tapes of the rape and torture of two teen-age girls by Paul Bernardo, whom he represented (S)

headline: Consumer Price Index: Again No Surprises
abstract: Labor Department reports consumer prices rose two-tenths of 1 percent in October; over the last year, consumer inflation shrank to 2.1 percent from 3 percent; chart; graph (L)

headline: Clock Ticks at Trade Talks With Focus on U.S. Demand
abstract: All eyes are on US, as negotiators from more than 100 countries try to hammer out global trade agreement in Geneva, Switzerland, to remove national barriers in banking, insurance and securities by midnight Dec 12; US is once again playing world's bad cop by threatening to walk away from treaty unless it gets what it wants; US is demanding that countries in Asia and Latin America make it easier for American financial companies to do business there (L)

headline: Corrections
abstract: Correction of listing of financial advice programs for the serious ill that ran with a Nov 16 article on a cancer survivor's efforts to save money

headline: Rome Journal; For Italy's Stuffy Museums, a Kind of Renaissance
abstract: Italy is undergoing renaissance in its traditionally languid and complacent approach to its vast and rich cultural heritage that has frustrated visitors who come to admire works of art; change has been spearheaded by Culture Min Walter Veltroni--also Deputy Prime Min--who prides himself with businesslike approach to government; museums long closed for restorations have reopened, visiting hours have been lengthened, new sources of funding have been tapped, off-site ticket sales and advance booking for popular exhibitions are now possible; in departure some critics say is overly American, bookshops and cafeterias have opened for business inside museums, with more on way; photo (M)

headline: Dollar Moves Mostly Higher As Korea Worries Ease a Bit
abstract: US dollar rises against most currencies; dollar weakens against Japanese yen (M)

headline: QUEBECOR'S UNSOLICITED BID FOR WATMOUGHS IS REJECTED
abstract: Quebecor Inc, Canada's largest printing company, makes unsolicited bid of $316.8 million for Watmoughs Holdings PLC, which Watmoughs rejects (S)

headline: Faces of the New York Economy; Immigrants Providing a Global Link
abstract: Article on faces of New York economy focuses on commercial photographer Zan Ng and advertising executive Joseph Liu of midtown advertising agency Admerasia, which employs 50 people and bills $20 million a year, that joins growing number of immigrant-owned businesses that have successfully capitalize on ethnic connections; photo (M)

headline: Northwest and Pilots Reported To Discuss Continental Alliance
abstract: Northwest Airlines executives and leaders of carrier's pilots' union meet to try to revive alliance that will enable Northwest to take effective control of Continental Airlines (S)

headline: THE ASIAN CRISIS: TOKYO'S ROLE ; As More Fissures Appear, Japan Starts to Form a Rescue Plan
abstract: Japan's fragile financial system shows further strains with collapse of Tokuyo City Bank, small regional bank, and rumors that Yasuda Trust & Banking Co, major bank, may seek bailout; ruling Liberal Democratic Party seeks to devise plan to use public funds to steady system; Bank of Japan has already made big loans to two failed companies, Hokkaido Takushoku Bank and Yamaichi Securities Co (M)

headline: 'Carlos' the Terrorist Is Convicted In France of Decades-Old Murders
abstract: Ilich Ramirez Sanchez, terrorist known as Carlos, is convicted and sentenced to life in prison in France for murder of two French police agents and Lebanese informant in Paris apartment 22 years ago; 48-year-old Venezuelan-born terrorist, self-desribed professional revolutionary in Palestinian cause, defiantly shouts 'Viva la revolucion!' and dismisses proceedings as American-led Israeli conspiracy; he is wanted in at least four other countries for numerous bombings, killings and attacks including kidnapping of 11 oil ministers in Vienna in 1975 and hijacking of Air France jet to Entebbe in 1976 (M)

headline: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING ; All Aboard for the Campaign for a Few Good Mentors
abstract: Advertising column describes ambitious project to sell concept of mentoring with public service announcements on television networks as well as mentions in episodes of television series; effort to promote mentoring has attracted support of at least six networks, working with nonprofit organizations (M)

headline: Wei Reportedly Tells President That Release of One Prisoner By Beijing 'Is Not Enough' : Clinton Meets With Dissident Despite Chinese Denunciations
abstract: WASHINGTONâ€”  Wei Jingsheng, the recently released Chinese dissident, met Monday with President Bill Clinton at the White House, four days after the Beijing authorities demanded that U.S. officials not grant an audience to a man they consider a common criminal.

headline: Polaroid to Revamp and Cut 1,500 Jobs
abstract: Polaroid Corp will take pretax charge of $310 million in fourth quarter to cut 15 percent of its work force and sell chemical plant in attempt to reduce costs; Polaroid agrees to sell its chemical manufacturing operations to International Specialty Products Inc for undisclosed amount (S)

headline: WINSTAR PURCHASE OF U.S. ONE ASSETS IS APPROVED
abstract: Winstar Communications Inc wins approval from Federal bankruptcy judge to buy virtually all assets of US One Communications Corp for $100 million, $80 million in cash and $20 million in stock (S)

headline: Hate Exams? Here's a Chance to Profit From Them
abstract: Computerized academic testing business is on rise, fueled in part by Pres Clinton's bid for more standardized tests; sharp rise in price of Advantage Learning Systems stock cited; table; photo (M)

headline: FINANCE BRIEFS
abstract: Debt     * AAR Corp., Elk Grove Village, Ill., is selling $60 million of notes due in 2007 through Goldman, Sachs & Co. The notes, which are rated Baa2 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and BBB by the Standard & Poor's Corporation, are priced at 99.8 to yield 6.903 percent.    * Bear Stearns Cos., New York, is selling $200 million of notes due in 2007 through Bear, Stearns & Co. The notes, which are rated A2 by Moody's and A by S.& P., are priced at 99.777 to yield 6.781 percent.

headline: Russia and Brazil Caught in Selling Surge
abstract: Even most buoyant of stock markets, like Russia and Brazil, succumb to tidal wave of selling on Oct 23; mutual funds specializing in Latin American stocks have been among best performers this year, and Russian funds have been even hotter; but major stock market indexes fall by bout 8 percent in Brazil, 4.5 percent in Mexico and 5 percent in Russia--two to four times worse than 2 percent decline suffered by American stocks (L)

headline: Rights Report Says Kabila's Troops Are Killing Civilians
abstract: Human Rights Watch/Africa and International Federation of Human Rights Leagues say they have proof that Pres Laurent Kabila's troops in Congo have killed large numbers of civilian refugees since last fall, and that killings continue; will publish report that includes pictures of bodies in area where 1,700 people, including many women and children, were apparently bludgeoned to death; report names officers in areas where massacres took place; charges Rwandan forces were heavily involved in atrocities and blames United States for giving Rwanda impression that US would not look too closely at behavior of Rwandan troops backing Kabila; Scott Campbell, who helped prepare report, says refugees were first attacked by then-Pres Mobutu Sese Seko's troops, then robbed by Rwandan Hutu militia members and then massacred by Kabila's troops and his Rwandan Tutsi allies (M)

headline: Stocks Flat in Japan
abstract: Stocks trade in narrow range and are flat in Tokyo (S)

headline: F.C.C. to Open Phone Market To Foreigners
abstract: Federal Communications Commission will take major step to open America's $200 billion telecommunications market to foreign competition, hoping to lower international calling rates for consumers and bolster opportunities for American communications companies elsewhere in world; FCC move will be last official action required to bring United States into line with accord reached last February in Geneva by 69 countries representing more than 90 percent of global $600 billion telecommunications market; accord will go into effect Jan 1; big American long-distance companies like AT&T and MCI could see their share of nation's $12 billion international calling market fall as foreign communications giants like Deutsche Telekom and France Telecom start offering service directly to American businesses and consumers (M)

headline: DAVCO ACQUISITION TO BUY REST OF DAVCO RESTAURANTS
abstract: Davco Acquisition Holding Inc says it will buy shares it does not already own in Davco Restaurants Inc for $20 each, or about $110 million (S)

headline: UNION PACIFIC RESOURCES REVISES ITS OFFER FOR PENNZOIL
abstract: Union Pacific Resources Group offers to pay $84 a share in cash for all of Pennzoil Co's shares; Union Pacific's original offer, which Pennzoil rejected, was to pay cash for 50.1 percent of Pennzoil's shares and stock valued at $84 a share for remaining Pennzoil shares (S)

headline: UST TO PAY $93.7 MILLION IN STOCK FOR SOMERSET SAVINGS
abstract: UST Corp agrees to buy Somerset Savings Bank for $93.7 million in stock (S)

headline: A Climate Change Glossary
abstract: Glossary of terms that play important role in climate change debate (M)2

headline: Greenspan Cautions on Inflation; Change in Tone a Jolt to Investors
abstract: Federal Reserve Chmn Alan Greenspan warns inflation may be on horizon, jolting investors and increasing chances that Federal Reserve may raise interst rates; says it is unrealistic to expect stock prices to continue to rise as quickly as in recent years; stocks, bond prices and dollar plunge on release of remarks, prepared for Congressional committee, as analysts see abrupt change of tone; Greenspan, in oral remarks, stresses Congress's failure to take advantage of strong economy to make more progress on politically painful issues like need to overhaul Social Security and Medicare; graph (M)

headline: Marketers of cars and communications and cleaning products choose new agencies.
abstract: Marketers of everything from cars to cleaning products make changes to their accounts, continuing weeks of brisk account activity (M)

headline: F.C.C. to Defer Decisions on Phone Deals
