abstract: Federal Communications Commission chairman, Reed E Hundt, informs Senate Commerce Committee chairman, John McCain, that FCC will defer preliminary ruling on Worldcom Inc's bid for MCI Communications Corp and ruling on AT&T Corp's challenge to BellSouth Corp's bid to offer long-distance phone service in South Carolina until Senate approves its new members and chairman; cites lame duck status of current commission; says he will reconsider if Senate delays confirmation of William E Kennard; Sen Jesse Helms reportedly threatens to block confirmation unless Kennard agrees to help Zebulon Lee and his Orion Communications get radio license in Asheville, NC (M)

headline: WHOLE FOODS TO BUY MERCHANT OF VINO FOR $41 MILLION
abstract: Whole Foods Market Inc agrees to acquire Merchant of Vino for $41.2 million in stock (S)

headline: Anne-Stine Ingstad, a Sifter Of Viking Secrets, Dies at 79
abstract: Anne-Stine Ingstad, Norwegian archeologist who sifted through sandy soil above Newfoundland beach and uncovered remains of 1,000-year-old Viking outpost, dies at age 79; photo (M)

headline: J. Masucci, 62, International Salsa Promoter
abstract: Jerry Masucci, owner of Fania Records and promoter of salsa music, dies at age 62 (S)

headline: NCR TO CUT 1,000 JOBS IN LATEST REVAMPING
abstract: NCR Corp says it will eliminate 1,000 jobs, or 2.6 percent of its work force, next year and give sales teams more authority in latest effort to increase sales; says its third-quarter loss narrowed to $9 million, from $33 million in year-earlier quarter (S)

headline: Microsoft to Appeal Ruling On Browser, Seeing 'Error'
abstract: Microsoft Corp says it will appeal Federal judge's temporary order to change one of its marketing practices, calling judge's ruling 'error' and 'inappropriate'; with appeal pending, Microsoft sketches out how it plans to comply with court order to allow personal computer makers to unbundle Microsoft's Internet browser from its windows operating system; Microsoft will offer PC makers two choices: current bundled product or original version of Windows 95 with slight programming changes--an operating system that is more than two years dated; Justice Dept says plan gives PC producers no real choice and violates spirit, if not letter, of judge's order (M)

headline: AMERICAN GENERAL TO BUY FIVE HOTELS FOR $119 MILLION
abstract: American General Hospitality Corp says it will buy five hotels in two separate transactions for $119 million; it will buy Holiday Inns in Alexandria, Va, Annapolis, Md, Hanover, Md, and Chicago, and a Ramada Plaza in Alexandria (S)

headline: U.N.'s Chief Offers Iraq Oil Compromise
abstract: UN Sec Gen Kofi Annan recommends that Security Council consider increasing amount of oil Iraq may sell to buy food and medicine, but stops short of proposing specific figure (S)

headline: ITT Plans More Reductions In Corporate Work Force
abstract: ITT Corp, facing crucial shareholder vote in November, announces another round of cost cuts, move analysts say could help in its fight to avoid takeover by Hilton Hotels Corp; moves--combining headquarters for its corporate, gaming and Sheraton hotel operations and eliminating 86 positions from its headquarters staff--will result in pretax savings of about $55 million a year; announcement is part of campaign to win support of shareholders who will vote on merits of competing plans (M)

headline: Growth of Unit Sales Slows at Volkswagen
abstract: Volkswagen AG says its unit sales in first 11 months of 1997 rose 7.8 percent (S)

headline: At Home, Rosy News for Jiang's Trip
abstract: China's Government-controlled television and newspapers have not mentioned impromptu debate on human rights between Pres Jiang Zemin and Pres Clinton at their news conference on Oct 29 (M)

headline: National Semiconductor Stock Plunges
abstract: Shares of National Semiconductor Corp tumble nearly 12 percent after company reports mixed results for its fiscal second quarter; shares fall $3.625 each, to $27; for quarter ended Nov 23, National earned $28.9 million, up 10.7 percent from $26.1 million in year-earlier period; sales rose 5 percent, to $719.9 million (S)

headline: MARKET TIMING
abstract: MONDAY  The Commerce Department reports on personal income and spending for September.  The Commerce Department reports on construction spending for September.  The National Association of Purchasing Management releases its purchasing managers index for October.    TUESDAY  The Conference Board issues its monthly report on leading economic indicators.  Mitsubishi Bank/Schroder Wertheim releases its weekly retail sales report.  LJR Redbook Research releases its weekly retail sales index.    WEDNESDAY  The Commerce Department reports on factory orders for September.    THURSDAY  The Labor Department reports initial weekly claims for unemployment insurance.   The Commerce Department reports on housing completions for September.    FRIDAY  The Labor Department reports on unemployment in October.  The Federal Reserve System reports on consumer credit for September.  The Commerce Department reports on wholesale trade for September.

headline: Judge Lifts Block On Publicis Bid
abstract: Federal appeals court throws out preliminary injunction blocking Publicis SA from making $269.4 million hostile bid for control of its former partner, True North Communications; Publicis says it will resume its bid immediately (S)

headline: Ayer Direct Buys Deare Marketing
abstract: Ayer Direct in New York, unit of N W Ayer & Partners, acquires Deare Marketing (S)

headline: HANIFEN, IMHOFF TO SELL FINANCIAL CLEARING UNIT TO FISERV
abstract: Hanifen, Imhoff Holdings Inc says it agreed to sell its financial clearing operations to Fiserv Inc for $97.2 million in cash and stock (S)

headline: Congress, the Kibbitzer at the Climate Table, Waits for Its Turn
abstract: Skeptical and suspicious Congress will be watching closely as Clinton Administration negotiates international treaty to curb global warming; coping with climate change is shaping up as another thorny intergenerational issue that forces lawmakers to make painful political choices now that will probably not yield tangible benefits for years or decades; few in Congress have studied issue in depth, but many are staking out stands consistent with those of their labor, business or environmental allies (M)

headline: Use of Placebo Is Ended for H.I.V. Study in Africa
abstract: Johns Hopkins University researchers have abandoned plan to use dummy pills in experiment on Ethiopian women who are pregnant and infected with AIDS virus; use of dummy pills as placebo has renewed debate over ethics of series of federally financed studies in third world (M)

headline: As Market Turmoil Eases, Korea Shifts Focus to Labor
abstract: Pres-elect Kim Dae Jung of South Korea meets with nation's top labor leaders to try to persuade them to accept increasingly grim economic reality; nation's intensely militant labor force is not expected to react favorably to any fundamental shift in labor practices, like abandoning virtually sacrosanct job security; Kim had pledged during his presidential campaign not to allow corporate layoffs; he now says that if layoffs have to come in financial sector, only later will they come to manufacturing industries; one labor leader warns of grave difficulties if workers are dismissed unfairly or precipitously; graph (M)

headline: Soft Sheen aims at women who really like to style their hair.
abstract: Advertising column describes Soft Sheen Products' new line of hair care products, called Alternatives, for young black women who change their hair styles frequently; television, radio and print campaign was prepared by Spike DDB; photo (M)

headline: Ford, After Latin Success, Sends 2 to Beef Up Sagging Europe Unit
abstract: Ford Motor Co, in an effort to strengthen day-to-day management at its troubled European unit, names James D Donaldson president of Ford of Europe, and Henry D G Wallace, chief financial officer; decision to send both men to Europe greatly strengthens the regional management group, which has limited power over such country-level subsidiaries as Ford of Britain and Fordverke in Germany; for the last four years, Ford has been pursuing an innovative management experiment, known as Ford 2000, aimed at uniting executives around the world based on their area of expertise; even with this coordination, Ford has failed to thrive in highly competitive European market, hence shift to strengthen management at the regional level; graph on Ford sales in Europe (M)

headline: VIEWPOINT; Web Commerce: Be Prepared
abstract: Edward R Berryman article offers advice for corporations on preparing for electronic commerce via Internet; cites need for tremendous commitment to organizational redefinition to reap benefits of electronic commerce (M)

headline: Former Smith Barney Executive Charged
abstract: Robert B Maloney, former regional director of Smith Barney Inc, is charged with Federal election fraud; Government says he funneled $39,000 through co-workers to Congressional campaign of his brother Repr James H Maloney (S)

headline: CASCADES AND DOMTAR PLAN A JOINT VENTURE
abstract: Cascades Inc and Domtar Inc create joint venture through merger of Cascades' containerboard operations an d Domtar's packaging division; venture, which would be 50 percent-owned by each company, would be largest Canadian producer of linerboard and corrugated materials (S)

headline: BLACKSTONE GROUP BUYS A 65% STAKE IN CLARK USA
abstract: Blackstone Group says it has bought 65 percent controlling stake in Clark USA Inc from Trizec Hahn Corp for about $135 million (S)

headline: BOLIDEN IS TURNED DOWN IN OFFER FOR WESTMIN RESOURCES
abstract: Westmin Resources Ltd says it rejected unsolicited offer of almost $809 million (Canadian) in stock and assumed debt from Boliden Ltd because price was too low (S)

headline: In Northeast Bank Flux, Who's Next in Line?
abstract: First Union Corp, by winning battle for Corestate Financial Corp, will achieve more than simply expanding its presence in Pennsylvania and New Jersey; it will solidify its role as dominant retail bank in Northeast, positioning itself for even more acquisitions; Mellon Bank, which has made overtures to Corestates but was rebuffed, becomes more vulnerable, with fewer chances to expand and with ever-bigger competitors closing in; map; chart (L)

headline: While Other Europeans Downsize, German Military Moves Into Lead : Armed Forces Surpass Expectations
abstract: BONNâ€”  Germany's armed forces continue evolving to fulfill their role as Europe's largest army, perhaps faster than most observers had expected.

headline: Taking a Turn Into Teaching
abstract: David Krane letter on Sept 28 article on career change into teaching (S)

headline: Bond Prices Drift Higher in Light Trading
abstract: Prices of US Treasury securities drift higher in light trading; 30-year bond rises 12/32, to price of 101 31/32, with yield dropping to 6.23 percent from 6.26 percent on Oct 6; graph (M)

headline: Dow Profit Down In Latest Quarter
abstract: Dow Chemical Co says third-quarter profit fell 10 percent; net income was $422 million from $469 million a year earlier; revenue fell 2.6 percent, to $4.86 billion from $4.99 billion (S)

headline: Treasuries Thrive as a Haven From Stocks
abstract: Treasury securities surge as stocks plunge around the world; benchmark 30-year issue rallies 1 26/32 to price of 103 6/32; yield declines to 6.14 percent, lowest level in 20 months (M)

headline: Waste Management Takes a Pretax Charge
abstract: Waste Management Inc takes pretax third-quarter charge of about $173 million and restates its accounts for past two years; says actions are based on first phase of review by its audit committee (S)

headline: Big H.M.O. a Victim Of Its Own Ambition
abstract: Oxford Health Plans grew as it promised the convenience and savings of a health maintenance organization with the freedom to see any doctor by agreeing to share the cost.    But Oxford has now become the victim of its own grand ambition. The H.M.O. has fallen behind in paying doctors and hospitals, owing hundreds of millions of dollars.

headline: Is McClatchy Bid for Cowles Too Rich?
abstract: McClatchy Newspapers Inc's $1.4 billion deal to acquire Cowles Media Co is well above $1 billion valuation that industry analysts had set for Cowles Media; Gary Pruitt, McClatchy's chairman and chief executive, says purchase of Cowles's flagship Minneapolis Star Tribune would strengthen McClatchy's quest for wider geographical base in cyclical industry; says Star Tribune's tone and editorial policy would be directed by its own publishers, not from edicts from McClatchy's flagship Sacramento Bee; Pruitt assures reporters and editors at Star Tribune that no cuts or changes are planned for news department at paper, and says management and direction of paper's reporting would be left in Minneapolis; Cowles heirs now number about 70, and there was pressure to cash out; photos; map (M)

headline: W. H. Smith Rejects Recent Takeover Offer
abstract: W H Smith Group PLC rejects takeover offer from Tim Waterstone, former owner of Smith's Waterstone's book-retail unit (S)

headline: GEON IN $76 MILLION DEAL TO BUY SYNERGISTICS INDUSTRIES
abstract: Geon Co says it has agreed to buy Synergistics Industries Ltd of Canada for about $76 million (US) (S)

headline: Regional Airline Strike Threat
abstract: Atlantic Southeast Airlines pilots vote to strike if contract talks with carrier's parent company, ASA Holdings Inc, break down at end of Oct; Air Line Pilots Association says 98 percent of voting pilots back strike (S)

headline: First Union Sought Deal For Corestates
abstract: Preliminary merger talks between the Corestates Financial Corporation, the last major bank based in Philadelphia, and the First Union Corporation of Charlotte, N.C., have recently ended, according to advisers to different parties close to the talks.    The informal talks, in which First Union proposed buying Corestates in a bid to consolidate its grip on consumer and business banking in the mid-Atlantic region, were serious enough for the chief executive of Corestates, Terrence A. Larsen, to have disclosed them to the board of his company. But the discussions had not progressed to the stage where either bank had discussed fundamental issues like the price of the transaction or who would assume what management positions in a combined company.

headline: After a Rocky Ride, It's Time to Recall the A B C's
abstract: Article on huge fluctuations in stock prices in last week revisits all those fundamental investment realities that pushed investor into the market to begin with; says economic fundamentals in US still look good; adds that over last 70 years or so the market has generated average return of about 11 percent, more than five percentage poitns better than bonds; notes those averages include some years when stock prices fell; drawing (L)

headline: BREED TO TAKE A PRETAX CHARGE OF ABOUT $300 MILLION
abstract: Breed Technologies Inc says it will take second-quarter pretax charge of $250 million to $330 million, halt dividend payments and report loss of 12 to 15 cents a share in its first quarter; charge reflects costs of cutting jobs and closing or selling some plants (S)

headline: William F. Knight, 93, Founder Of Orange Juice Plant in Florida
abstract: William Francis Knight, who established one of nation's first orange juice processing plants, dies at age 93 (M)

headline: Enron in Bid to Be Pennsylvania Utility
abstract: Enron Corp is seeking to take over Pennsylvania service area of Peco Energy Corp, offering to lower customers' electric rates by 20 percent and assume $5.5 billion in Peco costs (S)

headline: Maker of Rolls-Royces May Buy Back Shares
abstract: Vickers PLC, which makes Challenger 2 tanks and Rolls-Royce cars, says it might buy back some shares in latest step to refocus the company; Vickers faces hostile bid from Mayflower Corp PLC (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: INTEL CORP., Santa Clara, Calif., said it had made an undisclosed equity investment in the closely held One Touch Systems Inc., San Jose, Calif., which delivers interactive broadcasts.

headline: In Slap at U.S., Israel Reduces Role at Talks
abstract: Growing number of Arab countries are staying away from Middle East economic conference in Qatar to protest Israel's policies; Israel says that Foreign Minister David Levy will not attend conference; says Industry and Trade Min Natan Sharansky will lead Israeli delegation (M)

headline: Russian Partner in Iran Deal Postpones Its Bond Offering
abstract: Gazprom, major Russian partner in project to explore for natural gas in Iran, postpones bond offering to raise up to $3 billion following extraordinary pressure from US; postponement has temporarily headed off decision by Clinton Administration about whether to impose sanctions on companies involved (M)

headline: In a Game Built on Fantasy, the Perennials Win
abstract: Toy testers and publishers of Oppenheim Toy Portfolio newsletter call certain toys 'the blue chips'; they note certain toys that never seem to go out of fashion, even though there are 6,000 new toys on market each year; photo; chart with 10 best-selling toy product lines for last 12 years (M)

headline: Beyond Browsers
abstract: Analysis: in taking action against Microsoft Corp, Justice Dept is trying to seize control of competitive ground rules of computer industry that Microsoft has increasingly dictated in 1990's; at stake is Microsoft's ability to blend World Wide Web browser program seamlessly with its Windows 95 operating system, thus effectively eliminating browser market for its rivals; Microsoft announces first-quarter revenue of $3.13 billion, up 36 percent from year earlier, and income for quarter of $663 million, compared with $614 million (M)

headline: Borrowing Pace Slowed During August
abstract: Federal Reserve reports consumer credit rose by $4.3 billion in August, to $1.229 trillion, after rising revised $6.0 billion during July; graph (M)

headline: Trial of Financier Offers Peek Behind Scenes of Spain's Elite
abstract: Mario Conde, chairman of former Banco Espano de Credito SA, and 10 others are on trial in major embezzlement case that promises to reveal much about way modern Spain works; Conde was convicted in Mar of forgery and misappropriation; Banesto's rescue cost Spain's central bank $1.5 billion and bank has been taken over by Banco Santander (M)

headline: SEAGATE WARNS OF LOWER RESULTS IN ITS SECOND QUARTER
abstract: Seagate Technology Inc says earnings in its second quarter will be below analysts' expectations because of weak demand for high-end computer disk drives and steep price declines (S)

headline: Retail Sales Increased 0.3% in September
abstract: Commerce Dept reports retail sales increased 0.3 percent in September, fourth straight monthly increase; much of gain appears to reflect higher auto prices; sales declined at clothing and department stores; analysts say this report, combined with upward revisions for July and August, portray economy that is decelerating; graph (M)

headline: Not Ready for Medicare, and Uninsured
abstract: WITH nothing to protect her but a vial of heart medicine, Ruth Kain spent the last year and a half willing herself to stay well. Then, a week before Thanksgiving, she felt a crushing pain in her chest, jaw and left arm so severe that it took her breath away. She was taken to the hospital, where doctors discovered a major blockage in an artery.    Mrs. Kain, 64, of Ava, Mo., is one of millions of Americans aged 55 to 64 who find it difficult -- or impossible -- to obtain health insurance. While her pain has gone away, for now at least, her worries have not. Since her husband's retirement and the expiration of his employer-sponsored health insurance in 1995, Mrs. Kain has been unable to find coverage for her heart condition.

headline: Great Chocolate War Reveals Dark Side of Europe
abstract: Eight European countries, led by Belgium and France, require that chocolate be made exclusively with cocoa butter; seven others, led by Britain and Denmark, allow companies to mix in substitute vegetable fats; European Parliment on Oct 23 votes overwhelmingly that chocolate is something different from what companies in Britain, Denmark and other five countries have produced for decades; it also votes to force Britain and Ireland to rename their milk chocolate because it has too much milk by European standards; photo (M)

headline: Volatility Attracts Investors To New Chicago Contracts
abstract: Officials at three Chicago futures exchanges say plunge and sharp rebound of stock prices in last two days has not scared individual investors away from high-stakes world of futures and options trading (M)

headline: Merrill Names New Leader for Assets Unit
abstract: Merrill Lynch & Co appoints Jeffrey Peek to lead its asset-management business as company prepares to buy Mercury Asset Management Group PLC; Arthur Zeikel, president of unit since 1977, will become chairman (S)

headline: Crude Oil Prices Drop Again; Corn and Soybeans Are Lower
abstract: Crude oil prices fall sharply on New York Mercantile Exchange, as worries about tensions in Persian Gulf continue to ease; soybeans and corn fall as farmers sell grain in cash market after recent run-up in prices, and cocoa falls on improved outlook for West African crops (L)

headline: Getting New York Ready For a Hotter, Wetter Future
abstract: Variety of groups begin identifying steps to limit potential impact of global warming on New York metropolitan region--steps experts say are worth taking no matter how climate changes; most predictions concern length of summer heat waves, which currently average approximately 14 days, but which could be twice as long in warmer world; findings of study of likely effects of global warming in New York region, carried out by Regional Plan Assn, discussed; photo (M)

headline: Brazil Utilities Sold in Bidding
abstract: AES Corp and group led by Public Service Enterprise Group Inc, Newark, NJ-based utility, are winners in bidding for two Brazilian energy companies in latest round of utility sales; group consisting of pension funds, Public Service, and VBC Energia SA, a joint venture of Banco Votorantim, Banco Bradesco SA and Camargo Correa Industrial SA, bids $1.49 million for 90.8 percent stake in Norte-Nordeste de Distribuicao de Energia Eletrica; AES agrees to pay $1.37 billion for Centro-Oeste de Distribuicao de Energia Eletrica (S)

headline: Credit Suisse First Boston Has Europe Loss
abstract: Credit Suisse First Boston's European equity operations lose $50 million in October, which will wipe out department bonuses; firm's losses occurred because bank's traders had been betting that equity prices would be bound by narrow ranges; as it happened, equity markets in United States and Europe suffered huge price swings during month (S)

headline: Christmas in Beijing
Netscape's License Deal With Pentagon
abstract: Netscape Communications Corp plans to license its software to Defense Department; Netscape software provides security features to let Pentagon employees communicate, retrieve and share information across its computer network and Internet (S)

headline: Market Place ; The betting is that Hambrecht & Quist will get a takeover bid soon, whether or not it wants one.
abstract: Market Place column examines speculation that Hambrecht & Quist, leading investment bank for high-technology companies, will be taken over in near future, as takeover fever sweeps securities business; firm's shares soared 36 percent last week; graph (M)

headline: Bank Stocks Fall On Fears About Overseas Losses
abstract: Bank stocks plunge on fears about big banks' exposure to steep drops in overseas markets; many large banks with exposure to Latin America and other emerging markets helped lead stock market lower on Oct 30; Chase Manhattan Corp, nation's largest bank, may face significant losses, at least on paper, in trading Russian equivalent of Treasury bills, as Russian stock market falls 40 percent from August highs; some analysts say some of concern about banks' problems in emerging markets is overblown, but banks are casting wary eye on Latin America; graph (M)

headline: Gunter Grass Touches a Nerve in Germany Over 'Closet Racism'
abstract: German novelist Gunter Grass is locked in public fight with senior Government officials over remarks he made criticizing Germans as 'closet racists' in behavior toward would-be immigrants (M)

headline: A Top Dresdner Bank Executive Will Resign
abstract: Hans-Gunther Adenauer, top executive of Dresdner Bank AG, says he will resign from company's board of managers after having admitted to evading income taxes (M)

headline: MEDIA: PUBLISHING ; A symposium debates whether the press is impartial, and if that's a good thing.
abstract: Committee of Concerned Journalists is sponsoring symposiums around nation on whether press is and should be impartial; participants in recent symposium at Columbia University favor striving for high-minded impartiality; photo (M)

headline: $250 Million Stock Deal for Microprose
abstract: GT Interactive Software Corp will acquire Microprose Inc for about $250 million in stock (S)

headline: Key Rates
abstract: In percent                Previous   Year          Yesterday   Day   Ago               PRIME RATE   8.50   8.50   8.25        DISCOUNT RATE   5.00   5.00   5.00        FEDERAL FUNDS*   5.50   5.45   5.29        3-MO. headline: U.S. Says Iraq Spied on Inspectors To Know When to Hide Weapons
abstract: United States military and intelligence officials say Iraqi intelligence agents successfully spied on United Nations weapons inspectors this year and last, learning in advance of team's targets and moving swiftly to hide suspected weapons caches; say U-2 spy planes have provided evidence that Iraqis knew of no-notice inspections well ahead of time (M)

headline: U.S. Executive Kidnapped in Mexico; Policeman Slain in Chase
abstract: Vincent Carozza, American manager of Acapulco Princess Hotel, is dragged from his car inside hotel complex by nine armed kidnappers who reportedly wear black uniforms of Mexican federal police; local police give chase, and wild shootout ensues on main road; one local officer is killed and second wounded; abduction, apparently for ransom, is part of three-year crime epidemic that has Mexicans in despair (S)

headline: Web Genesis Picks Kirshenbaum Bond
abstract: Web Genesis Inc names Kirshenbaum Bond & Partners as first advertising agency to handle integrated marketing for the Globe, its community Web site; billings estimated at $5 million to $8 million (S)

headline: A Troubled Oxford Health Takes Action
abstract: Oxford Health Plans Inc announces organizational changes that chairman Stephen F Wiggins describes as 'turnaround plans'; says it hired Kevin F Hickey, longtime health care executive, as executive vice president, and is seeking new chief financial officer to replace Andrew B Cassidy, who resigned; says it will find at least two new outside directors with experience in complex regulated businesses like banking and credit cards; says it hired Computer Sciences Corp and Cambridge Technology Partners Inc to help correct its glitch-prone computer information systems; it blames those systems for hundred-million-dollar errors in payments to doctors and hospitals as well as for losses in revenues and members following delays in sending out bills for monthly premiums; securities analysts praise restructuring moves but say it will take year or more to repair Oxford's problems (M)

headline: INVESTING WITH: Foster S. Friess; Brandywine Fund
abstract: Interview with Foster S Friess, manager of Brandywine Fund, mutual fund that buys mostly mid-sized stocks with big growth prospects; graphs; photo (M)

headline: Getting the Picture; TV Stations Develop New Enthusiasm for Digital Future
abstract: Television stations around nation scramble to be first to put digital, high-definition programming on the air; they impatiently wait for manufacturers to finish work on new digital transmitters and recorders, for engineers to finish creating new pieces of digital equipment, and for consumers to buy new digital televisions; it costs $1 million or more to equip station to pass on digital, high-definition signal; stations in small markets complain they cannot afford to make the upgrade, and some station owners are trying to sell their stations and get out of televisoin business altogether rather than pay for costly upgrade; photos; drawing (M)

headline: SINGER TO ACQUIRE 80% STAKE IN GERMAN MANUFACTURER
abstract: Singer Co says it will acquire 80.5 percent stake in G M Pfaff AG from Semi-Tech Global Ltd for $157.5 million (S)

headline: Business Travel; PC Magazine's advice: Don't trade your travel agent for a World Wide Web site just yet.
abstract: PC Magazine rates many World Wide Web's top sites for business, as well as leisure, travel; suggests not to trade travel agent for World Wide Web site; magazine's observations on Web sites related to business travel noted; Lufthansa in January will introduce $150 million upgrade of its long-haul first-class and business-class service, in effort to catch up with trans-Atlantic competitors; Leading Hotels of the World, reservations organization that represents more than 300 luxury hotels, has begun guest recognition program; travelers can participate in program only if they are nominated by hotel general manager (Business Travel column) (L)

headline: Helping a Few Taxpayers At the Expense of Many?
abstract: Tax experts say practical benefits of Taxpayer Bill of Rights will be minor, with big chunk of expected $2.6 billion in reduced taxes over five years going to businesses; only tiny number of people will benefit--and then at expense of added burdens for perhaps a million taxpayers a year; centerpiece of bill is shift in legal burden of proof in tax disputes, so that taxpayers are presumed to be in the right and Internal Revenue Service must show otherwise; tax litigators say change will directly benefit no more than 28,000 taxpayers annually (L)

headline: Pump Maker Buys Another
abstract: Idex Corp agrees to buy closely held Knight Equipment International for $38 million in cash (S)

headline: Strong Sales Lift Profit at Rhone-Poulenc
abstract: Rhone-Poulenc SA says third quarter profits were up 38 percent, to 1.04 billion francs ($180 million) from year earlier; sales rose 7 percent in quarter, to 21.9 billion francs ($3.79 billion) (S)

headline: Treasuries Finish Mixed On Quiet Day
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities are mixed in quiet trading; price of 30-year bond rises 6/32, to 99 25/32, as yield drops to 6.14 percent from 6.16 percent; graph (M)

headline: 'Harp Boont': Don't Get Upset If You Understand Every Word
abstract: BOONVILLE, Californiaâ€”  The isolated sheep-ranching community of Boonville in Mendocino County has developed a way of talking that some call a language. And it has even been incorporated into their schools.

headline: Integrated Health to Buy Some Healthsouth Assets
abstract: Integrated Health Services Inc says it will buy long-term-care assets from Healthsouth Corp for $1.15 billion in cash; assets, with annual revenue of $925 million, will add to Integrated's services for patients after they leave hospital; sale includes 139 sites for long-term care, 12 specialty hospitals, 35 institutional pharmacy locations and more than 1,000 rehabilitation therapy contracts (M)

headline: No Storm In Pacific
abstract: News analysis of meeting of Pacific Rim leaders in Vancouver; to Clinton Administration, meeting was clear success, putting on display American political and economic influence over vital and unsettled region; photo of leaders (M)

headline: Clinton Plans to Lower Another Barrier to Trade With Vietnam
abstract: Clinton Administration, citing Vietnam's progress in allowing free emigration and resettling refugees, intends to move toward more normal trading relations; plans to grant Vietnam waiver from Jackson-Vanik Amendment, which bars full economic ties with countries that restrict travel and emigration (S)

headline: Hong Kong Journal; For China to Ponder: The Dark Side of Easy Street
abstract: Fruit Chan Kuo's new movie Made in Hong Kong is first independent film released after territory's return to Chinese rule on July 1; film etches disturbing portrait of young people adrift on mean streets; it has been released at time of growing uncertainty about what films can be made and shown in Hong Kong; photos (M)

headline: Judge Approves Hilton-Bally Pact
abstract: Agreement by Hilton Hotels Corp to settle lawsuits brought by Bally's Grand Inc shareholders for $97.2 million is approved by Delaware judge, over objections of some shareholders; under settlement, Hilton agrees to buy Bally's Grand shares it does not already own for $52.75 each and $42.75 for each stock warrant outstanding to end legal fight over Bally's Grand's planned Parisian-theme casino resort in Las Vegas, Nev (S)

headline: With Rare Bitterness, Mandela Attacks White Elite
abstract: South African Pres Nelson Mandela attacks white elite with rare bitterness, complaining they expect to retain economic advantages in exchange for relinquishing political power, last major speech as African National Congress head; charges apartheid-era leaders wage clandestine drive to destabilize multiracial democracy; some experts see speech legitimizing tougher line likely to be taken by his expected successor, Thabo Mbeki; map; photo (M)

headline: DuPont to Build Plant
abstract: DuPont Photomasks, unit of DuPont Corp, plans to build production facility in Gresham, Ore, by end of 1998; unit makes photomasks, which are quartz plates used in manufacturing semiconductor wafers (S)

headline: French Far-Right Leader Convicted of Slighting Holocaust
abstract: Jean-Marie Le Pen, far-right French politician, is convicted of denying Nazi crimes against humanity, a crime under French law (M)7

headline: Nike to Feature A New Slogan
abstract: Nike Inc says it will supplement its long-running theme, 'Just do it,' with new slogan, 'I can'; television campaign, created by Nike's lead worldwide creative agency, Wieden & Kennedy, will feature 'I Can' theme beginning on New Year's Day (S)

headline: Mexico and U.S. Take Steps on Arms, Drugs and Border Issues
abstract: Pres Clinton and Mexican Pres Ernesto Zedillo announce modest progress in resolving a number of central problems in complex US-Mexico diplomatic relationship; sign accord to fight trafficking in illegal weapons, announce plans for closer working relationship in drug interdiction, agree upon new extradition rules for criminals, and promise cooperation on economic development along 2,000-mile common border (M)

headline: Eurotunnel Plan Avoids Bankruptcy
abstract: Eurotunnel's creditor banks approve reorganization of more than $14 billion in debt, averting possibility of bankruptcy; under agreement, which follows two years of often difficult talks, Eurotunnel will give banks shares amounting to 45.5 percent of its capital, and banks will wipe out 1 billion pounds of debt (S)

headline: Economic Calendar
abstract: Expected dates for the release of major economic indicators this week.    MONDAY   None     TUESDAY   Consumer Confidence Nov.  Existing-Home Sales Oct.    WEDNESDAY   G.D.P. 3d Qtr. Rev.  Durable Goods Orders Oct.  Weekly Jobless Claims     THURSDAY   None     FRIDAY   Personal Income Oct.

headline: Israel Suggests New Pullback In West Bank
abstract: Israeli Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu, under stiff pressure from Washington to start moving on peace and from his restive supporters to hold fast, is reported to be considering an Israeli withdrawal from another 6 to 8 percent of West Bank (M)

headline: Dayton Peace Accord Meets Bosnia Stalemate
abstract: Promises of Dayton peace accord remain unfulfilled, as many Bosnians face obstacles when they try to return to their former homes; 350,000 refugees have returned to Bosnia, but most have been unable to return home; none of three ethnic leaderships has welcomed back minorities, although Serbs have been least flexible and were worst offenders in driving minorities from their midst; photo (M)

headline: Berlin Journal; In Tomorrow's City, What to Do With Yesterday?
abstract: Cacophony of endless construction continues to snarl Berlin, as planner confront less obvious question of building new German capital without reviving, or seeming to deny, evil history of Third Reich; discussion also encompasses geometric Communist-era buildings that might be torn down on esthetic and environmental grounds; intense debate centers on Schlossplatz in former East Berlin, vast space that was dominated for centuries by Berlin Palace, and lately by Communists' Palace of the Republic; photo; map (Berlin Journal) (M)

headline: Moscow Is Very, Very Cold (And a Bit Cold-Hearted)
abstract: Moscow is in grip of unseasonable cold wave that has killed five people and hospitalized many; many people are hurt falling on icy sidewalks or being hit by falling icicles (M)

headline: Miscellany
abstract: * Publishers Information Bureau, New York, said that magazine advertising pages in October increased 6.3 percent from October 1996, to 22,830. For the first 10 months of 1997, ad pages rose 5.4 percent from the corresponding period a year earlier to 184,998.

headline: Israel 'Humiliated,' Netanyahu Asserts
abstract: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu lashed out at President Clinton, saying ''the entire Jewish state feels humiliated'' by Mr. Clinton's refusal to meet him last week.    ''It's unbecoming,'' Mr. Netanyahu said in a CNN interview. ''It doesn't befit nations who are allies and even doesn't befit nations who are not allies, and I believe that the United States probably would agree with me if they thought about it.''

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Korea Delays Bond Sale, Rattling World Markets  The crisis in South Korea worsened as the country's largest state-owned bank abruptly postponed an important bond sale, meaning that South Korea must come up with other ways to pay or renegotiate billions of dollars in debts coming due in the next few weeks.

headline: Europe's Pollution Fighter Draws a Bead on U.S. and Japan
abstract: Ritt Bjerregaard, European Union's outspoken Environment Commissioner, is complaining about 'weak' United States and Japanese proposals for limiting emissions of gases like carbon dioxide that may contribute to global warming; European Union has called for cuts in so-called greenhouse gases that are far more stringent than those of rest of industrialized world, stand opposed by European business leaders (M)

headline: Albright Says Iraq Agrees to Let U.S. Inspectors Back
abstract: State Sec Madeleine K Albright says Iraq has told Russian Min Yevgeny M Primakov that it will allow unconditional return of all United Nations arms inspectors, including Americans, news briefing after extraordinary 2 AM meeting, Geneva, of five permanent UN Security Council members; expresses doubts about Iraqi commitment; says United States has not agreed to changes in inspections or sanctions; photos (M)

headline: Chief of Credit Unit at Sears Resigns
abstract: Steven Goldstein resigns as head of Sears, Roebuck & Co's credit division; Sears names Alan Lacy to succeed him; names Gary Crittenden to succeed Lacy as chief financial officer and names him executive vice president (S)

headline: To Streamline, G.M. Will Take Charges Up to $3 Billion
abstract: General Motors Corp announces that it will take charge against earnings of $2 billion to $3 billion as early as fourth quarter to pay for job cuts, write-downs in value of some factories and other changes intended to streamline company in long term; GM says actions are prompted by it continuing study of competitiveness of its major lines of business; bulk of job cuts are expected to come in Europe (L)

headline: FROM THE DESK OF; . . . And, in Conclusion, Just Look At the Screen
abstract: THERE is always a tricky moment in the corporate speech-writing process when someone (never I, the speech writer) raises the question, ''What about slides?''   ''Oh, right,'' the chief executive says. ''I guess we have to have slides.''

headline: Energen Buying Reserves
abstract: Energen Corp agrees to buy energy producing properties in West Texas for $44 million from B C Oil and Gas Ltd and its affiliates (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: BORDEN FOODS CORP., Columbus, Ohio, has agreed to sell its United States cheese business to Mid-America Dairymen Inc., Springfield, Mo., and its North American grocery products business to a group established by affiliates of E. M. Warburg, Pincus & Co. and the General Electric Co., for an undisclosed amount of cash.

headline: What's Fair In Setting Fund Value?
abstract: Analysis of dispute over use of 'fair value' system of pricing securities in mutual fund portfolios during recent market turmoil; at issue is whether price of international stock funds should be based on value of stocks at close of foreign market or at close of United States markets; Fidelity Investments and T Rowe Price factored in up-to-date prices, while some other funds gave new investors benefit of lower foreign prices on day when prices were battered abroad and rose sharply in later US trading (M)

headline: Group Will Sell Health Care Unit
abstract: Personnel Group of America Inc agrees to sell its Nursefinders home healthcare and staffing services unit to investment group led by Atlantic Medical Capital LP and CIBC Capital Partners for $65.3 million (S)

headline: Acquisitions by Group 1
abstract: Group 1 Automotive Inc agrees to acquire four automotive dealership groups for about $36 million in cash and $20 million in Group 1 common stock (S)

headline: Market Place; With turmoil abroad, some wanted the Fed to ease credit.
abstract: Market Place: Some stock traders now think there is risk of American economy slowing in response to events around the world and were hoping Federal Reserve would have eased credit; Fed's meeting came on another day of turmoil in world stock markets, and failure to act could be seen as indication the Fed is not willing to do anything to stem turmoil and its possible economic consequences (L)

headline: Brave New World of Competition
abstract: Top officials of European Commission take aim at price fixing in German publishing; at issue is age-old industry practice under which booksellers and publishers mutually agree not to mark book prices below publisher's suggested retail price in Germany, Austria and Switzerland; practice has been in place for 110 years, but now it is running afoul of free-trade advocates; small bookstores have been under pressure even with price agreement in place; without it, they fear for their existence; photos (M)

headline: Mbuji-Mayi Journal; In a Diamond-Studded Land, Poverty, Not Palaces
abstract: Mbuji-Mayi is diamond capital of Congo; many young men seek their fortunes in mines there, but most stay mired in Congo's proverty; map; photos (M)

headline: Teheran Journal; One Wife Is Not Enough? A Film to Provoke Iran
abstract: Iranian film Leila, fictional acccount of infertile woman whose husband takes a secnd wife in order to have a son, stirs up strong emotions in Iran, where multiple marriage has never been as freely tolerated as in Arab lands; Islamic law is basis of legal code, but multiple marriage must contend with Persian tradition, and is also target of women's rights movement; photo; film director Daryoush Mehrouji comments; photo (Teheran Journal) (S)

headline: West Coast Shifts At Saatchi & Saatchi
abstract: Joe Cronin, president and chief executive at Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Pacific, who also heads worldwide Toyota Motor Corp account, will relinquish his management duties to focus on Toyota; he will continue as as vice chairman of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising; Scott Gilbert succeeds Cronin at Saatchi & Saatchi Pacific (S)

headline: Is Japan's Rare, Bold Surprise Sufficient to Revive Economy?
abstract: Analysis of Prime Min Ryutaro Hashimoto's surprise package of tax cuts and public spending, and effect it may have on country's economy; this includes income tax cuts and public works spending in stimulus package worth around $38 billion; critics note package includes only about $300 in tax cuts a year for each Japanese family, not enough to prime stalled economy; private economists estimate that more than half of income tax cut will not be spent at stores, but will be put into savings accounts, as was case when Government cut taxes in 1994; United States is pleased that Hashimoto has taken at least some action, but skeptics claim any sign of movement on part of Japanese Government would be greeted with relief; graph (M)

headline: Antakya Journal; Asleep in the City's Dust, Martyrs, Lions and Saints
abstract: Residents of New York and other great metropolises who assume that the glories of their cities will last forever might take a cautionary lesson from this remote provincial outpost.    Antakya is what remains of the grandeur of ancient Antioch, an early center of Christianity and for centuries one of the world's most important cities.

headline: 3 Goodby Employees Forming Agency
abstract: Grant Richards, Scott Aal and Brian Hurley leave Goodby Silverstein & Partners to form new firm of Grant Scott & Hurley (S)

headline: TELESYSTEM BUYING NATIONAL BAND THREE
abstract: Telesystem International Wireless Inc to buy National Band Three Ltd, Britain, which is currently owned by Geotek Communications, Montvale, NJ, and Terrafon Budelfunk of Germany for total of $100 million (S)

headline: I.M.F. Reportedly to Seek More Capital
abstract: Michel Camdessus, managing director of International Monetary Fund, has requested $160 billion increase in fund's capital base because of economic crisis in Asia; Financial Times of London says Camdessus wants fund's board to raise $200 billion capital base by 70 to 80 percent, rather than 45 percent agreed in September (S)

headline: Mentoring Meets Networking In Formal Programs
abstract: Many corporations offer formal career mentoring programs in bid to retain top talent; group mentoring is often set up to enable people to meet people in other departments; photo (M)

headline: MARSHALL & ILSLEY TO ACQUIRE ADVANTAGE BANCORP
abstract: Marshall & Ilsley Corp agrees to acquire Advantage Bancorp Inc for about $201 million in stock (S)

headline: Paine Webber Forms Top Panel
abstract: Paine Webber Inc names Steven P Baum, director of global fixed income, to added post of director of capital markets; names chief financial officer Regina A Dolan to added post of chief administrative officer; she succeeds Ronald M Schwartz, who will retire; Baum and Dolan will join Mark B Sutton, Robert H Silver, chairman Donald B Marron and president Joseph J Grano Jr on new executive committee (S)

headline: Smith Barney Accord Seen In Bias Case
abstract: Smith Barney Inc is expected to announce settlement of class-action lawsuit that accused firm of denying women promotions and doing nothing while brokers harassed women employees; under settlement, women employees will take their claims to independent arbitrator outside securities industry; such a move is radical departure for Wall Street firm; settlement does not include any fixed amount of money; suit was filed in May 1996 by three female employees, and was later joined by 22 other current and former employees of brokerage firm (L)

headline: 3M Profit Rises 8% As Sales Are Strong
abstract: Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Co says earnings in third quarter rose 8.5 percent to $432 million, before gain from sale of billboard business; gain of $495 million resulted in net income of $927 million; revenue in quarter increased 5.6 percent, to $3.83 billion (S)

headline: Legal Experts Agree on an Outline for a Global Criminal Court
abstract: Legal experts from around world end two weeks of intensive negotiations at United Nations with rough outline for first permanent international criminal court; court is likely to be established by treaty at conference in Rome next summer; new court is expected to fill legal gap by taking on cases of genocide, war crimes and other crimes against humanity; still at issue is whether attacks on civilians, mass starvation or use of nuclear weapons and land mines will be considered war crimes; there is agreement that crimes of aggression aimed specifically at women will be listed separately, a result of outrage at use of rape and other sexual abuses as acts of war in recent conflicts in Balkans and Central Africa (M)

headline: From Science to Fiction; Military and Entertainment Industries Swap Expertise
abstract: Some aerospace companies and individual aerospace engineers in California are seeking their fortunes in entertainment business in wake of sharp cutbacks in military spending; they are applying their expertise to areas like movie special effects and rides for theme parks, casinos and shopping centers; flow of engineers, while small, reflects much larger shift in Southern California economy; since 1988, aerospace and electronics equipment industry--once the region's largest--has lost 135,000 jobs in Los Angeles County; in same period, county's entertainment industry has added 144,000 jobs and become area's biggest employer; graph; photos (L)

headline: 2d Ex-Head of Baron Files a Guilty Plea
abstract: A R Baron & Co's former president and chief compliance officer Mark Goldman pleads guilty to grand larceny and enterprise corruption--legal phrase for racketeering--and agrees to spend at least one year in jail; in May, Manhattan District Attorney Robert M Morgenthau charged 13 ex-Baron officials with running stock-manipulation scheme costing investors $75 million (S)

headline: Jordan, McGrath Picks Heir Apparent
abstract: Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor promotes Stephen Badenhop to new position of client services director and identifies him as heir apparent to Pat McGrath, agency's president (S)

headline: Updates: Media and Technology; Settlement in Piracy Case
abstract: Business Software Alliance, industry watchdog that polices software piracy, wins $150,000 settlement from MKDA, architectural firm using unlicensed copies of programs by Autodesk and other companies (S)

headline: National Review Changing Editor
abstract: John O'Sullivan, editor of National Review, will step down at end of year; O'Sullivan will be succeeded by Rich Lowry (S)

headline: Seat Sold for $1.5 Million
abstract: Seat on New York Stock Exchange sells for record $1.5 million, $25,000 more than previous high (S)

headline: Dario Fo Thanks Academy For Ennobling the Jesters
abstract: Dario Fo, Italian satirist who won 1997 Nobel Prize for Literature, delivers off-the-cuff performance before Swedish Academy in Stockholm during awards ceremonies trumpeting virtues of jesters throughout ages; photo (S)

headline: Asian Crisis Swells U.S. Trade Deficit
abstract: The United States trade deficit jumped to an eight-month high of $11.1 billion in September, the Government said, as financial turmoil in Asia helped widen the gap.

headline: After Flashing Causes Seizures, Japan Re-evaluates TV Cartoons
abstract: Japan's broadcasters agree to draw up voluntary guidelines for programs to help shield children from flash attacks that could cause seizures or unconsciousness, after incident this week that made thousands of television viewers ill; broadcasters are expected to pledge not to use animation techniques that have been linked to reports of illness among as many as 12,000 people, most of them children; they were affected by watching television program featuring popular cartoon figures called Pokemon, or Pocket Monsters; more than 700 viewers were hospitalized (S)

headline: Klaus's First Goal May Be to Get A Loyal Party Core Behind Him : Czech Leader Looks To Opposition Bench
abstract: PRAGUEâ€”  Out but not down, Vaclav Klaus, who was forced to resign as the Czech prime minister over political finance scandals, is preparing for what could be a long campaign of guerrilla politics led from the opposition benches.

headline: DIARY
abstract: SOUTH KOREA  A President and a Problem  South Koreans swept out the political establishment and elected as president a campaigner for democracy whom past dictators tried to kill. But the new President, Kim Dae Jung, may feel some of the apprehension that goes along with answered prayers. True, he is a legendary figure, a Lech Walesa of Korea, and his victory immediately made history, since it was the first time an opposition candidate was ever elected president in the country. But he immediately steps into severe economic turmoil. He plans a quick trip to the United States -- Wall Street, to be precise -- and promised to open Korean markets, usher in a free-market economy and abide by the austerity demanded under a rescue plan from the International Monetary Fund.

headline: Ericsson China Contracts
abstract: Ericsson AB, Swedish telecommunications equipment maker, wins three network expansion contracts totaling $223 million from China (S)

headline: FEDERAL-MOGUL TO CLOSE 13 SERVICE CENTERS
abstract: Federal-Mogul Corp will close 13 auto service centers, eliminating 25 to 30 jobs (S)

headline: Nissan's Profits Jump as Exports Offset Slump in Japan
abstract: Nissan Motor Co says its pretax profit rose 47 percent in fiscal first half, to 45.36 billion yen ($366 million) from year ago, as cost reductions and higher exports offset slump in Japanese sales; net income more than tripled, to 38.50 billion yen; sales rose 2 percent, to 1.776 trillion yen, and exports grew 26.3 percent in the half; exports to US grew 11 percent, to 148,000 units; auto sales in Japan have declined every month since April, when Government raised national sales tax, eliminated tax rebates and raised health insurance premiums (M)

headline: Treasury Securities Rise in Price
abstract: Prices of Treasury securities snap three-day decline after second part of Government's quarterly refunding of debt shows decent results; 30-year bond rises 9/32, to price of 102 2/32, with yield of 6.22 percent, down from 6.24 percent (S)

headline: Proffitt's Expected to Buy Carson Pirie Scott Chain
abstract: Proffitt's Inc is expected to reach agreement to acquire Carson Pirie Scott & Co, a retailer with 56 stores in Midwest (M)

headline: Senators Hear Welcome News on Cost of NATO's Expansion
abstract: Defense Sec William S Cohen and Sec of State Madeleine K Albright tell Senate hearing that Defense Department's initial estimates of cost of NATO expansion were too high; hold project will not become financial morass for United States (M)

headline: Asians Suffer Further Damage On Malaysian's New Remarks
abstract: Southeast Asian currencies again fall to record lows against US dollar, and analysts say further declines are likely because of continued concerns about region's faltering economic growth; Malaysia's Prime Min Mahathir Mohamad calls for more regulations on currency trading (M)

headline: INTERSTATE BAKERIES TO BUY NEW ENGLAND BAKER'S ASSETS
abstract: Interstate Bakeries Corp agrees to acquire assets of John J Nissen Baking Companies; terms undisclosed (S)

headline: CAPSTAR HOTEL AGREES TO ACQUIRE WINSTON HOSPITALITY
abstract: Capstar Hotel Co agrees to acquire Winston Hospitality Inc for $34 million in cash and other considerations (S)

headline: After 40 Slayings, Question Lingers: Who's Mexican Cartel's Boss?
abstract: Rafael Munoz Talavera, in open letter to Pres Ernesto Zedillo in Ciudad Juarez newspaper, denies that he is head of Mexico's largest narcotics cartel; portrays himself as target of unidentified traffickers who control cartel and hope to focus law enforcement efforts on him; US authorities once accused Munoz of heading border cartel responsible for smuggling 21 tons of cocaine that were discovered in Los Angeles warehouse in 1989; photo (M)

headline: Obituary : Jean Pasqualini, Who Wrote Account of China's Gulag, Dies
abstract: PARISâ€”  Jean Pasqualini, 71, who wrote a best-seller about his seven years as a prisoner in the Chinese "gulag," died in a hospital in a Paris suburb on Thursday after a long series of illnesses.

headline: '81 Reversal by Au Pair Judge Resulted in Homicidal Sequel
abstract: WASHINGTONâ€”  When Judge Hiller Zobel overruled a jury's finding and freed a British au pair who had been convicted of murder, it was the fourth time he had thrown out a verdict.

headline: House Panel Takes a Slap At Clinton Over China
abstract: House Committee on International Relations, deals sharp if largely symbolic rebuke to Clinton Administration's China policy, just four weeks before Pres Jiang Zemin is to visit Washington, when it votes to deny visas to Chinese officials who violate human rights (M)

headline: National Geographic Society Chief Resigns
abstract: Reg Murphy resigns as National Geographic Society president and chief executive; will remain vice chairman; John M Fahey Jr will succeed him, effective Mar 1; photo (M)

headline: U.S. Labels 30 Groups As Terrorists; Omits I.R.A.
abstract: State Department, fulfilling Congressional mandate, designates 30 groups as foreign terrorist organizations, making it illegal to provide funds for them and denying their members visas; does not include Irish Republican Army because group has set cease-fire, but says IRA remains under active review and warns against any resumption of violence (M)

headline: Security Officers Are a Focus in Mexico Massacre
abstract: Mexican Attorney General Jorge Madrazo Cuellar, who is leading investigation into the killings of 45 unarmed Indians in Chiapas village of Chenalho, says Federal agents are questioning security officials in the area; Zapatista rebels in Chiapas issue communique blaming Pres Ernesto Zedillo and his top political adviser, Interior Min Emilio Chuayffet, for the violence (M)

headline: Clintons Present Their Act To an Admiring Argentina
abstract: Pres Clinton and Hillary Rodham Clinton visit Buenos Aires, Argentina; Clinton holds televised town hall meeting, genially fielding questions from what producers call 'young leaders' in Buenos Aires and, by two-way link, in Miami and Los Angeles; Univision network says it reached up to 533 million households in 33 countries with Clinton's 'town hall'; Hillary Clinton, in address to 2,500 women, urges greater political involvement for women and promotes family planning, politically charged subject in Latin America; photo (M)

headline: BUSINESS DIGEST
abstract: Weak Earnings Hurt Stocks As Asia News Is Ignored  Stocks in the United States ended mostly lower for the first time this week, hurt by unexpected weakness in quarterly earnings that offset strength from rallies in Asia after Japan's Government proposed a large tax cut.    The catalyst for the Wall Street decline was news from Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing that fourth-quarter earnings would be more than 10 percent below estimates. Its stock fell nearly 10 percent and helped send the Dow Jones industrial average down 18.90 points, to 7.957.41, snapping a two-day rally. Most broader market barometers also ended lower. [Pages D12 and D4.]

headline: Throngs Mark Rabin Killing And Mourn Fading Peace
abstract: Estimated 200,000 Israelis gather in Tel Aviv to commemorate second anniversary of Yitzhak Rabin's assassination, and to mourn politics of peace that foundered with his death; rally underscores profound rift over what has become known as Oslo process, rift that has deepened since Rabin's death and election of Likud Government under Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu six months later (M)

headline: U.N. Investigates Report of Slaying of 2,000 Taliban Fighters
abstract: UN probes reports that as many as 2,000 fighters from Islamic Taliban movement were killed and buried in mass graves after being taken prisoner in northern Afghanistan by forces of coalition driven out of capital of Kabul in 1996 (M)

headline: Success of Chinese Visit May Turn on Prisoner Release
abstract: American and Chinese officials openly, but guardedly, discuss possibility that China will allow prominent dissident to leave prison in effort to soften criticism of nation's human rights conditions week before visit of Pres Jiang Zemin to US; prime candidates for release may be Wang Dan and Wei Jingsheng; photos (M)

headline: GATX to Take 4th-Quarter Charges
abstract: GATX Corp will take fourth-quarter charges of $150 million to pay for job cuts, writedowns and asset sales at two unit (S)

headline: Futurism Returns but Its Bad Image Lingers
abstract: VENICEâ€”  Filippo Tommaso Marinetti, poet, publicist, rabble-rouser and founder of Futurism, glorified speed, machines, mass culture, modern warfare and Benito Mussolini, to whom Marinetti remained faithful until the dictator's death in December 1944.

headline: Economic Scene; South Korea is facing some difficult economic choices.
abstract: Peter Passell Economic Scene column says for South Korea to complete its journey to economic maturity, its conglomerates need to be restructured, its insolvent banks must be liquidated or merged with foreign banks, and country must make leap from planning to decentralization with few barriers to entry for domestic or foreign competitors; notes International Monetary Fund is prescribing high interest rates along with tight budget to amass cash needed to pay off depositors in failed banks, but Prof Paul Krugman fears such fiscal austerity would throw hundreds of thousands out of work and may push economy into recession; drawing (M)

headline: QUAKER STATE TO SELL LIGHTING UNIT TO PENSKE VENTURE
abstract: Quaker State Corp plans to sell its vehicular lighting unit, Truck-Lite Co, to Penske Capital Partners LLC for undisclosed amount of cash (S)

headline: Market Place; Utilities are suddenly stumbling on the road to their brave new world of deregulation.
abstract: Utilities industry, which just a few years ago appeared to be marching steadily toward promised land of deregulation, with big savings in rates as consumers would choose from among a number of suppliers, instead is in disarray, stumbling, confused and not sure of its direction; problems discussed (Market Place column) (M)

headline: FLUOR SAYS IT MAY SELL EQUIPMENT LEASING UNIT
abstract: Fluor Corp says it may sell or restructure its equipment leasing unit, American Equipment Co, as part of larger review of its construction company's businesses (S)

headline: Business Travel; Cathay Pacific is offering a big discount on round-trip fares from the U.S. to Hong Kong.
abstract: Cathay Pacific, hoping to revive Hong Kong's slumping tourist industry as well as increase passenger loads, is offering economy-class round-trip fare for two from New York or Los Angeles for $999, plus taxes; Millennium Broadway hotel is planning special event to welcome in year 2000: it has offered to 'sell' 627-room hotel for three days to a single customer for $3 million; business travelers going abroad will be able to bone up on culture and commerce of countries they are visiting with series of books recently introduced by American Geographical Society; Hilton Hotels says it is equipping its hotels and corporate office in Southern California with charging stations for electrical vehicles (Business Travel column) (L)

headline: Drug Barons and Plastic Surgeons: Who's Dead, Who's Hiding?
abstract: Mexicans puzzle over fate of billionaire drug trafficker, Amado Carrillo Fuentes, who was reported to have died during plastic surgery three months ago; officials announce that three surgeons are charged with murder, but two of them apparently have already received brutal punishment, their mutilated bodies found along roadside; Carillo Fuentes enjoyed extraordinary license for years, moving tons of cocaine into US, but lost influence with security forces; many Mexicans believe he is still alive (S)

headline: People
abstract: * Neal Gomberg was named to the new position of executive vice president and group creative director at N. W. Ayer & Partners, New York, part of the MacManus Group. He had been senior partner and creative director at Ogilvy & Mather New York, part of the WPP Group.    * Gary Janz, senior vice president for strategic planning at Greenstone Roberts Advertising, Orlando, Fla., was promoted to executive vice president and general manager, succeeding Kathleen Ryan, who left to become chief executive for North American operations at Finex Communications, London, a strategic partner of Greenstone.

headline: GIBSON GREETINGS IS SET TO BEGIN ACQUISITION DRIVE
abstract: Gibson Greetings will use $106 million to begin making acquisitions in the first quarter of small greeting-card makers and other businesses as part of plan to broaden its product line (S)

headline: Markets Feel Minor Impact From Job Data
abstract: Stock prices rise and bond prices rebound after initial plunge, shrugging off unexpectedly strong Nov employment data; 30-year Treasury bond drops 16/32, to 100 20/32, to yield 6.08 percent; graph (M)

headline: Turk Critical of Ankara Freed 3 Weeks Into a 23-Year Term
abstract: Turkish Government yields to intense foreign and domestic pressure and releases Esber Yagmurdereli, blind social critic who begain serving 23-year prison term three weeks ago for allegedly supporting terrorism and spreading separatist propaganda (S)

headline: Sherwin-Williams Hires Ohio Agency
abstract: Sherwin-Williams Co names SBC Advertising the agency of record for stain-group section of its consumer brands division; account had been handled by Hanft, Byrne, Raboy, Abrams & Partners; billings estimated at $12 million (S)

headline: GARTNER ACQUIRES 32% STAKE IN JUPITER COMMUNICATIONS
abstract: Gartner Group Inc says it bought 32 percent stake in Jupiter Communications LLC for $8 million; says there will be no change in Jupiter's management (S)

headline: Dutch Troops Seize Two War Crimes Suspects, Wounding One
abstract: Dutch paratroopers and marines from NATO peacekeeping force in Bosnia detain two Bosnian Croat war crimes suspects; one, Vlatko Kupreskic, opens fire on troops and is wounded during raid in home village; Anto Furundzija is arrested in Vitez; detention and swift extradition to war crimes tribunal in The Hague spark angry protests by ethnic Croats; photo; Kupreskic, one of most notorious suspects, is charged in murders of scores of unarmed Muslim civilians in Ahmici and other places in 1993 (S)

headline: Building-Supply Chain May Buy British Rival
abstract: Meyer International PLC, a British timber and building materials merchant, is in talks to buy Harcos building materials unit of Harrisons & Crossfield PLC for more than $483 million (S)

headline: Pharmacia's Headquarters To Go to U.S. From Britain
abstract: Pharmacia & Upjohn, big multinational drug maker, says it will move its headquarters to mid-Atlantic state in US from Britain; Pharmacia declines to provide specific location (M)

headline: True North Granted Injunction
abstract: Battle between True North Communications and Publicis SA over True North's proposed acquisition of Bozell, Jacobs, Kenyon & Eckhardt turns again in True North's favor, raising prospects that True North shareholders may approve deal (S)

headline: BMW to Retain DeWitt Media
abstract: BMW of North America says it has retained DeWitt Media to handle its national media planning and buying account, with billings estimated at $80 million (S)

headline: Along the Old Silk Road, a New Effort to Shine
abstract: Historians say that no one knows when ancient town of Khiva, Uzbekistan, was founded, but that has not prevented Pres Islam Karimov from declaring Oct as its 2,500th anniversary; laborers have been working frantically to clean Khiva's streets and repair its imposing monuments; Karimov has planned lavish celebrations to which he has invited officials from around world; he has announced that Oct is also 2,500th birthday of Bukhara, where he is staging another extended party; maps; photo (M)

headline: Retailers' Earnings Near Expectations
abstract: Several of big retailers--Home Depot Inc, Dayton Hudson Corp, Ann Taylor Stores Corp and Limited Inc--report fiscal third-quarter operating earnings that are in line with or above analysts' expectations; Home Depot's operating profits rose to $299 million; it earned $236 million, up from $221 million; Dayton Hudson says net income rose to $160 million compared with $107 million a year earlier; Ann Taylor says net income fell to $2.2 million from $3.3 million a year earlier; Limited reports earnings of $42 million (S)

headline: U.S. Seems to Rule Out Meeting Between Clinton and Netanyahu
abstract: Pres Clinton apparently rules out meeting with Prime Min Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel while he is in United States; Administration denies intent to snub Israel over lack of progress in Mideast talks; Clinton plans to see Jordanian King Hussein, in US for medical tests; US expresses disappointment that Egypt and several other Arab states it invited to economic meeting in Qatar with Israel will not attend to protest stalled peace talks (M)

headline: Gornja Toponica Journal; Written on These Faces, the Torment of Serbia
abstract: Collapse of health system of Yugoslavia, which now comprises just Serbia and Montenegro, is nowhere more evident than in its six mental health institutions; 1,050 patients at largest institution, at Gornja Toponica, wander its dark, unheated halls, doped out on drugs and survive on food rations that staff members say are inadequate; previous director is on trial for selling huge quantities of hospital food, heating fuel and equipment, much of it donated from abroad, and pocketing the proceeds; photo; map (M)

headline: Market Place; Wincing at an Asia crisis tactic, S.E.C. backs fund 'fair pricing.'
abstract: Market Place: Barry Barbash, director of Securities and Exchange Commission's division of investment management, says surprisingly large number of investors used mutual funds to speculate on short-term swings in Asian markets during market turmoil in October; says unless industry reduces its reliance on performance rankings to generate sales and guide management of assets, investors are likely to stray ever further from regarding mutual funds as long-term investments; holds SEC will continue to examine how fund companies carry out 'fair value' pricing of mutual fund shares--rarely instituted practice that aroused considerable controversy among fund shareholders in October (L)

headline: PUBLISHER SAYS IT WILL REPORT A LOSS AND TAKE A CHARGE
abstract: Reader's Digest Assn expects loss in its first fiscal quarter because of weak sales and negative impact of dollar's strength on overseas revenue; will take pretax charge of $70 million to discontinue some businesses and cover severance costs for job cuts in Europe and United States (S)

headline: Crisis Ahead In East Asia Over Prices Of Property : Wall Street Claws Its Way Back
abstract: SINGAPOREâ€”  East Asia's property values will be the next victim of the region's financial turmoil and slowing growth, economists predicted Tuesday.

headline: Edwin Neilan, U.S. Chamber's Ex-Head, 92
abstract: Edwin P Neilan, former head of US Chamber of Commerce, dies at age 92; photo (S)

headline: COMPANY BRIEFS
abstract: FINANCIAL INDUSTRIES CORP. and the Intercontinental Life Corp., Austin, Tex., sold the Bridgeport Square office building complex in Austin for $78 million to an undisclosed buyer.     PEPSICO INC., New York, said its Frito-Lay unit had acquired Penhaumar S.A., an Argentine snack foods company, for an undisclosed price.

headline: WORLDTEX TO BUY ELASTIC FABRIC UNIT FOR $76.3 MILLION
abstract: Worldtex Inc says it agreed to buy Elastic Corp of America for $76.3 million in cash and assumption of $6 million in debt; Elastic is division of NFA Corp (S)

headline: In Melting Pot of Parisian Art World, Designers Gain Inspiration : Young Upstarts Reinvent French Style
abstract: PARISâ€”  Thanks more to a kick in the pants than a monetary upturn, the Paris fashion scene is pulling out of its sleeping beauty mode at last.

headline: Reshaping the Culture at Columbia/HCA
abstract: Dr Thomas F Frist Jr marks his 100th day as chairman and chief executive of Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp by outlining changes he says will fundamentally reshape health care giant; Columbia officials say speech is important part of Frist's effort to change direction and focus of health care company, as large criminal and civil investigation continues of many of its business practices; Frist says company is adopting new mission and values statement that emphasizes commitment to quality medical care and honesty in business practices; it makes no mention of financial performance; Frist announces appointments of Robert Waterman as general counsel and Dr Frank Houser as medical director and senior vice president of quality; photo (M)

headline: Market Place: Red-Hot Revival in Real Estate; Overheating Is Feared With Surge in Vulture Investing
abstract: Leslie Eaton Market Place column examines high-flying vulture funds in world of professional real estate investing; singles out Blackstone Group, which in five years has raised millions of dollars to buy real estate, produced returns of more than 50 percent a year and snagged many prominent properties in Manhatttan; notes some market watchers fear that real estate may overheat as competition for properties increases; real estate funds are adopting new strategies to sustain 20 percent or more annual returns their investors demand; fund operators are aware of cyclical nature of real estate and agree that investors must scale back their expectations for profits; say they hope to avoid excesses that led to disaster in late 1980's; photos; graphs (L)

headline: DOMINION TEXTILE ACCEPTS SWEETENED BID FROM POLYMER
abstract: Canadian fabric maker Dominion Textile Inc accepts sweetened offer from Polymer Group Inc worth $596 million (Canadian), or $421 million (US) (S)

headline: Offerings Set For Equities During Week
abstract: The following equity and convertible debt offerings are expected this week:    Advanced Energy Industries, Fort Collins, Colo., 2.5 million shares. UBS Securities Inc.

headline: Snow and Cold Hit Mexico, Causing Jump in Coffee Prices
abstract: Coffee prices soar on Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange in New York after snow and cold temperatures in Mexico raise concern that next year's harvest could be damaged; in other markets, platinum falls to lowest price in four and half years and palladium reaches three-month low amid expectations that weak economy would reduce demand from Japan, one of world's top importing countries (M)

headline: Hilton Hotels Extends Hostile Offer for ITT
abstract: Hilton Hotels Corp extends its cash tender offer to buy ITT Corp for $8 billion despite its apparent defeat in hostile takeover battle for company; Hilton says $70-a-share offer, which had expiration date of Oct 24, is now scheduled to expire at midnight Oct 31, unless again extended (S)1

headline: FROM THE DESK OF; Shopping On the Web: It's Scary Out There
abstract: Article by Alan Feigenbaum, certified financial planner, offers computer users suggestions on ways to avoid going into debt by making too many purchases on Internet (M)

headline: A Microsoft Browser Deal With @Home
abstract: Microsoft Corp appears to have won another skirmish in World Wide Web browser wars, announcing that At Home Network will develop special version of its software to work with At Home's cable-based Internet services (S)

headline: Cordiant Provides Details on Division
abstract: Cordiant PLC announces further details of its planned split, which will create separate operating companies centered on Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide and Bates Worldwide (S)

headline: MANITOWOC TO ACQUIRE MAKER OF BEVERAGE DISPENSERS
abstract: Manitowoc Co agrees to buy Servend International for $65 million to $75 million in cash (S)

headline: Paid Notice: Memorials  WEISS, WILMER
abstract: WEISS - Wilmer. East Coast friends, colleagues and admirers of Wilmer Weiss: Wilmer Weiss Memorial Evening Zoom Studio, 632 Broadway, 8th floor, 7-9PM Monday, October 27.

headline: A World of Christmases, Not Just for Christians
abstract: Christmas festivities in Japan are widespread, particularly the embrace of Santa Claus, although fewer than one percent of Japanese are Christians; photo (S)

headline: TRINITY INDUSTRIES ENDS TALKS TO BUY AMERICAN RAILCAR
abstract: Trinity Industries indefinitely suspends talks to acquire American Railcar Industries from Carl C Icahn because two sides are unable to agree on terms (S)

headline: An Old Tale Of Swindle Resurfaces In Bosnia
abstract: Story circulating in Bosnia is that in closing months of Bosnian war two years ago, Radovan Karadzic, leader of Bosnian Serbs, was swindled out of $6 million by arms dealer who promised to deliver nuclear weapon which could end war; Karadzic denies story, but Predrag Ceranic, head of secret police at time, has sheaf of documents to support his story; Ceranic's timing in announcing story--just before recent Bosnian Serb parliamentary elections--and his current allegiance to Karadzic's rival, Biljana Plavsic, raisequestions about truth of tale (M)

headline: Defying a Juggernaut; Netscape Maneuvers for Position in a Microsoft-Ruled World
abstract: Netscape Communications Corp shows more staying power than industry skeptics though possible in face of competition from formidable Microsoft Corp; Netscape is surviving, even thriving, under leadership of James L Barksdale, who has proved to be skillful salesman in persuading corporate America to buy from an Internet pioneer; supporters say Barksdale's greatest strength is his understanding of uses of technology; rivals at Microsoft see Barksdale as driving force behind Justice Department's decision to enter browser war and seek to stop Microsoft from forcing computer markers that use its Windows operating system to also use its Internet Explorer browsing program; photo (M)

headline: 3 Weak Days Trim Week's Gain in Dow
abstract: Dow Jones industrial average drops 16.21 points to 8,045.21; Russell index of 2,000 smaller companies rises 0.48 points to record 465.03; table (M)

headline: U.S. 'Updates' All-Out Atom War Guidelines
abstract: Clinton Administration for first time rewrites guidelines for Pentagon's use of nuclear weapons, moving away from strategy of winning all-out nuclear exchange to deterring use of nuclear weapons; new guidelines give Pentagon more flexibility in deterring or, if necessary, retaliating against, smaller rogue states that might use chemical or biological weapons against US or its allies (M)

headline: Mexico Shift by Goodyear
abstract: Goodyear Tire and Rubber Co will shift production of power transmission products to Mexico in effort to cut costs; move will eliminate about 150 jobs at plant in Lincoln, Neb, where products are now made (S)

headline: To Wash Down a Serbian Autumn, Sad Songs and Clear Plum Brandy
abstract: Serbs in small farming village of Rasovaca Donja make plum brandy, or slivovitz, during autumn; photo (M)
